webTitle: Letters: In memory of Charlotte Wilson

fields.headline: In memory of Charlotte
fields.trailText: We are writing to you as the family of Charlotte Wilson, the aid worker murdered last week (Briton among 20 killed in Burundi ambush, December 30), as the Guardian is a newspaper she respected and one that we trust.
fields.body:
We are writing to you as the family of Charlotte Wilson, the aid worker murdered last week (Briton among 20 killed in Burundi ambush, December 30), as the Guardian is a newspaper she respected and one that we trust.

Charlotte had strong beliefs about the region in which she worked. Despite our devastation and incalculable loss, we wish to highlight these beliefs as it is important that the work she was involved in should continue. The international community must support continuing Rwandan efforts towards reconciliation after the genocide. Rwanda must be given help in rebuilding its infrastructure, especially its educational and judicial systems. Charlotte believed passionately in education being the way forward for developing nations and in giving them the opportunity to stand on their own feet rather than fostering an aid-dependency culture.

In addition, we would like to highlight the fact that 19 other living, breathing human beings were also murdered in this premeditated mass-killing of innocent civilians. Such an action has the same degree of moral abhorrence whether it occurs in Burundi, Bosnia, Rwanda or any other part of the world. This should be considered as a war crime and investigated as such, not dismissed as unsolvable simply because it occurred in an African country. In an area that has already been let down by the international community, internal conflicts should not be exacerbated by the ready supply of arms to ruthless, undemocratic forces.

On a personal note, everyone who knew Charlotte would agree that she was a brilliant, vibrant and inspirational person. We cannot express how sorely she will be missed by her family and friends.
Margot, Richard and Catherine
Charlotte Wilson's mother, brother and sister

webTitle: Margaret's state of health causes Queen concern

fields.headline: Margaret's state of health causes Queen concern
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The royal family last night was awaiting the results of medical tests carried out at the weekend on Princess Margaret, who has been ill in bed at Sandringham over the entire Christmas period.
fields.body:
The royal family last night was awaiting the results of medical tests carried out at the weekend on Princess Margaret, who has been ill in bed at Sandringham over the entire Christmas period.

The Queen's younger sister was visited twice by the family's doctor on duty when the tests were taken. Yesterday her condition was officially said to be causing concern, though not alarm. The princess, 70 in August, was last seen in public at a ballet gala evening in London two months ago.

However, her two children, Viscount Linley and Lady Sarah Chatto, who were with the royal family at Sandringham over Christmas, are understood to have left the Norfolk estate.

Buckingham Palace officials took the unusual step of issuing a statement on the princess's health, although the statement stopped short of saying what was thought to be wrong.

A spokeswoman said: "We are not actually issuing bulletins. The princess is continuing to rest at Sandringham. She has got family such as the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh there, and nursing care is available."

Palace staff have rejected newspaper reports that the princess had been suffering from clinical depression, insisting that her ailments were physical. Lurid suggestions, allegedly from courtiers, that she had lost the will to live or was suffering from profound melancholy have been dismissed, though it has been conceded that she was dispirited by the time it had taken her to recover from ill-health.

She had a stroke in February 1998 while on holiday at her home on the West Indian island of Mustique. Last March her feet were badly scalded as she stepped into an over-hot bath, again on the island; she has had difficulty in walking ever since.

In 1985 she had part of one lung removed, the legacy of years of heavy smoking. In 1974 she is said to have suffered a nervous breakdown in the wake of her affair with Roddy Llewellyn.

The spokeswoman said: "She has had the stroke and the scalding incident, and progress has been slow since then."

The princess, usually seen in a wheelchair or walking laboriously with the aid of a stick, failed to attend Christmas services with the rest of the family at the Sandringham estate church.

At that stage she was said to be merely tired, but it was acknowledged at the weekend that she was unwell and that her condition had given cause for concern during the week.

Her former husband, Lord Snowdon, is being kept informed of her progress.The princess is thought likely to remain at Sandringham for the forseeable future.

webTitle: Money and politics - the winners and losers

fields.headline: Money and politics - the winners and losers
fields.standfirst: Political donations often spark controversy - as these people found when they became financially involved in politics
fields.trailText: Political donations often spark controversy - as these people found when they became financially involved in politics.
fields.body:
Lord Hamlyn
The publishing millionaire, who received a life peerage two years ago by the government, revealed today he was the source of a mystery £2m donation to Labour - which had campaigned on an "anti-sleaze" ticket.

Bernie Ecclestone
The Labour party returned £1m it received from the Formula 1 boss shortly after the 1997 election. The government decided to exempt motor racing from a ban on tobacco sponsorship after he had lobbied Tony Blair.

Lord Sainsbury
The science minister and millionaire publicly donated a record £2m to the Labour party in 1999.But there were still allegations that his gift had influenced his standing within the government.

Lord Ashcroft
The Tories' billionaire treasurer and main benefactor of up to £5m, was last year forced to promise he would repatriate himself to Britain before being allowed to take up the peerage secured for him by a grateful William Hague.

Geoffrey Robinson
The multi-millionaire former minister was dismissed from the Treasury after controversy surrounding his tax payments and his home loan to Cabinet minister Peter Mandelson.

Robert Bourne
The businessman, whose Legacy consortium is in negotiations to buy the Millennium Dome, has given £60,000 to the Labour party since 1997 and several thousand pounds to the constituency party of Chris Smith, the culture secretary.

Alan McGee
The boss of Creation records has been a donor in the past but has grown disenchanted with new Labour since the election and criticised the party in the press.

webTitle: Blair may ask £2m donor to go public

fields.headline: Blair may ask £2m donor to go public
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Labour party is poised to ask the anonymous £2m donor to its election war chest whether they are prepared to allow their name to be divulged in response to growing public demands for openness.
fields.body:
The Labour party is poised to ask the anonymous £2m donor to its election war chest whether they are prepared to allow their name to be divulged in response to growing public demands for openness.

As more Labour MPs and officials voiced public or private dismay at the prospect of another "Bernie Ecclestone" row to tarnish Tony Blair's squeaky clean image, party HQ at Millbank yesterday stuck by its refusal to confirm or deny the reported donation - or to identify the donor.

But there has been little attempt in private to dismiss the controversy as pre-election propaganda by the Tories, who are still sore over Labour's anti-sleaze campaign before the 1997 election. That produced the Nolan-Neill reforms which now threaten to embarrass ministers.

Under legal changes enacted by Labour in response to reports by Lords Nolan and Neill on standards in public life, all donors and the size of their gift to political parties will have to be identified after February 16.

But the reported £2m donation banked in December will avoid these requirements, leaving the donor to be identified only as one of many Labour supporters who wrote a cheque for more than £5,000 in 2000-01.

That raises the prospect that September's annual report will contain a list of names that, one senior party veteran predicted last night, will be "half-Nolan and half-not-Nolan". He added: "That will look a bit odd."

Officials are increasingly resigned to the need for openness - unlike the 1997 Ecclestone affair, when the formula one chief and his £1m cheque were kept secret for most of a damaging battle with the media.

That would mean seeking the donor's permission to name him or her, possibly when they have deliberately chosen to be protected by the existing rules from the massive - and aggressive - newspaper coverage that a £2m donor to Labour's funds would attract.

It was not clear last night whether the donor had already been approached. With the Christmas-New Year break still on many key players are not available, including Mr Blair's personal envoy and fundraiser, Lord Levy, who brokered the donation.

Yesterday he was saying nothing. But the leftwing Labour MP for Islington North, Jeremy Corbyn, said: "Any donation should be made public straight away. There is no case whatsoever for failing to reveal the source of donations."

It is the link between donations to Labour or Tory funds and political favours, honours or policy decisions which has increasingly discouraged firms and even wealthy individuals from making such gifts. "People ask, 'What are you getting from Tony Blair? Are you on the honours list?'" a former Labour official explained.

Other Labour MPs were publicly more circumspect. Michael Foster, who sits on the Commons standards and privileges committee, said: "If we have been given a donation on the basis that it is not disclosed and we are satisfied it comes from a legitimate source, there is no reason why we should have to declare it now."

webTitle: Labour looks for business backing

fields.headline: Labour looks for business backing
fields.standfirst:
Both main parties are behind schedule for possible May poll

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Both main parties are behind schedule for possible May poll.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is searching for a successful entrepreneur to play a high-profile role in the election after Labour officials privately admitted the party's campaign planning has slipped behind schedule.

Senior figures in the Millbank HQ blame the pressure on ministers of running the government for missing a pre-Christmas deadline to finalise strategy for an election that could be in May.

The prime minister and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, regard an endorsement from a well known industrialist or financier as crucial to persuading former Tory voters that Labour has run the country well. The Granada boss Gerry Robinson played that role in 1997 and could be asked to do it again if Millbank fails to come up with a successor.

The Labour peer Clive Hollick is to suggest possible names after meetings with Mr Blair and the general secretary, Margaret McDonagh.

The relative lack of preparedness is in sharp contrast to last time round, when Labour's campaign was in place by mid-1996, nearly a year before John Major went to the polls in May 1997.

A senior figure said Labour had to be prepared for a snap election in the summer or autumn of 1996. "Government is very different to opposition. Blair, Brown, [Peter] Mandelson and other ministers need to spend time getting the delivery of policies right as well as planning the campaign."

The prime minister is expected to go for a short campaign of no more than four weeks to deny William Hague the opportunity of getting a bandwagon moving.

Key personnel have been in place since early 2000 with Mr Brown and the Northern Ireland secretary, Mr Mandelson, reunited at the head of the campaign despite their personal and political rivalries.

Mr Blair will embark on the traditional nationwide tour as Mr Brown, chairman of election strategy, fronts the morning London media conferences and Mr Mandelson, chairman of election planning, plays a backroom role.

As well as persuading a new entrepreneur to endorse Labour, a series of other issues are outstanding - from the crucial, such as the manifesto, to the quest for a theme song to replace the last election's Things Can Only Get Better.

May 3 is still thought to be the favoured date with the campaign launched on the back of a three-day conference in Glasgow in the middle of February, a budget promising targeted tax cuts in early March and a string of giveaways, including a new child tax credit, in pay and benefit packets from April.

Labour strategists anticipate challenges on three fronts. The Scottish National party, Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats will present themselves as alternatives on the left while the Tories and the UK Independence party will attack from the right. Apathy, which Labour fears could cost up to 60 seats, is also a threat.

A £20m per party spending limit will change the face of the campaign. Both major parties spent more than that in 1997 when the Conservatives spent £13m on advertising alone.

The Tories are similarly unprepared and less ready to fight an election than Labour was at this point before the 1997 contest. They have not yet raised the £20m needed to spend up to the legal limit.

Much of the planning underway, however, mirrors Labour's tactics in opposition, including the promotion of a "president" William Hague rather than emphasising his team and a concentration on winnable constituencies. Central Office is also seeking high-profile converts to convince voters that the party is on the way back.

Strategists are also aware that selecting platforms could prove a nightmare with two of Mr Hague's better known lieutenants, the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, and the home affairs spokeswoman, Ann Widdecombe, at odds personally and politically. Plans to defend fox-hunting could also come unstuck over Ms Widdecombe's support for the blood sport to be outlawed.

An MP close to Mr Hague said: "Generating a sense of excitement for change will be difficult. Never has it been truer that oppositions do not win elections, governments lose them."

webTitle: Profile: Paul Hamlyn

fields.headline: Paul Hamlyn
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Paul Hamlyn, 75 next month, is a self-made man who made his fortune in publishing and gave its name to the Hamlyn books company.
fields.body:
Paul Hamlyn, 75 next month, is a self-made man who made his fortune in publishing and gave its name to the Hamlyn books company.

Lord Hamlyn started out at the age of 22 from a barrow in Camden Market with an inheritance of £350 from his grandfather. His business flourished and he created and sold two publishing empires to build a personal fortune estimated at £230m.

The first company was sold in 1964 for £2.25m and he later sold Octopus books for £530m, personally netting more than £150m.

Lord Hamlyn was made a life peer in the New Year honours list two years ago after donating hundreds of thousands to the Labour party. It was stressed at the time that the award recognised his charity work rather than the hefty contributions to Labour coffers.

He was also appointed CBE in 1993 by the Conservative government for charitable services.

He has been suffering from pneumonia, has Parkinson's disease and is recovering from cancer.

He was a refugee from Nazism, the son of Czech immigrants who brought him and the rest of his family to Britain in 1933. But he has little interest in Jewish tradition. "My father was an atheist and I have never been involved," he once said.

He changed his name early on from Hamburger, because he was tired of being nicknamed "sausage".

Despite his donations, friends say he is not a committed socialist but "just mildly skewed to the left". The 74-year-old peer is notable by his absence at Labour functions and during the runup to the last election was reportedly not even a party member.

His £2m gift follows a £500,000 donation to the party to fund its 1996 promotional campaign for its document, Road to the Manifesto.

His generosity to the party is matched by his financial commitment to arts charities. His charitable trust, set up in 1987, was said to be worth £64m less than a decade later.

He has also given money to the Bodleian Library in Oxford (£1m), the Royal Opera House (£200,000 a year) and the National Commission on Education (£1m).

In the early 1980s, Lord Hamlyn was one of many previous Labour supporters who helped to set the SDP wagon rolling with its "Gang of Four" leadership.

But his affections were soon back with Labour and in 1990 he gave £100,000 for the specific purpose of developing Labour policies for the arts and cultural issues.

When once asked what he felt about being rich, he replied: "One always has to be terribly careful about what one says. I mean, I don't mind it. I used to feel guilty about it and I no longer do. But it is quite a responsibility."

webTitle: George Carman

fields.headline: George Carman
fields.trailText: George Carman QC was the lawyer everyone wanted on their side.
fields.body:
George Carman QC was the lawyer everyone wanted on their side.

So much so that, when former Tory cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken started his libel action against the Guardian in April 1995, editor Alan Rusbridger said: "We'd better get Carman - before Aitken gets him."

Quite simply, he struck fear into the hearts of those standing before him in the witness box.

Born on October 6, 1929, in Blackpool, the barrister achieved notable courtroom victories both as a criminal lawyer and, later, in libel actions.

His ambitions first centred on the priesthood, but he later decided instead to go to Oxford University to read law.

From there, he worked on the northern circuit before moving to London.

Nicknamed Gorgeous George or Killer Carman, three-times-married Mr Carman became one of Britain's most respected courtroom performers.

Standing 5ft 3in tall, Mr Carman was donnish, bespectacled and always courteous - even when he was taking a witness apart.

He was variously described as "smooth and silky", "the master of the soundbite" and "past master of the wink, wink, nudge, nudge".

He used his considerable skills to grill politicians, soap stars and sportsmen alike in the witness box.

Mr Carman reportedly bet journalists covering the 1981 acquittal of Dr Leonard Arthur that he would make a juror cry within 10 minutes of starting his closing speech - a bet he collected after a woman wiped away a tear on nine minutes 30 seconds.

Dr Arthur was cleared of murdering a Down's syndrome baby after prescribing nursing care only for the child.

Always something of an outsider, Mr Carman never became part of the legal establishment and never became a judge, saying that he would find it hard to keep quiet on the bench and preferred the "blood and sand of the arena".

Jonathan Aitken, cricketer Ian Botham and EastEnders star Gillian Taylforth all came under scrutiny during his relentless cross-examinations.

It was his 1979 defence of former Liberal party leader Jeremy Thorpe, who was acquitted of attempting to murder gay model Norman Scott, which first propelled Mr Carman into the legal limelight.

Following Mr Thorpe's acquittal, Mr Carman took on a number of high-profile criminal trials, including in 1988 actress Maria Aitken -sister of Jonathan Aitken - who was cleared of smuggling cocaine and, in 1989, comedian Ken Dodd, who was cleared of tax charges.

Moving into libel actions during the 1990s, Mr Carman became known for his last-minute flourishes.

One of his most famous successes was in the action brought in 1994 against the Sun newspaper by actor Ms Taylforth, over a report about an alleged act of indecency between her and her fiance Geoff Knights in a Range Rover car on a slipway off the A1. She failed in her action.

In 1993, Mr Carman successfully defended the peer the Marquis of Bristol against heroin and cocaine charges. After hearing Mr Carman shoot holes in the prosecution case, the judge ordered the jury to find him not guilty.

In 1996, cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan hired Mr Carman to defend him in a libel case brought by England cricketing legends Ian Botham and Allan Lamb.

Mr Botham and Mr Lamb attempted to sue Mr Khan after he said that illegal ball tampering was common among fast bowlers.

They also sued him over a newspaper article in which he allegedly accused them of racism, being uneducated and lacking class and upbringing. The pair lost.

Commonly a friend of newspapers, as well as foe, Mr Carman triggered Mr Aitken's downfall during the Tory politician's libel action against the Guardian.

In this case Mr Carman, representing the Guardian and Granada, produced last-minute documents regarding Mr Aitken's stay at the Paris Ritz, and asked to re-examine Mr Aitken on the matter.

He highlighted suspicions that Mr Aitken had lied under oath - starting a process that eventually saw the former Tory minister jailed.

On another occasion, in 1997, Mr Carman again won a case for the Guardian by defeating a libel claim from five Metropolitan police officers, who said that they had been identified in a corruption investigation, despite not being named.

His last big victory came at the end of 1998 when another former Tory minister Neil Hamilton failed in his marathon libel battle Mohammed Al Fayed.

Like many before him, the Harrod's tycoon had called Mr Carman when the case came along. And, also like many before him, he picked a winner.

webTitle: Algerian 'critical' after street stabbing

fields.headline: Algerian 'critical' after street stabbing
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An Algerian man was yesterday fighting for his life after being stabbed repeatedly in a racist attack that may have been filmed by a passerby.
fields.body:
An Algerian man was yesterday fighting for his life after being stabbed repeatedly in a racist attack that may have been filmed by a passerby.

The victim, 38, and his wife are understood to have celebrated the new year at a restaurant in London's West End and were leaving when the attack happened at 12.30am.

Police said an argument involving racist language developed between the Algerian, who lives in north London, and a man on the street.

The victim was stabbed in the head, neck and chest and was treated at the scene by a doctor who arrived with an ambulance crew.

He was transferred to intensive care at a London hospital, where his condition was last night said to be critical.

Police said they were treating the attack - on the corner of Old Compton Street and Greek Street, Soho - as a racially motivated attempted murder and were seeking a man seen running from the scene. He was described as black, possibly African, aged 26 to 28 and about 5ft 7in tall. It is thought that his face was injured during the confrontation.

A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said the nature of the argument remained unclear, and would not discuss what the racist remarks were.

Detectives are keen to examine video footage of the attack believed to have been filmed by a passerby.

The spokeswoman said: "The sequence of events isn't clear. At 12.30am on New Year's Day, the area would have been very busy, and some people have come forward. But we want other people to contact us."

Witnesses should contact the incident room on 020 7437 1212 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555111.

webTitle: Statue, Chain, and Medal

fields.headline: Statue, Chain, and Medal
fields.trailText: IBROX REMEMBERS
fields.body:
IBROX REMEMBERS

A statue of John Greig, the former Rangers captain and manager, was today unveiled at Ibrox during a service to commemorate the 66 supporters who lost their lives in the 1971 Ibrox disaster.

Thirty years ago today, Rangers played host to Celtic for the traditional Ne'erday match between the Old Firm. The match was dull and looked to be petering out into a goal-less draw until Jimmy Johnstone dramatically scored for Celtic in the 89th minute. As many as 25,000 disappointed Rangers fans immediately decided to leave the ground via Stairway 13, a 50-yard flight of steps.

But within 70 seconds of Johnstone's goal, Colin Stein scrambled an improbable equaliser. The crowd roared, and as spectators turned back up the stairwell to see what was going on, some fell. The result was a sickening pile-up, as bodies were crushed against steel barriers and timber walls.

The bronze statue of Greig, which is situated at the former site of the infamous exit, also remembers two victims who died on the stairway in separate incidents during the Sixties, as well as the 25 victims of the 1902 disaster at the stadium. Games across Scotland this afternoon held a minute's silence in memory of the fans.

EAST END BOY

Sex. Drugs. Violence. And rousing choruses of Knees Up, Mother Brown in every pub from Bow to Bethnal Green. "No wonder everyone agrees that London's East End is the best place in the entire world!" exclaimed a cheery Fiver this morning. Until we saw the Mirror's report that West Ham's Paolo Di Canio was "set to leave join Lazio in a £4m deal", that is.

Happily, Redknapp quickly poured a large pot of Fisherman's Daughter (ie: water) over the Di Canio rumours. "There's no chance of him moving at all," he chirped. But when the Fiver asked why didn't he play against United, Arry started shuffling awkwardly. "Paolo had a cold, I think. He's not going anywhere, he's not well sometimes," he insisted - before shoving several 'genuine' silver chains into a suitcase and disappearing down the nearest side-street.

Even better news came when we discovered Arry was probably telling the truth. This afternoon Di Canio's agent, Matteo Roggi, insisted there had been no contact between him and Lazio. "There are just rumours going around and those are not useful for Paolo and for his club," he claimed. "He has a contract at West Ham until 2003 and he is very happy to stay there. I don't think that he wants to move anywhere else. He gets on very well with [Arry] Redknapp and his team-mates. He has a beautiful house and a beautiful car." And - being an East End boy - a lovely mum too, we'll be bound.

SANDER WESTERVELD'S RANT OF THE DAY

"The truth is I didn't know whether to laugh or be angry at what Ian Edwards wrote on the back page [of the Daily Mirror]. What was printed was out of order. The first lines of the article read: 'Liverpool's Sander Westerveld has produced an amazing excuse for his Boxing Day blunder. He is blaming ice on the ball.'

"Now, hang on a minute. If Edwards had read my website properly, he would have seen that nowhere did I blame ice on the ball! It might be a good idea if the sports editor of the Mirror checked the accuracy of his stories, because if a paper is to be considered a quality one, the least it should do is avoid misleading the public.

"Let me stress at this point that I won't miss one minute's sleep because of this. I update my website because I want people to know the facts. I know Christmas is past us, but Ian Edwards could do worse than buy himself a couple of late presents, such as a pair of glasses and some reading lessons."

THEY'RE ALL DOOMED!

According to Alex Ferguson, Manchester United are in "danger". Not, as you'd imagine, from the floods of saliva crashing down from the press box at Old Trafford, but from this 11-point lead they're currently being forced to suffer. "It's an unhealthy position for us to be in, in a way," Fergie insisted today. "It's a dangerous situation that we are in, because all the talk is going to be that the league is over and that sort of thing," he continued in the most ridiculous manner.

"Arsenal, because of the experience they have got, will be a challenger!" he cried, desperately trying to psyche out a rival who gave up the ghost a long time ago. And his pathetically transparent mind games didn't stop there. "When you're winning games the confidence is high and I think Sunderland could continue to challenge ... Liverpool are a big, strong athletic team and they will keep going ... Ips- ..." he went on and on, as if anybody cares about the less-exciting-than-the-SPL-and-that's-official Premiership any more.

The Fiver can only ask: who on earth is Fergie trying to kid? Let's face it, United will definitely win the league this season (not that we're deliberately tempting fate or anything). Even that nutter Manchester bookmaker who lost £500,000 after paying out too soon on United in 1998 is coughing up early - again - so sure is he that Fergie's men won't burn his fingers a second time. In other words, there's really nothing left to look forward to this season. Unless, upon finding limitless transfer funds in the Old Trafford coffers, Fergie finally completes his transition into Private Frazer from Dad's Army and tries to convince the world's media that United are "doomed".

THE RUMOUR MILL

Martin Palermo's agents will travel to England this week to negotiate with Chelsea and West Ham, reports Planet Football.

Manchester City have made a £3.5m bid for West Ham captain Steve Lomas.

Dave Jones is the favourite to become manager of Wolves, according to Teamtalk.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Former Leeds striker Tony Yeboah has been convicted of evading £738,000 of tax in a German court. Yeboah, who currently plays for Hamburg, was fined £130,000, after prosecutors told the court that his former club Eintracht Frankfurt had used a fictitious promotional contract to avoid tax payments in 1993.

Juan Pablo Angel looks likely to complete his £9.5m move to Aston Villa after securing a work permit.

Lorenzo Amoruso is having talks with Harry Redknapp over a possible move to West Ham.

The SPL could scrap their winter break next season to avoid a fixture pile-up in World Cup year. SPL director of administration Iain Blair said: "With the World Cup starting in May next year and the possibility of two Scottish clubs in the Champions League and Scotland playing a World Cup play-off, we are already looking at what can be done."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (1.40am)

You want stories of regional newsreaders? We've got stories of regional newsreaders. "Someone once told me East Midlands Today presenter Kathy Rochford was going out with a fencer," writes Fiver reader Martin Russell. "For a long time I figured he must be some sword-fighting he-man with white suit and novelty face mask, and so gave up on my dream of running away with her to foreign climes. "

Sky Sports 1: Live Scottish Football (7pm, 12midnight)

"But actually he meant a guy who bangs in posts for six foot larch-lap panels. Damn."

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 1.30am)

Meanwhile, great news from Dave Boyle, who spotted McCaff out boozing on New Year's Eve. "I spotted McCaff in the Grove Park Hotel in Chiswick. Whilst there, the hospitable bar staff brought out bags full of festive fun goodies, such as paper hats, balloons, party poppers and those paper things that make a noise as they unravel."

Sky Sports 2: World Football Show (6.30pm, 11.30pm SS1, 2.30am SS1)

"Did McCaff join in the fun? No, alas, he did not. What a spoilsport. He left at 10.30, to where I don't know. He might have been going to another pub. He and his blond lady companion didn't even take their party bags with them. But I did."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on Five with Ian Payne (7pm)

"McCaff's party bag now proudly resides at a friend's house where I ended up that night. It doesn't get much better than that, does it?"

webTitle: Labour's mystery benefactor

fields.headline: Labour's mystery benefactor
fields.standfirst:
Labour party has attempted to stem accusations of sleaze by naming a £2m donor. Mark Oliver explains why the issue of party funding won't go away

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Labour party has attempted to stem accusations of sleaze by naming a £2m donor. Mark Oliver explains why the issue of party funding won't go away.
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.body:
So who is Labour's mystery benefactor?
Paul Hamlyn, a publishing magnate and life peer.

Did he have to identify himself?
No. Technically, by banking the money before Christmas, Labour would have postponed the need to disclose the benefactor and scale of donation. Under the current rules the names of donors need not be revealed until the autumn, when the party's annual accounts are published, listing people who have given more than £5,000.

Then why did Lord Hamlyn come forward?
He said he had decided to make his gift public although he was under no obligation to do so. But Labour had faced mounting criticism because the money had been banked before its own anti-sleaze legislation comes into force on February 16.

Has Lord Hamlyn given Labour money in the past?
Yes. He is believed to have donated hundreds of thousands of pounds to the party.

Why did he receive a peerage?
There is no suggestion that the millionaire publisher's peerage is linked to his donations to Labour. When he was made a life peer two years ago it was stressed that the award recognised his charity work.

Why is the issue of donations important?
Money and power have always had a fraught relationship where the suspicion of buying favour is concerned. Labour was anxious to avoid a repeat of the Bernie Ecclestone affair.

What happened then?
Within months of Labour's landslide election victory in 1997, the Formula 1 chief gave £1m to Labour. After the donation the government relaxed proposed rules which would have curtailed tobacco advertising within the sport. The prime minister, Tony Blair, felt it necessary to return the donation after a storm of criticism.

Who was calling for this year's donor to be named?
Many Labour MPs, including former transport minister Glenda Jackson, ex-defence minister Peter Kilfoyle, and Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party.

The Tories accused Labour of "hypocrisy". Many Conservatives are still bitter about the way Labour managed to portray them as sleaze-ridden during the last election. The Neil Hamilton cash-for-questions affair and Jonathan Aitken's downfall did the Tories lasting damage.

A leader in today's Times newspaper said: "A party with nothing to hide would surely grasp the chance, especially with an election looming, to show its commitment to the spirit as well as the letter of its own legislation."

Are there other instances where Labour has faced criticism over sleaze?
The terms apparently offered to Legacy, the consortium run by Robert Bourne, in its "preferred bid" for the site of the vacated Millennium Dome have been attacked as being too favourable. Mr Bourne has given substantial donations to Labour, including to the constituency of Chris Smith, the culture secretary.

When science minister Lord Sainsbury gave £2m to the party in 1999 - setting a new record - he revealed the fact and many commentators and politicians regarded this as the way to conduct donations in the future.

How are Britain's political parties funded?
In the past, the Tories have attracted big business donors, with their coffers dwarfing the funds given by trades unions to Labour.

But unions have threatened to cut their contributions to Labour's general election campaign by £4m. There had been hopes within Labour of receiving £10m from the unions but this is now reported to be more likely to be nearer to £6m.

Labour spent a record £25m on its 1997 campaign. About £8m of that was donated from trades unions. Labour was also attracting unprecedented funding from the private sector and individual businessmen.

Is Labour likely to attract similar sums?
No. Contributions are drying up, potential donors fearing negative publicity of the type suffered by Mr Ecclestone. And Labour's grass-roots supporters are feeling both disillusioned with the Labour party and confident that it will win the election irrespective of the size of union donations.

And are there further restrictions now in place?
Yes. New laws impose a £20m cap on how much a political party can spend on campaigning - and there is now a growing possibility that both the major parties will underspend as they struggle to attract funds.

The Tory treasurer, Lord Ashcroft of Chichester, recently attempted to lower the proposed £20m election spending cap to £13m, prompting fresh doubts about the Conservatives' ability to fund their campaign.

The Conservatives have been reliant on Lord Ashcroft's own donations of around £5m since the last election, have a £9m overdraft and are also having trouble raising money from big donors. Lord Ashcroft was embroiled in scandal this year when a cross-party committee of peers to barred him from sitting in the House of Lords until he started to pay full British taxes. He was based in Florida at the time.

fields.bodyText: So who is Labour's mystery benefactor? Paul Hamlyn, a publishing magnate and life peer. Did he have to identify himself? No. Technically, by banking the money before Christmas, Labour would have postponed the need to disclose the benefactor and scale of donation. Under the current rules the names of donors need not be revealed until the autumn, when the party's annual accounts are published, listing people who have given more than £5,000. Then why did Lord Hamlyn come forward? He said he had decided to make his gift public although he was under no obligation to do so. But Labour had faced mounting criticism because the money had been banked before its own anti-sleaze legislation comes into force on February 16. Has Lord Hamlyn given Labour money in the past? Yes. He is believed to have donated hundreds of thousands of pounds to the party. Why did he receive a peerage? There is no suggestion that the millionaire publisher's peerage is linked to his donations to Labour. When he was made a life peer two years ago it was stressed that the award recognised his charity work. Why is the issue of donations important? Money and power have always had a fraught relationship where the suspicion of buying favour is concerned. Labour was anxious to avoid a repeat of the Bernie Ecclestone affair. What happened then? Within months of Labour's landslide election victory in 1997, the Formula 1 chief gave £1m to Labour. After the donation the government relaxed proposed rules which would have curtailed tobacco advertising within the sport. The prime minister, Tony Blair, felt it necessary to return the donation after a storm of criticism. Who was calling for this year's donor to be named? Many Labour MPs, including former transport minister Glenda Jackson, ex-defence minister Peter Kilfoyle, and Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party. The Tories accused Labour of "hypocrisy". Many Conservatives are still bitter about the way Labour managed to portray them as sleaze-ridden during the last election. The Neil Hamilton cash-for-questions affair and Jonathan Aitken's downfall did the Tories lasting damage. A leader in today's Times newspaper said: "A party with nothing to hide would surely grasp the chance, especially with an election looming, to show its commitment to the spirit as well as the letter of its own legislation." Are there other instances where Labour has faced criticism over sleaze? The terms apparently offered to Legacy, the consortium run by Robert Bourne, in its "preferred bid" for the site of the vacated Millennium Dome have been attacked as being too favourable. Mr Bourne has given substantial donations to Labour, including to the constituency of Chris Smith, the culture secretary. When science minister Lord Sainsbury gave £2m to the party in 1999 - setting a new record - he revealed the fact and many commentators and politicians regarded this as the way to conduct donations in the future. How are Britain's political parties funded? In the past, the Tories have attracted big business donors, with their coffers dwarfing the funds given by trades unions to Labour. But unions have threatened to cut their contributions to Labour's general election campaign by £4m. There had been hopes within Labour of receiving £10m from the unions but this is now reported to be more likely to be nearer to £6m. Labour spent a record £25m on its 1997 campaign. About £8m of that was donated from trades unions. Labour was also attracting unprecedented funding from the private sector and individual businessmen. Is Labour likely to attract similar sums? No. Contributions are drying up, potential donors fearing negative publicity of the type suffered by Mr Ecclestone. And Labour's grass-roots supporters are feeling both disillusioned with the Labour party and confident that it will win the election irrespective of the size of union donations. webTitle: George Carman QC dies

fields.headline: George Carman QC dies
fields.trailText: George Carman QC, Britain's most celebrated barrister, died today aged 71, his son announced.
fields.body:
George Carman QC, Britain's most celebrated barrister, died today aged 71, his son announced.

Mr Carman, who retired last year, had suffered from prostate cancer for four-and-a-half years.

Dominic Carman said that his father was a small man "but, with his stage as a courtroom and his audience as the jury, he was a giant among men".

Speaking from Mr Carman senior's home in Wimbledon, south-west London, the barrister's close friend Karen Phillips said: "It's very sad. We have been expecting it. I am just glad that he has gone quickly and he has not suffered at all and it's been very, very peaceful."

Mr Carman, who announced that he was suffering from prostate cancer in September last year, had criticised Britain's approach to the disease.

He said: "I would also like to mention the fact that, having looked at the government figures for cancer research in this country, we are way behind the major European countries and the United States, and I think it is time that problem was addressed by all the political parties."

The most feared cross-examiner of his generation first announced he was retiring on doctors' orders to undergo treatment for a "little local difficulty".

However, a few days later, on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, he said that he had changed his mind about keeping the details secret.

Mr Carman told Sir David: "I feel it important to say, to dispel rumour and for other reasons, that in fact I have suffered from prostate cancer for over three years. I mention that now publicly for these reasons.

"First, I don't want speculation and rumour to continue and so people know exactly what my little problem is.

"But, much more importantly, I want to send out a message to people who do suffer from cancer, to tell them that you can work.

"You can help the doctors enormously by having a positive attitude, and anybody who has the misfortune to get the disease is not at the end of the road."

Mr Carman said that, during his fight against the disease, he sometimes underwent medical treatment before court. "Half past eight in the hospital, 9.45 at the royal courts of justice."

He disclosed that he had been undergoing treatment while delivering some of his most memorable courtroom performances, including last year's victory for the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, against the former Tory minister, Neil Hamilton, over claims that he took cash for asking questions in parliament.

In one of his many celebrated courtroom soundbites, Mr Carman famously described Mr Hamilton as "on the make and on the take".

The most sought-after libel advocate of his generation, he regularly featured in lists of £1m a year QCs, although his earnings were probably not quite that high.

In fact, in August, he revealed that his income was so meagre in his first few years of practice that he washed dishes to make ends meet.

After five years he was earning "as much as a Manchester bus driver without overtime".

It was the trial of the former Liberal leader, Jeremy Thorpe, for conspiracy to murder, that first brought him to prominence.

webTitle: Woman killed in giant landslide in Wales

fields.headline: Woman killed in giant landslide in Wales
fields.trailText: A woman was killed and a man critically injured when a giant landslide on a 200ft cliff swept cars down onto a beach in north Wales today.
fields.body:
A woman was killed and a man critically injured when a giant landslide on a 200ft cliff swept cars down onto a beach in north Wales today.

Seven cars were believed to have been caught in the landslip, which struck at just after 11.30am, on a long stretch of road which winds its way down to the beach at Nefyn on the remote Lleyn peninsula.

Two of the cars were reported to have been swept at least 40ft down towards the sea and were left sticking out of the mud as emergency services launched a major rescue operation in the face of an incoming tide.

North Wales Fire Service said that some of the cars involved had been left hanging precariously over the edge of the damaged road following the incident.

The woman who died was recovered by a lifeboat but declared dead at the lifeboat base at nearby Porthdinllaen. The man was flown by RAF helicopter to Gwynedd hospital in nearby Bangor with serious, though not life threatening, injuries.

A North Wales Police spokesman later said that there were no reports of any further casualties.

"The clear-up operation is under way and will continue during the afternoon, as will the search of the rubble by the search and rescue dogs," he added.

Police were interviewing witnesses to discover exactly what happened in the landslide. Coastguards warned people to stay away from the area as the rescue operation went on.

A spokeswoman for Gwynedd council said torrential rain over the last few months was thought to have caused the landslide in the cliff.

"The problem is all the coast in that particular area is of clay and sand so you can imagine the effect of tremendous rain over the last few months," she said.

There had been another, smaller slide in the same area over the Christmas period.

HM Coastguard Cliff Rescue teams were scrambled to the scene, together with a lifeboat and RAF and police helicopters.

A fire service spokesman said a specialist rescue vehicle from the fire station at Caernarfon was called to the scene in addition to two crews from the seaside town of Pwllheli.

"We understand that ambulance personnel rescued one casualty from one vehicle and we have rescued two persons from the other vehicle.

"Our officer at the scene says there is a danger of further landslides. The area is not yet fully secure. This is a major operation for all the emergency services," the spokesman added.

Today's tragedy comes less than a week after cliffs along one mile of the Dorset coastline slid into the sea.

Although no one was injured during the collapse near Charmouth last Wednesday, Dorset police warned people to stay away and fenced off the surrounding area.

The clay and soil covered beach has been attracting tourists and a police helicopter had to be scrambled to order fossil hunters away from the area.

Dorset Police spokesman Mike Maber said that he hoped the tragedy in north Wales would alert people to the dangers still present in the Charmouth area.

Weather experts said the combination of heavy rain, freezing temperatures and rough seas were the likely cause of the recent landslides.

"The heavy rain over the past 36 hours will have saturated the mud on the cliffs in north Wales," said a PA WeatherCentre spokesman.

webTitle: George Carman QC: a career in quotations

fields.headline: George Carman QC: a career in quotations
fields.standfirst: Memorable sayings by and about the legendary barrister
fields.trailText: Master of the soundbite George Carman QC used his rapier wit to attack - and defend - some of the most famous names in Britain.     Many colleagues said it was his ability to plant a vivid and telling picture of his quarry in the jury's head that won him some of his most  famous libel victories.     Here are some memorable bons mots from his cases:
fields.body:
Master of the soundbite George Carman QC used his rapier wit to attack - and defend - some of the most famous names in Britain. Many colleagues said it was his ability to plant a vivid and telling picture of his quarry in the jury's head that won him some of his most famous libel victories. Here are some memorable bons mots from his cases:

On Sonia Sutcliffe, wife of the Yorkshire Ripper:
"She danced on the graves of her husband's victims. She is a clever, confident, cold and calculating woman. She has sought to excite sympathy at every available opportunity in the witness box. The truth and Sonia do not make good bedfellows."

On David Mellor:
"Behaved like an ostrich and put his head in the sand, thereby exposing his thinking parts."

On Neil Hamilton, in his battle with Mohamed Al Fayed:
"On the make and on the take" and "a man with no honour left".

On Ken Dodd, whom he defended on tax evasion charges:
"Some accountants are comedians, but comedians are never accountants."

And what they said about him:

Jani Allen, a South African journalist who sued over claims that she had an affair with neo-Nazi leader Eugene Terreblanche:
"Whatever award is given for libel, being cross-examined by you would not make it enough money."

Alan Rusbridger, Guardian editor, on receiving a writ from Jonathan Aitken:
"We'd better get Carman - before Aitken gets him."

Virgin boss Richard Branson:
"I asked my solicitor who I should most dread having on the other side to cross-examine me, and he said George Carman. I said let's get this man. Quickly."

webTitle: 'We felt we were poisoning her'

fields.headline: 'We felt we were poisoning her'
fields.standfirst: When Lexie McConnell was given drugs for an eye problem, her parents knew something was terribly wrong, but were told to keep feeding her the tablets. Sarah Boseley on a tragic waste of life
fields.trailText: When Lexie McConnell was given drugs for an eye problem, her parents knew something was terribly wrong, but were told to keep feeding her the tablets. Sarah Boseley on a tragic waste of life.
fields.body:
The story of Lexie McConnell's death has the horrifying inexorability of Greek tragedy, chilling to the heart of anyone with a child. Lexie was nine. She was a happy, bright and extrovert girl. Her parents nurtured and protected her, as good parents do. But they were powerless to save her. In trying to do the best for her, they were led to do the worst. She died because her immune system had been destroyed by drugs her mother gave her on the doctor's orders for a minor eye infection, crushed and mixed with honey to make them more palatable.

What makes it so terrible is that they knew something was gravely wrong and struggled against the reassurances of the medical profession. They are still struggling - for an admission that doctors got it wrong, and to safeguard the children of the future.

Lexie's parents say it is surprising they are still alive. Her father, Art, was once a successful violinist. Now he plays only for friends. Eight years after his little girl died, his face is marked with grief even when he smiles. He cannot relate the way she died without breaking down. Lexie's artist mother, Vicky, is calmer, but tells of the unspeakable horror of the realisation that she, under doctors' orders, may have fatally damaged her child.

For the first time, they feel able to tell their whole story, following the lifting of a "gagging order" agreed between their lawyers and the lawyers for the hospital where Lexie died. They were given £100,000 as an out-of-court settlement of their legal case against the Oxfordshire health authority and the John Radcliffe Hospital, but with some stringent conditions attached - not to talk to the press and not to pursue their complaint to the General Medical Council against the doctors who treated their daughter. The health authority and the NHS Litigation Authority vehemently deny demanding any sort of condition, saying the gagging agreement was offered out of the blue, drawn up by the McConnells' own lawyers.

Regardless, Art and Vicky McConnell do not intend to keep silent. They don't have the three things they want: an explanation, an apology and an assurance that no child will ever again be treated in the way that Lexie was. "We won't rest without knowing that all drugs used on children have been tested prop erly for safety," says Art. "I can see us carrying on for the rest of our lives."

The couple live in Abingdon, near Oxford, where they moved from Wales the year before Lexie died. Art had been head of strings at the College of Music and Drama in Cardiff, but wanted to be nearer London. Lexie, whose given name was Alexandra, had got over her homesickness, had loads of friends, was top of her class at school and was showing a talent for the piano, says her father.

In July 1992 at sports day she was hit in the left eye hard with a tennis ball. She was crying and in pain for about 20 minutes and her vision was blurred, but then she recovered. Nobody thought any more about it. "We were on holiday in August on the Isle of Wight and Lex said to me one morning, 'Dad - I've got a bit of blur in my left eye'," says Art. "She'd discovered it because she and her friend were playing opticians and they were reading an eye chart that they had drawn up.

"It sounds so extraordinary, the whole thing. Two months later she was dead, and this is how it started."

The GP sent Lexie to a consultant paediatric neurologist at the John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford rather than an opthalmologist, in case the problem was not with the eye at all. But a brain scan and a lumbur puncture showed nothing. The consultant decided something was causing inflammation, probably congenital toxoplasmosis - an organism that can damage the retina.

The consultant prescribed steroids and antibiotics. Art knew somebody whose face had swollen up on steroids and asked if there were any side effects. "He said any drug can have side-effects, even paracetemol," says Vicky.

Lexie was put on 80mg a day of the steroid prednisolone. The British National Formulary - the prescribing bible used by doctors - recommended at the time a maximum dose of 60mg for adults with serious disease, and that only for short periods with a reduction in the dose after a few days. Like most drugs, steroids are not licensed for use in children. Doctors have to use their judgement based on the information available. Much of that information is provided by drug manufacturers after clinical trials. But few trials are carried out on children.

Lexie was put on 80mg a day for three weeks and five days. She was also taking 4g a day of sulphadiazine and 25mg of pyrimethamine. Both antibiotics are recommended for toxoplasmosis - unlike the steroids - but can affect the liver.

It isn't easy for a nine-year-old child to take 24 tablets a day, and some of them were large. "They were like horse pills," says Vicky. "I had to crush them up in honey. It was a Friday when she had her first prescription. Within 24 hours she was feeling very nauseous and had a terrible headache."

She gestures to the green sofa where Lexie lay all night, in case she wanted to be sick. "She was on the sofa, and I was sitting in the chair next to her trying to get some sleep and I looked and I could almost see her face swelling. I thought - poor kid - after all this and she's got mumps."

It wasn't mumps. The next day Art was immediately convinced Lexie was reacting to the drugs. They called the GP, who agreed that might be the cause of the swelling, but said he would check with the consultant. Art and Vicky phoned every day for an answer. Eventually, a week after Lexie began taking the tablets, Vicky went to the surgery where a locum called the hospital and got confirmation that the prescription was right. Who from, Vicky does not know. They asked more than once whether Lexie could stop taking the pills, but were told it was dangerous to give up steroids. The body goes into shock unless they are withdrawn gradually.

Lexie had hardly been to school since she started the drugs. Sometimes she felt too ill. Sometimes she would say she was well enough in the morning, only to be sent home. She was lethargic and put on a gross amount of weight to the point where her father could no longer lift her. The consultant confirmed that she was "cushiongoid" - that she had swollen up as a reaction to steroids. Her parents were eaten up with anxiety.

"At one point I was so upset I threw the whole lot of pills across the kitchen and said I can't do this," says Vicky. Art picks up from her - they pass the story from one to the other. "I put her to bed and I said Vick, it is almost as if we are poisoning our own child. She said yes, I know."

"We were trying not to upset each other," says Vicky. "Right from the moment they are born, you feed them the right things and give them vegetables and wash your hands after you have been to the loo and yet we felt we were the ones who were poisoning her."

After one of the weekly visits to the consultant, Lexie complained of stomach pain. It got so bad she couldn't walk. When the GP arrived, he prodded her stomach and suggested it was constipation. In fact, she had the liver disease hepatitis.

Vicky rang the surgery again in the night and the on-call GP had Lexie admitted to hospital, but the constipation diagnosis went with her. The hospital doctor told the couple to go home and leave Lexie. "She was nine years-old and frightened. I wasn't going home," says Vicky. "That really put his back up. He thought he was looking at a spoilt brat making a fuss because she was constipated. She was crying in pain. I went to the doctor to tell him and he turned his back on me." At the inquest, he apologised. He was not the only doctor to dismiss the parents' anxieties. A consultant paediatrician the next morning wrote in Lexie's notes: "Neurotic mother winding up child."

By then, spots were rapidly spreading across Lexie's body. This was no rash. Lexie's parents had a meeting with her consultant and another paediatrician. What makes it so terrible is that they knew something was gravely wrong and struggled against the reassurances of the medical profession. They are still struggling - for an admission that doctors got it wrong, and to safeguard the children of the future. Lexie's parents say it is surprising they are still alive. Her father, Art, was once a successful violinist. Now he plays only for friends. Eight years after his little girl died, his face is marked with grief even when he smiles. He cannot relate the way she died without breaking down. Lexie's artist mother, Vicky, is calmer, but tells of the unspeakable horror of the realisation that she, under doctors' orders, may have fatally damaged her child. For the first time, they feel able to tell their whole story, following the lifting of a "gagging order" agreed between their lawyers and the lawyers for the hospital where Lexie died. The British National Formulary - the prescribing bible used by doctors - recommended at the time a maximum dose of 60mg for adults with serious disease, and that only for short periods with a reduction in the dose after a few days. She gestures to the green sofa where Lexie lay all night, in case she wanted to be sick. "She was on the sofa, and I was sitting in the chair next to her trying to get some sleep and I looked and I could almost see her face swelling. I thought - poor kid - after all this and she's got mumps." It wasn't mumps. The next day Art was immediately convinced Lexie was reacting to the drugs. webTitle: The diary of a junior doctor

fields.headline: White coat, black heart
fields.standfirst: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.trailText: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.body:
I often think about how we keep families out of the resuscitation room in A&E. How the sight of their dying father with a triple-bore central line sticking out of his blood-soaked neck, and his groin betraying the scars of my traumatic practice runs at inserting a femoral arterial line, his chest covered in electrode pads, being used as a coffee table for bits of equipment, and his trousers lying in half on the trolley beneath him . . . how it all might be too disturbing for the relatives.

To be honest, the sound of them in tears outside the door, demanding to be let in, is often the only thing that can bring home what exactly is unfolding before me, and that alone feels like a good enough reason not to let them in, because you don't want to think about that kind of thing when the registrar is barking out instructions and you're trying to get arterial blood gases off quickly enough to impress the anaesthetist so that he'll talk you through the next patient's femoral arterial line (get to do a few yourself, it looks great on the CV).

Gradually, by subterfuge, these episodes are changing me, or at least cleaving off my work persona from the boy next door I imagine I must still be. The process of depersonalisation that starts in casualty is just as real on the wards. You cannot rely on innate charm with patients at three in the morning, and you cannot afford to take it personally when that notoriously unhelpful nurse on 7E starts bouncing up and down and giving you grief about somebody else's blood form.

Sometimes I am astonished to catch myself on autopilot, asking nothing but pertinent questions (I kid you not), smiling away, almost completely unaware of the fact that I am talking to a person and not a box with "query unstable angina" written on its forehead, who may or may not need IV isoket and heparin depending on how highly it scores on the tick list in my head. The rare occasions when I offend or cause distress are the times when I am foolish enough to chance my luck at just being myself.

But the strangest thing is that this hugely effective depersonalisation of the patients, this reinvention of myself as a walking bedside manner, is exactly what I have started to do to myself, as the only way to stave off the powerful inner drive towards self-pity and resentment of the NHS, and how it has ruined my life.

It is a resentment that has cut even deeper over the festive period, when everyone else is at home watching It's a Wonderful Life on the sofa with their mum and dad, and the only way to cope is to make yourself love the job, by buying into the delusory self- sacrificing herd mentality of junior doctors, where nothing outside the hospital matters any more, where you do not expect to have a life, where friends are a thing of the past, where disasters are a challenge and where you have to love your work because to expect anything more from life is to court disappointment. So this is what I have learned this year, more than how to manage myocardial infarction: how to stop the patients from punishing me, how to cope with evil politics on the ward, and how to stop taking it as a personal affront or judgment on my character when a patient gets ill.

So if I grit my teeth hard enough, the festive period (which was anything but) was a delight. The day after Boxing Day A&E was full to boiling, and the casualty sister was sending patients up to the admissions ward (about a million miles away, since you ask) before they had even been seen. Each and every one of them was a social and medical disaster zone, neglected by all and sundry for the entirety of the preceding week, and there was nothing we could do for most of them but admit them to our Gomer Hotel. (Gomer: noun, medical: unloved geriatric patient on his or her last legs for no apparent reason. [abbrev. for Get Out of My Emergency Room].) These people are sent to punish us. Let them come. Our admissions list, previously an index of pain, went on to a fifth page, and we loved it.

I have become a medic. I have put my blinkers on, drawn up my galoshes, and waded into the bloodbath before me. The patients over the four-day-long Christmas holiday were underhydrated and grossly mismanaged, dry as a crisp: it wasn't my fault, but, better than that, it was a great opportunity to practise my central line technique.

webTitle: Self help books

fields.headline: A better you?
fields.standfirst: It's new year, and the shops are full of books promising to transform your life. Laura Barton casts an eye over them
fields.trailText: It's new year, and the shops are full of books promising to transform your life. Laura Barton casts an eye over them
fields.body:
Post-Christmas, early January, and the shops are just bulging with publications that promise a whole new, shinier, downright perkier you. Books such as Elizabeth Somer's The Origin Diet: How Living in Tune With Your Evolutionary Roots Will Reduce Disease, Boost Vitality, Add Healthy Years to Your Life and Help You Live Longer, Feel Healthier and Lose Weight. Crikey O'Riley, is there nothing this book can't do? It even makes a good doorstop.

And then there's The Sugar Addict's Total Recovery Program by Kathleen DesMaisons PhD,which guides you out of the "fog" of sugar addiction. DesMaisons provides recipes, meal plans and practical tips to steer you clear of the teeth-rotting, mood-swinging demon. You've heard it all before, and probably on Oprah, but Kathleen deserves a mention if only because her last bestseller was entitled Potatoes Not Prozac.

Just a quick squint at the contents pages of The Diet Cure by Julia Ross is enough to make you spurn the Special K. "Are You Suffering Because of Low Calorie Dieting?", "Is Depleted Brain Chemistry the Problem?" Absolutely, Julia, how right you are. Now pass me the foie gras. On the other hand, Jay Cooper would attribute it all to body type. His new publication, The Body Code Diet and Fitness Programme , sorts the wheat from the chaff, the men from the boys, and the rest of us into "Communicators", "Warriors", "Nurturers" and "Visionaries" who all require special diets and exercise regimes to suit. Together we can master our metabolisms.

There are three main sections in Stephanie Winston's book Getting Out From Under: Redefining Your Priorities in an Overwhelming World . Part one helps you to gain time in your life immediately; it's the add-water-and-stir solution. Part two helps you to "Examine Your Personal Universe" for which you will need a hand-held mirror and a pair of tweezers. Winston suggests that you formulate a solar-system approach to your life, to help you decide what is really important, and what is Pluto, and in part three, you learn to build on your new-found self-knowledge. I cannot believe I just said that.

Organizing From the Inside Out: The Foolproof System for Organizing Your Home, Your Office and Your Life is by Julie Morgenstern, a board director of the National Association of Professional Organizers in the US. Julie tells us that it is not our fault if we are disorganised; we simply never learnt how to be organised. But Julie Morgenstern is here to teach us. With her digestible "analyze, strategize, attack" formula. Thank God for the Atlantic Ocean.

The Journey To You - A Shamen's Path to Empowerment by Ross Heaven. Heaven by name, heavenly by nature, Ross is a practising Shaman with unwavering eyes and the hint of a mullet. He is here to teach us of the ancient practice of Shamanism, and the fact that "YOU have control of this world, indeed that YOU are the sole creator of the world you occupy - and that YOU have the power to change it". Which may come as something of a shock.

The Longevity Code: Your Personal Prescription for a Longer, Sweeter Life by Zorba Paster MD, for whom the anagrammatic possibilities are endless, relies on a bevy of self-tests, anecdotes and probably Venn diagrams, to assess our "Five Spheres of Wellness". Elsewhere there are 76 "boosters" to make our lives peachy - "Take care of your teeth and gums," for example, and "Don't live in a violent environment." Pearls of wisdom, apparently gleaned from the fortune cookie school of psychology.

How to Have Magnificent Sex: The Seven Dimensions of a Vital Sexual Connection is the new book by Lana Holstein MD, who has spent 25 years proclaiming that a sex life is a "birthright". And now, ladies and gentlemen, Lana has honed her theory into seven essential points: understanding the body, exploring the senses, recharging desire, opening the heart, boosting intimacy, baring the soul and embracing the spirit. You can maybe add these to your "To do" list when you are redefining your priorities in an overwhelming world. At the end of each Dimension, Holstein provides suggestions for you folk to try at home - with the curtains closed. Explore the senses, for example, by indulging in forms of non- sexual contact such as dancing or bare-knuckle fighting. Later on, there's even a section dedicated to Tantric sex, for which you will need a Sting album. Or long-player, as he probably likes to call it.

A word, here, must be spared for Mr Steven Carter and his natty guide This is How Love Works: Nine Essential Secrets You Need to Know , not only for its splendidly toe-curling chapter titles - Make "We" a Priority and Take Off the Masks, for example - but also for Steven's brilliant use of stale-couple scenarios to illustrate his point - "Carla and Bryan moved in together one year ago, and ever since then they have been playing 'the thermostat game'." If you know the rules of "the thermostat game", please write in.

Relationship Rescue: A Seven-Step Strategy for Reconnecting With Your Partner is by Phillip C McGraw PhD. "I'm prepared to kick a hole in the wall of the pain-ridden, unhappy maze you've gotten yourself into," says Dr Phil, who is essentially the Mr T of counselling. And with his trusty Seven Step Strategy - which probably involves ropes, underground tunnels and a cagoule - he will liberate us. No straggling, you there at the back! Your first task is to wade through endless questionnaires, profiles and tests such as "List Five Things That Today Would Make You Fall Out Of Love With Your Partner".

Only after this period of self-analysis, are you and your partner ready to "reconnect", by taking it in turns to give monologues on subjects such as "The most positive thing I took away from my Mother and Father's relationship was . . ." This process usually takes half an hour a day over the course of two weeks, but you can probably cram it into an afternoon, if you're in a rush.

Speaking of which, The Multi-Orgasmic Couple: Sexual Secrets Every Couple Should Know by Mantak Chia, Maneewan Chia, Douglas Abrams and Rachel Carlton Abrams is a charming introduction to Taoist sexual theory, where a man is fire, and a woman water. Illustrations are provided by the same artist who so enhanced The Joy of Sex. Cynics may suggest that he can only draw naked people "at it". The thought never entered my head.

A word, here, must be spared for Mr Steven Carter and his natty guide This is How Love Works: Nine Essential Secrets You Need to Know , not only for its splendidly toe-curling chapter titles - Make "We" a Priority and Take Off the Masks, for example - but also for Steven's brilliant use of stale-couple scenarios to illustrate his point - "Carla and Bryan moved in together one year ago, and ever since then they have been playing 'the thermostat game'." If you know the rules of "the thermostat game", please write in. Relationship Rescue: A Seven-Step Strategy for Reconnecting With Your Partner is by Phillip C McGraw PhD. "I'm prepared to kick a hole in the wall of the pain-ridden, unhappy maze you've gotten yourself into," says Dr Phil, who is essentially the Mr T of counselling. And with his trusty Seven Step Strategy - which probably involves ropes, underground tunnels and a cagoule - he will liberate us. No straggling, you there at the back! Your first task is to wade through endless questionnaires, profiles and tests such as "List Five Things That Today Would Make You Fall Out Of Love With Your Partner". Only after this period of self-analysis, are you and your partner ready to "reconnect", by taking it in turns to give monologues on subjects such as "The most positive thing I took away from my Mother and Father's relationship was . . ." This process usually takes half an hour a day over the course of two weeks, but you can probably cram it into an afternoon, if you're in a rush. Speaking of which, The Multi-Orgasmic Couple: Sexual Secrets Every Couple Should Know by Mantak Chia, Maneewan Chia, Douglas Abrams and Rachel Carlton Abrams is a charming introduction to Taoist sexual theory, where a man is fire, and a woman water. Illustrations are provided by the same artist who so enhanced The Joy of Sex. Cynics may suggest that he can only draw naked people "at it". The thought never entered my head.

webTitle: Dear doctor

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.body:
Mood swings

Q: I have been taking Microgynon for five months, and though I experienced premenstrual moodiness before, now I feel quite unstable and the mood swings are very severe. What do we know about how mood is affected by birth-control pills?

A: Premenstrual mood swings (PMS) are sometimes cured by the contraceptive pill, and sometimes they're not. Although the pill stops ovulation, the progestogen part of the pill can make PMS worse. Other options to reduce PMS include eating high-carbohydrate foods every three hours to keep blood-sugar levels stable, exercise and using vitamin and mineral supplements which include vitamin B6 and magnesium. The evidence for these strategies is limited but they may be worth a try. Evening primrose oil is good for breast tenderness and may help mood swings too. Anti-depressants such as Prozac or drugs to stop ovulation can be prescribed if you are desperate.

Lead in the water

Q: I have recently moved into an old Edwardian house with lead pipes and wonder whether we should replace them with plastic ones to avoid the risk of lead poisoning for our young children. How do I know whether it's necessary?

A: Too much lead in the water is bad for the developing nervous systems of unborn babies and young children. So pregnant women and young kids may be at risk if lead levels in your water are high. The water companies have a legal obligation to keep lead levels below 50 micrograms/litre. And there's a new EU directive to ensure that these levels are halved by 2003 and down to 10 micrograms/litre by the end of 2013, which makes you wonder how safe our current levels really are. There is a very good leaflet called Lead in Drinking Water, available from the Drinking Water Inspectorate (020-7944 5956) or from their website at www.dwi.detr.gov.uk.

Hearing loss

Q: I'm 68 and my hearing's going. The TV is a mumble and I often find it hard to hear what people are saying to me if there's a lot of background noise. I hate the idea of sporting a hearing aid. Can you suggest anything?

A: If it's any comfort, half of all people over 60 have hearing loss due to advancing years. The fancy term is "presbyacusis" and it's due to deterioration of the tiny hair cells in the inner ear. It becomes hard to distinguish sounds so people seem to be mumbling, you may not catch names or phone numbers, noisy places become a nightmare, listening takes a lot of concentration and you may give up and withdraw into yourself. TV or music may sound very loud even though you can't differentiate individual words. On the positive side, the vast majority of those with presbyacusis benefit from a hearing aid. The first step is to get formal hearing tests (audiometry) via your GP, an ENT specialist or local hearing aid centre. There is a wide range of hearing aids now available, especially in the private sector. They can be fitted behind the ear, within the ear, buried deeply in the ear canal, or built into your specs so no one knows you're wearing one.

Is it safe to fly?

Q: I'm pregnant and want to go on holiday. Is it safe to fly?

A:There's no evidence that air travel is dangerous for your developing baby, despite the fall in oxygen that occurs during a flight. If you are very anaemic, this fall in oxygen could theoretically be harmful for mother and baby alike so you'd be well advised to wait until your blood count is near normal. Airlines don't want you to give birth mid-flight - they're quite busy enough pushing those trolleys up and down the aisles - so they won't usually let you fly beyond 34 weeks. You are at increased risk of thrombosis while pregnant, so you should take care to walk around at least once an hour, have plenty of non-alcoholic drinks and move your legs around while sitting. Don't take aspirin - it's not good for the baby.

If you're going somewhere exotic, you'll want special advice about vaccines and avoiding infections. British Airways Travel Clinics, tel: 01276 685040.

Memory loss

Q: My husband's getting slightly depressed about a serious deterioration in his memory (he is 67). His GP has prescribed anti-depressants, which may deal with the depression, but not with the cause of it. Is treating the memory loss too expensive, or does the GP think there is nothing he can do?

A: Memory loss due to dementia is relatively rare in men of your husband's age, whereas depression is more common. Both can cause memory loss, although in depression, the memory loss fluctuates depending on mood, and in dementia the memory loss is progressive. Depressed people are often very worried about memory loss, have been depressed in the past, may have been recently bereaved, and seem unable to enjoy life.

Dementia may start with short-term memory loss so that recent events are hard to recall, while childhood memories remain clear. But the gradual disintegration of personality gradually sets in with inability to get dressed, self-neglect, inability to recognise people and objects and eventually loss of language, continence and behavioural norms.

If you think your husband is not improving on the anti-depressants, that his memory is getting worse and that these other features of dementia are setting in, you should insist on a referral to a psychiatrist or neurologist who runs a memory clinic. They will be able to use a formal method of assessing memory such as the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) and order other tests if needed.
