webTitle: Lord Hamlyn is Labour's £2m donor

fields.headline: Lord Hamlyn is Labour's £2m donor
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Paul Hamlyn, of the publishing family, today disclosed that he was the mystery donor who recently gave £2m to the Labour party.
fields.body:
Paul Hamlyn, of the publishing family, today disclosed that he was the mystery donor who recently gave £2m to the Labour party.

He said that he had decided to make his gift public although he was under no obligation to do so.

"I'm proud to be a longstanding supporter of the Labour party and the Labour government," he added.

Lord Hamlyn said that the £2m gift was "one of several large donations I have made to political and other causes."

His disclosure comes after days of mounting pressure on Labour to reveal the source of the cash, which was given before new rules that would have required disclosure come into effect next month.

Lord Hamlyn, who was appointed CBE in 1993 by the Conservative government for charitable services, said in his statement: "Having followed the debate on donations to the Labour party for the past few days, I'm happy to make public that I recently made a £2m donation to the party...

"I believe anyone who wants to see Britain develop as a strong economy and a fairer society has a vested interest in seeing the re-election of the Labour government.

"Under the existing legislation, I'm under no obligation to disclose the sum I have donated, but I'm happy to do so. I have said nothing until now because I'm overseas recovering from serious illness. For that reason I will be making no further comment.

"I make no apologies for supporting the Labour party in this way. Our democracy depends on vibrant political parties and, for years, the Conservatives had a virtual monopoly on large donations from individuals.

"I'm glad that has changed and I'm proud of the role I have played in helping the Labour party."

Friends said that Lord Hamlyn was suffering from pneumonia, has Parkinson's disease and is recovering from cancer.

Cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, a close ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair, told ITN: "It was this government that introduced changes which require the naming of donors. People who make donations before that - it's matter for them to decide if they make their names public.

"Lord Hamlyn has made his name public. I know he has been ill, so I think it's rather unkind to criticise him for only allowing his name to come forward at this moment."

Labour party chairwoman Maggie Jones said: "Paul Hamlyn is a respected businessman and a well-known supporter of the Labour party. The party is proud of the fact that people like him support us and that we are able to attract substantial donations from business people.

"As promised, the Labour party has made a number of changes to tighten the rules on party funding. Tony Blair was the first political leader to disclose a list of donors over £5,000.

"This Labour government has legislated for the greater transparency we promised. From February 16, when the new law comes into effect, the size of donations, as well as the names of donors will be published.

"Over the past few years, the Labour party has received a number of substantial donations, and it would be quite wrong if the Labour party alone was under an obligation to apply new rules retrospectively.

"If those rules are to be made retrospective, then they must be made retrospective for everyone, including the Conservatives - who still have not told us how they funded the 1997 election campaign."

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

webTitle: Playing with the phantoms of Prussia past

fields.headline: Playing with the phantoms of Prussia past
fields.standfirst: Pre-world war German history has its surreal stories but, as John Hooper discovers, nostalgia can be threatening to some
fields.trailText: Pre-world war German history has its surreal stories but, as John Hooper discovers, nostalgia can be threatening to some.
fields.body:
A snowy night in Potsdam. A lone accordionist, muffled against the blizzard, plays in a cobbled alleyway. Beyond him in the Klosterkeller, Potsdam's oldest tavern - founded in 1730 - all is warm and cosy. Yet utterly bizarre.

The place has been taken over by giants. None is less than six foot four. Some are approaching seven foot. And they are all wearing the uniform of the royal guards of Prussia's "soldier king".

Friedrich Wilhelm I, who ruled from 1713 to 1740, collected human beings as a hobby. Press gangs were sent out around Prussia - and latterly to other countries - to drag back the biggest men they could find to serve as the king's "lange Kerls" or tall fellows.

Ten years ago, a Potsdam pathologist and military history enthusiast, got together with friends to recreate the corps.

"We wanted to bring history alive and make this particular bit of the past vivid for others", says its present "commander", Bernd Kuhl, resplendent in red, white and blue, a 200-year-old sword dangling at his side.

Under his command, the reborn lange Kerls train, drill, put on displays - they have been as far afield as the US - attend historical lectures and gather at social evenings like this one, which is aimed at recreating the atmosphere of one of Friedrich Wilhem's smoking evenings or "Tabak Kollegium".

"The only problem", confided one of his men, "is that we are all non-smokers."

Anywhere else, the lange Kerls would be seen as a colourful, if eccentric, additions to the local scene. In Potsdam, too, they figure prominently on tourist postcards.

Yet their home town is the one place in the world in which they cannot stage a parade or exercise. On their first and only march through Potsdam, they were attacked by egg-throwing protestors.

The lange Kerls may be playing, but their game is a highly controversial one, for they are conjuring up a phantom. It is the phantom of Prussia, the region or country whose aggressive militarism is seen by many as lying at the root of the evils that Germany brought to the 20th century.

Nor are the lange Kerls the only ones. This year sees the 300th anniversary of Prussia's foundation. January 18 is the day in 1701 that Friedrich III, the elector of Brandenburg, crowned himself Friedrich I, king of Prussia.

To commemorate the anniversary, the regional authorities in Brandenburg and Berlin, which together formed the core of old Prussia, have arranged for a year-long series of exhibitions and festivals highlighting their common heritage.

The aim is more than just a historical one. Leading politicians in Brandenburg and Berlin would like to reunite their two regions after a failed attempt five years ago.

In the context of Germany's tortured history, this is a potentially explosive scheme.

After the second of the country's defeats in global conflicts, the victors tried to obliterate Prussia with all the vigour of an exorcist driving a stake into a vampire's heart. The allies declared it dead in 1947.

Berlin, Prussia's latter-day capital, was occupied and divided. The new, communist German Democratic Republic (GDR) which gained control of Potsdam, Prussia's earlier capital, went beyond mere words, expelling a large part of the city's population and, in an attempt to lay the ghosts of the past, resettling Germans there from elsewhere.

A reunited Prussia, though it would doubtless be called something different - most likely Berlin-Brandenburg - would be the seat of the German capital and, whatever ethos it evolved (or recovered), could be expected to exert an influence, through Berlin, on the character of Germany as a whole.

The issue is all the more sensitive because it concerns a part of Germany that not only has a militaristic past, but also a strong far-right presence today.

In parts of east Berlin and in many of the villages of rural Brandenburg, the dominant youth culture is pure neo-Nazi.

"All this nostalgia is not harmless", argues Wolfgang Wipperman, professor of modern history at the Free University of Berlin. "It is one aspect of the rewriting of German history.

"This is very important now that Berlin, the old capital of Prussia, is once again the capital of a reunified Germany."

But his views are by no means universally shared. Professor Julius Schoeps is also a professor of Modern History, at the University of Potsdam.

"Prussia was twin-faced", he says. "It was militaristic, certainly. But it was also modernising. Look, I am a Jew and, for Jews, Prussia was a state that brought emancipation - in 1812.

"Prussia was two things. It was a military ideal. But it also stood for modernism and enlightenment."

The lange Kerls and their patron take a similar view.

"What we want to represent is the small, modest Prussia", said their drill sergeant, Klaus Brucker.

Yet is clear that there are those who would like to turn the past of this bleak, windswept tract of Europe to other ends. Earlier this year, for the first time since the second world war, far-right demonstrators made a point of marching through the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin.

Comparisons were immediately drawn with the Nazis' torchlight processions under the same arch, but what was overlooked was that the Brandenburg Gate was also a symbol of Prussian triumphalism and unity.

On the latest march through the gate, demonstrators from the extreme-right NPD unfurled a banner. On it were the words "Prussia's law and order".

webTitle: Canal Plus to sell stake in Eurosport

fields.headline: Canal Plus to sell stake in Eurosport
fields.trailText: 3pm: French pay-TV channel Canal Plus is to sell its stake in Eurosport and set up a rival network, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
French pay-TV channel Canal Plus is to sell its stake in sports channel Eurosport and set up a rival network.

Canal Plus will pocket £170m from the sale of its 49.5% holding, which has been triggered by the company's merger with owner Vivendi and Seagram of Canada last year.

French TV operator TF1, which owns the rest of the sports channel, is likely to acquire the Canal Plus stake.

Canal Plus said it will remain a key customer of Eurosport, but its new channel will compete in some areas.

Analysts said that the sale was inevitable since Canal Plus had agreed to dump its holding if its ownership structure changed, but the market is looking for good news from a company which has had difficulty with its merger partners.

Marc Loneux, media analyst at Commerzbank, said: "We are waiting for many things, but the market is not waiting for negative or marginal news like this."

Vivendi Universal, the company created by the Vivendi and Seagram link-up, has attracted criticism from industry observers, who say it has drastically reduced shareholder value.

A recent boardroom shuffle parachuted several members of the Vivendi Universal management team into Canal Plus, prompting rumours of a fallout between Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier and Pierre Lescure, his counterpart at the pay-TV channel.

Marc Loneux, media analyst at Commerzbank, said: "We are waiting for many things, but the market is not waiting for negative or marginal news like this." Vivendi Universal, the company created by the Vivendi and Seagram link-up, has attracted criticism from industry observers, who say it has drastically reduced shareholder value. webTitle: Interview: Ben Kingsley

fields.headline: 'I can do anything'
fields.standfirst: He could have been a rock'n'roller but turned to acting instead. Now Ben Kingsley is firmly established among Britain's heavyweight stars. But the journey has been painful, he tells Brian Logan
fields.trailText: He could have been a rock'n'roller but turned to acting instead. Now Ben Kingsley is firmly established among Britain's heavyweight stars. But the journey has been painful, he tells Brian Logan.
fields.body:
Ben Kingsley holds forth on acting. He wants you to hear what he has to say, which is that "there's so much crap talked about acting", and that performance comes "from my intuition, my soul, my urgency". It's coming in a great flood, because he's rejuvenated. He says so himself. "Somewhere in your career, your work changes. It becomes less anal, less careful and more spontaneous, more to do with the information that your soul carries."

Now, Kingsley's CV doesn't demonstrate the most carefree of performers. The bright young Royal Shakespeare Company star of the 1970s bagged an Oscar for his role in Gandhi, and the subsequent string of films documenting 20th-century history. He consolidated a reputation as one of our heavyweight dramatic talents, starring in Schindler's List and Death and the Maiden, and playing Lenin and Simon Wiesenthal, Stanley Spencer and Shostakovich.

But "I am - hello! - an actor, an entertainer, a song-and-dance man," says Kingsley. "I can do anything." Song and dance may be surplus to requirements, but his role in Sexy Beast, the latest British movie about the London criminal underworld, will startle anyone who had the wiry 56-year-old gathering dust in the worthy-but-dull pigeonhole.

"I love creatures in their pure form," says Kingsley. He's found just such a creature in gangland chief Don Logan, who descends upon émigré crim Ray Winstone, bent on luring him back from Spain to Blighty for the ultimate bank job. It's a joy to watch these two fine actors spar on screen; Kingsley's, in particular, is a revelatory performance. His Don is drumskin-taut, a study in violence always about to unspring; he's a little man making himself big by psychotic force of will. He's terrifying.

"Don's pure form," says Kingsley, "is rage. I wouldn't like to stand next to Don at a bar and ask him for a light. If he says to you, 'What you fucking looking at?', you just know there's nothing you can do to get out of that killer grip." He pauses, then whispers at me conspiratorially: "I won't do it to you, because I know it's scary when I do it."

It's a measure of Kingsley's achievement that you believe Winstone to be physically intimidated by his ferrety aggressor. Something of Don Logan persists in Kingsley the interviewee. He's given to sudden mood swings and darts across the room; his manner is supercilious; he raises his voice to keep being heard. He has no time for the suggestion that Britain's geezer-chic film boom, of which Sexy Beast is an admittedly superior part, is rooted in fantasy. "That hunger of the flesh, that longing for ease, that terror of incarceration, that insistence on tribal honour being obeyed: all of that exists, and it exists everywhere. I just know that this film is so true."

Truth is an important quality for Kingsley. He may seek to shed gravitas, but he insists that his films should "reflect who we are, where we are and why we are".

"I was fortunate as a young actor," he explains, "to go straight to the RSC, where I learned that being an actor can bring with it wonderful responsibilities." The son of a Ugandan Asian GP and christened Krishna Bhanji, Kingsley - the name came from his grandfather, a Zanzibar-based spice trader nicknamed King Clove - fell in love with theatre when he saw Ian Holm's Hamlet. He was soon starring in Coronation Street; Brian Epstein, however, sought to lure him into rock music. "I wonder if I'd still be alive by now," Kingsley reflects. "As a singer, I might have fallen among thieves."

Instead, Stratford came calling. Over some 20 years with the RSC, Kingsley starred in Trevor Nunn's Nicholas Nickleby, Peter Brook's legendary Midsummer Night's Dream and in the title role in Othello.

So when he sees the film industry bent on "outlawing tragedy", on eradicating all that's painful or unhappy in stories about human beings, it appals him. "To offer to our tribe, as storytellers, narratives which are absent of a dark side is a terrible disservice. I'm just fighting for the right," he insists, "for a film to be stirring and brilliant and illuminating."

Few would argue; fewer still would contradict Kingsley, whose roster of grandiose roles adds weight to his case. But the actor hasn't always been able to speak with such unassailable authority. In the past, he's expressed regret that "as an actor there's no autonomy, unless you're prepared to risk the possibility of starving."

As a result, the man who was Gandhi has starred in his fair share of stinkers, including Michael Winner's notorious 1998 flop Parting Shots. I'd read that he suffered a slump in morale 10 years ago ("I was doing really bad work . . . and I was not in a good state"), but asked about it now, he denies the crisis of confidence. "There have not been any troughs as regards my work. There's never been a trough of my assurance."

The reason for his current soaring self-regard is that "there is a lot of creative energy in me right now. In the work I'm now doing, I know that my soul - my soul - is fully articulate."

"We can talk about a cello having a soul," he continues, "but when an actor talks about his soul people think, 'What a pretentious wanker'. A cello's soul is the resonance that makes it unique: how it was made, when it was made, who's played it. Mine may be who my parents were, what I know about life, who I love and have loved. All that makes my bones resonate. If a director is fortunate enough to tap into that, it's an endless well of information."

As a performer who, in accordance with some of the less respectful actorly stereotypes, puts his creative processes on a pedestal, Kingsley is infuriated that "I don't honestly think people know what acting is."

Notwithstanding his own claim to have prepared for the role of Gandhi by spinning cotton, he takes aim at the "imposed reputation" he has for Method-style rehearsal. "If I were to play somebody who ran a fish and chip shop, I would not work in a fish and chip shop for three months. Staring at chips is not going to help me in my performance. My performance" - and he jabs at his breast - "is in here: it all, all, all comes from here."

So what's in here? He's a mass of contradictions: the "entertainer" with a string of heavy credits; the censorious critic of trash who appeared in Parting Shots and Species; the Oscar-winner still seeking credit for his craft. What's given Kingsley the drive to, as he phrases it, "be seen and heard - a very primal urge"?

His voice drops to an acid hiss. "As a child, I was neither seen nor heard. I was not taken seriously. Everything I attempted to articulate was diminished, distorted or interrupted. It's a miracle that I got out of that: affluent, middle-class, horrible. That is why I honour that child and voice in me by saying: 'They're going to hear me, and see me, and I'm not going to be interrupted. I'll put them in a place where they can't interrupt me'. "

It comes from nowhere, this volcanic self-revelation, and it's gone as quickly. As explanations go for the urge to "be seen and heard", it's well worn - if seldom so vehemently expressed. But Kingsley doesn't dwell on the subject, far less go into detail. Perhaps he's aware of how forlorn it appears, justifying his life's work as vengeance for childhood slights, because he's off again, making himself heard. "Very soon preconceptions of me, if there are any left, will be meaningless, because I'll be moving too fast. 'Who's that bloke in the white car? No, he's on a yellow horse.' 'Who's that bloke on the yellow horse? No, he's holding a black jaguar.' 'That bloke holding the black jaguar? No, he's a clown up there on the tightrope . . .' "

He makes a karate action with his arms, to indicate how confused we'll all be. The child in him will be pleased at that.

I, Kingsley: the actor and his movies

Gandhi (1982) Kingsley's breakthrough role; his best actor Oscar was one of eight given to Richard Attenborough's three-hour epic charting the subcontinent's tortuous path to independence.

Silas Marner (1985) Fondly remembered BBC adaptation of the George Eliot novella, with Kingsley outstanding in the title role as the miserly weaver whose heart is softened by little Eppie (a pre-Absolute Beginners Patsy Kensit).

Pascali's Island (1988) Meditative intrigue about deception and betrayal adapted from Barry Unsworth's novel, with Kingsley impressive as the translator/spy who crosses paths with archaeologist Charles Dance.

Bugsy (1991) Another Kingsley performance noted by the Academy, though he didn't win for his side-man role as mobster Meyer Lanksy - alongside free-spending mafioso Bugsy Siegel (Warren Beatty).

Schindler's List (1993) Kingsley was somewhat overshadowed by co-stars Liam Neeson and Ralph Fiennes in Spielberg's heart-wrenching Holocaust epic, but did key work as accountant Itzhak Stern, the man who ran Schindler's factory for him and the film's most prominent Jewish character.

Death and the Maiden (1994) Film of Ariel Dorfman's hit play, with Kingsley the doctor taken hostage by a former torture victim convinced he was her oppressor. Heavyweight talent (Sigourney Weaver, director Roman Polanski) but underwhelming result.

Species (1995) Trashy-but-successful sci-fi thriller, with Kingsley as a boffin on an alien bug hunt, tracking down shape-shifting ET Natasha Henstridge.

Parting Shots (1998) Embarrassing Michael Winner vanity project, with Kingsley joning a gallery of Brit stars as an Italian chef bumped off by gunman Chris Rea.

 Sexy Beast is released on January 12.

webTitle: Amazon announces record sales for December

fields.headline: Amazon posts record sales for December
fields.trailText: 3pm: Online shopping service Amazon.co.uk had its best month ever in December, reports Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
The UK section of online shopping service Amazon had its best month ever in December.

It sold more than 3.3m items, more than double last year's sales.

According to internet ratings company NetValue, at least 15% of all internet users visited Amazon during December.

Amazon had a stellar Christmas in other countries besides the UK and the US, according to Media Metrix, another company that tracks the performance of internet companies.

Amazon ranked as the number one e-commerce site in Australia, Canada, the UK and the US. It pulled in a top five ranking in Brazil, Denmark, France and Japan.

Another top performer was Tesco.com, proving that old world retailing know-how can be transferred successfully to the online marketplace.

The company's grocery delivery service saw the average order price soar above its previous mark of £86 and filled an additional 10,000 delivery slots that had been added for the Christmas rush.

Tesco added an extra 400 staff members to cope with demand.

webTitle: Compromise solution to WH Smith distribution row

fields.headline: Compromise solution to WHS distribution row
fields.standfirst: November 27: Distribution row escalates
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Associated Newspapers says it will renew its £100m contract with WH Smith if it scraps its controversial distribution plans, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Associated Newspapers says it will renew its £100m distribution contract with WH Smith if the company keeps its promise to scrap plans to distribute newspapers exclusively through supermarkets.

The publisher of the Daily Mail and Evening Standard gave six months' notice in November on its contract with WH Smith in protest at the group's plans.

Following last-ditch talks, WH Smith agreed a number of concessions that go some way towards allaying the newspaper group's fears about the effect WH Smith's plans would have on sales in cornershops, particularly in rural areas.

Mike Newman, Associated's circulation director, said: "If WH Smith is in a position to support the industry alternative to its plans Associated Newspapers will back out of its plans to terminate these contracts."

A spokeswoman for WH Smith confirmed that a compromise agreement with publishers would be announced by the end of this week.

However, she denied that WH Smith - which has been bullish about its plans - was backing down in the face of industry pressure.

"We always said that if we could get an agreement which met with the needs of all parties then we would consider abandoning the planned national distribution system," she said,

The spokeswoman added that the compromise solution would reject the so-called Blueprint proposed by magazine publishers' alliance the Periodical Publishers' Association, but would draw some aspects from it.

WH Smith's plans for a national distribution system, originally set up with supermarket Tesco, was met with fury by newspaper and magazine publishers.

Publishers and consumer groups accused the newsagent of "bully boy" tactics after it threatened to stop carrying magazines published by Gruner & Jahr UK if the company refused to go along with its plans. They warned that as many as 12,000 small retailers could close if the plans went ahead.

A PPA spokeswoman refused to comment on the plans, saying only that "discussions are ongoing". Key to the Blueprint proposal was a "central publications unit", providing the arms of the distribution business with accounts and auditing information.

WH Smith said this feature would remain, but would not say who will be responsible for the key function.

webTitle: Arafat's last despairing bid for peace

fields.headline: Arafat's last despairing bid for peace
fields.standfirst:
As the Palestinian leader heads for Washington, Derek Brown examines the limited options for an end to the bloodshed.

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As the Palestinian leader heads for Washington, Derek Brown examines the limited options for an end to the bloodshed.
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is heading for Washington in what seems to be a last despairing bid to revive the Middle East peace process before president Bill Clinton steps down on January 20.

The Oslo peace accord was the first and greatest diplomatic triumph of the Clinton presidency. Now, more than seven years on, it seems to be disintegrating in a welter of blood and harsh rhetoric.

Arafat's spokesman said that the trip was "a decisive visit at which the future of the peace process will be determined".

But the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, who has no immediate plans to follow Arafat to Washington, has accused the Palestinian leader of wasting time, and of not seriously seeking peace.

The Palestinians, backed by Egypt, have asked for urgent clarification of the latest plan put forward by Washington for a final peace settlement.

Israel has already accepted the outline plan, but with serious reservations.

In an ominous further development, Barak - himself a former army chief of staff - has told Israeli military commanders to prepare for a worsening unrest, and possibly even a regional war.

He said today: "There is a greater possibility of a general deterioration, and the general command needs to be ready."

Israel has heaped all the blame for the last three months of bitter clashes on Arafat and the Palestinian leadership, even though, of the 357 people killed so far, just 40 have been Israelis.

Public opinion in Israel has been inflamed by recent bomb explosions and by attacks on Jewish settlements on the West Bank. Polls suggest that Barak is doomed to lose the February 6 direct election for the prime ministership.

His rival, hardline rightwinger Ariel Sharon, has said that he will order the bombing of Palestinian towns to stop the violence.

webTitle: Former publisher Hamlyn revealed as Labour's £2m donor

fields.headline: Former publisher Hamlyn revealed as Labour's £2m donor
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Former book publisher Lord Hamlyn has been revealed as the Labour party's £2m mystery donor, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Former book publisher Lord Hamlyn has been revealed as the mystery donor who gave £2m to the Labour party.

The Labour peer has made millions from the Hamlyn publishing company, which was sold to rivals Reed Elsevier in the 1980s.

"I'm proud to be a long-standing supporter of the Labour party and the Labour governmnent," he said in a statement.

Lord Hamlyn said the £2m gift was "one of several large donations I have made to political and other causes".

"Under existing legislation I am under no obligation to disclose the sum I have donated but I am happy to do so.

"I have said nothing until now because I am overseas recovering from serious illness," he added. Made a life peer in 1998 by Tony Blair, Lord Hamlyn has worked as a director at News International, Heinemann publishers and Reed Elsevier before his recent retirement. He still heads the Paul Hamlyn foundation, which makes donations to the arts and educational causes.

A Labour spokesman said that Lord Hamlyn was listed as a donor who had given more than £5,000 to the party in the past.

The revelation follows pressure on the party to reveal the source of the donation, although new rules that require disclosure will not be implemented until next month.

He still heads the Paul Hamlyn foundation, which makes donations to the arts and educational causes. A Labour spokesman said that Lord Hamlyn was listed as a donor who had given more than £5,000 to the party in the past. The revelation follows pressure on the party to reveal the source of the donation, although new rules that require disclosure will not be implemented until next month.

webTitle: January 2 ratings

fields.headline: TFI Friday bows out with a whimper
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Not even Sir Elton John's TV presenting debut could save the final TFI Friday from flopping in the ratings, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
In the end, not even Sir Elton John's TV presenting debut could save the ratings for TFI Friday, Channel 4's long-running entertainment show.

Channel 4 had already announced it was axing the show after ratings declined and regular presenter Chris Evans had ducked out of hosting the show's final run.

But the station hoped the combination of Sir Elton presenting and the fact that it was TFI's last outing would boost the audience figures for the last show on Friday December 22.

In the event, TFI Friday spluttered out of existence, beaten by virtually everything around it including a repeat of Harry Enfield's Festive Television Programme on BBC2.

True, the show averaged 2.3m in its 9.30pm slot, over a million more than the previous week's TFI, which ran in the programme's usual 6pm Friday night berth.

But that audience is nothing special for 9.30-10.30pm, where the previous week a repeat of two Trigger Happy TV episodes averaged 3m viewers for Channel 4 over 60 minutes.

But Sir Elton can take comfort in the fact that the grand finale was not the biggest celebrity flop.

The December 8 edition, fronted by Donna Air and Fun Lovin' Criminals front man Huey, pulled in just 1m viewers.

Meanwhile on New Year's Day, ITV gave a new twist to its hugely successful Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? quiz show format with a special featuring couples.

Millionaire drew 12m and won a 41% share over 60 minutes from 8pm. In its first half-hour it averaged 10.4m and was beaten by EastEnders, which had 12.3m.

Elsewhere last night, the premiere of movie Waking Ned pulled in 8.7m for ITV from 9pm.

The ITV film beat BBC1's single drama, Gentleman's Relish, starring Billy Connolly and Sarah Lancashire, which still drew a respectable 7.7m.

And new BBC1 drama series 2,000 Acres of Sky, starring Michelle Collins and Paul Kaye, kicked off with 7.2m and one in four viewers from 8.30pm against Millionaire.

Channel 4 scored with a repeat of naff TV marathon The 100 Greatest TV Moments from Hell, which pulled in 3m viewers over three hours from 8.30pm.

Before that Channel 4's film of Antony Sher's turn as Macbeth in the critically acclaimed Royal Shakespeare Company production of the play drew only 0.6m.

webTitle: Salary boost for top scientists

fields.headline: Salary boost for top scientists
fields.trailText: British universities are being invited to bid for a share of a £4m annual fund aimed at attracting the world's top scientists to the UK and keeping them here with salaries potentially in excess of £100,000.
fields.body:
British universities are being invited to bid for a share of a £4m annual fund aimed at attracting the world's top scientists to the UK and keeping them here with salaries potentially in excess of £100,000.

Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, said he wanted "the David Beckhams and Steve Redgraves of the science world" doing research in the UK.

In partnership with the Wolfson Foundation he intends to spend £20m over the next five years in an effort to reverse the brain drain. The awards will be flexible, but will "typically" be £75,000 a year, half to top up the researcher's basic salary and half for research expenses. This will mean some award-holders could enjoy salaries of £100,000 or more. It is estimated that 35 new awards will be made in each of the first two years. The first awards could start as early as April, though many will coincide with the start of the academic year. The scheme is due for review in 2002.

The money should not only attract world class scientists to the UK but nurture researchers at an early stage of their career, said Lord Sainsbury. "The scheme is designed to promote a UK Brain Gain boosting our increasingly knowledge-driven economy. I expect to see the scheme used to make some very high awards and recruit new talent, but the overall emphasis is on flexibility to match individual circumstances." The scheme will be administered by the Royal Society, whose president, Sir Robert May, said: "Britain's universities need to offer competitive salaries and research expenses to attract and retain world class scientists."

Further details about the scheme can be found on the Royal Society web-site at www.royalsoc.ac.uk

The Association of University Teachers gave a qualified welcome to the scheme but said talk of creating a premier league did not stand up. "It does not meet the outstanding needs of research staff or attract new postgraduates into the profession," said spokesman Andrew Pakes.

PhD students on average received £7,000 a year and research staff £18,000, compared to £22,000 for London Underground station staff, he added.

webTitle: Cities cash in on art scene

fields.headline: Cities cash in on art scene
fields.trailText: Inspired by the success of Bilbao's Guggenheim museum, many run-down areas of Britain are using art as a means of attracting investment. David Harding explains
fields.body:
Welcome to Deptford, Britain's answer to the Left Bank. The idea might sound preposterous but this run-down corner of south-east London is trying to reinvent itself.

Part of the capital's docklands' industrial past, with an unemployment rate more than twice the national average, Deptford is desperate for regeneration. The way it has chosen to do that is through art.

In 2002, the Laban Centre, a contemporary dance training institute, will open in the Creekside area. The multi-million pound site will nestle alongside existing art galleries. In the same borough is Goldsmith's College, which counts Damien Hirst among its former pupils.

Local MP Joan Ruddock said Paris's Left Bank is "absolutely the feel" Deptford wants to create. Deptford is not alone. Margate, West Bromwich, Walsall, Gateshead and Salford are just some of those who have chosen similar paths.

Art has become the latest - and most fashionable - weapon to be used by a number of UK towns to aid regeneration. As more and more of us visit museums and galleries, around 68 million people per year, towns are trying to cash in on the "'Bilbao effect". They want to emulate the success of the Basque town since the building of the world-renowned Guggenheim museum there in October 1997, by using artists, galleries and museums as a catalyst to draw in investment and gain an international reputation. The £10m Turner Gallery, named after local artist JMW Turner, will open in Margate in 2003. Chris Chambers, head of regeneration and development at Thanet District Council, sees the gallery as a "main driver" for business in the town. It will need to be -unemployment in parts of Thanet reaches 22%.

In the same year, West Bromwich, the seventh most deprived area in the UK, will unveil the £47m c/PLEX art centre comprising a gallery, public art and business space in an area where there is no arts provision for about 300,000 people.

"People are just dying for this sort of thing to happen," said Heather Peak, marketing co-ordinator with Jubilee Arts, the group overseeing the project. "There's a kind of disbelief that it will happen because there's so little investment in this area." Alsop and Stormer, who recently won awards as well as plaudits for their Peckham Library building, will design the centre.

If West Bromwich needs any inspiration, it need only look down the road to Walsall. There, the £21m New Art Gallery that opened in February, has helped put the town on the map and revitalised the town's fortunes. About 220,000 people have visited the gallery - 80,000 more than predicted - and it is starting to pick up tourists from the Tate Modern.

Art has had a huge impact on regeneration according to nearby businesses that estimate the gallery has added an extra £4,000 to the average day's takings. Because of its success, Walsall is now embarking upon a £23m second-phase regeneration of the town.

Peter Jenkinson, the gallery's director, said people are just beginning to realise the extent to which art can help revitalise as well as change people's perceptions about art.

"We underestimate the power of the arts in the regeneration of our towns and cities. In Walsall, the New Art Gallery has had a profound economic impact from its 220,000 visitors but just as importantly, has transformed the hearts and minds of local people leading to much greater aspirations for the future."

But not everyone is convinced. Tim Schadla-Hall, a reader in public archaeology at University College London, says he is "naturally suspicious" that art is a catalyst for regeneration.

"I find it difficult to believe that modern art works in terms of regeneration. I think there is a lack of hard, statistical evidence," he says.

Certainly, Walsall's anecdotal evidence is the only one forthcoming. Most of the projects are, at the moment, relying on the passionate optimism of those involved.

Most of the schemes receive funding from the Lottery and Schadla-Hall points to Sheffield's ill-fated National Centre for Popular Music, now in the hands of receivers, as an example that the best intentions, and money from the Lottery may not always work. But many remain undeterred.

Salford is to open the £28.5m Imperial War Museum North in 2002, opposite the now established Lowry. Gateshead is to get its very £60m Music Centre, designed by Foster and Partners, in the same year.

The Bilbao trail looks far from going cold. Several towns believe the best way to regenerate is through art. Time will tell if they join Walsall or Sheffield in redeveloping their town's fortunes.

webTitle: TalkSport revamps programme line-up

fields.headline: TalkSport revamps programme line-up
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: TalkSport has undergone a programming reshuffle less than a year after the radio station reinvented itself from the ashes of Talk Radio, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
TalkSport has undergone a programming reshuffle less than a year after the radio station reinvented itself as a sports station from the ashes of Talk Radio.

Tom Watt's drivetime slot is being replaced on four days a week by Paul Hawksbee and Andy Jacobs, who move from the Thursday Night Kickabout slot.

Station bosses believe that Mr Hawksbee, who founded football magazine 90 Minutes, and Mr Jacobs, a former editor of FHM, have a broader appeal to listeners than Mr Watt, who has an "encyclopaedic" knowledge of football but less broader sports knowledge.

Mr Watt will continue to present the drivetime show on Friday.

Meanwhile Mike Parry, a Talk Radio veteran and former print journalist, joins Alan Brazil on the breakfast show, and is also promoted to programme director of TalkSport.

Mr Parry, a former colleague of Kelvin MacKenzie, boss of TalkSport owner Wireless Group, joined Talk Radio in 1998 and parted company with the station after just a few weeks, but was invited back to help spearhead the station's relaunch.

A spokesman said that the changes represented a fine-tuning of the station's scheduling, rather than a "revolution".

But the radio station has made a number of dramatic changes to its programming over the past two years.

Just before the rebranding Mr MacKenzie axed the Big Boys Breakfast duo of former colleagues David Banks and Nick Ferrari.

The spokesman denied that the changes represented a loss of confidence in TalkSport's format.

He said: "We had a successful station before the rebranding, but advertisers wanted to reach their targets more easily."

TalkSport posted a small increase in its audience figures at the last Rajar audience figures, to 2.053m listeners, reversing a decline that left the station with a 17% decline at the end of 1999.

webTitle: A brilliant mistake

fields.headline: A brilliant mistake
fields.standfirst: Twelve years ago,  Liz Campbell was 18 and pregnant, and so enraged by attitudes towards her that she wrote a piece for this paper about teenage motherhood. Here she looks back at what happened after she made a brilliant mistake.
fields.trailText: Twelve years ago, Liz Campbell was 18 and pregnant, and so enraged by attitudes towards her that she wrote a piece for this paper about teenage motherhood. Here she looks back at what happened after she made a brilliant mistake
fields.body:
Twelve years ago, I was at secondary school. I was also pregnant with my first child. The most shocking consequence of the pregnancy test had not been the impending baby (which I accepted with that trademark teenage mixture of boundless optimism and bravado), but my instant descent to an underclass about which everyone seemed to reserve the right to be rude and scornful.

I borrowed a typewriter and vented my fury in an article published in the Guardian. Here's a taster: "I have found the attitudes of many members of the medical profession presumptuous and patronising . . . I am determined to prove that teenage parents are not social problems, vegetating on bleak council estates, but capable of achieving the same goals as others."

I grew up in a single-parent family in the days when it was unusual (at least in Norfolk) and John Craven still talked gravely on Newsround about "broken homes". Mum struggled to provide for my sister and me, working evenings in pubs while she studied for a degree. She assumed we had learned from her mistakes and was horrified that I might even contemplate not terminating my pregnancy. Eviction from the family home followed swiftly.

I was referred to a social worker who was also pregnant (but in a strange parallel universe where everyone could afford maternity clothes and people said "Congratulations" rather than "God, what are you going to do?"). I assumed she would offer practical help (housing, money for baby equipment, childcare support so I could finish my education). In reality, there was little other than an archaic mother and baby home run by the Catholic church and a care system predicated on the assumption that no one got any qualifications anyway. When she tried to find common ground between us ("Isn't morning sickness the pits?"), I found it hard to contain my anger. Eventually my boyfriend's parents took pity on me.

I considered myself quite ordinary (we lived in a small terrace house and I went to the local comprehensive) but much of my pregnancy was spent waiting in long queues (at the housing office, at the DSS, at social services) with people who suddenly made me feel obscenely well-educated, healthy and privileged. I never realised so many people were living lives so devoid of opportunity. The thought that I would be joining them was terrifying.

Following the birth of my son Joshua, I was allocated a grim council flat on a desolate estate apparently reserved for teenage mothers and ex-psychiatric patients. I saw desperately poor teenage women struggling to provide basic care for their children against substantial odds, in an environment in which carpets and washing machines were luxury items.

I was deemed "fortunate" (and I was compared with the other people queuing at the DSS), but this limited my entitlement to help. Finishing my education seemed a sensible route out of the benefits system, but social services did not provide care for children not categorised as "at risk". To qualify, I needed to prove I was about to neglect my son, put him into care or be admitted to a psychiatric unit - all of which began to look increasingly possible as I contemplated spending my life trying to make ends meet on the estate.

So I lived with Josh's father (a teenage undergraduate) in his poky university rooms, because at least I was surrounded by people whose lives were filled with opportunity and hope. Nevertheless, motherhood came as a tremendous shock and I was miserable and isolated.

I started my degree when Josh was a toddler and, almost inevitably, I separated from his father. Unusually (for teenage fathers), he remains actively and positively involved.

Essex University was a fantastic place to be a teenage mother. There was a campus nursery, I lived in a shared house with lots of babysitters and I had a ball, despite making some embarrassing mistakes. Universities are full of rich kids writing glib essays about "structural inequalities" and as a sociology student, I wrote my dissertation on teenage motherhood, confident that at least I was prepared for the humility of the powerless working-class women I interviewed. I wasn't - and I reluctantly recognised that my impending graduation proved nothing about schoolgirl mothers.

Teenage motherhood is linked to poverty and low educational achievement (middle-class girls have more reasons not to get pregnant and those who do overwhelmingly choose abortion). The vast majority of the women I spoke to were from families who already lived in poverty on "sink" estates. Their lives were characterised by educational failure and some had spent time in care. They hoped for the best ("I'd like us to get a nice house - when my boyfriend gets a job"), but expected the worst ("Well, they usually leave you, don't they?").

I found little evidence that they would have been any better off had they delayed motherhood into their 20s. If their children fared badly at school and drifted into delinquency, they were simply taking their places in a cycle of deprivation that owed a great deal to the failure of our social care system and little to maternal age or moral laxity. Our shared experience of being teenage mothers did not magically dissolve the inequalities between us. My attempts to form a sisterhood ("Yes, I remember when I had mould up the walls") were met with the same derision I had shown the social worker four years earlier.

I argued that patriarchy seeks to control women by dictating the circumstances in which it is desirable to reproduce. Deprived working-class boys can indulge in the sort of laddish resistance to dominant morality that is celebrated by Guy Ritchie et al. Working-class women have fewer role models and for them, reproduction can be (or appear to be) a way of acting in the world and changing your life.

Teenagers experiment and take risks. If teenage fathers emerge from irresponsible sex relatively unscathed, they have male peers disabled by a range of reckless behaviours in which stupid driving features prominently. Their treatment and rehabilitation costs thousands. Generally they are pitied, rather than castigated, by Tory politicians and the tabloid press.

By contrast, student politics was kind to teenage mothers in the early 90s. The NUS had (belatedly) woken up to the discrimination faced by sections of its population and suddenly, if you wanted to get ahead in student politics, you needed an oppression. I never had to say more than: "Speaking as a teenage mother" to prompt a standing ovation. Getting my tokens out for the lads became a way of life. So what if the macho politicos who occupied the lecture theatres in support of a campus nursery were ignorant of the realities of teenage motherhood?

Childcare began to be taken seriously and I became sabbatical vice-president of the Students Union. My election night celebrations included the sort of spontaneity that results in morning sickness, but by then I'd convinced myself I was invincible. I survived on a week's maternity leave following the birth of Hannah, but I was too exhausted to fight any more. It was time to move on.

Subsequently, I followed a typical graduate trajectory. I trained as an English teacher and married a local government officer. We got a mortgage and had a third child. Occasionally, when colleagues were berating female pupils for squandering our taxes on their wanton reproduction, I'd "out" myself as a schoolgirl mother. The sudden staffroom silence would be broken by: "Oh, but you're different; at least your kids have the same father."

"Well, um, actually . . . " And there would be a frantic scramble to find ways to separate me (someone similar to themselves) from the seething amoral hordes on the local estates.

As a student, I was taught that "deviants" become so defined by their label that normal "non-deviant" life is impossible. It is probably the only way to explain my decision to become a Labour councillor. Looking across the rows of balding heads at my first meeting, I saw what an oddity I was (less than a fifth of our councillors are women and I'm 20 years younger than all of them). In a world dominated by old men who live their politics, my lack of a long-suffering wife has turned a morning spent doing the playgroup shift and mopping the kitchen floor into something verging on subversive.

When JK Rowling spoke in support of single mothers, Nigella Lawson applauded her, noting that "feckless teenage mothers" accounted for only 3% of single parents (phew!). Substitute the words "teenage mothers" with "asylum seekers" or "travellers" and you begin to hear the complaints of a disgruntled minority convinced they've been denied their fair share of life's rewards (from council housing to the moral high ground) and are trying to apportion blame.

This scapegoating of society's most disadvantaged has not lessened in the years since I wrote my original article. Back then I yearned for a public arena in which to challenge these attitudes. Now that I've found one, I'm relying on my son (my brilliant mistake) to nudge me if I get complacent.

Finishing my education seemed a sensible route out of the benefits system, but social services did not provide care for children not categorised as "at risk". To qualify, I needed to prove I was about to neglect my son, put him into care or be admitted to a psychiatric unit - all of which began to look increasingly possible as I contemplated spending my life trying to make ends meet on the estate. So I lived with Josh's father (a teenage undergraduate) in his poky university rooms, because at least I was surrounded by people whose lives were filled with opportunity and hope. Nevertheless, motherhood came as a tremendous shock and I was miserable and isolated. I started my degree when Josh was a toddler and, almost inevitably, I separated from his father. Unusually (for teenage fathers), he remains actively and positively involved. Essex University was a fantastic place to be a teenage mother. There was a campus nursery, I lived in a shared house with lots of babysitters and I had a ball, despite making some embarrassing mistakes. Universities are full of rich kids writing glib essays about "structural inequalities" and as a sociology student, I wrote my dissertation on teenage motherhood, confident that at least I was prepared for the humility of the powerless working-class women I interviewed. I wasn't - and I reluctantly recognised that my impending graduation proved nothing about schoolgirl mothers. Teenage motherhood is linked to poverty and low educational achievement (middle-class girls have more reasons not to get pregnant and those who do overwhelmingly choose abortion). The vast majority of the women I spoke to were from families who already lived in poverty on "sink" estates. Their lives were characterised by educational failure and some had spent time in care. They hoped for the best ("I'd like us to get a nice house - when my boyfriend gets a job"), but expected the worst ("Well, they usually leave you, don't they?"). I found little evidence that they would have been any better off had they delayed motherhood into their 20s. If their children fared badly at school and drifted into delinquency, they were simply taking their places in a cycle of deprivation that owed a great deal to the failure of our social care system and little to maternal age or moral laxity. Our shared experience of being teenage mothers did not magically dissolve the inequalities between us. My attempts to form a sisterhood ("Yes, I remember when I had mould up the walls") were met with the same derision I had shown the social worker four years earlier. I argued that patriarchy seeks to control women by dictating the circumstances in which it is desirable to reproduce. Deprived working-class boys can indulge in the sort of laddish resistance to dominant morality that is celebrated by Guy Ritchie et al. Working-class women have fewer role models and for them, reproduction can be (or appear to be) a way of acting in the world and changing your life. Teenagers experiment and take risks. If teenage fathers emerge from irresponsible sex relatively unscathed, they have male peers disabled by a range of reckless behaviours in which stupid driving features prominently. Their treatment and rehabilitation costs thousands. Generally they are pitied, rather than castigated, by Tory politicians and the tabloid press. By contrast, student politics was kind to teenage mothers in the early 90s. The NUS had (belatedly) woken up to the discrimination faced by sections of its population and suddenly, if you wanted to get ahead in student politics, you needed an oppression. I never had to say more than: "Speaking as a teenage mother" to prompt a standing ovation. Getting my tokens out for the lads became a way of life. So what if the macho politicos who occupied the lecture theatres in support of a campus nursery were ignorant of the realities of teenage motherhood? Childcare began to be taken seriously and I became sabbatical vice-president of the Students Union. My election night celebrations included the sort of spontaneity that results in morning sickness, but by then I'd convinced myself I was invincible. I survived on a week's maternity leave following the birth of Hannah, but I was too exhausted to fight any more. It was time to move on. Subsequently, I followed a typical graduate trajectory. I trained as an English teacher and married a local government officer. We got a mortgage and had a third child. Occasionally, when colleagues were berating female pupils for squandering our taxes on their wanton reproduction, I'd "out" myself as a schoolgirl mother. The sudden staffroom silence would be broken by: "Oh, but you're different; at least your kids have the same father." "Well, um, actually . . . " And there would be a frantic scramble to find ways to separate me (someone similar to themselves) from the seething amoral hordes on the local estates. As a student, I was taught that "deviants" become so defined by their label that normal "non-deviant" life is impossible. It is probably the only way to explain my decision to become a Labour councillor. Looking across the rows of balding heads at my first meeting, I saw what an oddity I was (less than a fifth of our councillors are women and I'm 20 years younger than all of them). In a world dominated by old men who live their politics, my lack of a long-suffering wife has turned a morning spent doing the playgroup shift and mopping the kitchen floor into something verging on subversive. When JK Rowling spoke in support of single mothers, Nigella Lawson applauded her, noting that "feckless teenage mothers" accounted for only 3% of single parents (phew!). Substitute the words "teenage mothers" with "asylum seekers" or "travellers" and you begin to hear the complaints of a disgruntled minority convinced they've been denied their fair share of life's rewards (from council housing to the moral high ground) and are trying to apportion blame. This scapegoating of society's most disadvantaged has not lessened in the years since I wrote my original article. Back then I yearned for a public arena in which to challenge these attitudes. Now that I've found one, I'm relying on my son (my brilliant mistake) to nudge me if I get complacent.

webTitle: Daily Star poaches Sun's top football writer

fields.headline: Daily Star nets Sun's top football writer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
1pm: Sun soccer writer Brian Woolnough has been poached by the Daily Star as Richard Desmond squares up for a circulation war, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The Sun's star football writer, Brian Woolnough, has been poached by the Daily Star in a deal believed to be worth at least £140,000.

Neither the Sun nor the Daily Star would confirm his appointment, but a source close to negotiations said that Mr Woolnough has signed a deal with Northern & Shell, which owns the Star, to become the paper's chief sports writer.

A veteran Sun journalist, Mr Woolnough also presents the Sky Sports weekly football programme, Hold the Back Page, and has written books about the sport.

He has been at the Sun for more than 25 years and is believed to have upped his salary by some £40,000 in the new deal.

Two years ago the Mirror tried to poach Mr Woolnough but he was persuaded to stay put after News International offered him a stint on Sky TV.

The signing represents a coup for Daily Star owner Richard Desmond, who has made clear his intention to pitch the Star aggressively against the Sun.

It is also a reflection of his commitment to the Star, which has been promised more staff from the day Mr Desmond took over.

By contrast staff at the Daily Express have been battling against a relentless stream of cutbacks.

Mr Woolnough's departure will leave a gaping hole at the Sun and all eyes will now be on the paper to see who will replace him.

webTitle: January 1 ratings

fields.headline: BBC wins New Year battle
fields.trailText: 11.30am TV overnights: The BBC won the New Year's Eve ratings battle after ITV effectively bowed out of the fight, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC won the midnight ratings battle on New Year's Eve after ITV effectively bowed out of the annual fight with a repeat of an Andrew Lloyd Webber documentary.

Dale Winton delivered 7m viewers to BBC1 for the start of 2001 as presenter of The National Lottery New Year's Stars, the equivalent of a 47% audience share according to unofficial overnights.

Before that Goodbye 2000, a humorous look at the year presented by Angus Deayton, pulled in 6.6m and a 42% audience share on BBC1 from 10.45-11.45pm.

But ITV effectively shut up shop for the final 45 minutes of the year, offering up a repeat of The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber from 11.15pm.

The celebrity-filled musical tribute, filmed at the Royal Albert Hall to mark the composer's 50th birthday, got an audience of just 3.5m.

On BBC2, Jools at the New Year Hootenanny pulled in 1.5m viewers and an 11% share of the audience from 11.55pm-1am.

Channel 5 snuck into the new year just ahead of Channel 4. Karaoke show Night Fever got 1.1m on Channel 5 from 11.05pm-1am; while Channel 4's repeated History of the Pop Video took 1m over the same period.

ITV was number one in the peak-time battle.

Stars and Their Lives won a 9.3m audience, Coronation Street took 11.8m and an Inspector Morse repeat got 5.5m from 8.30pm.

On BBC1, a repeat of David Copperfield ran in two parts either side of EastEnders from 6.45-10.20pm.

The first half averaged 4.3m while the second took 4.8m. EastEnders pulled in 9.1m from 8pm.

Overall, ITV had 35.2% of the peak-time (6-10.30pm) audience, while BBC1 had 27.3%.

webTitle: Murders in Burundi 'war crimes' says dead aid worker's family

fields.headline: Murders in Burundi 'war crimes' says dead aid worker's family
fields.trailText: Relatives of the British aid worker killed in Burundi last week have written to the Guardian calling for the murder to be treated as a war crime.
fields.body:
Relatives of the British aid worker killed in Burundi last week have written to the Guardian calling for the murder to be treated as a war crime.

Charlotte Wilson, 27, who was working as a teacher in Rwanda for Voluntary Service Overseas, was one of 20 or more people who died when a gang ambushed their bus as it travelled to the Burundian capital, Bujumbur. Her Burundian fiance was also killed.

Her mother Margot, sister Catherine and brother Richard have called for a full investigation into the murders in their letter.

"Nineteen other living, breathing human beings were also murdered in this premeditated mass-killing of innocent civilians," they wrote.

"Such an action has the same degree of moral abhorrence whether it occurs in Burundi, Bosnia, Rwanda or any other part of the world.

"This should be considered as a war crime and investigated as such, not dismissed as insolvable simply because it occurred in an African country."

Recalling Ms Wilson as "brilliant, vibrant and inspirational", they added: "It is important that the work she was involved in should continue. The international community must support continuing Rwandan efforts towards reconciliation after the genocide.

"Rwanda must be given help in rebuilding its infrastructure."

The VSO is unclear why Ms Wilson, who was regarded as cautious and responsible, was travelling to Burundi by road despite warnings that this was unsafe.

Hutu rebels, under pressure to sign a peace agreement with the Tutsi-led army and government, have increased attacks on civilians. But the rebels who mounted the bus attack may have been motivated primarily by banditry.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman last night expressed sympathy for Ms Wilson's family, but said that the government would need to consider carefully before backing their calls for the case to be considered as a war crime as this was a specific legal term.

She said: "We take this very seriously and have condemned outright the rebel attack on innocent citizens, but this is obviously a complex legal matter."

Full text of letter

In memory of Charlotte

webTitle: Prescott loses grip on Whitehall empire

fields.headline: Prescott loses grip on Whitehall empire
fields.standfirst:
More about transport
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: John Prescott is losing control of transport policy to his deputy, Gus MacDonald, and under the strain of this power struggle their sprawling ministry is said to be effectively breaking up.
fields.body:
John Prescott is losing control of transport policy to his deputy, Gus MacDonald, and under the strain of this power struggle their sprawling ministry is said to be effectively breaking up.

Senior officials in the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions claim that the rivalry between the two politicians has triggered increasingly bitter battles between the environment and transport wings of the merged body.

Mr Prescott and Lord MacDonald of Tradeston have clashed over road, rail and air issues during recent months. A key Westminster figure close to both maintains that the Labour peer is winning against the deputy prime minister. Tony Blair appointed Lord MacDonald late last year to revitalise transport after the Conservatives identified it as one of Labour's weak points. The DETR was also considered too big for Mr Prescott to manage.

"Gus is obviously in a difficult position," said a Labour MP. "He's got to be loyal to his boss and he's got to also do it for Blair and [Chancellor Gordon] Brown for that matter. Gus sees himself as the managing director transport, Prezza as the department's chief executive and Blair as the chairman. It is obvious that Gus has taken more and more of a role."

The conflict came to a head when the environment side of the ministry was misled about the extent of a road building programme unveiled shortly before Christmas by Lord MacDonald. The u-turn on policy by the government entailed more than 70 road bypasses.

The plan was championed in the department by Lord MacDonald, minister of state for transport, despite reservations by Mr Prescott. Michael Meacher, the department's minister of state for the enviroment, complained he was not properly consulted.

Lord MacDonald also took charge of the government's controversial plan to privatise air traffic control. Mr Prescott was said by an adviser to have been furious at not being consulted before his deputy negotiated a deal with the Conservatives on this issue, involving what was presented as a three-month delay, to get the sale through the House of Lords.

And the peer is resisting pressure from Mr Prescott to "come down heavy" on the rail companies, arguing the government should work with rather than against the operators to get them to run decent train services as demanded by passengers.

The tussle has prompted concern in and out of government among supporters of the merged DETR - created by the marriage of the old environment and transport ministries - that the potential benefits of policy coordination are being lost.

As well as transport, Mr Prescott's department is responsible for many other things, from local authorities and regional development to water and the wider environment, including global warming. But it is transport that is Mr Prescott's specialist subject and the former seafarer - who made his mark in opposition during the late 1980s and early 1990s after the Clapham, Lockerbie and Marchioness disasters - jealously guarded it during his early years in government.

Lord MacDonald's links with Downing Street, however, make him more powerful than the three previous transport deputies Mr Prescott had in 30 months - Gavin Strang, John Reid and Helen Liddell.

Mr Prescott persuaded the prime minister to remove the transport post from the cabinet in Labour's first reshuffle but Lord MacDonald is a cabinet member in all but salary, attending and speaking at the Thursday morning meetings.

Mr Prescott is now thought to believe he made a mistake taking the reins of the complex DETR rather than acting as a Cabinet Office enforcer. He is widely expected to give up the department after the election.

Parts of the DETR may be hived off, possibly to a new social inclusion department with regional development agencies passing to trade and industry. But Mr Blair has shown no signs of wanting to split environment from transport.

webTitle: Clergy want employee status

fields.headline: Clergy want employee status
fields.trailText: Church of England clergy may petition the government to alter their legal status to establish that they are employed by man not God, and protect them from unfair dismissal by bishops.
fields.body:
Church of England clergy may petition the government to alter their legal status to establish that they are employed by man not God, and protect them from unfair dismissal by bishops.

The move is under consideration by MSF, the professional union which represents about 10% of Anglican vicars, together with some Roman Catholic priests, as part of a claim for pay rises of up to 50%.

The notion that vicars are not employees of the Church of England, but of God, has been used to defend their lack of employment rights.

The Rev Bill Ward, executive committee member for MSF's clergy and church workers' section, said: "We can be summarily dismissed, and there is no legal protection. We may have a vocation, but so do many other groups like doctors and nurses and they are classed as employees. The government could change this by declaring us employees too and change the law through an order in council."

Clergy are paid stipends that are considered to be allowances rather than salaries, and they do not have negotiating rights.

The union is making representations to the clergy stipends review group of the archbishops' council, the executive body of the Church of England, for an improvement in pay and conditions.

The group is expected to report soon; any settlement would apply only to Anglican clerics, but other denominations may follow suit.

The union argues that clergy, paid an average of £16,420, should obtain comparability with social workers and senior teachers, or at least with cathedral residentiary canons, who receive about £5,000 more.

To rank with senior classroom teachers, clergy would need to receive about £25,000 a year.

The church argues that many clergy receive free lodging, and that it cannot afford such an increase.

webTitle: Labour faces rebellion on home sale packs

fields.headline: Labour faces rebellion on home sale packs
fields.trailText: The government faces a backbench revolt on the first day of the new parliamentary term next week when Labour MPs protest against plans to require people selling their homes to obtain a "seller's pack" which could cost between £300 and £400 to produce.
fields.body:
The government faces a backbench revolt on the first day of the new parliamentary term next week when Labour MPs protest against plans to require people selling their homes to obtain a "seller's pack" which could cost between £300 and £400 to produce.

MPs with constituencies in areas of economic and social decline - including the midlands and the north of England - fear that the idea will alienate voters who are struggling to find buyers for properties worth only £10,000 or less, often burdened with negative equity.

"This legislation was drawn up by civil servants who commute to London from Sevenoaks," one MP said. "Unless it is improved it will backfire in predominantly Labour areas."

The purpose behind such a pack is to help both buyers and sellers to speed up the process and prevent gazumping. Faster surveys and searches - provided in the pack - would result in quicker negotiations and completions.

Gazumping is again common in the booming south-east of England, but inconceivable in poorer areas - where some homes in decayed terraces have been on sale for years - beset by job losses, drugs and vandalism.

Many of these homes were bought from local councils or the old national coal board at discount prices in the Thatcher era. Then their new owners saw values slide as communities declined.

The issue was raised at the last pre-Christmas meeting of the parliamentary Labour party, too late to alert many MPs who will be asked to vote on the second reading of the homes bill next Monday, the day they return to the Commons.

The bill, delayed from last year, contains two distinct halves, one to restore the duty on local authorities to tackle homelessness, the other to help the housing market by speeding sales.

Ministers in John Prescott's environment department believe that they must also devise strategies to regenerate neighbourhoods hit by decay. They want to tackle unemployment and crime as well as housing problems.

MPs involved in the coalfield communities campaign, like Mick Clapham, MP for Barnsley West and Penistone, and Llin Golding, MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme, are said to be concerned - as is Bolsover's Dennis Skinner - that vendors will not want to spend £300 on a seller's pack when they have little hope of getting the money back by selling at a price that includes it.

Another potential rebel, Joe Ashton, MP for the old mining constituency of Bassetlaw, on the Notts-South Yorkshire border, argues that the solution will be to amend the homes bill to exempt houses in council tax band A, worth below £50,000. He said yesterday that Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, was sympathetic to the suggestion.

webTitle: DotComGuy returns to the real world

fields.headline: DotComGuy returns to the real world
fields.trailText: 11.15am:The new year brought to an end one of the more bizarre internet experiments - the self-imposed isolation of DotComGuy, reports Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
The final hours of 2000 brought to a close one of the more bizarre internet experiments - the self-imposed isolation of DotComGuy, a US computer programmer who spent the entire year living off the internet.

Supported by corporate sponsors flush with the then-plentiful dot.com cash, Mitch Maddox changed his name legally to DotComGuy before settling in for a year of delivered groceries, chatroom social contact and webcams recording and broadcasting his every move.

Dismissed by many as the most absurd stunt in a year awash with publicity stunts, DotComGuy nevertheless managed to attract a number of corporate sponsors, including NetB@nk, PhoneFree.com, Network Solutions and Peapod, the online grocer.

Mr Maddox intends to revert back to his given name now that the stunt is over, and will marry a woman he met in an online chat session from his website, DotComGuy.com.

Paying for the honeymoon may prove difficult, however. Several gossip sites report that Mr Maddox's sponsors haven't come up with the $100,000 he was supposed to collect upon successful completion of the stunt.

Mr Maddox's spokeswoman was not available for comment.

webTitle: French steal march on Lara Croft

fields.headline: French steal march on Lara Croft
fields.standfirst:
Parisian studio lays claim to most realistic virtual star

Net news
fields.trailText: Parisian studio lays claim to most realistic virtual star.
fields.body:
A long time ago, God created Eve. Now the French have made their own version. The new Eve likes cats, Gandhi and the footballer Zinedine Zidane. She is 162cm (5ft 4in) tall and wants to be a film star. The only problem is, she isn't real.

Eve Solal is being touted in France as the most realistic virtual star yet, capable of expressing human emotions and charming those who see her.

Her makers, Attitude Studio of Paris, claim she has a much more expressive face and mobile body than predecessors such as the virtual newsreader Ananova or Lara Croft, star of the video game Tomb Raider.

Since Christmas, Eve has had her own website but she will be officially launched in France next month with great media hoopla, including radio interviews, a five-page women's magazine feature and internet appearances.

"Soon Eve will appear in a feature film or take on the role of a presenter on an internet site or television," said Marc Viance, 24, head of Attitude Studio.

Her (real) agent, Jacques Olivier Broner of the Rouge agency in Paris, is looking for work in films, TV or video games for his client.

But Attitude Studio bosses do not want their creation to appear in a fully computer-animated film like Toy Story; rather, they want her to star opposite flesh-and-blood human actors.

But why is Eve better than her predecessors? "Ananova only exists on the internet, she's cut off at the shoulders and she has only two expressions," Mr Viance said. "And as for Lara Croft, she only appears in action situations, and she does not have much in the way of facial expressions."

Attitude Studio has used "motion capture" technology to make Eve. Cameras film the movements of an actor from different angles and these are mapped on to the virtual star using sophisticated software.

The couturier Thierry Mugler used similar technology to create a virtual mannequin to show off his spring collection last year.

To make Eve's facial expressions convincingly human, a software package called Emotion Mapper was used, which involves filtering video images of each muscle movement of a real face through computer programmes and then grafting them on to Eve's face.

Emotion Mapper is particularly easy to use when an actor is replaced in certain scenes by a virtual stunt double.

In the film The Matrix, for example, several scenes used a virtual Keanu Reeves constructed with Emotion Mapper and"motion capture" technology. Eve Solal goes one step further in that she is based not on one single human prototype, but on several.

Eve costs 2,000F (£190) a minute to produce, which gives her a competitive edge over many real movie stars.

She is the latest virtual nubile female star created by men. The first such icon, Kyoto Date, 16, was launched in Japan in 1996. Able to sing and dance, this creation briefly captivated young Japanese people and her single, Love Communication, reached the top of the Japanese charts.

Like Kyoto Date, Eve has a biography and a list of likes and dislikes. She was born on May 3 1978 just outside Paris. She weighs 48kg (7st 7lb). Her father, is a doctor and her mother is a housewife.

She exchanged her first kisses with Damien, her first love was Frederic and she has had sexual experiences, but no further details are provided.

She lives in the fashionable Parisian clubbing street of Rue de Lappe and works as a waitress. Her favourite film is LA Confidential and she likes ginger.

At present, the only way of getting in touch with Eve is by calling her on her mobile phone. "Hi," the caller is told. "This is Eve's answering machine. Leave me a message and I'll get back to you."

After leaving several messages, however, I am still waiting for a call.

Eve Solal website
News service with virtual newscaster Ananova
