webTitle: Ad watchdogs to investigate lesbian kiss poster ads

fields.headline: Ad watchdogs to investigate lesbian kiss poster ads
fields.standfirst: Dec 28: lesbian embrace breaks ad taboo
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Advertising watchdogs are to investigate the controversial lesbian poster campaign by Queercompany, reports Dan Milmo.
Dec 28: lesbian embrace breaks ad taboo
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority has launched an investigation into the controversial lesbian poster campaign by internet firm Queercompany.

Ten complaints have been received about the advert, which shows two women kissing on a bed.

"We are introducing a preliminary investigation, which we do after we receive any complaint. We will be approaching the advertisers," said an ASA spokeswoman.

However, the spokeswoman added that the reaction paled in comparison to the uproar that greeted the Opium advertising campaign featuring naked model Sophie Dahl, which was withdrawn following 730 complaints.

A spokesman for Queercompany, which offers online financial products and services to the gay and lesbian market, brushed off the news, saying it was a "very low" number of complaints.

"It is very sad that people should complain about a very tender, romantic image which is not pornographic like the Sophie Dahl campaign," he said.

"But the ASA has rejected complaints against our adverts in the past and we expect the same reaction this time."

The spokesman added that the company has received over 140 emails supporting the poster, and that the police have requested copies for their sensitivity and diversity training programmes.

"People are saying they love the poster and are asking where they can get hold of copies. Obviously it is making a real difference," he added.

Queercompany is bracing itself for further controversy when the male version of the poster is launched in the middle of this month.

Anti-Corp is the advertising agency behind the campaign, after Queercompany split from previous agency St Luke's in September last year.

The ASA has been closely monitoring the Queercompany adverts, which include an image of two men embracing next to the words, "Thank God for Men".

webTitle: Obituary: Julius Epstein

fields.headline: Julius Epstein
fields.standfirst: Prolific screenwriter whose coolness towards Casablanca belied its cult success
fields.trailText: Prolific screenwriter whose coolness towards Casablanca belied its cult success.
fields.body:
The romance of the film Casablanca transcends the cult which has built up around it. Yet never has that 1943 Oscar-winning masterpiece been so misunderstood as by its screeenwriter, Julius Epstein, who has died aged 91. It was, he observed, "slick shit". As for the cult, he once suggested it had only been the death of Humphrey Bogart in 1955 that created it.

Routinely assigned to Casablanca by Warner Brothers in 1942, Epstein and his twin brother, Philip, never expected it to shake free of its chaotic creation. Not only was their work in transforming a ropey, unpublished play, Everybody Comes To Rick's, given a political twist by a third screenwriter, Howard Koch, but changes were demanded from day to day, not least for the ending. Such uncertainty was of a piece with its seemingly haphazard casting - at one point Ronald Reagan was a candidate for the role of Rick.

There is no greater symptom of the film's triumphant muddle than the fact that Dooley Wilson, who plays the theme, As Time Goes By, was a drummer; his piano-playing was dubbed by other fingers. "We were not making art," said Epstein. "We were making a living."

Between 1934 and 1984, Epstein worked on more than 50 films. His life was a classic rise from obscurity, with hard slog bringing a lucky break. He and his brother were born on New York's lower east side where, as schoolboys, they cleaned out their father's livery stables each day. Despite this and a penchant for boxing - both ran teams at Penn State University - Julius developed a taste for restoration comedy and Molière.

Broadway was his goal; the writing of press releases, a stop-gap. Such work threw up a radio columnist, Jerry Wald, who duly bluffed his way into Hollywood and was hard put to write screenplays. He summoned Julius from New York and gave him $25 a week to ghostwrite. This yielded Twenty Million Sweethearts (1934) for Dick Powell and Ginger Rogers. Epstein continued such ghosting, then, in 1935, came up with his own elegant flying drama, Living On Velvet. A contract with Warners was his, leaving Wald to call on the services of Philip Epstein, who, with his brother, had written a play which was performed in New York.

In 1938, Four Daughters got Epstein his first Oscar nomination. Meanwhile, the brothers' collaboration galvanised Philip's talent for screwball comedy, and in 1938 he wrote The Mad Miss Manton. To write of one is to write of the other, such was their bond. If The Bride Came C.O.D. (1941) now seems forced, the same can hardly be said of their 1942 versions of The Man Who Came to Dinner and The Male Animal. One of their finest adaptations was of Arsenic And Old Lace (1944) for Frank Capra, with whom they had a brief wartime propaganda stint in Washington.

They could be relied upon to give new life to scripts which a star found lacking. James Cagney insisted upon them being brought in to work on Yankee Doodle Dandy (1942), to exhilarating effect.

They were keen practical jokers. A high farce could be made about the production of Casablanca. Executive producer Jack Warner complained, for example, that the brothers were not in at nine - "Get in at nine; even bank presidents get in at nine." They responded by sending him part of a script with the note, "have the bank president finish the script". When Warner complained that one scene was the worst in motion-picture history, Epstein said: "How is that possible? It was written at nine o'clock."

To one scene in Casablanca, Koch added Humprey Bogart's line, "I don't buy or sell human beings." A worthy sentiment, but when it came back to the Epsteins, they gave it true life in Sydney Greenstreet's reply, "That's too bad. That's Casablanca's leading commodity."

Such was the brothers' closeness that, when driving across Sunset Boulevard and Beverly Glen, Claude Rains's line, "Round up the usual suspects", came to them simultaneously. "Whenever I drive past the spot, I raise my hand in salute," recalled Julius.

With this success, the brothers began to produce at Warners. Alas, Mr Skeffington (1946), with Bette Davis and Claude Rains, is more serviceable than inspired, as was their pleasant Doris Day vehicle, Romance On The High Seas (1948).

A move to Paramount and an adaptation of JM Barrie's Forever Female (1953) had them location-hunting in a wood when Philip got poison oak badly, for which he was prescribed liquid cortisone by the bottleful. His family believes this triggered a cancer which killed him in 1952.

Julius was devastated. He continued writing but, despite such successes as The Tender Trap (1955) and Fanny (1961), it was not until 1972 that his spirit met its match in a novella by that brilliant, underrated novelist Peter De Vries - the Oscar-nominated Pete 'n' Tillie, with Walter Matthau and Carol Burnett. In 1977, he collaborated, surprisingly perhaps, on the screenplay for Sam Peckinpah's violent account of life on the German side of the second world war, Cross Of Iron.

Rather more muted was another De Vries adaptation, the Oscar-nominated Reuben Reuben (1983). Epstein always claimed special regard for this account of a Dylan Thomas-like poet (Tom Conti) at loose in small-town New England. It appears to have been made on the cheap, and veers between comedy and drama. "Now I thank people from the bottom of my pacemaker," remarked Epstein in old age, but in his heart he knew that it would always be hard to match Casablanca. Howard Koch died five years ago, so with Epstein's death, the last substantial player in the story of the film has passed.

Epstein's marriage to Frances Sage ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife Ann, and two children from his first marriage. A son from his second marriage predeceased him in 1999.

Howard Koch died five years ago, so with Epstein's death, the last substantial player in the story of the film has passed. Epstein's marriage to Frances Sage ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife Ann, and two children from his first marriage. A son from his second marriage predeceased him in 1999.  Julius J Epstein, screenwriter, born August 22 1909; died December 30 2000.

webTitle: Gloves are for boxing but not for pitch battles

fields.headline: Gloves are for boxing but not for pitch battles
fields.trailText: Why the slow encroachment of gloves on to the field of play is ruining football.
fields.body:
During the 30s, Chilton Colliery met Stockton in a Northern League match. Despite protests that it was too cold for football, the referee ordered play to go ahead. In the 83rd minute the official was finally forced to concede defeat to the freezing temperatures and abandon the match. His decision came too late for one of the players, who had earlier collapsed with exposure.

Two decades later a game between Bishop Auckland and Shildon went ahead despite the fact that there was so much snow on the pitch that Bishop's goalkeeper Harry Sharratt was able to amuse himself during the first half by building a snowman on his goal line.

It was surely nostalgia for such displays of good old-fashioned senseless British pluck that provoked Alan Curbishley's recent outburst about players' clothing. "When you wear woolly hats, gloves and all sorts, you cannot play properly," the Charlton boss thundered. And quite right too.

Older readers will recall a time when even goalkeepers didn't dare wear gloves. Thirty years ago any child who tried to slip a pair on when taking up a position between the sticks would find the PE teacher sneering: "Oh dear, does the nasty ball sting diddums' lickle fingers?"

The games master would then go on sarcastically to posit a future in which a generation of namby-pamby stars would refuse to head the ball unless they were wearing a crash helmet, insist that the floodlights be fitted with heat bulbs and strap hot-water bottles to their torsos on frosty afternoons (which, to judge by his body shape, has actually come to pass in the case of Phil Stamp).

The man who changed such attitudes to hand protection was the 70s German goalie Sepp Maier. As an argument for legislation against the slow encroachment of gloves on to the field of play, Curbishley could not do better than to cite Maier. The Bayern Munich custodian started off with perfectly normal mitts but gradually expanded them until by the end of his career they looked like a pair of enormous flatfish. Indeed naturalists believe that the noise of Maier clapping his hands to encourage his team-mates is the nearest we will ever come to hearing the sound of manta rays mating.

Maier's vast gloves were reinforced with wire. In millennia to come archaeologists will discover their skeletal metal remains and conclude that during the latter part of the 20th century a species of huge-handed homo sapiens roamed northern Europe until they all starved to death one bank holiday weekend because their mighty salami-like fingers were incapable of successfully punching their pin numbers into ATMs.

As if gloves were not bad enough, some overseas players are flagrantly wearing vests under their shirts. For managers of the old school, raised in the harsh environment of, well, the old school, such developments must set alarm bells ringing.

They know where it will lead. One minute it's keeping his vest on during games, the next it's a note from Mother excusing him from showers because he's going through "that shy awkward phase".

At least vests are worn to keep warm, though. That cannot be the main purpose of gloves. If it were, why would so many players wear them in combination with sleeveless shirts? When you are cold you cover up. And tuck your shirt in.

No, these gloves are a role-play thing. The mix of bare arms and black leather makes even the most tender winger feel like he is in a cyberpunk movie. Don't I look cool and tough!

Gloves are just fashion masquerading as utility. They are a fad like cycling shorts. Time was, there was not a striker in the land who did not don a pair of these form-hugging garments. Supposed to guard against hamstring strains, their main effect may well have been psychological, suggesting dynamic bursts of speed even where none existed, the football equivalent of the go-faster stripe.

And where are they now?

Mouldering in the back of the changing room lockers with the peroxide bottles and those strips players used to stick across their hooters to increase oxygen intake. If Curbishley bides his time the gloves will probably join them there before too long.

webTitle: Milburn pledges £87.5m for cancer

fields.headline: Milburn pledges £87.5m for cancer
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has earmarked £87.5m to help diagnose and treat cancer over the next four years. The announcement comes as a new report was due to be published outlining "shocking" waiting periods for treatment of the disease.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has earmarked £87.5m to help diagnose and treat cancer over the next four years. The announcement comes as a new report was due to be published outlining "shocking" waiting periods for treatment of the disease.

Mr Milburn said the money would be allocated over the next four years for tackling cancers of the stomach, pancreas and oesophagus.

The cash will be spent on reducing the 18,000 deaths a year from these cancers by developing more specialist services.

Mr Milburn said: "Too many of the patients who receive services do so in a fragmented way and don't get the specialist care that they need."

The announcement of the funding coincides with a new report outlining ways of organising cancer care services. The report, drawn up by doctors, nurses and managers in a year-long study, shows ways of improving waiting times and results in cancer care.

Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, welcomed the extra funds for stomach cancer treatment. He said, however, that the report revealed some "shockingly long" waits for treatment in cancer care generally. In some cases, the time between diagnosis and treatment had taken six months, he said.

He added: "The report has revealed some appalling baseline results which, not surprisingly, when people looked at them, could be improved."

"Things will not get dramatically better until the 600 new cancer consultants appear and 600 new nurses. We need new pathologists and radiologists. We are grossly under-resourced after years and years of starvation in cancer care."

Mr Milburn said an extra £20m would be spent on new equipment to detect and treat heart disease. Most of the money will be invested in GP surgeries as well as hospitals to help monitor heart disease patients more effectively.

He said: "Decades of neglect left NHS cancer and heart services short of the investment they need. Now that failure to invest is being reversed."

At the Labour Party conference last year Mr Milburn promised that waiting times for all cancer treatment would be slashed to one month by 2005 as part of the three-year NHS cancer plan.

By this year women with breast cancer will wait only a month between diagnosis and treatment.

He announced that by this year children with cancer, people with acute leukaemia and men with testicular cancer who are given an urgent referral by their GP will receive treatment within a month.

The plan admits that it will take until 2008 for access to treatment for all types of cancer to compare with the best in Europe.

webTitle: Scotland remembers victims of Ibrox, 30 years on

fields.headline: Scotland remembers victims of Ibrox, 30 years on
fields.trailText: John Greig, revered as the greatest ever captain of Rangers, has been bustling around Ibrox in charge of the club's PR department. Amid his scurrying, he could be forgiven for forgetting that they are about to unveil his statue in sombre circumstances at Ibrox today.
fields.body:
John Greig, revered as the greatest ever captain of Rangers, has been bustling around Ibrox in charge of the club's PR department. Amid his scurrying, he could be forgiven for forgetting that they are about to unveil his statue in sombre circumstances at Ibrox today.

Today it will be 30 years since Rangers' darkest moment. The Ibrox disaster of January 2 1971 was a foretaste of the shocking incidents that afflicted British football in the last quarter of the 20th century, and if a reminder were needed that such tragedies are by no means restricted to the past it came with Saturday's crush at the final of the Joao Havelange Cup in Brazil in which 104 fans were injured.

Football games across Scotland today will hold a minute's silence in memory of the fans, and survivors and relatives will gather at Ibrox at 3pm. A service for relatives of the bereaved, on the very spot where the infamous stairway 13 stood and where Greig's statue is to be unveiled, will commemorate the 66 supporters who lost their lives.

Ibrox, carved into its contemporary all-seated theatre as a consequence of that day, is no stranger to tragedy. The first Ibrox disaster of 1902 had 25 deaths when old timber terraces holding 75,000 people watching an international between England and Scotland gave way under the strain and supporters plunged to their death. In the 1960s there were at least two further incidents involving fatalities on stairway 13.

On January 2 1971 all these dire portents reached their climax. A crowd of 80,000 was gathered inside Ibrox watching Rangers and Celtic play out an apparent no-score draw. The game, though, took a dramatic twist in the last two minutes, first when Jimmy Johnstone put Celtic ahead in the 89th minute and 70 seconds later when Colin Stein equalised for Rangers. These two goals are at the heart of perhaps the most enduring myth about any sporting tragedy in Britain. The aftermath was gruesome.

The old Ibrox was in the classic mould of the oval football arena, with four wide stairways down from the ter races, two at each end, spilling spectators from its maw.

Stairway 13, one of those four exits, was a 50-yard flight of steps with six tubular-steel barriers running from top to bottom, among which only one fan needed to stumble in order to trigger a crush. In addition supporters found themselves penned in by solid timber walls embedded in concrete on either side which refused to yield to the pressure.

It is estimated that as many as 25,000 were seeking their exit down the staircase after the final whistle when a fall and then further stumbles resulted in a human pile-up. The pressure of the crush was so great that the steel barriers were twisted and wrecked.

Robert McElroy, a Rangers historian and supporter for 40 years, spoke last week of many supporters' wariness of stairway 13. "There was always a terrible crush approaching it," he said, "and as a historian I had been aware of the previous incidents prior to the disaster.

"In fact, I remember my father always believed that once you actually got on to the stairs you were probably quite safe. I think many supporters believed this, that it was the congested build-up that was the scary bit. Alas, this proved mistaken."

Among the spectators at the Rangers end that day were Walter Smith and Alex Ferguson. Smith, later to become the manager of Rangers, escaped the carnage by somehow wresting himself free from the congestion and clambering over a fence down the grass embankment. "It isn't something I particularly enjoy talking about but I recall it all vividly," he said. "Even when I was working at Rangers every day it was hard to see the ground without thinking about that match."

As to the myth, that Celtic's goal triggered an exodus of Rangers fans who then heard the roar for Stein's equaliser and turned to go back up the stairway, the fatal accident inquiry found that the crush developed 10 minutes after the final whistle and that the goals had nothing to do with it. Both Johnstone and particularly Stein have taken solace from this after years of being repeatedly cited as the unwitting catalysts of the tragedy.

The disaster did at least lead to change. The prime minister Edward Heath set up an inquiry into ground safety, which eventually led to the Safety of Sports Grounds Act of 1975, which introduced safety certificates.

webTitle: Round-up

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers went a goal down and had Mark Hughes sent off at Norwich , but were still disappointed not to gain their fifth successive win.
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers went a goal down and had Mark Hughes sent off at Norwich , but were still disappointed not to gain their fifth successive win.

"I'm a little disappointed," Graeme Souness said. "We looked the better side for long periods and created the better chances but unfortunately we couldn't take them."

Adrian Forbes gave Norwich the lead after half an hour when Stig Inge Bjornebye was caught in possession, then Hughes was sent off for the ninth time in his career for a bodycheck on Darel Russell just before half-time. But Blackburn equalised through Junior Bent, who was also denied twice by excellent saves from Andy Marshall.

Souness suggested that the occasional Hughes dismissal was a price he was prepared to pay for such a valuable "natural competitor". "The man's 37 and I'm not in a position to teach him anything now," the manager said.

West Bromwich Albion moved above Blackburn into third place in the First Division with a 1-0 win over Barnsley gained with a late own-goal. Second-placed Bolton closed the gap on Fulham to seven points with a 2-0 win at Preston . Michael Ricketts played only eight minutes but that was long enough to get the clinching goal.

Wigan missed the chance to go top of the Second Division by drawing 0-0 at home to Wrexham . Brighton missed the chance to close the gap on Chesterfield in the Third Division by losing 2-0 at home to Southend .

Walsall moved up to second in the Second when Jorge Leitao's 12th goal of the season gave them a 1-0 win over Swindon , beaten for the third time in succession.

It was an even worse day for Lionel Perez, the Cambridge United and former Newcastle and Sunderland goalkeeper. Not only did Cambridge lose 6-2 at Bristol City , he was sent off seven minutes from time for - what do you expect? - "deliberate handball".

webTitle: Robson backs Rebrov to shine

fields.headline: Robson backs Rebrov to shine
fields.trailText: Sol Campbell has revealed his new year resolution to stay at Tottenham, and yesterday there was a further encouraging message to Spurs fans with a vote of confidence in Sergei Rebrov.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell has revealed his new year resolution to stay at Tottenham, and yesterday there was a further encouraging message to Spurs fans with a vote of confidence in Sergei Rebrov.

It came not from George Graham, under increasing pressure himself, but from his managerial adversary tonight, Newcastle's Bobby Robson, who lost out to Tottenham in the pursuit of the £11m Ukrainian striker last summer.

As Graham considered recalling Spurs' record signing after dropping him before the disturbing 3-0 defeat at Ipswich, Robson insisted Rebrov would show his true worth at Tottenham if both club and player gave it time.

"I liked him when he played in Kiev," said Robson. "I thought he was a great player, but he's finding it very difficult and tough.

"It doesn't surprise me that a foreigner takes six months to settle in. Our football is not easy, it's a high-pressure, dynamic game. It's not the most superb technical slow-passing game that you might see abroad sometimes."

Without seeing a Spurs win in six games and a goal in the last three, Graham must be tempted to restore Rebrov to the starting line-up at White Hart Lane tonight, especially after Saturday's pairing of Gary Doherty and Willem Korsten looked so lightweight.

Graham needs a rapid improvement from Rebrov, who may partner Les Ferdinand up front if the latter has recovered from a head injury. But Stephen Carr is likely to be missing again from defence with groin trouble.

Newcastle overcame their own injury handicap against Manchester United and Robson waits now on two of his South American midfielders, Clarence Acuna and Christian Bassedas, before finalising his side.

webTitle: First Taiwan-China voyages for half a century

fields.headline: First Taiwan-China voyages for half a century
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText:
Three Taiwanese ships made the first direct legal voyages to mainland China in 51 years today, raising hopes for better relations.
Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.body:
Three Taiwanese ships made the first direct legal voyages to mainland China in 51 years today, carrying government officials and religious pilgrims, and raising hopes for better relations.

Crowds of well-wishers with firecrackers and dragon dancers saw the vessels off from Kinmen and Matsu, Taiwanese coastal islands that at one time were shelled regularly from nearby China.

They arrived a few hours later in the Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei, which had been off-limits to direct travel since the two sides split in a civil war that ended in 1949.

Taiwan lifted a ban on Kinmen and Matsu on New Year's Day, legalising a trade carried on for years by smugglers. A Taiwanese tourist boat on what was to be the first crossing yesterday was forced to turn back by bad weather.

Direct transportation between the main island of Taiwan and China is still banned. But many Taiwanese hope lifting some travel restrictions will ease tensions with a giant neighbour that has threatened to take Taiwan, which it regards as a renegade territory, by force.

"This is a first step in improving cross-straits relations. What we need is lots more of this interaction and coordination," said Chen En-tse, a member of the Kinmen county council. He was among 190 passengers who traveled to Xiamen aboard the Tai Wu, named after the port city's tallest mountain.

The Taiwanese ranged in age from a young girl held in her father's arms to elderly, silver-haired men and women. Many were officials and community leaders. They were met by Xiamen police, officials and women from an official welcoming committee holding a banner reading "Warmly welcome our Taiwan neighbours".

Later, the Taiwanese filed onto buses to head to a gala lunch with Xiamen's official in charge of Taiwan-related affairs.

A second ship carried the group's luggage. Taiwanese tour operators who organised the trip hoped to bring back 100 elderly Chinese passengers on this ship's return trip to Kinmen.

"I am proud to be able to witness this epoch-making event," Taiwanese politician Lee Chu-feng, one of the visitors, told Taiwan state radio. Mr Lee said that after Taiwan began allowing indirect travel and trade links to China in the early 1990s, he had made 20 visits to Xiamen from Kinmen but previously had to detour through Hong Kong.

In Matsu, government officials waved from the harbour as the Taima ship steamed away carrying more than 500 worshippers of Matsu, the patron goddess of fishermen popular in Taiwan and south-east China. Forty Chinese security and police officers greeted the ship when it arrived three-and-a-half hours later in the port of Mawei, near the Chinese city of Fuzhou, Taiwan radio reported.

People aboard were thrilled to be testing Taiwan's new policy. "I got up at 2am for this trip. I want to see my relatives and I want to see China," said Chen Pao-chu, 60, a chemist.

Kinmen County Commissioner Chen Shui-tsai, who led the delegation aboard the Tai Wu, told reporters that he hoped his island would one day be the site of a first summit by leaders of China and Taiwan.

Taiwan opened the links between its two small islands and China without discussion with Beijing, which has grudgingly accepted the move but has not indicated to what extent it will cooperate. The Taiwanese leader, Chang Chun-hsiung, said the links could be "a very important step to herald the end of confrontations that have prevailed for 51 years."

If all goes well, Taiwan has said it will make an even bigger move: allowing ships, planes and mail from its main island to cross the 100-mile-wide Taiwan strait to the mainland.

China has become Taiwan's second biggest trading partner, but Taiwanese businesses complain that they are losing money because they cannot travel or ship goods directly to the mainland. Many believe opening the "big links" would create a booming trade area.

fields.bodyText: Three Taiwanese ships made the first direct legal voyages to mainland China in 51 years today, carrying government officials and religious pilgrims, and raising hopes for better relations. Crowds of well-wishers with firecrackers and dragon dancers saw the vessels off from Kinmen and Matsu, Taiwanese coastal islands that at one time were shelled regularly from nearby China. They arrived a few hours later in the Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei, which had been off-limits to direct travel since the two sides split in a civil war that ended in 1949. Taiwan lifted a ban on Kinmen and Matsu on New Year's Day, legalising a trade carried on for years by smugglers. A Taiwanese tourist boat on what was to be the first crossing yesterday was forced to turn back by bad weather. Direct transportation between the main island of Taiwan and China is still banned. But many Taiwanese hope lifting some travel restrictions will ease tensions with a giant neighbour that has threatened to take Taiwan, which it regards as a renegade territory, by force. "This is a first step in improving cross-straits relations. What we need is lots more of this interaction and coordination," said Chen En-tse, a member of the Kinmen county council. He was among 190 passengers who traveled to Xiamen aboard the Tai Wu, named after the port city's tallest mountain. The Taiwanese ranged in age from a young girl held in her father's arms to elderly, silver-haired men and women. Many were officials and community leaders. They were met by Xiamen police, officials and women from an official welcoming committee holding a banner reading "Warmly welcome our Taiwan neighbours". Later, the Taiwanese filed onto buses to head to a gala lunch with Xiamen's official in charge of Taiwan-related affairs. A second ship carried the group's luggage. Taiwanese tour operators who organised the trip hoped to bring back 100 elderly Chinese passengers on this ship's return trip to Kinmen. "I am proud to be able to witness this epoch-making event," Taiwanese politician Lee Chu-feng, one of the visitors, told Taiwan state radio. Mr Lee said that after Taiwan began allowing indirect travel and trade links to China in the early 1990s, he had made 20 visits to Xiamen from Kinmen but previously had to detour through Hong Kong. In Matsu, government officials waved from the harbour as the Taima ship steamed away carrying more than 500 worshippers of Matsu, the patron goddess of fishermen popular in Taiwan and south-east China. Forty Chinese security and police officers greeted the ship when it arrived three-and-a-half hours later in the port of Mawei, near the Chinese city of Fuzhou, Taiwan radio reported. People aboard were thrilled to be testing Taiwan's new policy. "I got up at 2am for this trip. I want to see my relatives and I want to see China," said Chen Pao-chu, 60, a chemist. Kinmen County Commissioner Chen Shui-tsai, who led the delegation aboard the Tai Wu, told reporters that he hoped his island would one day be the site of a first summit by leaders of China and Taiwan. Taiwan opened the links between its two small islands and China without discussion with Beijing, which has grudgingly accepted the move but has not indicated to what extent it will cooperate. The Taiwanese leader, Chang Chun-hsiung, said the links could be "a very important step to herald the end of confrontations that have prevailed for 51 years." If all goes well, Taiwan has said it will make an even bigger move: allowing ships, planes and mail from its main island to cross the 100-mile-wide Taiwan strait to the mainland. China has become Taiwan's second biggest trading partner, but Taiwanese businesses complain that they are losing money because they cannot travel or ship goods directly to the mainland. Many believe opening the "big links" would create a booming trade area. webTitle: British troops to remain in Sierra Leone all year

fields.headline: British troops to remain in Sierra Leone all year
fields.trailText: British troops are likely to remain in Sierra Leone until the end of this year, the commander of the British contingent in the West African country said yesterday.
fields.body:
British troops are likely to remain in Sierra Leone until the end of this year, the commander of the British contingent in the West African country said yesterday.

Brigadier Jonathan Riley said the end of the war against the rebel Revolutionary United Front was in sight but he added: "I think that we will be there in much the same numbers for the rest of the year".

He said government-held areas had been peaceful over Christmas, a fact local people ascribed to the presence of British troops.

There are some 500 British soldiers in the country, mainly engaged in training the Sierra Leone army. There is also a British military headquarters staffed by senior officers.

"We will leave when the war is either won or resolved on favourable terms," Brig Riley told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "My reading of the situation of the rebels is that they are not in a good way and their situation is getting worse".

He added: "I think the end is in sight. In the short term, I think that we will be there in much the same numbers for the rest of the year". Thereafter Britain would maintain a small training detachment, like those it has in other countries such as South Africa.

The brigadier said that more than 6,000 of the 10,500 Sierra Leone army soldiers had completed training, putting the country on the way towards what he called a "properly-constituted professional army".

However, concern remains about the future of the UN peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone, with two of the main contributors - India and Jordan - pulling their troops out.

The RUF rebels have killed tens of thousands of civilians and maimed, raped and kidnapped more since launching a bid to overthrow the government and secure the country's lucrative diamond mines.

The rebels have signed and discarded three peace accords since launching their war in 1991. The collapse of the accord in May brought a buildup of UN peacekeepers and the deployment of hundreds of British troops to advise the Sierra Leone army. The UN is searching for replacements for the Indian and Jordanian contingents.

webTitle: Power of Phillips lights up Wearside

fields.headline: Power of Phillips lights up Wearside
fields.trailText: The pre-match pyrotechnics may have fizzled out but Sunderland's season is proving more explosive by the day. Yesterday's stunning second-half display floored Ipswich Town, propelled Peter Reid's team back up to third - level on points with Arsenal - and had Mackems drooling at the prospect of European football next season.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
The pre-match pyrotechnics may have fizzled out but Sunderland's season is proving more explosive by the day. Yesterday's stunning second-half display floored Ipswich Town, propelled Peter Reid's team back up to third - level on points with Arsenal - and had Mackems drooling at the prospect of European football next season.

Europe? "Easy - you said that, not me," said a smiling Reid. "Last year the press had us challenging for Europe and we didn't win for 11 games."

In terms of overall ability, Reid added, "we're a long way behind Arsenal and Manchester United and we just have to keep going, but that performance was fantastic. Once we got into our rhythm, the pace and power of the team was really good."

Ipswich's manager George Burley was more prepared to elaborate on what the whole of Wearside was thinking. "They are a very powerful side on a great run," he said. "I can see them up there at the end of the season."

Sunderland's blistering display after the interval apparently had nothing to do with Reid's half-time talk and instead centred on one striker regaining his best form, Kevin Phillips, and another who has had little chance to generate any form at all. Danny Dichio was making his first Premiership start after almost three years at the club and, having hit Richard Wright's legs from close range early in the second half, he picked himself up admirably to fill the void left by Niall Quinn's absence.

It was Dichio's flick which bypassed the floundering Titus Bramble and Mark Venus just before the hour, allowing Phillips to burst through the shoddy rearguard and place his fifth goal in three games beyond Wright. Then the England striker wriggled free of Venus and squared the ball unselfishly for Dichio to score his first of the season.

"I though Danny was outstanding," said Reid. "He's an underrated player and I wouldn't have bought him if I didn't fancy him. The partnership looked perfect up front and, as for Kevin, how anyone ever doubted him as a finisher is beyond me. If he doesn't get a chance for England then we must have some of the best strikers on the planet over here."

To raucous celebrations the substitute Stefan Schwarz capped the win with a volley from Darren Williams's cross. The red-and-white hordes basked in victory, the painful memory of the opening 20 minutes, when Ipswich had baffled them with clever, incisive football of their own, forgotten in the euphoria. Sunderland's supporters are used to sloppy starts; if the Premiership were measured on the opening 45 minutes they would now be fretting over relegation.

Ipswich, zipping passes with the confidence fuelled by as many away league wins as United, ran the hosts ragged with pretty triangles and late charges from midfield.

The sparky entrance merited their fifth-minute reward. After Michael Gray crunched Alun Armstrong unfairly, advantage was played and Fabian Wilnis chipped the ball into the space vacated by the Sunderland left-back. Matt Holland sprang forward and crossed low for Marcus Stewart, outsprinting the on-rushing Thomas Sorensen, to lob the ball in for his 14th goal of the season.

Then James Scowcroft's centre was dummied by Stewart and Emerson Thome had to snap at Holland's feet to block his shot. Yet from such a platform the visitors stumbled. Stewart's horrendous lunge at Gavin McCann flustered his team-mates as much as Sunderland's midfielder and Ipswich promptly conceded another free-kick on the edge of their area as Dichio was fouled.

Julio Arca curled the ball sumptuously into the top corner. So decisive was that goal in waking up the home side that, on being substituted late on, the brilliant Argentine got a warm hug from Sunderland's No2 Bobby Saxton - quite possibly the most terrifying moment of his fledgling English career.

Although they continued to threaten despite Sunderland's goal rush - Sorensen saved well from Martijn Reuser's vicious shot - the Tractor Boys left with unfamiliar defeat stinging their pride.

Ipswich's entire back line was booked and looked uncomfortable. Burley said: "It's incredible for us to be doing so well and we've got a standard to live up to now. We let that slip today."

webTitle: Naylor rewards Ward's faith

fields.headline: Naylor rewards Ward's faith
fields.trailText: John Ward's claim to be named the manager of Wolves this week was emphatically endorsed by his young players yesterday.
fields.body:
John Ward's claim to be named the manager of Wolves this week was emphatically endorsed by his young players yesterday.

The caretaker manager, third favourite in a three-horse race with David Jones and Dave Bassett, was interviewed for the permanent job on Sunday and has already urged the Molineaux board to build for the future from within the club's developing talent. And the players returned the compliment with a performance of grit and determination, coming from behind to score a late winner through Lee Naylor.

Ward's words of wisdom to the Wolves directors, who have achieved nothing by brandishing the chequebook, were backed up by the performances of the 20-year-old Naylor and 19-year-old striker Adam Proudlock.

Ward's delight in the victory and the performance of his players was in stark contrast to the feelings of Burnley's manager Stan Ternent, whose side have now lost five games in succession, three of them at Turf Moor.

The Burnley fans were treated to a bright start but they were distinctly unhappy at the end, booing the players off and even booing the 86th-minute substitute Ronnie Jepson as he came on. It drew a strong reaction from Ternent. "Fans showed their frustration but the vast majority understand what is happening," he said, "though you do get a few morons who boo when it is completely uncalled for."

Burnley got down to work more quickly, with Graham Branch beating the Wolves goalkeeper Michael Oakes in the ninth minute. Branch finished well from 12 yards and for 25 minutes Wolves struggled to get into the game until their own Branch - Michael, Graham's cousin - shot just wide from the edge of the box.

Wolves equalised in the 28th minute after Proudlock finished a sweeping move by running on to a low cross from Naylor and scoring from six yards. And Naylor decided the match five minutes from time with a swerving left-foot free-kick masked by Carl Robinson's run; Nik Michopoulos, Burnley's goalkeeper, was left stranded on his line as the ball finished in the corner.

webTitle: James calamity spurs Chelsea

fields.headline: James calamity spurs Chelsea
fields.trailText: The Football Association must be tempted to investigate whether David James is on the payroll at Stamford Bridge. In May the Aston Villa goalkeeper dropped a free-kick to hand Chelsea the FA Cup. Yesterday his embarrassing blunder gave Claudio Ranieri's side three points.
fields.body:
The Football Association must be tempted to investigate whether David James is on the payroll at Stamford Bridge. In May the Aston Villa goalkeeper dropped a free-kick to hand Chelsea the FA Cup. Yesterday his embarrassing blunder gave Claudio Ranieri's side three points.

The expression on the 30-year-old's face as he handed his gloves to a Villa supporter at the end told the story. In striking a clearance at Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink just before half-time he had offered the Dutch striker an open goal and decided the match in favour of a fitful Chelsea.

Neither James's otherwise impressive performance nor a late foray forward for a corner could undo the damage. A fine early save from Gus Poyet will soon be forgotten and his talent seems certain forever to be undermined by these flashes of incompetence. No doubt the England keeper will be making as grovelling an apology to his manager John Gregory as Gregory did to Doug Ellis last week.

"I have to confess I was on my way down to the dressing room for the half-time chat so I haven't seen it," Gregory said, "but I gather it was pretty horrific." He knows the impact this will have on a man who has been gradually shaking off the "Calamity James" tag he earned during his time at Anfield.

James must hope Sven-Goran Eriksson does not get a copy of the video and he will take little comfort from learning that Poyet, Chelsea's captain in place of the dropped Dennis Wise, described the mistake as "the difference" between the teams.

Ranieri's side just about deserved to win, having created the better chances and struck the bar, but they gave a far from convincing performance and were becoming increasingly frustrated by Villa's defensive approach at the time the goal arrived.

When Chelsea moved the ball at pace with one or two touches, as they did at the start of both halves, they looked impressive. Yet too often they failed to find that fluency. After Hasselbaink had hit the woodwork early in the second half they created almost nothing.

It was their good fortune that the long spells of possession Villa enjoyed after the interval produced little end product. Gilles de Bilde, playing the last game of his three-month loan from Sheffield Wednesday, should have equalised and Gregory will hope Juan Pablo Angel gets clearance to make his debut soon. The Colombian will play in a fortnight at the earliest, Gregory says.

It will help Chelsea in their desire to get back into Europe if they can start to replicate their success at home on their travels. It is seven wins and a draw at Stamford Bridge since Ranieri took over and still not a victory has been gained away. After the collapse from 2-0 up at Ipswich, the Italian at least showed his ruthlessness.

Dropped to the bench were not only Wise but Gianfranco Zola and the goalkeeper Ed de Goey. In a glimpse of the future, Chelsea paraded their young Danish signing Jesper Gronkjaer before kick-off and fielded six outfield players aged 24 or under, half of them English.

One of those, Jon Harley, was involved in much of Chelsea's good early work as they created four chances inside 20 minutes. James was forced off his line to clear as Hasselbaink bore down on goal and then made his fine stop when Poyet headed a Harley cross goalwards.

But all that was to be undermined as half-time loomed. Booting a Steve Staunton back pass upfield seemed simple enough but James struck the ball straight at Hasselbaink's feet and the striker, despite mishitting his shot, squeezed a looping effort just over the line before Gareth Southgate could clear. For James, memories of the dropped free-kick that allowed Roberto di Matteo that Wembley winner may have flooded back.

After Hasselbaink's thunderous shot had struck the bar, with Sam Dalla Bona volleying the rebound over, Villa threatened with new adventure. But De Bilde allowed Carlo Cudicini to save at his near post when Mario Melchiot underhit a backpass and James was left to contemplate a very unhappy new year.

webTitle: Gift of Flowers for Bradford

fields.headline: Gift of Flowers for Bradford
fields.trailText: Bradford City are still cut adrift at the bottom of the Premiership but, after their first away win for nine months, their impressive new manager Jim Jefferies can at least view everyone else without recourse to a powerful telescope.
fields.body:
Bradford City are still cut adrift at the bottom of the Premiership but, after their first away win for nine months, their impressive new manager Jim Jefferies can at least view everyone else without recourse to a powerful telescope.

Until this performance their away successes this season comprised two draws, and unlike Chelsea and Tottenham, who had also failed to win on the road, their home record is not much better.

Here, though, despite losing their previous three games and with half their squad in the treatment room, they played with vigour and a scarcely plausible confidence to inflict upon Leicester only their second defeat at home this season.

Leicester, it must be said, were awful and after their 6-1 Boxing Day defeat by Arsenal they are in mini-crisis. They are an essentially small club who should be proud of their sixth position. But they are short of goalscorers and in midfield the loss of Neil Lennon has wounded them deeply. Here they never looked likely to recover once a gaffe by their goalkeeper Tim Flowers put them two down. Flowers, who played only after passing a fitness test on his injured thigh, did not reappear for the second half.

Before the end, almost mockingly, Stan Collymore came off the bench to face the Leicester side with whom he had had such a brief and unhappy association. But by that stage Filbert Street was beyond further embarrassment.

Jefferies said: "Over 90 minutes - or 95 minutes I think we had in the end - that was as well as we've played all season. We're still five points adrift, or six behind the fourth-from-bottom club. But we do have a match in hand and if we show the same organisation and workrate in the matches to come we could be back in the hunt again. We played well and deserved this win.

"No one gave us a chance after our defeat on Boxing Day, when we put in one of our worst performances, so I was delighted to see the lads had the character to bounce back."

Leicester's manager Peter Taylor looked forlorn. "It was very disappointing. In the last couple of matches we've been as bad as at any time this season. Until then I had been pleased with the way things were going.

"There is a lack of confidence and a lack of leaders at the moment. It was Tim's decision to come off at half-time. I would rather have put on three outfield players but he was really struggling." He added that the goalkeeper's mistake was "the first I've seen from him since I've been here".

Eoin Jess, on loan to Bradford from Aberdeen, made an eye-catching debut operating just behind Dean Saunders and Robbie Blake and scored the opening goal in the 25th minute. It was from his pass that Blake cut inside Robbie Savage only to see his deflected shot cleared off the line by Andy Impey. From the rebound Jess drove home. Jess's loan agreement lasts three months but Jefferies hopes to make the move permanent after that.

Leicester had not recovered when, five minutes later, they fell further behind. Phil Gilchrist fouled Dean Windass and from the free-kick, just outside the penalty area, Wayne Jacobs scored. Although Flowers was partially unsighted he got down for the ball, only to see it roll through his arms.

Leicester pulled one back seven minutes before half-time with a Muzzy Izzet penalty after Windass had brought down Darren Eadie but they were not good enough to build on this.

"Bradford are fighting for their lives and today worked harder than us and looked brighter too," said Taylor. He looked about as bright as next month's Christmas lights.

Here they never looked likely to recover once a gaffe by their goalkeeper Tim Flowers put them two down. Flowers, who played only after passing a fitness test on his injured thigh, did not reappear for the second half. Before the end, almost mockingly, Stan Collymore came off the bench to face the Leicester side with whom he had had such a brief and unhappy association. But by that stage Filbert Street was beyond further embarrassment. Jefferies said: "Over 90 minutes - or 95 minutes I think we had in the end - that was as well as we've played all season. We're still five points adrift, or six behind the fourth-from-bottom club. But we do have a match in hand and if we show the same organisation and workrate in the matches to come we could be back in the hunt again. We played well and deserved this win. "No one gave us a chance after our defeat on Boxing Day, when we put in one of our worst performances, so I was delighted to see the lads had the character to bounce back." Leicester's manager Peter Taylor looked forlorn. "It was very disappointing. In the last couple of matches we've been as bad as at any time this season. Until then I had been pleased with the way things were going. "There is a lack of confidence and a lack of leaders at the moment. It was Tim's decision to come off at half-time. I would rather have put on three outfield players but he was really struggling." He added that the goalkeeper's mistake was "the first I've seen from him since I've been here". Eoin Jess, on loan to Bradford from Aberdeen, made an eye-catching debut operating just behind Dean Saunders and Robbie Blake and scored the opening goal in the 25th minute. It was from his pass that Blake cut inside Robbie Savage only to see his deflected shot cleared off the line by Andy Impey. From the rebound Jess drove home. Jess's loan agreement lasts three months but Jefferies hopes to make the move permanent after that. Leicester had not recovered when, five minutes later, they fell further behind. Phil Gilchrist fouled Dean Windass and from the free-kick, just outside the penalty area, Wayne Jacobs scored. Although Flowers was partially unsighted he got down for the ball, only to see it roll through his arms. Leicester pulled one back seven minutes before half-time with a Muzzy Izzet penalty after Windass had brought down Darren Eadie but they were not good enough to build on this. "Bradford are fighting for their lives and today worked harder than us and looked brighter too," said Taylor. He looked about as bright as next month's Christmas lights.

webTitle: Edworthy strikes it lucky to deny Royle the spoils

fields.headline: Edworthy strikes it lucky to deny Royle the spoils
fields.trailText: The rarity value of Marc Edworthy's second-half goal was matched by its timeliness as it ensured Coventry City remain on the cusp of the relegation zone rather than in it.
fields.body:
The rarity value of Marc Edworthy's second-half goal was matched by its timeliness as it ensured Coventry City remain on the cusp of the relegation zone rather than in it.

Until yesterday the full-back had not scored for Coventry or, as near as damn it, anyone else. In a career that has taken in Plymouth Argyle, Crystal Palace and now Coventry, he had only one league goal to his name. But doubling his tally means it is a case of as you were at the foot of the Premiership table.

The goal, which cancelled out Paulo Wanchope's 54th-minute strike, keeps the Sky Blues of Coventry ahead of their Mancunian counterparts but it is a result that Joe Royle welcomes more than Gordon Strachan.

Royle's team went into the game looking for their first win in five attempts and Royle responded to what is becoming a desperate situation with desperate measures: making six changes to his team.

The sextet included a first appearance in 15 months for the centre-back Andy Morrison and the return of Richard Edghill. Royle also gave a full debut to Darren Huckerby and the forward, once of Coventry, responded by setting up Wanchope's goal.

Minutes later Huckerby repeated the diagonal ball that had unhinged the hosts' defence but Wanchope was unable to reprise his role in the action replay and shot weakly at Chris Kirkland.

"Had that gone in it would surely have given us the three points," said Royle. "Nevertheless I'm not displeased with the draw, especially as we were very, very poor against Charlton the other day."

Huckerby's purposeful and incisive approach work counted for nothing when Edworthy, switched from right to left-back in a tactical re-shuffle by Strachan, equalised from distance in the 72nd minute.

Hit more in hope than expectation, the ball dipped underneath the diving Nicky Weaver's body and prompted an inevitable inquest into the keeper's culpability.

Royle stood by his man. "He's been outstanding for us for the past couple of years so it would be unfair to have a go," the manager said.

In fairness to Weaver, a combination of his quickness of thought and athleticism prevented Coventry from going ahead in the 33rd minute when a shot from Barry Quinn deflected off Edghill.

Weaver palmed that to safety but profligacy in front of goal by Coventry's forwards meant that he did not have to make such a spectacular intervention again.

It all added up to a familiar story for Strachan. "I wasn't happy with the draw," he said. "We keep making chances and failing to take them; it's a familiar story. But I do draw some comfort from it. If we're talking about missing goals rather than letting them in it means we're improving."

webTitle: County give the pack new hope

fields.headline: County give the pack new hope
fields.trailText: Fulham's first away league defeat in eight months offered the tantalising prospect of a First Division title race worthy of the name for the new year.
fields.body:
Fulham's first away league defeat in eight months offered the tantalising prospect of a First Division title race worthy of the name for the new year.

Stockport were the unlikely agents of a most unexpected, if deserved, result that came courtesy of goals either side of half-time by their Finland midfielder Jarkko Wiss and their young full-back Peter Clark.

But it was the manner of the defeat as much as the scoreline itself which will offer a glimmer of hope to those teams immediately below Fulham, even if Jean Tigana's team lead second-placed Bolton by seven points and have two games in hand.

Harried, chased and consistently outfought in key areas by Stockport, the remainder of the season will prove whether this first league defeat since Preston won at Craven Cottage on October 24 was a mere diversion on the road to the Premiership or the first signs of a nasty traffic jam.

"I have no doubt promotion will go down to the wire," said Fulham's midfielder Lee Clark. "Even when I was at Sunderland and we won the division with a record number of points, we were not promoted until a couple of weeks before the end of the season.

"People outside the club have been saying the promotion race is over, that it is us and one other team to go up, but we have never thought that way. This was a reminder to everyone that there is still a long way to go."

The contest initially bore all the hallmarks of becoming Fulham's 20th win of the campaign, and three times Louis Saha would have added to his 21 goals had he capitalised on some shaky handling from Carlo Nash, recalled on the eve of the game from a loan spell at Wolves.

But the 40th minute saw a trip by Andy Melville on the gangling County youngster Aaron Wilbraham and, with it, a dramatic change to the pattern of the match.

At the free-kick County astutely lined three players in front of the ball, obscuring the view of Maik Taylor, Mike Flynn touched the ball to Wiss and the Finn drove a low shot into the left-hand corner.

Two minutes after half-time, Clark scored a goal of remarkable skill and audacity for a young defender who was rescued from the anonymity of Carlisle for £75,000 in summer.

The 21-year-old collected Chris Coleman's clearance 40 yards from goal, surged forward, outmanoeuvred three defenders and retained his composure to stab the ball past Taylor.

There followed a flurry of Fulham chances, mostly inspired by the arrival of the French midfielder Nicolas Sahnoun, who hit a post from 25 yards and set up his fellow replacement Andrejs Stolcers for a shot which Nash diverted against the bar.

But sterling defensive work, illustrated by Ali Gibb's tackle on Saha and Kevin Cooper's spectacular headed clearance of a corner from under the bar, ensured the day belonged to Stockport.

Stockport's manager Andy Kilner said: "It's a tremendous achievement to beat a side like Fulham who have destroyed many a side this year, who will do so for the rest of the season and who will be in the Premiership next year."

webTitle: Beasant works his charms

fields.headline: Beasant works his charms
fields.trailText: Birmingham were spared the dubious delights of a match at frozen Fulham on Saturday but spluttered on their return to action yesterday when they squandered a 14th-minute penalty and then conceded two late goals to their fellow play-off contenders.
fields.body:
Birmingham were spared the dubious delights of a match at frozen Fulham on Saturday but spluttered on their return to action yesterday when they squandered a 14th-minute penalty and then conceded two late goals to their fellow play-off contenders.

Despite the sticky mud at St Andrews the home side at times threatened to overrun David Platt's team, also in dire need of holiday points after being held 0-0 at home by Norwich. But it all went wrong for City after Forest's 41-year-old goalkeeper Dave Beasant saved Martin Grainger's 14th-minute spot-kick.

That set the tone for their day as the impressive Beasant's goal enjoyed a charmed life with both Darren Purse and Marcelo hitting a post in the second half before Forest struck against the run of play.

A minute after Marcelo had smashed his shot against the woodwork, Forest broke down the left where Purse was ruled to have impeded Gary Jones on the edge of the area. Forest's captain Chris Bart-Williams slotted away his penalty to Ian Bennett's left. Forest then clinched it via David Prutton's close-range goal after Andy Reid's storming break.

Later a rueful City manager Trevor Francis said: "I cannot believe we have been beaten after dominating so much of the game. We only have ourselves to blame."

His opposite number Platt admitted: "It was a smash-and-grab job. We rode our luck. Dave Beasant performed exceptionally well and the rest of the team battled hard."

webTitle: Business is currently Pooming at Derby

fields.headline: Business is currently Pooming at Derby
fields.trailText: The chorus of what sounded like booing at the final whistle could have misled the neutral into believing Derby's supporters were dissatisfied. In fact they were "Pooming", paying vocal tribute to their Estonian goalkeeper Mart Poom.
fields.body:
The chorus of what sounded like booing at the final whistle could have misled the neutral into believing Derby's supporters were dissatisfied. In fact they were "Pooming", paying vocal tribute to their Estonian goalkeeper Mart Poom.

His four saves of the highest quality ensured Derby hung on for what could be three crucial points, hauling themselves above Everton in the frantic dogfight in the lower regions of the Premiership.

They must also appreciate the emergence of Danny Higginbotham on the left flank, allowing Seth Johnson to take his preferred place in the centre of midfield. His curling deliveries behind the Everton back three were a constant threat and Higginbotham, having stolen a yard on Stefano Eranio, should have done better than to poke Johnson's fifth-minute cross over the bar.

For Everton, Duncan Ferguson, making only his second full start since his summer move from Newcastle, was the lone target, and to make matters worse the Scot's strength in the air required him to return to his own penalty area for every Derby set piece.

Higginbotham and Johnson, together with Deon Burton up front, formed a shaven-headed triangle on the left that consistently outmanoeuvred the Everton midfield. With Chris Riggott, Taribo West and Horacio Carbonari looking comfortable behind them it was a surprise when Everton all but took the lead on 17 minutes. Steve Watson headed a Mark Pembridge cross against the bar, and when West sliced the rebound towards his own net Poom had to make his first excellent save.

Three minutes later Derby scored. Johnson, inevitably, crossed from the left, the lively Malcolm Christie stepped over the ball, Everton's defence bought the dummy and the ball ran through for Burton to lift over Thomas Myhre.

Neither side were particularly creative for the rest of the half, in contrast to the first 20 minutes of the second period when a double substitution by Walter Smith gave Everton a better balance. They exploited it with such verve that at times it seemed only Poom stood in their way. But what a barrier he formed. David Weir and Mark Pembridge had extended him to the full when Ferguson's right-foot curler found its way through a pack of players. Hav ing barely seen it, Poom flung himself to his left and touched the ball around the post. Ferguson collapsed in disbelief.

After that, for all that Everton flung themselves forward, there was a lack of belief about the balls they pumped into the opposition area. Indeed it was Derby who came nearest to scoring as Christie chased down a long clearance, beat Michael Ball for pace and rounded Myhre, though not before the goalkeeper had obstructed him enough to unbalance the young striker.

"Too honest, he should have gone down," sighed Jim Smith afterwards, before adding to the chorus of praise for Poom. "Fantastic. He won us the game. He's one of the four best keepers in the Premiership."

Certainly no goalkeeper in the top division has made more saves, even though Smith made the point that Derby's nine clean sheets in 13 games had not been solely Poom's responsibility: "The back three have gelled as a unit and they have given him confidence."

"We could have done without him playing like that," said Walter Smith, somewhat grimly. One point from the last six games is a sorry sum, and the imminent return of players such as Richard Gough and Abel Xavier, together with the virus-hit Kevin Campbell, cannot come quickly enough.

webTitle: Babbel finally makes sense of Liverpool gabble

fields.headline: Babbel finally makes sense of Liverpool gabble
fields.trailText: Liverpool's new year began as happily as they would have wished, but only just and only if results are all that matter. After a bright first half by both sides, the game tailed off scrappily and it needed a header by Markus Babbel four minutes from time to secure all the points and turn growing impatience in the crowd into relief.
fields.body:
Liverpool's new year began as happily as they would have wished, but only just and only if results are all that matter. After a bright first half by both sides, the game tailed off scrappily and it needed a header by Markus Babbel four minutes from time to secure all the points and turn growing impatience in the crowd into relief.

Southampton, enjoying the bounce of James Beattie's goals over the past two months, had taken only eight minutes to equalise Steven Gerrard's early strike, held their own for more than an hour and were denied a hand-ball penalty. But Gérard Houllier, though conceding that "it was not the best Liverpool performance in terms of passing and movement", added: "I don't think we were lucky. We dominated a confident team."

In possession and territory that may have been true. In imagination, though, they looked increasingly bereft, which is why the Anfield fans were restive at the incompetence of it all. Houllier was right when he said his three substitutes made the difference. "They brought freshness and desire to make the game our way when the guidelines of our play had gone."

Emile Heskey was briefly at his burly, bustling best; Gary McAllister, bald as a ball-bearing, kept the midfield machinery in running order; and Gerrard, lying deep, got forward unnoticed to inject pace and purpose. In the second minute, from 25 yards, his rocket forced Paul Jones to palm away for a corner. In the 12th, from five yards deeper, and again not picked up, he beat the keeper to his top left-hand corner with another bullet still rising.

For once the Southampton goal was not Beattie's, though it owed something to the fear that his 10 goals in 10 games struck in Liverpool's defence. Stéphane Henchoz had already been glad to concede a corner when Claus Lundekvam's long ball found Beattie beyond him. Then Sami Hyypia did the same and Marian Pahars' corner cleared everyone to find Trond Soltvedt beyond the far post.

Southampton regained full composure, Liverpool realised they had a battle on their hands and could not work out how to break down the organisation that Matt Oakley had marshalled in front of his back four. If Southampton threatened only on the break, Liverpool hardly made a clear-cut chance.

The winner came from a corner, won by Michael Owen's burst past Jason Dodd, nodded back by Hyypia and in by Babbel. Just previously, from Pahars' free-kick, Henchoz shot up a hand under pressure from Beattie and clearly palmed the ball out. "They have to catch it nowadays if you're away," said Glenn Hoddle, the visiting manager.

Asked about Gerrard's international potential, the former England coach said: "He plays with his head up, a rarity these days." If only more of his team-mates did the same.

webTitle: Investors flee LetsBuyIt.com

fields.headline: Investors flee LetsBuyIt.com
fields.standfirst: Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Investors are deserting beleaguered internet retailer LetsBuyIt.com amid rumours of imminent closure, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Investors are fleeing beleaguered internet retailer LetsBuyIt.com amid rumours of an imminent shutdown.

Letsbuyit's shares crashed 69% to 25p in early trading on the Frankfurt stock exchange after they were suspended last Friday.

The cash-strapped company, which allows consumers to team up when they buy goods, was last week forced to seek court protection from its creditors and the website has stopped taking orders.

According to reports, the Amsterdam-based group is this morning meeting a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, who will decide whether it should resume business.

Today the site appears with a notice advising users that the service is limited to "window-shopping". It says: "At present we are unable to take any orders, but please feel free to browse the site."

Letsbuyit is estimated to have only £11.4m left in the bank, and has made a loss of £16.5m in the previous quarter. It raised just £42m from its July flotation, leaving it crippled with constant cash flow problems.

Most of its custom comes from Germany, Britain and the nordic region, but sales have been hit by the fall in consumer confidence in online shopping.

Like other struggling dotcoms, the group has been given short shrift every time it has gone to the market for extra cash. In November, it failed to persuade shareholders to part with a further £50m.

The company has used these factors as its main excuses, claiming that otherwise it has met all customer and revenue targets.

Letsbuyit was not available for comment.

Like other struggling dotcoms, the group has been given short shrift every time it has gone to the market for extra cash. In November, it failed to persuade shareholders to part with a further £50m. The company has used these factors as its main excuses, claiming that otherwise it has met all customer and revenue targets. Letsbuyit was not available for comment.

webTitle: Guileless Gunners crack up

fields.headline: Guileless Gunners crack up
fields.trailText: If Arsenal have begun 2001 the way they mean to go on then even the idea of finishing runners-up to Manchester United in the Premiership will soon become something less than a comfortable assumption. Yesterday Arsène Wenger's admittedly weakened team looked more like the old year doddering out than the new one gurgling in.
fields.body:
If Arsenal have begun 2001 the way they mean to go on then even the idea of finishing runners-up to Manchester United in the Premiership will soon become something less than a comfortable assumption. Yesterday Arsène Wenger's admittedly weakened team looked more like the old year doddering out than the new one gurgling in.

For Charlton the victory was historic, for most of their followers literally so. The last time Athletic had beaten Arsenal, in March 1956, Sam Bartram was playing his last game in goal, Anthony Eden was the prime minister and the Suez crisis still lay in the future.

Then again Manchester United did win the championship that season so what goes around still comes around, even after a time lapse of 44 years. Though Jonatan Johansson's header six minutes before half-time decided the contest, the pivotal moment came a quarter of an hour from the end when Dean Kiely kept faith with Bartram's memory by saving a penalty from Nelson Vivas.

Arsenal have had an unfestive season. Five points from five matches is no way to maintain pressure at the top and now they are second only on goal difference from Sunderland, who held them to 2-2 at Highbury on Saturday.

Yesterday the absence of six of Wenger's regular team, with Tony Adams and Thierry Henry the latest casualties, was always going to be troublesome against a Charlton side who have glowed with confidence at home since returning to the Premiership. But as the Arsenal manager said after wards: "When you lose players you have to forget about the absentees and carry on."

Clearly Wenger is not happy with his team's attitude away from home. "When you play for Arsenal you must fight for every ball and [take] more responsibility," he said. "You can dream about how good you are but the table tells you the truth."

Until Charlton scored with their first chance Arsenal had retained possession often enough to suggest that if the game did not end goalless and guileless they would have the better chance of winning it, probably with a breakaway. Certainly as Claus Jensen and Scott Parker struggled to find a way past Patrick Vieira and Vivas, it was difficult to see how Alan Curbishley's attack would find the net.

Stymied in midfield, Charlton had resorted to high balls towards Johansson and Shaun Bartlett, easy stuff for centre-backs. Yet when a goal did arrive it followed a straightforward centre from the right which Adams or Martin Keown, also missing yesterday, would have cleared without a moment's thought. Gilles Grimandi, though, did not get a clean header to Radostin Kishishev's cross, enabling Graham Stuart to centre from the left for Johansson to duck between two defenders and nod into the left-hand corner of the net.

Had Bartlett not wasted the best of several more chances that Charlton created early in the second half, completely miscuing after Andy Todd and Johansson had brushed aside Arsenal's cover on the right, Wenger and his players would have been put out of their misery a little earlier. As it was their frustrations had barely begun.

With just over an hour gone Silvinho and Robert Pires gave way to Ashley Cole and Tomas Danilevicius, a Moscow-born Lithuanian with a Greek passport. In the 75th minute Mark Fish upended Danilevicius to give away a penalty in any language and Arsenal's chances of sloping away with a point looked bright.

Yet the apparent unwillingness of anyone to take the kick offered a clue to what followed: Vivas, who drew the short straw, struck firmly enough but at a height which allowed Kiely to pull off an outstanding save.

"It's not about who might or might not have taken the penalty," said Wenger. "You can't hide behind that." Nevertheless when an Arsenal side cannot find a string of volunteers to take a penalty at Charlton, something is in urgent need of attention.

For Charlton's part the win confirmed how much Curbishley's team have matured since their first abortive season in the Premiership. But whereas Charlton would be happy to finish in the top half of the table, Arsenal would be mortified not to make the top three and with that next season's Champions League. That, however, is starting to look a possibility.

webTitle: No hangover for the champions

fields.headline: No hangover for the champions
fields.trailText: If they have not done so already, Manchester United may feel the time has come to stock up on supplies of silver polish. Last night they strutted 11 points clear of Arsenal in the title race, although on this evidence the difference between the best and the rest is more like several light-years.
fields.body:
If they have not done so already, Manchester United may feel the time has come to stock up on supplies of silver polish. Last night they strutted 11 points clear of Arsenal in the title race, although on this evidence the difference between the best and the rest is more like several light-years.

Little more than two weeks after Liverpool showed that Old Trafford may not be impregnable after all, any shred of hope proffered by United's first home defeat in two years can be consigned to the garbage bin. Sir Alex Ferguson will deny it until he is purple in the face but this victory, after the most pivotal week of the season to date, means the championship is almost a foregone conclusion.

That 1-0 reverse to Gérard Houllier's side was always likely to be more of a seasonal splutter than the first symptoms of a more serious ailment, and in all likelihood it should have no greater consequence for United now than becoming an irksome statistic.

Any momentary twinge of unease felt by England's premier club has been calmed by the foibles of their rivals. Leeds and Chelsea have proved as durable as the Millennium Dome. Liverpool's defeat of Southampton yesterday does not camouflage the fact that they still lack a winning mentality. Arsenal's defeat at Charlton epitomises their festive torpor, and United will not regard either Sunderland or Ipswich as credible challengers.

For that, Ferguson rarely looks beyond Highbury and even though the United manager is not one for public fanfares - "complacency does not win points," he preaches - a seventh title in nine seasons is becoming a case of when rather than if. "If we were to let it slip now it would be really embarrassing," he admitted.

At times United touched exhilarating heights, particularly in the first half, when Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's third-minute strike and Stuart Pearce's own-goal did scant justice to their superiority. West Ham are not pushovers but when Solskjaer gave United the lead before most of the visitors had worked up a bead of sweat they were staring down the barrel of their 11th consecutive defeat at Old Trafford.

Not once but twice Rigobert Song commited the cardinal sin of surrendering possession on the edge of his own penalty area. He was rescued in the first instance by Pearce's clearing header, but when the ball came back to Song a second time Solskjaer took it off his toe with the stealth of a pickpocket before driving an instinctive shot of unnerving precision inside Shaka Hislop's right-hand post.

Song partially made amends when he cleared a Dwight Yorke header off the goalline midway through the first half but by then West Ham's players bore the bewildered look of a rabbit dazzled by headlights. A juggernaut's, at that.

Ryan Giggs had a thunderous effort tipped over by Hislop, and David Beckham twice went close to doubling the lead with a couple of long-range specials. In this mood the England man could probably chip the ball into a teacup.

On 33 minutes the inevitable arrived, albeit in freakish circumstances. This time another sweeping move culminated in Phil Neville crossing from the right. Pearce thrust out his left leg but the ball spun off his foot and dribbled beyond his own goalkeeper.

Before half-time there could, perhaps should, have been more, United's every attack sending West Ham's defenders scattering like warthogs disturbed by a prowling cheetah. In front of another record Premiership crowd - 67,603 - this particular new year's hunt was hardly likely to be called off after the interval and, sure enough, United's superb approach play was rewarded again on 57 minutes. Roy Keane supplied the cross and Dwight Yorke's diving header did the rest.

With Paolo di Canio crying off with flu, West Ham's threat was negligible before Frédéric Kanouté headed in Pearce's corner in the 70th minute. They were flattered and Harry Redknapp was not fooled. "United are frightening," he said. "Others have spent £80m but there's no one near them." Can Arsenal recover as in 1997-98? "Not a chance."

Whether United's plutocracy is a good thing for the Premiership remains open to debate but for those in their slipstream the depressing reality is that it likely to get worse before it gets better. On Thursday Jaap Stam, Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole should all return from injury in a friendly at Wrexham. As 2001 is ushered in, the rest of the Premiership should be worried. Very worried, indeed.
