webTitle: Pressures build for rich and poor alike in the new boom towns

fields.headline: Pressures build for rich and poor alike in the new boom towns
fields.trailText: The town of Reading is booming. From the enormous Oracle shopping mall in the centre, heaving with sale bargain hunters, to the 180 acre GreenPark development in sight of the M4, where new offices are rising, it is impossible to avoid the signs of success. Unemployment is nil, wages are high and life, it seems, is sweet.
fields.body:
The town of Reading is booming. From the enormous Oracle shopping mall in the centre, heaving with sale bargain hunters, to the 180 acre GreenPark development in sight of the M4, where new offices are rising, it is impossible to avoid the signs of success. Unemployment is nil, wages are high and life, it seems, is sweet.

In the last 10 years the Thames Valley corridor has become Britain's own silicon valley with Reading at its heart. Formerly famous for its jail, the town is now home to IT giants such as Compaq, Microsoft, and shortly Cisco Systems.

Every silver lining has a cloud, however. According to concerned local MPs the Berkshire town is facing a "crisis of prosperity", an unforeseen flipside to the growth of the last 10 years. Reading is facing recruitment problems among nurses, police officers, teachers and bus drivers. Its infrastructure is sagging under the weight of traffic and, crucially, a housing shortage is pricing the low paid out of town.

The pattern, now familiar in London, where demand for housing has driven the cost of living beyond the salaries of those in the public sector, is being repeated to the west.

The prosperity problem is seen as so severe that the town's MPs are lobbying against new jobs. The imminent arrival of Cisco has caused disquiet, with Jane Griffiths, MP for Reading East, questioning whether there are the people to fill the jobs. A one bedroom flat in Reading starts at £80,000, with two bedroom houses closer to £130,000. These prices may be affordable for an IT graduate on a salary of £25,000, but they are beyond the reach of a nurse on a salary of £16,000.

James Walthall, 30, is a charge nurse at the Royal Berkshire hospital. With a degree and 11 years' experience, his salary is at the top end of the nursing scale - £26,000 - yet it is impossible for him to live within 15 miles of the hospital. Instead he commutes from Didcot, Oxfordshire, a 50 mile round trip.

"It costs around £200 to get to work each month, but there's no choice," he said. "My wife and I bought a three bedroom house in Didcot three years ago for £87,500. A similar property in Reading would cost around £160,000. We wouldn't get the mortgage."

Mr Walthall estimates that 55% of his nurses face a similar predicament, a problem which is causing a shortage of nurses.

"They try to make up the shortfall with overseas recruits - we recently recruited in India - but unless there's some sort of weighting we just won't get the staff."

The problem is more marked among the town's firefighters. While there is no shortage of potential recruits few of them live near their station. Of the six members of red watch at Whitley Wood station, less than a mile from Green Park, only one lives in Reading.

David Wilson, the watch commander, commutes daily from Alresford near Winchester, Hampshire, an 80 mile round trip, and his deputy travels from the Isle of Wight for the four days out of eight he works.

Mr Wilson said: "There's a couple of lads from Portsmouth, one from Barnstaple, and I've heard of lads coming down from Northampton and Lincoln and crashing with their mates. It is impossible to live here on a firefighter's wage."

With national pay deals failing to take into account differences in the cost of living, said Mr Wilson, public sector workers suffered from a topsy-turvy version of the north-south divide in which those from prosperous regions were penalised.

The phenomenon is repeated across the public sector. Reading schools are testing a scheme to offer teachers from south Wales accommodation with local teachers, subsidising their travel and rent. Thames Valley police have had to deal with new recruits leaving for another force as soon as they have qualified. Meanwhile, 120 bus services have suffered cancellations in the past year because of a lack of drivers.

But according to Manda Rigby, director of marketing for Cisco, Reading will continue to appeal to companies looking to expand away from London.

"The area has fabulous transport links with the M4 and the railway and it is not far from Heathrow. It may bring problems at the moment, but it is an investment in Reading's future. If there was not full employment I don't imagine that MPs would be complaining."

webTitle: Prosperous old capital strains against its boundaries

fields.headline: Prosperous old capital strains against its boundaries
fields.trailText: Unemployment has fallen to an all-time low. House prices are soaring, with prime city centre properties fetching over £1m. Developers are queuing for every available piece of land to accommodate new businesses and a fast-expanding population.
fields.body:
Unemployment has fallen to an all-time low. House prices are soaring, with prime city centre properties fetching over £1m. Developers are queuing for every available piece of land to accommodate new businesses and a fast-expanding population.

While most British and some European cities are shedding people and jobs, Edinburgh is out-performing them all to become the fastest growing centre in the UK, topping most quality of life surveys.

So successful has the city become in attracting financial and high technology companies that, in common with south-east England, it is experiencing a shortage of workers.

New figures show that Donald Anderson, Labour leader of Edinburgh council, can boast that in many respects the city's economy is healthier than London's.

Unemployment, at 2.7%, is half the London level, down by three-quarters in four years. Mr Anderson recently reported that youth unemployment, the plague of other cities, is no longer a problem in Edinburgh. In the 16-24 age group, only 27 had been out of work for more than a year.

Buoyed by the prestige of a parliament and a strengthening financial centre second only to the City of London, the Scottish capital is poised for its biggest expansion since the creation of its 18th century Georgian new town, with its elegant terraces and circuses.

With its population projected to rise by 50,000 to 490,000 in the next 14 years - and the likelihood of 25,000 new jobs in the next four years alone - land in a redesignated green belt has been earmarked for a 21st century "new town".

The wedge between the Craigmiller housing scheme and Dalkeith, Midlothian, a joint venture between the city council and a local developer, could house 20,000 by 2020. With schools, shopping centre and modern transport links to the city, the 1,400 hectare (3,500 acre) area underlines the pressure facing the city.

Edinburgh is designated a world heritage site and thus protected from rash development, so there is precious little building land left. As a result, demand is growing for the release of more green belt. "There is not a patch of land which developers do not have an option on, so we are trying to consolidate expansion to protect the rest of the city," said Mr Anderson.

"We don't want to lose the big attraction of Edinburgh that you can be in open countryside after driving just 10 minutes from the city centre."

To maintain a level of prosperity which has brought Edinburgh a new financial district in its west end - helping to swell funds under management to £350bn - the city will increasingly have to look beyond its borders for workers.

Last month plans were unveiled to reopen part of a railway line linking Edinburgh with the Scottish Borders - emerging commuter territory - which closed 30 years ago. Councillors hope the line could reopen by 2008, under a public-private partnership, after the Scottish parliament passes a special order.

While talk of a Scottish "home counties" might be premature, businesspeople and councillors in Edinburgh believe more commuting will be needed to service the growing economy. Many people are being priced out of the housing market, while 20,000 are on the council waiting list for rented homes.

Simon Fairclough, marketing director of the Edinburgh Solicitors Property Centre, said: "Builders are selling off the drawing board." Some properties in the new town go for over £1m.

Ray Perman, chief executive of Scottish financial enterprise, said many big institutions were moving to Edinburgh. "They have seen overheating in London, and the difficulty of getting good quality people...English money is moving up here."

webTitle: Labour faces rebellion on home sale packs

fields.headline: Labour faces rebellion on home sale packs
fields.trailText: The government faces a backbench revolt on the first day of the new parliamentary term next week when Labour MPs protest against plans to require people selling their homes to obtain a "seller's pack" which could cost between £300 and £400 to produce. Michael White reports
fields.body:
The government faces a backbench revolt on the first day of the new parliamentary term next week when Labour MPs protest against plans to require people selling their homes to obtain a "seller's pack" which could cost between £300 and £400 to produce.

MPs with constituencies in areas of economic and social decline - including the midlands and the north of England - fear that the idea will alienate voters who are struggling to find buyers for properties worth only £10,000 or less, often burdened with negative equity.

"This legislation was drawn up by civil servants who commute to London from Sevenoaks," one MP said. "Unless it is improved it will backfire in predominantly Labour areas."

The purpose behind such a pack is to help both buyers and sellers to speed up the process and prevent gazumping. Faster surveys and searches - provided in the pack - would result in quicker negotiations and completions.

Gazumping is again common in the booming south-east of England, but inconceivable in poorer areas - where some homes in decayed terraces have been on sale for years - beset by job losses, drugs and vandalism.

Many of these homes were bought from local councils or the old national coal board at discount prices in the Thatcher era. Then their new owners saw values slide as communities declined.

The issue was raised at the last pre-Christmas meeting of the parliamentary Labour party, too late to alert many MPs who will be asked to vote on the second reading of the homes bill next Monday, the day they return to the Commons.

The bill, delayed from last year, contains two distinct halves, one to restore the duty on local authorities to tackle homelessness, the other to help the housing market by speeding sales.

Ministers in John Prescott's environment department believe that they must also devise strategies to regenerate neighbourhoods hit by decay. They want to tackle unemployment and crime as well as housing problems.

MPs involved in the coalfield communities campaign, like Mick Clapham, MP for Barnsley West and Penistone, and Llin Golding, MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme, are said to be concerned - as is Bolsover's Dennis Skinner - that vendors will not want to spend £300 on a seller's pack when they have little hope of getting the money back by selling at a price that includes it.

Another potential rebel, Joe Ashton, MP for the old mining constituency of Bassetlaw, on the Notts-South Yorkshire border, argues that the solution will be to amend the homes bill to exempt houses in council tax band A, worth below £50,000. He said yesterday that Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, was sympathetic to the suggestion.

webTitle: US: The 26th banished word list

fields.headline: Why dot.coms and chads had to go
fields.trailText: It may be an impoverished country, a man's name or even dimpled and pregnant, but whatever it means, Americans are fed up with it.
fields.body:
It may be an impoverished country, a man's name or even dimpled and pregnant, but whatever it means, Americans are fed up with it.

Chad, which came to national prominence after the November 7 presidential election, was the runaway leader of the 26th annual banished word list, compiled by the Lake Superior State University and published yesterday.

Hundreds of people sent in suggestions for words that should be banned because of "mis-use, over-use or general uselessness". And, after hearing endless discussions of how a tiny slip of paper should or would influence the presidential election, Americans made their feelings clear on the word "chad".

Mike Warner of Anchorage, Alaska, said: "We've heard it 12 times an hour on the news. Chad has gotta go."

Another political phrase that failed to connect with voters during last year's marathon elections was "fuzzy math", the less-than-clear term offered by George W Bush during the televised debates.

Words and phrases to be outlawed in previous years include "free gift" in 1988 and "live audience" in 1983, 1987 and 1990. Last year's list tried to exile the much misspelt "millennium" as well as "wake-up call" - a favourite among politicians around the world.

Other words to have received a no-vote in 2000 included dot.com, which followed a dislike for "e-" anything the year before.

Words which originated among the youthful denizens of America's west coast also began to annoy fellow citizens during a year when fewer people were making any money there.

"Dude" - which featured in a slacker film "Dude, where's my car?"- was also on the 2000 list of most hated words.

In entertainment, "diva" was also rated as most overused. Jennifer McGraw, of Brevort, Michigan, complained: "I thought it was bad when I heard Madonna described as a diva. Since then, I've seem promotions for shows on male divas and transvestite divas."

Other phrases on this year's list include: "Have a good one", "One of the only", and "Manual recount by hand".

But at least no one in America is saying: "You are the weakest link. Goodbye!" The popular British quiz show has not crossed the Atlantic - yet.

webTitle: Sponsorship and nursing

fields.headline: Sponsorship and nursing
fields.standfirst: The Royal College of Nursing is to produce new guidelines on nurse sponsorship as worries grow about the expansion of commercial activity within the profession.
fields.trailText: Analysis: The Royal College of Nursing is to produce new guidelines on nurse sponsorship as worries grow about the expansion of commercial activity within the profession.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing is to produce new guidelines on nurse sponsorship as worries grow about the expansion of commercial activity within the profession.

The guidelines will cover not only sponsorship of nursing posts but also the ethics of accepting freebies such as T-shirts and biros or of taking up free study trips paid for by commercial companies.

The sponsorship of stoma nursing posts is the most controversial example of these public-private "partnerships" but in recent years, sponsorship has also been extended into continence nursing, epilepsy, Parkinson's disease, MS and many other chronic conditions.

The aim of the guidelines, which are expected to be agreed early next year and will go to all trusts as well as college members, is to clarify what is and is not acceptable, and to stamp out some of the worst excesses of past sponsorship deals.

In stoma nursing these have included offering inducements to nurses such as company cars, mobile phones and even free air miles. One manufacturer ran a loyalty card scheme complete with free gifts for patients who stuck with its products.

In another case, one of the companies bidding for a sponsorship deal reportedly offered a trust £100,000 a year - £40,000 of which would pay for a stoma care nurse while the trust would be free to spend the remaining £60,000 however it wished.

Partly as a result of these abuses, many sponsorship arrangements in other areas of nursing aim to keep nurse and sponsor at arm's length.

Innovex NHS Solutions is a health organisation, largely funded by drug companies, which employs a large number of nurses in chronic disease management such as MS and obstructive pulmonary disease.

But although drug companies are the "sponsors", they have no direct influence on the nurses themselves. Innovex admits some companies have tried to push it "over the line" but it has successfully resisted these pressures.

In a different model, the Parkinson's Disease Society has linked up with drug companies to fund a total of 100 Parkinson's disease nurses around the country.

The idea is that they provide pump priming for these specialist nurses over a period of two years, at the end of which it is hoped the trust will pick up the tabs. As a result 57 nurses have now been assimilated into the NHS.

The drug companies gain from such schemes, says RCN nursing policy and practice adviser Sue Thomas, because the disease is getting a higher profile and prescriptions are being dispensed to patients who might otherwise not have been identified.

At the same time the health service benefits because none of these posts would have existed without sponsorship. "In the past many patients with chronic disease had a very poor service," said Ms Thomas. "We can't get away from the fact that sponsorship has helped to bring very real benefits - and we wouldn't want to lose them."

Julia Breeze, who chairs the RCN gastroenterology and stoma care nursing forum, is also clear about the symbiotic nature of the relationship: "We need the companies just as much as they need us."

Ironically, at a time when sponsorship in general is growing, there is now a real threat that some companies could withdraw their funding of stoma care posts - a trend that has helped concentrate minds among both nurses and patients.

The threat has emerged because the Department of Health is looking to cut back on the money stoma companies currently earn from their dispensing service.

Such a move, warns one of the main patients' groups, the Ileostomy Association, would almost certainly lead to a sharp fall in sponsorship deals.

Said association secretary Bruce McKenzie: "I don't care who pays for the nurses, I just want to make sure they're there. They make such a big difference to our lives. Our fear is that if these people go the effect on patients will be massive."

webTitle: A brief guide to NHS sponsorship

fields.headline: A brief guide to NHS sponsorship
fields.standfirst: The Department of Health has published the following case studies to guide staff on how to deal with offers from commercial sponsors.
fields.trailText: The Department of Health has published case studies to guide staff on how to deal with offers from commercial sponsors.
fields.body:
A clinician wishes to include a new drug, manufactured by a company with which he has links eg. company shares, research grant, in the trust formulary.
Trust committee (eg drug and therapeutics committee) should require declarations of interest from clinicians submitting proposals for new products to be added to formularies and ensure the decision is based on clinical and cost effectiveness information.

A pharmaceutical industry representative wishes to present the case for a new product being included on a trust formulary.
The trust should establish and adopt a reasonable policy on approaches from industry representatives. Industry representatives should be required to sign up to compliance with such a policy before being given access to any meetings.

An offer from a company to provide for training of staff.
Employers should be careful to ensure that staff are not pressurised by sponsors of training to alter their own activity to accord with sponsors' wishes, where these are not backed up by appropriate evidence. Training provided by industry may be above board if it is unbiased, has mutual benefit for both the NHS and the sponsoring company, is evidence based and the hospitality is appropriate. However, participants should assess whether they may be influenced unduly and also bear in mind what benefits the company might derive (eg exposure to NHS, professional contacts, potential allies to use later, names of who to influence) often without the participants realising.

A manufacturer of ostomy equipment offers to sponsor a stoma nurse post in an NHS trust.
The trust should not accept the sponsorship if it would require the stoma nurse to recommend the sponsor's (products) in preference to other clinically appropriate appliances, nor if it requires the trust to recommend patients to use a particular dispensing service or withhold information about other products. Existing contracts containing any such provisions should, where possible, be urgently renegotiated.

A manufacturer of a particular type of nicotine replacement therapy offers to provide their product at a reduced rate to a health action zone or a health authority.
This arrangement is acceptable provided that there is a clear clinical view that these products are appropriate to particular patients and there is no obligation to also prescribe these products to other patients for whom an alternative product would be at least as beneficial.

A pharmaceutical company offers to provide starter packs at a discounted price.
This type of sponsorship is acceptable, but should always be declared in order to avoid any suspicion that subsequent prescribing might be inappropriate and linked to the provision of starter packs.

A catering company offers to provide discounted products to an NHS trust.
This agreement is acceptable, but should be routinely declared to the health authority.

A high tech home health care provider offers to supply equipment at reduced rate in return for business linked to a specific product.
Health authority contract negotiators should advise the company that any contract will not prejudice the provision of the most appropriate service to patients, and will not bear any relation to other contracts.

A manufacturer offers to pay the travelling costs or accommodation costs for clinicians invited to a conference to view medical products.
Only clinicians with a specific interest in the products should attend and the travel costs incurred should be paid for by the trust, unless the chief executive/director of finance gives approval for the potential supplier to take responsibility for the costs. Such decisions should be taken at least at director of finance level.

webTitle: Millions in health sponsorship under threat

fields.headline: Millions in health sponsorship under threat
fields.standfirst: New guidelines on NHS sponsorship issued by the Department of Health could lead to the termination of contracts worth millions of pounds between health trusts and outside companies.
fields.trailText: Analysis: New guidelines on NHS sponsorship issued by the Department of Health (DoH) could lead to the termination of contracts worth millions of pounds between health trusts and outside companies, writes Andrew Cole
fields.body:
New guidelines on NHS sponsorship issued by the Department of Health (DoH) could lead to the termination of contracts worth millions of pounds between health trusts and outside companies. The guidance lays down a number of principles for future sponsorship arrangements but the bottom line is clear: outside money should never dictate what is best for the patient.

And it goes on to warn that any existing sponsorship contracts that fail to meet these standards should be renegotiated.

That move could be accompanied by the sound of the ripping up of contracts across the NHS because it is clear that the central motivation for much health sponsorship is to get preferential treatment for a particular company's product.

In stoma care, for instance, more than 60% of the country's 600 stoma nursing posts are now financed by the stoma care companies.

The nurse will still be employed by the trust but the contracts will offer the company some tangible benefits in return for its investment - an investment which can be worth as much as £100,000 each year.

Some contracts, for instance, stipulate that a certain proportion of patients treated should be fitted with the sponsoring company's stoma bag.

That proportion is often more than 50%. That can be very big money indeed for the manufacturer since once a patient is fitted with a bag they may be using that product - along with a range of accessories - for life.

Julia Breeze, who chairs the Royal College of Nursing gastroenterology and stoma care nursing forum, recalls how when she was a sponsored stoma nurse, the sponsoring company complained that only 30% of her patients were going home with the company's products and that the figure must be increased.

She resisted successfully, but has no doubt other nurses are put under similar pressures and that in some cases they succumb.

The other common way in which sponsoring companies can recoup their investment is by inserting a clause in the contract that stipulates they should be the sole dispenser of any stoma care equipment to the patient in their home.

This may be small print but it is big business because it entitles them to 25% of the cost of each item dispensed - money that the NHS forks out on top of the cost of the product.

The new guidelines suggest this would no longer be acceptable and says such clauses should be urgently renegotiated.

Although Ms Breeze remains uneasy about sponsorship, she says stoma services cannot survive without it. "We are a very expensive commodity and the money isn't there for us otherwise - there are so many competing needs in the NHS these days," she said.

Stoma care nursing may be the biggest target for sponsorship but it is by no means the only one.

Continence care and a number of chronic conditions such as Parkinson's, MS and inflammatory bowel disease have attracted the attention of manufacturers and drug companies who can see big advantages in teaming up with clinicians.

RCN nurse adviser Susan Scott believes the pressures are likely to increase now that nurses have some prescribing powers. The only way forward is to be completely open about the process and to be clear the patient's interests must always come first.

"The absolute bottom line is that any nurse has got to use her clinical judgement knowledge and skill to ensure that the product or service is the right one for that patient," said Ms Scott.

British Healthcare Trades Association director Ray Hodgkinson says the industry probably now regrets ever having got involved in sponsorship in the first place.

"If a company goes into sponsorship it must be trying to influence its sales," he said. "But the problem is it can create issues of conflict of interest between commercial and clinical considerations."

So might they start backtracking? That's not easy, says Mr Hodgkinson, partly because many sponsorship deals have been initiated not by the companies but by the NHS itself.

Indeed he is aware of many tendering processes where trusts ask the bidders to propose sponsorship tie-ups as part of their tender.

It all shows just how complex the world of health sponsorship has now become - and how difficult it is going to be to disentangle.

webTitle: January 2 Media Briefing

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Big corporations and governments are moving to curb the protests of 'cyber hippies' who want to make the net a corporate-free zone. P3
Liquid News presenter Christopher Price has netted a £250,000 deal to stay at the corporation as the BBC gears up to put the bulletin at the heart of its BBC3 schedule. P7
The new Moroccan president has dashed hopes of a new liberal regime with a press crackdown. P11
The French are hoping to create a virtual rival to Lara Croft with Eve Solal, a new cyber-character. P12
The meltdown in tech stocks has failed to deter investors, with twice as many companies floating in 2000 as 1999. P17

THE INDEPENDENT

Commercial broadcasters, including Disney, Nickelodeon, ITV and Fox Kids Network are uniting to lobby the Culture secretary, Chris Smith, to block the BBC from launching new children's channels. P5
The BBC Castaways have left the island full of praise for the project. P7
WH Smith is expected to confirm this week that it is to abandon plans to launch a national distribution network for magazines. P11

MEDIA SECTION
Vogue.com editor-in-chief Abigail Chisman explains why the magazine's site is making a profit. P8
Why Hollywood bible Variety is changing the way we speak. P8
Economist journalists are facing a difficult transition in the move to a televised version of the famously anonymous journal. P8

THE TIMES

The stars of the BBC's Castaway programme will leave the Hebridean island of Taransay today after a year. P3
The new head of the National Trust wants to rebrand the organisation in a less elitest mould. P2
Dome bosses nearly cancelled its New Year's Eve party because it was seen as tarnishing the project's image. P5
MTV presenter Troy Hartman, known for his daring TV escapades, was forced to land his aircraft in a Las Vegas street when its engines failed. P17
The prospect for IPOs looks set to remain sluggish over the coming months, according to a KPMG analyst. P23
Andersen Consulting has rebranded itself as Accenture, at a cost of over $175 m. P24

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Online retailers have managed to buck predictions for a sales slump, with preliminary figures from Amazon.com suggesting the retailer doubled sales over Christmas. P2

webTitle: Crackdown on NHS sponsorship

fields.headline: Crackdown on NHS sponsorship
fields.trailText: The NHS is to crack down on sponsorship deals in which commercial firms pay for health service staff and equipment in exchange for "endorsement" of their products, amid fears that such arrangements are compromising clinical judgments.
fields.body:
The NHS is to crack down on sponsorship deals in which commercial firms pay for health service staff and equipment in exchange for "endorsement" of their products, amid fears that such arrangements are compromising clinical judgments.

The move could lead to the tearing up of thousands of contracts worth millions of pounds every year to the NHS, and which help pay for specialist services which otherwise might not be provided by the health service.

Such sponsorship deals are often connected to the care of chronic conditions such as continence nursing, epilepsy, Parkinson's disease, and multiple sclerosis, but are also used as a marketing tool by suppliers of products such as prosthetic hips.

The crackdown will dismay some patient groups because it will potentially threaten the provision of services.

New guidance forces NHS trusts to review all agreements in which suppliers meet all or part of the cost of certain staff members, provide discounts on drugs and equipment, or subsidise research and training, in return for contracts.

Ministers do not want to prevent "collaborative partnerships" with private sector suppliers, but want to ensure that such deals "should always be based upon clinical evidence that the product is best for their patients".

The guidance expressly outlaws deals whereby sponsorship is linked to the purchase of particular products, or use of a particular supplier - although there is evidence that many trusts are tied in to such contracts.

More than 360 of the UK's 600 nursing posts dedicated to stoma care - treatment following bowel surgery such as colostomy - are financed by the suppliers of stoma bags in deals worth up to £100,000 per year to a trust.

According to the Royal College of Nursing, some stoma deals stipulate that a certain proportion - as much as 50% - of patients treated at a particular trust should be fitted with the sponsoring companies' stoma bag.

Some deals stipulate that the sponsor should be the sole dispenser of stoma care equipment to the patients at home - a non-skilled distribution job that is worth up to 25% of each item bought by the NHS.

Julia Breeze, who chairs the Royal College of Nursing gastroenterology and stoma care nursing forum, said it would be difficult for many trusts to pull out of sponsorship deals without threatening services.

"We are an expensive commodity and the money isn't there for us otherwise - there are so many competing needs in the NHS these days," she said.

Ray Hodgkinson, director of the British Healthcare Trades Association, admitted that sponsorship was used by firms as a way of increasing sales. But he added that many such deals were initiated by the NHS itself.

A recent house of commons public accounts committee report revealed that five NHS trusts had admitted to auditors that their choice of artificial hip supplier was influenced by the "incentives" on offer, including free equipment and research funding.

The Royal College of Nursing is to produce its own guidelines on sponsorship in the next few weeks in a bid to stamp out unnaceptable sponsorship deals. It said stoma company "inducements" to nurses have included company cars, mobile phones and free air miles.

webTitle: Refugees pour back to London

fields.headline: Refugees pour back to London
fields.trailText: Britain's system for dealing with asylum seekers is in complete disarray after the collapse of attempts to disperse potential refugees around the country. By Martin Bright and Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
Britain's system for dealing with asylum seekers is in complete disarray after the collapse of attempts to disperse potential refugees around the country.

Local councils and refugee groups have warned Ministers that asylum seekers in their thousands are drifting back to London after dispersal, or are simply choosing to remain in the capital or the south east without any money for housing.

The compulsory dispersal system was introduced with a fanfare last April to ease the burden of supporting asylum seekers on a few councils in these areas. It was designed to house 65,000 people across the UK by next April.

But the latest figures from the Home Office show that only 9,340 have so far been dispersed, despite generous financial incentives for private companies to find empty properties, and the removal of all money for accommodation from those who fail to comply. Home Office officials told The Observer that the target has now been cut to 36,000.

The North West and Yorkshire have each taken 2,500 people, still well short of their targets of 6,000. But in some areas the figures are even lower. The South West has taken only 209 asylum seekers under the scheme and, so far, only nine people have been sent to Wales.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the British Refugee Council, said asylum seekers were rejecting dispersal in droves because they are often sent to sink estates where they are too frightened to venture outside their homes.

'Many asylum seekers are giving up their right to accommodation and squeezing into already cramped conditions with relatives so they can reach proper legal support, pursue their claims with the Home Office or simply feel safe,' he said.

'To ensure the dispersal programme works, asylum seekers need to feel confident that their basic needs will be met and that they are not at risk of racial harassment.'

The collapse of the dispersal programme comes as the Government braces itself for record asylum applications. Attempts to toughen the system by introducing a compulsory voucher system have done nothing to deter people. Up to November, 70,215 asylum seekers had entered the country. With a further 7,000 expected in December, this year's total is set to far exceed the 71,000 who arrived in 1999.

The Government also faces criticism over the rising cost of asylum. By next April this will have risen to £694 million, an increase of 18 per cent over last year.

Steve Hitchins, leader of Islington Council in London, said: 'I don't know a single council in London that doesn't want this problem dealt with humanely, but the money to deal with it has to come from central government. The Government believed that if they made life hard for people when they arrived in Britain, word would get back, and they wouldn't come here in the first place. They have been completely wrong.'

Amanda Sebestyen, of the Asylum Education and Legal Fund, said: 'People are just being shunted into places where there is no one qualified to help them. Because of this many have no chance of getting asylum, even though they have a clear-cut case.'

She said government claims to have cut the backlog of asylum applications to under 70,000 were boosted by a 40 per cent rise in the number rejected for not filling in their forms correctly.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes, whose Southwark constituency is home to many asylum seekers, said: 'The Home Office must take responsibility for what is going on and recognise that dispersal just has not worked. There is huge pressure on London boroughs and housing services are already stretched beyond capacity.'

A Home Office spokesman insisted last night: 'We have yet to feel the deterrent effect of many of the measures we have put in place.' The backlog of asylum seekers awaiting decisions on their applications was being reduced.

'The numbers [of asylum seekers entering the country] were increasing before we enacted these measures. They could have been much higher if we had done nothing.'

The crisis has led the Government to draw up secret plans to house increasing numbers of asylum seekers in prisons. At the beginning of December, Home Secretary Jack Straw ordered the creation of 500 new places in prisons, including Liverpool and two London jails.

webTitle: Barak casts doubt on Arafat peace bid

fields.headline: Barak casts doubt on Arafat peace bid
fields.standfirst:
Further violence in Gaza Strip as Palestinian leader heads to US for talks with Clinton
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
Further violence in Gaza Strip as Palestinian leader heads to US for talks with Clinton
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak said today that he doubted Yasser Arafat was serious about reaching a peace deal soon, as the Palestinian leader arrived in Washington for talks with the US president, Bill Clinton, on US proposals for an agreement.

Meanwhile in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian man was killed and seven were wounded by Israeli troops in two separate shootings, and two Israeli soldiers were hurt by roadside bombs detonated near two Jewish settlements.

Israeli troops have tightened their six-week blockade of Palestinian towns after 40 Israelis were hurt yesterday in a car bombing in the coastal town of Netanya.

Israel also closed the Palestinian airport in Gaza and shut down border crossings between Gaza and Egypt and between the West Bank and Jordan. In Gaza, soldiers closed three main thoroughfares today, in effect cutting the strip in half.

The continuing violence complicates prospects that a peace deal can be reached before Mr Clinton leaves office on January 20.

Mr Arafat is heading to Washington today for a meeting today with the US president to discuss Mr Clinton's outline for a peace deal, proposed on December 23. The two leaders spoke by phone for about 45 minutes yesterday, and Mr Barak also spoke to Mr Clinton.

Mr Clinton's proposals include asking Israel to surrender sovereignty over a Jerusalem site revered by both Muslims and Jews, and asking Palestinians to renounce their claim of the "right of return" of 4m Palestinian refugees and their families.

Mr Arafat's spokesman, Nabil Aburdeneh, described Mr Arafat's trip as "a decisive visit at which the future of the peace process will be determined".

Israel has accepted the US ideas in principle, though with some misgivings. The Palestinians have raised concerns about the fate of Palestinian refugees and the extent of Arab control over parts of Jerusalem, and have sought clarifications from Mr Clinton.

Mr Barak today accused Mr Arafat of wasting time. "President Clinton has three weeks left, and it's unlikely an agreement will be reached in the last three days or week of his term," the prime minister told Israel army radio.

"Since Arafat has wasted most of this time in dragging his feet ... we have very serious doubts about the seriousness of his intentions to reach an arrangement."

Mr Barak said that the Netanya bombing showed that Mr Arafat and his Palestinian Authority were encouraging anti-Israeli violence.

All contacts between Israel and the Palestinians had been cut off, he said. There was now "a greater possibility of a general deterioration, and the [army's] general command needs to be ready".

Official talks broke down after violence broke out three months ago. The bloodshed has killed 357 people, the vast majority Palestinians.

Today, Palestinians detonated bombs close to Israeli army positions near the Jewish settlements of Dugit and Kfar Darom. Two soldiers were wounded, the army said.

Near Dugit, Israeli troops fired at Palestinian farms in response to the explosion, killing 52-year-old Sabri Awad Khader, who was working in his fields, Palestinian security officials said. The army confirmed that troops had opened fire, but said it had no knowledge of a farmer being killed.

Near the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, seven Palestinians were wounded when soldiers opened fire on them from a jeep, Palestinian hospital officials said.

Before agreeing to the Washington trip, Mr Arafat declared his people would continue to resist what he called Israeli aggression.

webTitle: Palestinians lose out in the war of words

fields.headline: Palestinians lose out in the war of words
fields.standfirst:
As he checks the region's news sites for information on the bloody conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, Derek Brown finds a glaring disparity in the state of the media on both sides

Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As he checks the region's news sites for information on the bloody conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, Derek Brown finds a glaring disparity in the state of the media on both sides.
fields.body:
Periodically, you will find on this site a review of the Middle East papers, intended to give an insight into the thinking behind the grisly events in the region.

Clearly, one aim of such a review must be to present a balance of views. That, alas, is an uphill task - but an instructive one.

To put it bluntly, Israeli websites are slick, coherent, plausible and up to the minute. Arab websites are all too often littered with broken links, shrill propaganda, lame reporting and are maddeningly out of date.

An important qualification here: we are talking only about anglophone websites, and not taking account of Arab language - or Hebrew - sites.

But it's fair to say that the disparity in quality of English language output reflects pretty accurately the same disparity in the vernacular media.

Take the two principal English daily newspapers in Israel, the stridently hawkish Jerusalem Post and the more liberal Tel Aviv-based Ha'aretz.

Both contain comprehensive reportage, lively commentary, and a service of breaking news. A similar service is provided by the excellent fortnightly news magazine, Jerusalem Report, which also has high-quality, in-depth reporting on both sides of the conflict.

There is simply no equivalent on the Palestinian side. Indeed, the only regular English language paper there is the Palestine Times, published monthly and containing mostly strident anti-Israeli rhetoric.

The Palestinians now have their own Palestinian Ministry of Information, which struggles to provide even a basic English language service.

Its daily summary of the Arabic press headlines was last updated on December 4.

Elsewhere in the region, there is a surprising lack of urgency in coverage of the crisis.

Papers like the Khaleej Times and the Gulf News, carry copious reports, virtually all of them compiled from Western news agencies.

The editorial line is strongly pro-Palestinian, of course, but their calls for a strong and united Arab response are more ritualistic than convincing.

There are brighter spots in the narrow spectrum of the Arab media. The Jordan Times, published on Israel's doorstep, has a distinctively sober line in its reportage and comment columns, and is generally - though not invariably - up to date.

And the Dubai-based Arabia.com site site offers a comprehensive spread of news and features from throughout the region.

In general, though, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that Israel's overwhelming advantage in firepower is matched by its enormous superiority in wordpower.

webTitle: Net tightens around the hacktivists

fields.headline: Net tightens around the hacktivists
fields.standfirst:
Big corporations and governments want to curb the protests of the cyber hippies

Net news
Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText: Big corporations and governments want to curb the protests of the cyber hippies, writes Tania Branigan.
fields.body:
Rocketing numbers of political campaigners are embracing the internet with the fervour their parents showed for sit-ins as they try to claw back its independence and make online actions a standard part of modern protests.

Computer activists - "hacktivists", as they have become known - are squaring up to governments and corporations who want to restrict their activities. They are not opposed to business, but their immediate political aims, which range from improvements in working conditions to political independence, are fuelled by anger at the commercial dominance of cyberspace. Their tactics range from sending straightforward emails of complaint to crashing websites or diverting visitors to different sites. Some have overwhelmed servers with email "bombs" of thousands of protest messages or launched computer viruses and worms.

In the US election both Republican and Democratic sites were defaced with anti-Bush and anti-Gore sentiments, while the Middle East conflict has been fought almost as heatedly online as in the real world. Palestinian and Israeli computer users have defaced websites, set up spoof sites as propaganda and even stolen the credit card details of their enemies.

Ingenious

But so far hacktivism has been dominated by social justice and leftwing issues, with the far right using the internet only to organise and recruit. In one case campaigners diverted visitors seeking the Ku Klux Klan site to hatewatch.org instead; public reaction is likely to be very different when someone tries to do the opposite.

That day may come sooner rather than later, as new programs make it easy for activists with little computer knowledge to enter systems or crash a website. These newcomers have joined the original hackers: highly skilled and ingenious programmers who share a distaste for authority and belief in freedom of information. Some are malicious; most see their hobby as a technical challenge; and increasingly, many are investigating its political possibilities.

"People don't like the way the internet is increasingly commercialised," says Paul Taylor, a sociologist at Salford University who has written a book on hackers and is currently researching hacktivism. "Comparisons are made with the land enclosure acts - who owns common land? There are a lot of insidious ways in which corporate power has increased and is pervading the whole social fabric. It's happened within the structure of the internet; big corporations have got an advantage over governments and their values are getting incorporated into government policies."

Underlying tensions are coming to a head with the advent of new legislation and information-gathering techniques. In Britain, the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act has given the police and security services the power to collect internet data without a warrant and to demand the keys to encrypted material. In the United States, the FBI is seeking the right to capture all messages sent across the internet with software called Carnivore. This would allow them to trawl for emails containing particular words.

In both cases, the authorities insist that the measures are essential to combat international crime and terrorism. But others worry that they will be used to monitor and discourage legitimate political activity and will ultimately ensure that only "acceptable" voices are heard on the net. Hacktivists fear that politicians, often lacking technical expertise, will be easily swayed by business.

"The prime minister of this country, by his own admission, gets most of his information on the internet from his kids," says Paul Mobbs, co-founder of the UK-based Electrohippies. "Politicians don't know the first thing about it."

He fears that individuals may be driven off the net because they have no rights to access. They are dependent on internet service providers who, for commercial reasons, are likely to refuse to host material that is controversial or which could attract expensive legal action and who could block users requesting certain sites.

"E-commerce has driven the internet over the past few years. Anyone who's not part of that is not supposed to be there," Mr Mobbs complains. He acknowledges the damage that some hacktivists have caused and accepts the need for policing. But he also says security forces and businesses are scaremongering and believes that the RIP Act and Terrorism Act are a dangerous combination.

"These new laws, rather than enabling free use of the internet by all, are seeking to blur the distinction between public protest, crime and terrorism in order to provide a 'safe environment' for corporations to do their deals," he says. "The British government is seeking to define a 'virtual corporate free state' where corporations can do business free from public pressure."

What delights the protesters - but worries their opponents - is that the internet acts as a magnifying glass for discontent. Individuals using computers can wield power they could never command on the street: it takes dozens, maybe hundreds, to occupy a building and unveil a banner but only one to hack into a computer system and take over a website. One person can bring down an e-commerce site, disrupting or halting a firm's trading.

Oxblood Ruffin, of the respected hacker group Cult of the Dead Cow, suggests that the versatility and technical knowhow of protesters offers them a chance to redress imbalances of power in the real world: "Hacktivism allows us to mount better arguments, rally unseen allies, and take on any tyranny," writes Ruffin, who is based in Toronto. "It shrinks any Goliath down to his true size. Usually puny.

"Where a large physical mass is the currency of protest on the street, or at the ballot box, it is an irrelevance on the internet. Or more correctly, it is not always necessary ... To think that it takes a lot of people to execute an act of civil disobedience on the internet is naive. Programs make a difference, not people."

For that reason, detractors argue that hacktivists are a classic example of power without responsibility. But unlike the original hackers many are happy to discuss their actions openly: Mr Mobbs publishes his address and phone number on the web. The Electrohippies informed the World Trade Organisation before launching an attack on its website in November 1999, and ensured that their own site linked to sites supportive as well as critical of the organisation.

They debate their tactics with passion and sophistication, citing Aristotle, Thoreau and Lord Acton. Many, like the Electrohippies, refuse to access other people's computer systems and regard denial of service attacks as a last resort. Oxblood Ruffin goes further and insists they are unforgiveable: "Denial of service attacks are a violation of the freedoms of expression and assembly," he insists. "You do not make a better point in a public forum by shouting down your opponent. Say something more intelligent or observe your opponents' technology and leverage your assets against them in creative and legal ways."

It seems inevitable that many of the protesters' tactics will be outlawed. Dr Taylor agrees that some measures may be needed, but suggests that we have overreacted, encouraged by security specialists who have a clear commercial interest in playing up the threat to worried businesses and who may mislead the public with their real world analogies.

One firm described the Electrohippies as "terrorists" for their WTO action. Yet the Electrohippies refuse to intrude into computer systems. "I think we have really twisted values," says Dr Taylor. "In the Kosovan war the Pentagon was scared of using cyber warfare in case it was a war crime - but they bombed civilians. It seems to me that it's quite skewed values by which 1,500 lives are less relevant than the legal elements of cyber war. People talk about the Tamils sending email bombs to the Sri Lankan government, but surely that's better than real ones."

He predicts that a "cat and mouse" game will ensue as talented hackers find new ways to protest every time governments ban an old tactic. Oxblood Ruffin, one of the most technically advanced of the hacktivists, is currently working on a complex program that could mark the next significant stage in online activism: it focuses on giving people a tool rather than criticising or disabling opponents.

Project X, which should be completed by next summer, will enable users around the world to access websites normally blocked by their governments - such as human rights sites - without attracting attention. Ruffin, who has recruited leading underground programmers to assist him, believes it could jump-start a new movement of politically aware hackers.

"We are trying to keep the internet healthy. The hacking community has been online the longest, outside the military and academia, and we have something to say about how the internet develops."

Weapons of online warfare

Denial of service attack One of the most popular methods of attacking websites. Users run a program that makes thousands of requests for a site simultaneously, slowing the speed at which the server fetches pages or in some cases crashing the server totally so that the target site - and others hosted there - cannot be accessed

Mail bombing Inundating an email address with thousands of messages, again slowing or even crashing the server. It inconveniences other server users and prevents the targets finding genuine messages in their inboxes

Defacing Changing the information shown on another person's website. It involves hacking into the target's computer system and is therefore illegal

Hijacking Redirecting anyone trying to visit a certain site elsewhere. Again, it is illegal because it involves accessing the target's computer system without their permission

webTitle: BBC Choice newsreader gets £250,000 deal

fields.headline: BBC Choice newsreader gets £250,000 deal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A little-known newsreader on one of the BBC's digital channels has signed a £250,000 deal to stay with the corporation, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
A little-known newsreader on one of the BBC's digital channels has signed a £250,000 deal to stay with the corporation.

The two-year deal given to Christopher Price, who fronts a daily entertainment news show on BBC Choice, will raise eyebrows at BBC News. But the head of BBC Choice, Stuart Murphy, wants to keep Mr Price as the channel evolves into the BBC's youth and entertainment network, BBC3.

Without such a deal, it was feared he would be poached as his profile grew.

The amount involved is not in the Trevor McDonald league, but compares well with the £150,000 that some of the new breed of newcasters at ITV are paid.

Mr Price, 33, presents Liquid News, a half-hour programme with a cult following. It is broadcast daily at 8.30pm, the heart of peak time, and will be the linchpin of the new channel's schedule. Mr Price is therefore likely to become a household name.

His acerbic style has caused ripples at BBC News - one show featured the comedian Scott Capuro and included banter on German pornography and allusions to under-age gay sex.

Attempts by other channels to produce entertainment news shows have met with mixed success. ITV's Celebrity! has not been well-received, and Channel 5's Exclusive was cut back from a daily to a weekly show. Liquid News, produced by BBC News and with its own reporters, is felt to have struck the right tone.

Mr Price began his BBC career in local radio, and joined Radio 5 Live's launch in 1994. He moved to BBC News 24, the rolling news channel, in 1997. As well as slots as a news presenter, he presented the nightly entertainment news show Zero Thirty, elements of which were transferred to Liquid News last May. Despite its potential for controversy, the show and its presenter have the backing of Mr Murphy and and executives at BBC News.

BBC TV news has found it hard to report showbusiness and entertainment on BBC1 bulletins, fearing accusations of dumbing down. Liquid News will get a cash injection and a makeover in the new year. Its executive producer, Chris Wilson, is involved in a plan to develop BBC3's national news, which is also aimed at a young audience.

webTitle: Number of boys held on remand doubles

fields.headline: Number of boys held on remand doubles
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 boys aged 15 and 16 have been remanded in custody in the past eight months despite a 10-year-old government pledge, enshrined in legislation, to end the much-criticised practice.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 boys aged 15 and 16 have been remanded in custody in the past eight months despite a 10-year-old government pledge, enshrined in legislation, to end the much-criticised practice.

Some 1,068 unconvicted boys under 17 were remanded to young offenders' institutions between April and November, more than double the 440 who were held on remand in 1992 when the practice was supposed to be phased out. About 300 of those held this year were aged just 15 and were remanded for an average of six weeks while waiting for their cases to come to court.

The practice of sending teenage girls to youth prisons to await trial was abolished in the early 1980s.

There has been concern for more than 20 years about the use of custody for such young boys, triggered by a series of scandals in young offender jails involving persistent bullying and teenage suicides.

The appalling conditions in which some unconvicted teenagers are held were highlighted recently by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, in his reports on Feltham and Portland young offender institutions and by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf's criticism last month of the "corrosive" atmosphere inside some youth jails.

The latest Home Office figures show that a pledge to phase out the use of custody for such teenagers, first made by the Conservative government in 1991 and repeated by every successive home secretary, has been left on the shelf. The promise was enshrined in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act which said that unless the boy was charged with a serious violent or sexual offence, or had a history of absconding, they should be held in local authority secure units. Ministers hoped to build extra units to ensure the practice was abolished by 1996. There are only 441 places in local authority secure units and the National Association of Probation Officers claims that their expansion has not been a priority for successive ministers.

But new figures obtained by Napo show that far from ending the scandal it is now twice as bad. Previous studies have shown that about 30% of those remanded in custody are held for serious violent offences such as robbery or for being involved in sex crimes. Most have been charged with burglary, stealing cars or other types of theft.

A recent study by the youth justice board has also shown there is wide inconsistency between magistrates' benches over their use of custody for teenage offenders.

Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the probation union, said: "Successive governments' records on remanding 15 and 16 year olds to prison custody is quite scandalous. It is now 10 years since the initial pledge was given to end the practice. The conditions are wholly unacceptable. Successive prison inspectorate reports have condemned the conditions in young offenders' institutions as being conducive to bullying, self injury and further crime. Ending the practice must be a priority after the next election."

webTitle: Ransom demand for stolen pictures

fields.headline: Ransom demand for stolen pictures
fields.trailText: Robbers who made off with three paintings by Rembrandt and Renoir from the National Museum in Stockholm have demanded "several million kronor" - hundreds of thousands of pounds - for the safe return of the stolen works of art, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Robbers who made off with three paintings by Rembrandt and Renoir from the National Museum in Stockholm have demanded "several million kronor" - hundreds of thousands of pounds - for the safe return of the stolen works of art, police said yesterday.

Police received several photographs of the stolen paintings, but police superintendent Leif Jennekvist said that the authorities were refusing to pay ransom money for the art.

"We have had a contact with a middleman at a certain stage and we have had a demand for payment," Mr Jennekvist said. "However, it is not our task to deal with stolen art and our attitude is that we do not negotiate about this with criminals."

Mr Jennekvist declined to specify how much money was demanded, saying only that it was "several million kronor".

The paintings have been missing since a man walked into the state-owned museum five minutes before closing time on December 22 and pointed a submachine gun at an unarmed guard while two people who were already inside snatched the paintings off walls.

webTitle: Heseltine calls for halt to sale of dome contents until deal is sealed

fields.headline: Heseltine calls for halt to sale of dome contents until deal is sealed
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Former deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine yesterday called for a halt to the sale of the contents of the Millennium Dome until the contract for its conversion to a business park had been sealed.
fields.body:
Former deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine yesterday called for a halt to the sale of the contents of the Millennium Dome until the contract for its conversion to a business park had been sealed.

Workmen have moved into the dome following its closure on New Year's Eve to strip the contents for an auction which it is hoped will raise £50m.

There was further controversy last night when it emerged that dome management and staff are to share bonuses that could total £3m.

Mr Heseltine, Conservative MP for Henley, and the minister responsible for dreaming up the dome project, said it was "madness" to strip the interior of the Greenwich building until it was certain it would not be reopened as a visitor attraction. The move was premature when the business park deal proposed by Legacy plc, which has offered £125m to buy the dome, had not been sealed.

He told the Times: "It's madness. They have not signed anything at all. Legacy has only got first preference.

"The government is weakening the option of someone else coming in, in the event of the Legacy bid failing, if they sell off all the internal assets."

A fellow former dome commissioner, Simon Jenkins, one of the attraction's most long-standing and vocal supporters, backed Mr Heseltine's call.

The contents of the 12 theme zones and the 2,000-seat stadium would be vital to an alternative scheme fronted by the dome's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, to keep the site open as a theme park by day and use it as a concert venue in the evenings, he said.

Legacy said: "We are confident our bid will succeed. We see no reason to change it."

On bonuses, a dome spokesman said that in almost all cases these were retention bonuses roughly equivalent to a month's salary.

For the six current and former executive directors the bonuses would be linked to performance. The New Millennium Experience Company board, meeting this month, would decide if they should be paid. "At this stage, none are expecting to receive anything like their theoretical maximum bonus," a spokesman said.

The only likely exception was Mr Gerbeau, whose bonus would be £50,000.

webTitle: Choosing a child's

fields.headline: Remember this?
fields.standfirst: Choosing a child's "big" school is a worryingly subjective business, says Sophie Radice
fields.trailText: Choosing a child's "big" school is a worryingly subjective business, says Sophie Radice.
fields.body:
It's been a gruelling few months for parents with children moving to secondary school next September. Most state schools and a fair number of independent schools have had their open days and parents' evenings in the last term with deadlines for applications at the end of December.

For many parents it has been surprisingly traumatic. Not only are they making a huge decision about their child's future, but they may have to face long suppressed feelings about their own school life.

While the experience of primary or prep school has become a distant, even rose-tinted memory (although I was put off sending my son to the primary school I went to because they still had the same school secretary and she was just as horrible to me as she had been when I was a child), few do not easily remember much of our secondary school experience.

Most of us know our duty as parents is to clear our minds and judge schools solely on whether they suit our children who are educated in systems which have changed considerably. At the same time, taking my 10-year-old son Louis round schools a year early (I had friends whose kids did not get into any of their chosen schools so I wanted to be prepared), it surprised me how hard it is not to let your own educational past colour your impression of a particular school or even a whole educational sector.

We went to see one comprehensive with a fantastic reputation, but because I went to a comparatively small school I could not get beyond the overwhelming size of the school. Robert Dunnington, 39, and his partner Rachel have looked around seven schools for their 10-year-old son in the last few weeks, ranging from a prestigious private day school to an comprehensive with unimpressive league table results.

"We have tried to keep a really open mind and have seen a wide range of schools so that we can compare them," says Dunnington. "We both went to comprehensives, although we had totally different experiences because Rachel lived in a rural area and went to an all girls' school.

"We tried not to be intimidated or over-impressed by flashy buildings and smooth rhetoric of the private schools nor to be too damning of the less glossy comprehensives. We told each other how much education has changed since we went to school.

"Nevertheless I went into a stuffy science class in one comprehensive where most of the pupils had their coats on and there was that awful, familiar smell of boredom and body odour. Nothing on earth could have persuaded me to send my son to that school."

This experience does not seem uncommon. The familiarity - or unfamiliarity - of a school can hinder a parent's ability to judge the school on its merits. Sara Lowry, 32, whose only daughter is in year six, admits: "I am adamant that Clara will not go to a single sex school. We haven't gone to see any girls' schools because I hated my girls' grammar school and worry that my attitude towards men has been horribly affected by that.

"But Clara seems very different from me and, of course, she might prefer it. Her father has offered to arrange to go round some girls' schools by private arrangement if she wants and I will try really hard not to be so hung-up on this issue."

Like Lowry, some parents seem determined not to send their child to anything remotely resembling their own "alma mater". Footballer Vinny Jones claimed he sent his daughter to a very expensive school so that she would mix with "posh people", whereas my parents did the opposite. Having gone to prestigious boarding schools, they knew they wanted something much more liberal and relaxed for their children.

Scratch the surface of a pushy parent desperate to get their child into the school with the best results - perhaps without considering other aspects of their child's all-round education - and you will often find someone who feels that they didn't do very well at school or that they were frustrated by being at a school or having parents who did not encourage them.

Hetty Einzig, research and development director at the Parenting Education and Support Forum, believes this is inevitable. "Of course, our past must influence our choice of school for our children. None of us can avoid drawing on our own experience, but being aware is the first step to managing those feelings and trying to put them to good use.

"For parents and children looking round secondary schools when they are used to the intimacy of a primary school, it can seem like a jungle. It is really important to include your child in the selection process and to discuss with them that there are different elements at play, such as your own responses due to your experience."

But many of those who had a positive school experience seem naturally to veer towards sending their child to the very school they went to. Petra Fried's daughter Lauren attends Camden School for Girls, of which she is an old girl. "I was affected by my own school days because they were very happy," she says.

"When we went round the school for Lauren I felt it was an even friendlier place, with quite a few of the same teachers. No doubt my enthusiasm affected Lauren, but I also felt that it would really suit her, even though she is different from me. I think she likes the continuity of me having been to the school."

Such continuity is more common in the private sector, where families put down their child's name at birth. Here some parents don't want to break tradition. Richard Harding, 43, says he was utterly miserable at his boys' boarding school but would still find it difficult to send his eight-year-old son anywhere else.

"It has made me resourceful and pretty tough. It would be too much of a leap away from my family's expectations to send him to any other type of school. Actually, his boarding school is a much better place now and I am secretly relieved."

Educational psychologist Sonya Hinton, author of a package for parents, pupils and teachers on the difficult transition to secondary school, says: "Parents should understand that the decision of 'which school' is not something that should be done on behalf of but with their child. The children will have anxieties of their own which will not be the same as their parents', and which have to be given significant weight, time and consideration.

"The way you handle this change from the familiar to the new and strange will deeply affect the way your child copes, not only with this leap forward but with the many changes in their lifetime."

webTitle: Teaching children to manage money

fields.headline: Cash benefit
fields.standfirst:
Lots of children will be given money for Christmas, but do they know how to manage it? Anne McHardy finds one group keen to teach them

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lots of children will be given money for Christmas, but do they know how to manage it? Anne McHardy finds one group keen to teach them.
fields.body:
Wendy van den Hende has one heartfelt thing to say about the charity of which she is director, the Personal Finance Education Group (PFEG), which offers financial education to the under-16s: "I wish it had existed while my children were still at school."

Her two sons are young adults, one at university, one finishing a postgraduate gap year, and so they are too old to have benefited from the addition of personal finance to the curriculum as part of personal, social and health education (PSHE).

University students face student loans, tuition fees, post-graduation debts of £12,000 as a norm, an uncertain job market, and increasingly sophisticated banking structures. That alone indicates why PFEG wants to make children financially literate.

Its target is not limited to any particular social or academic level. One area where PFEG material has been tested with impressive results is in three special schools in Surrey for pupils with moderate learning difficulties.

"Our society has large sections that are financially illiterate, completely excluded - 20% of the nation does not have a bank account. In England and Wales, 6% - and in Scotland 13% - have no access to financial provision, not insurance, not a savings account," says van den Hende. "We do not want that to continue. Everyone has the right to participate fully."

Even in wealthy households, the children may have little understanding. If everything is bought on credit cards - where the supermarket appears to give money with the groceries - the children may have little real knowledge.

"Sometimes those from families with less money are much more cash-aware than some of the ones where everything is done with credit cards," says van den Hende. "If you are living in a household where you have to get the card charged with cash before the electricity will work, then you have a direct knowledge of the relationship between cash and services."

Last year, financial competency was part of the national Maths 2000 project. From September, financial capability became part of PSHE at all the key stages of primary and secondary school. For key stages 3 and 4, at 14 and then at GCSE, the government has made financial education statutory, encouraging it to be taught across the curriculum.

While the aim is worthy, van den Hende explains, there was no obvious way for teachers to fit personal finance into an already crowded curriculum; nor were there reliable resources available. Where financial institutions offered resources packs, these came branded and with no guarantee that they would match the national curriculum.

The motivating force for PFEG came from the finance sector itself, led by the City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority (FSA), which has a statutory duty to provide financial education. FSA money and muscle are vital to PFEG, which was founded in 1998, but which has recently relaunched its website. Alongside the revamped website, PFEG is planning a £1.9m push to recruit 400 secondary schools, 10% of the country's total, by next spring.

In the 1999 project in Surrey, the number of pupils with an understanding of budgeting improved from 12% to 87.5%, and those with an ability to calculate disposable income rose from none to 50%, with a matching increase in key skills.

Jessica Clarke, a manager at the Surrey Education Business Partnership, part of a national network, was instrumental in setting up the scheme in the county. She contacted PFEG, inviting van den Hende's predecessor to meet the partnership and to help teachers set up individual projects.

Year 10 pupils in the scheme made and then sold a product: candles, cards or bird boxes. They then worked out budgets based on what they had earned. "It was really successful," says Clarke. "Students are more confident with numeracy, more ready to put their hands up."

Useful links

www.pfeg.org.uk
