webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText:
The third degree

•"God rest ye" is not a message that academics expect from the merry gentlemen of the Quality Assurance Agency, whose demands for lorryloads of paperwork are legendary. And it's not one that they will have received this festive season. The Christmas card from chief executive John Randall shows a weary don (see below) surrounded by piles of QA paperwork. (The Guardian should declare an interest here - it's a cartoon by our own wonderful Andrzej Krauze.) Is this what Randall means by a "lighter touch" regime?
fields.body:
The third degree

"God rest ye" is not a message that academics expect from the merry gentlemen of the Quality Assurance Agency, whose demands for lorryloads of paperwork are legendary. And it's not one that they will have received this festive season. The Christmas card from chief executive John Randall shows a weary don (see below) surrounded by piles of QA paperwork. (The Guardian should declare an interest here - it's a cartoon by our own wonderful Andrzej Krauze.) Is this what Randall means by a "lighter touch" regime?

A new language to cope with new technology is charted in the US-based Chronicle of Higher Education. Optimistic company sales patter about "plug and play" has already given way to the widespread practice of "plug and pray" on campus. Many a "technofeeb" on the staff has, it seems, begun to resent the overly helpful "back-seat mouser" who constantly shows them where to click or scroll. And both students and staff now suffer from "netlag", the physical condition described as jetlag with eyestrain.

Academics are also struggling to grasp the concept of the "web year", which is defined as: "About 90 days. Readily understood in Silicon Valley, the concept is just beginning to hit home with university officials who negotiate licensing agreements."

Kings College London is about to make itself popular with the music industry - but very unpopular with students. A spin-out company led by Mark Sandler, professor of signal processing, is marketing a new form of audio streaming technology called zerochain, which offers the potential for high-quality pay-per- listen. He says it offers a lifeline to an industry threatened by the public's ability to download music from the internet. With any luck, a student somewhere will be working out how to beat the new system and keep rock'n'roll free, man.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us:
donald.macleod@theguardian.com
lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News Pirates

Brand piracy is becoming an increasing threat to universities, warn solicitors Mills and Reeve. As distance learning and "webu-cation" expand, the qualities that make institutions attractive - high standards, excellent teaching, research and integrity - are also making them targets for pirates. Big multinationals have experience of the problem, but educational institutions are the "soft underbelly of the brand world," says the firm's Martin Goodger.

In its simplest form, e-brand piracy involves unauthorised use of a university's name on a pirate website. More sophisticated pirates are using names in "meta-tags" - used to attract search engines - and in hidden text on their home page. Internet users searching for the University of Poppleton, for example, may find themselves directed to a pirate site instead.

Register obvious variants of your name or brand as domain names, advises Goodger. It is possible to challenge pirates who have got there first, but court action can be expensive.

martyn.goodger@mills-reeve.com

Universe

Following a trend
American researchers conducting a survey into stalking on campus were surprised to find that 42% of the victims were men, in contrast to the general population, where almost four in five reported cases are against women. The study of "obsessive relational intrusion" at Rutgers University and University of Pennsylvania has divided academics - are young women becoming more aggressive, or is over-reporting trivialising the more serious dangers to female students? "In my experience, men report because it's a damn nuisance - women report out of a primal fear," said Stephen M Thompson, sexual assault services coordinator at Central Michigan University. But some believe that many male students fail to report incidents for fear of seeming weak.

Full story in the Chronicle of Higher Education: www.chronicle.com

Research news

Diminishing returns
A new world ranking of economics departments makes gloomy reading for Brits and confirms the growing alarm about our failure to compete with US institutions in the "dismal science". The London School of Economics makes it into 16th place, behind 15 Americans. At least it has the satisfaction of pipping Oxford (19th) and thrashing Cambridge (33rd) in the league table compiled by Tom Coupé of the Université Libre de Bruxelles, who provides an explanation of his ranking system on http://student.ulb.ac.be/~tcoupe/ ranking.html.

Uprooted
The Amazon rainforest has been expanding southward in the past 3,000 years because of increased rainfall and solar radiation, Leicester University geographers reported in the journal Science.

webTitle: Nato intervenes to get Serbian hostages freed

fields.headline: Nato intervenes to get Serbian hostages freed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato is being dragged into a low-intensity war waged on Europe's hottest border, as ethnic Albanians in southern Serbia seek to join UN-administered Kosovo and separate from Serbia.
fields.body:
Nato is being dragged into a low-intensity war waged on Europe's hottest border, as ethnic Albanians in southern Serbia seek to join UN-administered Kosovo and separate from Serbia.

The latest demonstration of Nato involvement in the buffer zone with Kosovo - officially part of Serbia, but controlled by Kosovan Albanian rebels - comes after rebels snatched six Serbian hostages there on Sunday.

The captives were released yesterday after intensive diplomatic efforts by Yugoslav and Nato authorities, and were said by Serbia's deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic, to be "in good shape".

Tension rose further on New Year's Eve when villagers raised the Albanian flag in Veliki Trnovac - which sits right on the fringe of the buffer zone. Nato sent two peacekeepers into sovereign Serbian territory, in a move which calmed the situation but was in direct breach of the technical-military agreement signed after the Nato bombing.

The six Serbs were taken from their cars at the Mucibaba checkpoint as they entered the buffer zone from Kosovo. The rebels then gave Belgrade a three-day deadline for the release of 120 Albanian prisoners held in Serbian jails.

Serbia's prime minister designate, Zoran Djindjic, who was in southern Serbia when the kidnapping took place, said earlier that the US ambassador, William Montgomery, had given assurances to him that the six Serbs would be released and had called on the Serb police to exercise restraint. The US diplomat condemned the hostage-taking as an act of extremism.

The rebel acts did much to undermine confidence-building measures that K-For, the Nato-led Kosovo peacekeeping force, had brokered to rebuild trust between the Serb and Albanian communities.

The day before the incidents, K-For won an agreement between Serbia and the ethnic Albanian rebels for both sides to remove checkpoints and pull back from their positions in Veliki Trnovac.

The moderate Albanian mayor of Presevo, Rizim Halimi, said: "After yesterday's agreement, this is not good. This can only harm our relations."

Despite technically having no right to operate in southern Serbia, K-For is increasingly acting as a liaison point for Serb and Albanian forces over troubles in the Serbian zone.

According to the agreement signed after the bombing, K-For should not go beyond the administrative border and only lightly armed Serbian police are allowed into the three-mile buffer zone.

New Year's Eve was the first time K-For peacekeepers are known to have been deployed in Serbian territory. According to a local source, the soldiers celebrated New Year with the Albanians of Veliki Trnovac, in order to ease tensions.

The K-For liaison over the six recent hostages mirrors a role it played last month when four Serbs were snatched on the same road. K-For also ensured the return of bodies after rebels killed four Serb policemen in the buffer zone in an assault in November.

Ten days ago, a rebel commander in the buffer zone said he wanted K-For to take over control of the three municipalities of southern Serbia that the rebels call eastern Kosovo.

Commander Lleshi said: "In the Yugoslav and Serbian constitution there were rules for all the rights of minorities to be respected. But these were practically eliminated. So we want a monitoring mission and K-For here."

webTitle: Dozens feared dead in Turkish shipwreck

fields.headline: Dozens feared dead in Turkish shipwreck
fields.trailText: At least six people drowned and 45 were missing, feared dead, after a cargo ship carrying illegal immigrants split in two and sank yesterday off the southern Turkish resort of Kemer.
fields.body:
At least six people drowned and 45 were missing, feared dead, after a cargo ship carrying illegal immigrants split in two and sank yesterday off the southern Turkish resort of Kemer.

Six crew members, including the Greek captain, and 26 passengers were rescued, said Can Karaca, the coastguard commander who was in charge of rescue efforts. The captain was detained for questioning.

Many of the missing were believed to have been locked in a cargo unit in the sunken half of the ship. "There is little hope of finding them alive," said Mr Karaca.

At least 83 people - 10 crew members and 73 passengers - were on board the Georgian-flagged Pati when it suffered a mechanical failure and drifted on to rocks in a storm early yesterday, said Ertugrul Dokuzoglu, governor of the Antalya region. He said more people may have been on board.

"Prosecutors have begun an investigation into where these people were picked up and who organised it. The ship left Antalya harbour registered as empty," he said.

All the passengers were illegal immigrants trying to make their way to Greece. Survivors identified them as Pakistanis, Moroccans and Bangladeshis. Mr Dokuzoglu said Indian and Afghan refugees were also believed to be on board.

An official of the shipping company which had hired the vessel said the ship had left Antalya bound for Greece. The crew was composed of Greeks, Albanians, Indians and one Georgian. AP

webTitle: Setback for first Taiwan-China trip

fields.headline: Setback for first Taiwan-China trip
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: High winds and lashing waves yesterday forced a Taiwanese tourist boat to cancel a trip to China that would have been the first legal direct voyage between the longtime rivals for more than 50 years.
fields.body:
High winds and lashing waves yesterday forced a Taiwanese tourist boat to cancel a trip to China that would have been the first legal direct voyage between the longtime rivals for more than 50 years.

Fifty-one passengers had boarded the boat, Hai An, on the Taiwanese-controlled island of Quemoy - just a few miles off China's coast - with hopes that their trip would help start a new era of exchanges. But about half an hour after setting sail, the boat returned to port.

"We can wait five more minutes to sail over but we can't wait another 50 years," said Hsu Der-lin, an engineer who live on Quemoy.

The boat's return immediately sparked unconfirmed reports in the local media that China had suddenly decided not to allow the boat to sail to its final destination, the southeastern port city of Xiamen.

A Chinese official in Xiamen also said he doubted that the weather was really to blame, saying he believed the trip was halted for political reasons. Neither Taiwan nor China wanted a private group to inaugurate direct links, he said.

But the boat's captain, Hong Ya-di, insisted that the trip was cancelled because of unsafe conditions. He rescheduled the voyage for January 8.

Today, two more boats plan to sail to China. One will carry a delegation led by Quemoy's county commissioner to Xiamen, while the other boat's passengers are Buddhist pilgrims visiting a temple.

webTitle: Media bans dash hopes for Morocco

fields.headline: Media bans dash hopes for Morocco
fields.trailText: When Mohammed VI succeeded Hassan II as king in July 1999 there were hopes of a more liberal climate in Morocco.
fields.body:
When Mohammed VI succeeded Hassan II as king in July 1999 there were hopes of a more liberal climate in Morocco.

The new king set himself the task of loosening the authoritarian regime he inherited from his father, who earned a reputation as a despot in the 1970s.

Expectations rose higher as Mohammed began work on pushing through an educational and judicial reform programme tabled by his prime minister, Abderrahmane Youssoufi, a secular socialist who had spent years in exile.

But last month Mr Youssoufi launched a savage attack on the press, banning outright three weeklies, including the independent French language publication Demain, published in Casablanca. Its editor, Ali Lmrabet, received death threats.

Mr Lmrabet founded his weekly in 1997 and it quickly achieved a reputation for its fearless reporting. Its comparatively long survival was probably due to the fact that it is published in French rather than Arabic.

Although the bans on Demain and the two other publications, Le Journal and Assahifa, an Arabic-language weekly, were said to have been implemented because of a political story threatening "the stability of the country", the action against Demain was in fact almost certainly motivated by its exposure of a huge drug smuggling conspiracy involving senior political and judicial figures.

Assahifa and Le Journal were banned after they revealed a political - albeit rather historical - scandal. In 1972, the minister for defence, General Mohammed Oufkir, staged an unsuccessful coup against King Hassan. Last month, the two weeklies published a letter from a former opposition leader, Mohamed Basri, claiming that Mr Youssoufi was aware of the plot.

Relations between the government and monarchy in Morocco are delicate, and the government response was savage.

Demain did not publish Mr Basri's statement. It merely commented on the story, as did other publications, although its cover did pose the question: "Did he plot against the monarchy?"

But revelations of political and judicial involvement in the drug trade sealed its fate.

"Why was Demain banned?" Mr Lmrabet asks in an unpublished editorial in his banned publication which has been obtained by The Guardian.

"Did the information on the drug trade which the magazine has been disseminating for some weeks have something to do with it?"

Demain claimed there was "a strange channel which allows criminals, convicted by the courts and sought by the police, to appear before a judge in Tétouan [said to be the centre of drug smuggling] and be absolved in three minutes".

Mr Lmrabet claims that a recent anti-corruption campaign had been organised to protect the interests of "certain figures involved in national high finance, still untouchable".

Demain was about to publish taped conversations between drug dealers, revealing connections with high-ranking figures in Morocco and Spain. "Names to make you shiver," Mr Lmrabet said. "Those whose rank protects them from judicial pursuit."

Speaking from Casablanca, Mr Lmrabet said that he had been forced to let 15 of his 20 staff go. "We and the other editors tried to start a new journal but our applications were turned down by the king's prosecutor," he said. "This is totally illegal, the king's prosecutor does not have such powers. By law anyone can apply to start a magazine and they are obliged to accept.

"What we have now is a repressive partnership between the army, the government and the king. To ban three journals in one stroke is unheard of in Morocco.

"I can't help laughing at this, but there is nothing really to laugh at. Now they are throwing all kinds of accusations at me. They said I worked for the Spanish secret service and then, because I ran an interview with Binyamin Netanyahu when he was prime minister, that I worked for Mossad [Israel's secret service]."

webTitle: Hugo Young on Labour's election strategy

fields.headline: Mr Blair must resist the urge to be more 'radical'
fields.standfirst:
What the voters want is a return to a politics based on principles

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: What the voters want is a return to a politics based on principles.
fields.body:
Not long ago, one of the prime minister's close advisers asked me about my election strategy. He reckoned that I had about 40 columns to write before polling day, and wondered how I planned to use them. The question takes its place in this reporter's lifelong journey around the gulf between the political and the journalistic mind. I pocketed the high-level confirmation that, barring accidents, May 3 is the appointed day, but confessed that I had not yet blocked out my personal pre-election game plan. I hadn't thought about it, and didn't expect to do so. The columnist lives from week to week, agenda-less in any calculating way. My zealous friend seemed startled, even reproachful, to hear it.

On the other hand, I begin 2001 crystal clear, for once, on the strategy he should be advising his master to pursue. A debate is buzzing in high Labour circles about whether to go into the election with a "radical", or what amounts to a conservative, manifesto. The answer sounds obvious. But it's not the right one. The issue is posed in the wrong way, and what this means is that the radical option should be avoided.

The connotations of radical are of course attractive. They speak to many Labour discontents, especially the belief that first-term Blair has not been radical enough. Radical is exciting, radical is confident, radical is affirmative, radical is creative, radical is confessional about the errors of the past. It postulates a ground-zero attack on the forces of conservatism. It may befit a government about to shed the protective coat of panic which has guarded it against follies that could jeopardise a fat second term.

But radical is a buzzword not a programme. The very asking of the question, one soon understands, concerns presentation more than substance. The issue is not about whether to produce, from an overflowing raft of radical alternatives, an arresting selection, but whether to frame the Labour manifesto as one of enormous radical excitement - or of responsible, even struggling, continuity. Radical is all about spin. The debate is thus in danger of deepening the very problem that has most blighted the first term, which is public scepticism about how many of the words ministers say can actually be believed.

Far from dissipating scepticism, an avowedly radical manifesto will increase it. More promises, more claims, more adventures into the quango-strewn excitement of novel government initiatives can attract, after the first term, only more mistrust. The government is rightly worried about a public that has turned off politics. But voters, rather than thirsting for another dose of inspirational novelty, will begin to reconsider their cynicism only if Mr Blair rectifies two different concerns: first, the lack of follow-through, and second the dilution of what one might call principle.

The government already has a core programme which is radical in its ambition if not its methods: the building of public services that befit the fourth strongest economy in the world. It started late. It mistrusted the support it would get from its new business constituency. It didn't provide the money. The gusher will only be opened this year, following ministers' belated rediscovery of certain old beliefs. They have now made a massive bet on public delivery of the services essential to a civilised society.

There may be important details yet to agree on how this should be done, especially in education budgets at all levels. But, in health and transport especially, the overwhelming issue is competence and richness in delivery. This will be exceedingly difficult to achieve. The state of much of the public sector, as ministers are well aware, is appalling. Far too many people at the bottom end of society live with their glasses, defying Candide Blair's questing optimism, a great deal worse than half-empty. What they need above all is unswerving follow-through on pledges the government has already made, with the resources it is at last beginning to apply.

This might be an unglamorous approach to the election. It is, in a word, conservative. It emphasises toil not spin. It affirms the traditional rather than the radical strain in the progressive make-up: but the tradition, in this case, which first-term Blair has already redefined. And there's a parallel need which mirrors the same impulse away from all-singing and blazing originality towards sober loyalties in which people can have trust.

Laying the ground for his second term, Mr Blair should revisit some Labour traditions, aka principles, whose neglect in the first term are a prime cause of his supporters' demand that he should now do better.

Equality is often cited as one such area of dereliction. Actually, this is overstated, mainly due to ministers' first-term terror of being found guilty of hammering the rich. Gordon Brown has done quite a lot for equality, always excepting an increase in income tax. Liberty, on the other hand, has been a casualty. No liberal principle has been safe. This was the government that crudely swept all protest off the streets, to make Jiang Zemin feel more comfortable and protect trade deals with China that depended on his pleasure. More pervasively, its contribution to the complexities of crime and punishment has been to abandon every doubt about prison, every restraint on judges, every sophisticated study of statistics, every subtle social analysis that any progressive politician once believed in.

Can one hope this was mere first-termism? Abandoning it, in the comfort of a second term, is something I'd be prepared to call radical. In Labour language, it's conservatively back to the roots. That should not just be Blair's strategy. On reflection, perhaps 40 columns have found their agenda after all.

webTitle: Man on BA Kenya flight 'not trying to crash plane'

fields.headline: Man on BA Kenya flight 'not trying to crash plane'
fields.trailText: A Kenyan student who almost caused a British Airways jumbo jet to crash is suffering from acute paranoia and was not attempting to harm any of the aircraft's 398 passengers and crew, doctors in Kenya said yesterday.
fields.body:
A Kenyan student who almost caused a British Airways jumbo jet to crash is suffering from acute paranoia and was not attempting to harm any of the aircraft's 398 passengers and crew, doctors in Kenya said yesterday.

Paul Kefa Mukonyi, 27, had been suffering from paranoia since November and dashed into the cockpit of the Boeing 747-400 flight from Gatwick to Nairobi last Friday because he felt threatened by other passengers, said Dr Frank Njenga, a consulting psychiatrist at Nairobi hospital.

"We are of the very firm belief from his story that at no point did our patient contemplate the hijacking or doing harm to anyone," Dr Njenga said. "When everybody was settling down [in the aircraft] he felt completely crowded ... and he said people in front and behind were threatening him. He ran toward the front of the airplane ... believing people were in hot pursuit."

The Kenya-bound British Airways flight survived two violent nosedives over Sudan after Mr Mukonyi burst into cockpit and struggled with the co-pilot.

Mr Mukonyi was restrained with the help of the captain and passengers close to the cockpit. During the two-minute fight, he disengaged the autopilot, causing the plane to plummet around 19,000ft. The plane later landed safely.

Mr Mukonyi, who is receiving medical attention in Nairobi hospital for his mental illness, is unaware of the disaster he almost caused, his doctors said.

"All he remembers is somebody hit him on the back [and] somebody put a finger in his eye. When he came to, he was so frightened," said Dr Dan Gikonyo, another consulting physician. "To him, he was the one who was in danger."

Since November, Mukonyi had believed he was being followed and spied on by a group of people - mostly of north African Arab origin - in Lyon, France, where he had been studying tourism since September 1999. He had been awarded a French government scholarship.

His illness could have been brought on by the stress of exams, Dr Gikonyo said.

Mr Mukonyi kept a diary of his fears and on at least three occasions reported his concerns to French police. The police said they could not help because he had no physical injuries or proof that he was being followed. As his fears increased he felt that he must escape to Kenya.

Dr Njenga said it would be wrong to blame anyone for letting the Kenyan fly because prior to the flight all those involved in the evaluation of Mr Mukonyi, whom he described as a "very bright young man," were security personnel.

But he added, "there were many opportunities in the weeks and days preceding this incident when an alert security person could have said there is something wrong with this person and we will not let him board".

Mr Mukonyi contacted police at Lyon airport before flying to London, believing he was still being followed, and told security personnel at Gatwick that he was scared to fly, the doctors said.

At Gatwick, Mr Mukonyi was given a security escort to the aircraft and told "The safest place you can be is in the aircraft," Dr Njenga said.

It is not clear whether charges will be brought against Mr Mukonyi, but his doctors said that in his current state he is not fit to stand trial. However, doctors believe that with the correct medication he would make a full recovery.

British Airways said it was reviewing in-flight security following the incident. The cockpit door is normally locked during takeoff and landing but open during the flight.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bangladesh toll rises to 106 | Czech rebels in fight for airtime | Rock threatens Alpine homes
fields.body:
Bangladesh toll rises to 106

The Bangladesh ferry disaster death toll rose to 106 yesterday after 41 more bodies were found. About 100 people are still missing. The overloaded boat sank on Friday after hitting another vessel in thick fog on the Meghna river near Chandpur, 60 miles from Dhaka.
Reuters
Dhaka

Czech rebels in fight for airtime

Rebel staff at state-run Czech TV called a strike yesterday in a fight for control of the air with their new chief, Jiri Hodac. They say he has political links and would interfere with the news. Mr Hodac denies any bias and is putting together bulletins with makeshift staff, but satellite and cable viewers can see "pirate" newscasts made by strikers.
Reuters
Prague

Rock threatens Alpine homes

Emergency services evacuated 300 people from their homes near France's border with Italy yesterday, fearing the collapse of a 500-tonne rock. It was not clear whether heavy rain or a recent minor earthquake had dislodged the massive boulder which was balancing precariously over a mountain tunnel east of Menton and above the houses of the evacuees.
Reuters
Paris

Cambodia bans right-hand cars

After years of warnings and delays, a ban on right-hand drive vehicles in Cambodia came into effect yesterday. The ban is meant to stem the tide of smuggled and stolen vehicles from neigh bouring Thailand where motorists drive on the left. In Cambodia, they drive on the right.
AP
Phnom Penh

Two killed in church attack

Two churchgoers died and dozens were injured when suspected members of an anti-Catholic cult hacked at them with swords and set them on fire in St Lucia. Four or five men carried out the attack at the Catholic cathedral in the island's capital, Castries, on New Year's Eve.
Reuters
St Lucia

Art thieves issue demand

Robbers who stole three paintings by Rembrandt and Renoir from the National Museum in Stockholm on December 22 have demanded hundreds of thousands of pounds for the return of the pictures. Police said they had had contact with a middleman. The paintings are government property and were not insured.
AP
Stockholm

webTitle: Australia's 100th birthday bash rekindles republican flame

fields.headline: Australia's 100th birthday bash rekindles republican flame
fields.standfirst:
Just 13 months after Australia voted not to ditch the Queen, the anti-monarchist tide is building again

Special report: Australia and the monarchy
fields.trailText: Just 13 months after Australia voted not to ditch the Queen, the anti-monarchist tide is building again.
fields.body:
Australia began its centenary celebrations yesterday with a dawn ceremony at Uluru, or Ayers Rock, and a spectacular parade as 500,000 people lined the streets of Sydney.

Its 100th year as a nation will be marked by events including a centenary Test match, a politicians' cycle ride and, in tribute to the bewhiskered men who drew its colonies together and wrote its constitution, a founding fathers' beard-growing competition.

But the celebrations of Australia's 1901 federation will also be the target of a renewed campaign for the removal of the Queen as head of state.

The prime minister, John Howard, said the Australian achievement of the last 100 years had been massive: "We've gone through depression, we've gone through enormous changes of mass migration, we've gone through the challenges of modernisation and globalisation - and yet we do remain a very cohesive society."

Australia's 1901 agreement to federate followed a referendum and years of debate about the form of the nation's government. The form that was eventually adopted - a constitutional monarchy with Britain's head of state as its ceremonial ruler - was approved by an act of the British parliament.

The deputy chairman of the centenary celebrations, Rodney Cavalier, admitted the republican question would be one of the "dust clouds of distraction" during the £13m celebrations.

Australia narrowly rejected becoming a republic in a referendum 13 months ago when 55% of its voters backed the status quo. The Australian Republican Movement (ARM) predicted that a fresh plebiscite on the issue could come as early as 2003 and will use the centenary celebrations to relaunch its campaign.

ARM chairman Greg Barns said: "We have had 100 years of federation, but there is one thing we haven't done - we haven't severed the link with an institution which is outmoded even in Britain itself and bears no relevance to Australia."

Most observers believe that the political tide could turn against the Queen in Australia when the pro-monarchist Mr Howard is either defeated in this year's federal election, or retires mid-term, in 2003, as he has hinted he is likely to do. The prime minister's heir apparent in the Liberal party is Peter Costello, the treasurer and deputy leader, who vigorously campaigned for a republic during the referendum campaign.

The opposition Labour party is committed to a three-stage referendum, starting with a simple Yes-No vote, to bring about a republic. Its leader, Kim Beazley, has promised that Australia will be a republic by 2010 if Labour wins power.

But Australia's monarchists say that the republic question should not resurface in centenary year. It was settled "for the time being by a very clear vote", said Professor David Flint, convener of Australians for Constitutional Monarchy (ACM). "I don't think that the centenary is the time to bring it up. The centenary should be a uniting, not a dividing year."

Prof Flint said voters would give short shrift to any politician who attempted to push forward the republic issue again so soon after the No vote. "I think this may well be because the constitution is all working so well. It's like your motor car. When your car is working well you don't pull it apart and check on it, you leave it running."

The former prime minister Paul Keating, an avowed republican, famous in Britain for breaking royal protocol to pat the Queen on the back, is dismissive of that argument.

"That's a highly dangerous approach for Australia to take," he said. "Most things don't break. They just wear out, or cease doing what they are meant to do as well as they once did. Our national approach in the 21st century ought to be much more, 'If it's not performing as effectively as it can, then change it'."

webTitle: Appreciation: Colin Cowdrey

fields.headline: Appreciation: Colin Cowdrey
fields.trailText: Checking over personal cricketing memorabilia, I came across a handwritten fragment by Neville Cardus, from an article commissioned for the Guardian on Colin Cowdrey (Obituary, December 6).
fields.body:
Checking over personal cricketing memorabilia, I came across a handwritten fragment by Neville Cardus, from an article commissioned for the Guardian on Colin Cowdrey (Obituary, December 6). It refers to his first appearance in Australia in 1954.

Cowdrey, Cardus wrote, "is to make his bow before the crowd at the Sydney cricket ground, an enclosure as pregnant with history as Lord's (or Old Trafford), grandly and poignantly haunted by the shades of Victor Trumper, Charles Macartney, MA Noble. This unrazored newcomer had to face not only Australia's most critical watchers, but also, and not incidentally, an attack containing Keith Miller, Benaud, Simpson, Crawford and Davidson - the last- named not yet, but soon to become, one of the most gifted and lovely-to-see quick left-arm bowlers of any period.

"Facing such bowling, versus New South Wales, and facing a dangerous position for his team, the fresh aspirant scored 110 in his first innings and 103 in the second.

"In the third Test match of the rubber of this same tour of the novice's Test-match christening, England's first innings, at the game's outset, was well-nigh wrecked by Keith Miller. Melbourne was the scene; and Miller fiercely overthrew Hutton, Edrich and Compton for next to nothing. He nearly equalled SF Barnes's famous pre-lunch achievement, for at the interval, his figures were 9 overs, 8 maidens, 5 runs and 3 wickets.

"England's final total was a beggarly 191, of which the so-far anonymous tyro scored 102. Seldom has a Test match individual century halved the team's full innings' aggregate. The name of this just-beyond-teen-aged gallant was none other than Colin Cowdrey."

Two generations separated the men, but as Cardus would say, "Judge every man against the context of his times." For people at home, Cowdrey's performances, like those of Hutton, Tyson, Trueman, Bedser, Compton, Wardle and the rest, lit a grim winter. The pity is that he did not live to see the 2000 winter illumined, similarly, by Nasser Hussain's team.

webTitle: Old economy to make a comeback

fields.headline: Old economy to make a comeback
fields.standfirst:
All eyes on the lookout for dot.com dottiness, interest rate rises, the general election and a slowdown in the US

More net news
fields.trailText: All eyes on the lookout for dot.com dottiness, interest rate rises, the general election and a slowdown in the US.
fields.body:
When you are at the top, they say, there is only one way to go. And the stock market's performance last year certainly proved that old maxim. At virtually the very end of the old millennium - December 30 1999 to be precise - the FTSE 100 index stood proudly at 6,930 points, an all time high. It never hit that level again.

The boom in technology and internet shares came to a juddering halt, as dot.com dottiness followed the biotech boom and Dutch tulip fever into the dustbin of history. The Techmark 100 index has more than halved from a peak of 5,743 points in early March to its 2,564, in the wake of hefty falls on the US technology market Nasdaq, hit by a seemingly endless series of profit warnings from major and minor outfits alike.

This slump in so-called new economy shares was mainly responsible for bringing the wider market down. With little recovery in old economy companies to compensate, by the end of the year the FTSE 100 had fallen to 6,222 - a 10% drop over the 12 months. Private investors who believed the much hyped rise in share prices - especially in smaller, more volatile stocks - would carry on forever learnt a nasty and abrupt lesson. Many City institutions, fearful of missing out on the boom, also ended up with their fingers burnt.

All of which justified our decision this time last year to avoid trying to predict any winners for 2000. Our list of likely losers proved prophetic. Arthur Shaw, a window frames maker which reinvented itself as an online music business, was 18p a year ago. It now stands at 3.25p. Property group Bolton has fallen from 10.75p to 5.5p. Shell company Ronson has slid from 2p to 0.75p.

Dan Wagner's Dialog, after a traumatic year, has curtailed its ambitions, been renamed Bright Station, and has seen its shares drop from 91p to 23.5p (albeit that it touched 230p during the course of 2000). Internet investment group Jellyworks typified the fall from grace for dot.com incubators. The company, 111.5p when mentioned here last year as one to avoid, was sold to Shore Capital in an all paper deal valuing it at around 29p a share.

Then there was Knutsford. In some ways a symbol of the market's euphoria, Knutsford soared from nothing to a value of around £1bn in a matter of days. This was based on little more than the backing of four entrepreneurs - the so-called Awesome Foursome of Archie Norman, Nigel Wray, Nick Leslau and Julian Richer - whose ambition was to take over a large retailer.

Sainsbury and Marks & Spencer were among the names bandied about. In the end it all fell apart, and Knutsford bought a small US financial group no one had ever heard of. Now called WILink its shares - traded at 250p last January - languish at 4p.

What then of the year ahead? There are a number of uncertainties which are likely to influence the future direction of shares. Most analysts believe UK interest rates have peaked, and that the next move may be downwards. There is some debate however, as to when this might happen. Pessimists believe a cut will not happen until near the end of the year. A few die-hards are even forecasting a further rise.

But much depends on another key factor - a general election. Widely predicted to take place in May, the uncertainty over timing and outcome (although in truth not many people are betting against Labour getting back in) is likely to hang over the market. Added to that is the prospect of a pre-election Budget giveaway, which could have unintended economic consequences and cast a shadow over interest rate policy. On top of all that, there is growing talk of a slowdown in the United States which would drag down the rest of the world's leading economies.

Despite this, the general view seems to be that, even if technology shares do not again hit the heady heights of early 2000, there is likely to be a recovery in the previously overlooked old economy shares. In that event the FTSE 100 index could well end 2001 at a new peak.

So here are 10 companies to watch out for in the next 12 months, ranging from established names like House of Fraser and Cable & Wireless to more speculative stocks such as Systems Union.

Berkeley Homes

South-eastern housebuilder Berkeley, now at 755p, is likely to continue on its growth path. The company says its niche is providing top quality homes at reasonable prices (this seems to mean an average selling price of around £290,000) and it is still seeing plenty of buyers despite some evidence that the London market may be drifting lower.

Recent results showed a 24% rise in half-year profits to £75m, and it says it is on track to complete around 3,500 house sales in the current year which could give full-year profits of some £160m.

It recently sold a half-share of its upmarket Gunwarf Quays development in Portsmouth for £80m. The proceeds will cut its borrowings to around £100m, giving it plenty of scope to make further land purchases or even go on the acquisition trail.

Cable & Wireless

Cable & Wireless, 903p, is being valued by the City as if it were an incumbent telephone operator like BT or France Telecom. This used to be the case when it owned Hong Kong Telecom, but is far from the truth these days, since it has now turned itself into a fast growing internet services business.

Analysts say it should be rated closer to Energis and Colt. It is expected to sell off parts of its Optus operations in Australia, including the cable TV and mobile businesses, which should be received positively by the market.

After spending two and a half years disposing of unwanted divisions it has around £3.5bn in cash which will give it enough fire power to snap up technology assets at good prices.

The company is expected to make a number of smaller acquisitions to take it into highly rated areas like web hosting services. This leaves its shares looking undervalued.

House of Fraser

House of Fraser has suffered in the general gloom about retailers, and also from trading problems at a couple of its key stores. But it could be time for a bounce back.

The company has established brand names like Dickens & Jones, DH Evans and Army & Navy and, at its share price of 61p, it is well below its net asset value of around 100p a share. It also has a good dividend yield of around 9%, which should provide some support to the shares.

Its half-year profits were knocked to the tune of £3.5m due to refurbishment of its Oxford Street and Guildford stores, but the benefits of sprucing up these key sites should start to show through shortly. A lot depends on the crucial Christmas trading period, of course, but analysts are expecting profits of around £19m for the current year, up from £17.4m, and rising to £25m next year.

Jacobs Holdings

After a torrid time over the past 12 months, culminating in the disposal of its loss-making Ontime Logistics subsidiary, this should be the year that Jacobs Holdings (now at 30.5p) finally starts to deliver some performance to its long suffering shareholders. Not, perhaps, from any startling improvement in its core shipping and vehicle handling businesses, but from a realisation that fat property profits are on the horizon.

By moving its Dart Line ferry business from Dartford to P&O's newly acquired Shell Haven on the opposite bank of the Thames, Jacobs is freeing up its 60-acre freehold site for a joint redevelopment with P&O. With land values on the adjoining Crossways Business Park reaching £600,000 an acre, scope to speed up Dart Line's growth from its new home at Shell Haven, and even the prospect of profits from its residual interest in a large airfield site in Oxfordshire, Jacobs shares look set for a bounce.

Northern Recruitment

Northern Recruitment, which specialises in placing permanent and contract staff in the north of England and Scotland, issued a profits warning in November. It said it was suffering from several clients moving their recruitment plans to later in the year, which would hit its half-year figures.

But investors could do worse than follow the example of Midlands entrepreneur Bob Morton, who has built up a 9.25% stake in the business. Chief executive Lorna Moran holds more than 50% of the company so there is little chance of a hostile takeover.

Investors like Mr Morton, however, are attracted by the dividend yield of 6% and believe the company is likely to get back on track during the course of the year. At 45p the shares are a speculative recovery play.

Shire

Now a constituent of the FTSE 100 index, pharmaceutical group Shire spooked investors at the tailend of the year with a $4bn (£2.7bn) all share offer for Canada's BioChem.

There were suggestions the company had paid too much, and concerns about the amount of paper to be issued. But there were similar doubts when Shire acquired US group Roberts last year. Those worries were soon scotched and the deal seen as a valid one.

The same is likely to be true this time round. The track record of chief executive Rolf Stahel is likely to persuade investors of the merits of the BioChem takeover, and the deal continues the move to lessen the company's dependence on the hyper activity drug Adderall. Shire's shares now stand at £10.55, well off their 12-month high of £15.08, and look likely to stage a recovery.

Systems Union

The bursting of the technology bubble has not helped this internet and software group, formerly known as freecom. But some of its problems were self-induced.

When it floated at the end of 1999 it shares soared to more than 550p and it used its paper to make a number of acquisitions. These included accountancy software group Pegasus - subject of a three-way bid battle - and Oneview.net, an online business serving smaller companies. Unfortunately Oneview did not have the number of customers it had originally said, and investors treated the revelation harshly.

Chief executive Michael Williams later resigned, to be replaced by Paul Coleman. Mr Coleman has now disposed of the e-tailing side of the business, including Oneview and the freecom operations, to a management team.

Now it is focussed on software, and has become one of Europe's biggest accountancy software firms. It is cash rich, should have a turnover of around £90m next year and move into profit. There is also the outside chance of a bid from someone like Sage. At 70p, the shares are a reasonable bet on recovery.

The Techmark 100 index has more than halved from a peak of 5,743 points in early March to its 2,564, in the wake of hefty falls on the US technology market Nasdaq, hit by a seemingly endless series of profit warnings from major and minor outfits alike. This slump in so-called new economy shares was mainly responsible for bringing the wider market down. With little recovery in old economy companies to compensate, by the end of the year the FTSE 100 had fallen to 6,222 - a 10% drop over the 12 months. Private investors who believed the much hyped rise in share prices - especially in smaller, more volatile stocks - would carry on forever learnt a nasty and abrupt lesson. Many City institutions, fearful of missing out on the boom, also ended up with their fingers burnt. All of which justified our decision this time last year to avoid trying to predict any winners for 2000. Our list of likely losers proved prophetic. Arthur Shaw, a window frames maker which reinvented itself as an online music business, was 18p a year ago. It now stands at 3.25p. Property group Bolton has fallen from 10.75p to 5.5p. Shell company Ronson has slid from 2p to 0.75p. Dan Wagner's Dialog, after a traumatic year, has curtailed its ambitions, been renamed Bright Station, and has seen its shares drop from 91p to 23.5p (albeit that it touched 230p during the course of 2000). Internet investment group Jellyworks typified the fall from grace for dot.com incubators. The company, 111.5p when mentioned here last year as one to avoid, was sold to Shore Capital in an all paper deal valuing it at around 29p a share. Then there was Knutsford. In some ways a symbol of the market's euphoria, Knutsford soared from nothing to a value of around £1bn in a matter of days. This was based on little more than the backing of four entrepreneurs - the so-called Awesome Foursome of Archie Norman, Nigel Wray, Nick Leslau and Julian Richer - whose ambition was to take over a large retailer. Sainsbury and Marks & Spencer were among the names bandied about. In the end it all fell apart, and Knutsford bought a small US financial group no one had ever heard of. Now called WILink its shares - traded at 250p last January - languish at 4p. What then of the year ahead? There are a number of uncertainties which are likely to influence the future direction of shares. Most analysts believe UK interest rates have peaked, and that the next move may be downwards. There is some debate however, as to when this might happen. Pessimists believe a cut will not happen until near the end of the year. A few die-hards are even forecasting a further rise. But much depends on another key factor - a general election. Widely predicted to take place in May, the uncertainty over timing and outcome (although in truth not many people are betting against Labour getting back in) is likely to hang over the market. Added to that is the prospect of a pre-election Budget giveaway, which could have unintended economic consequences and cast a shadow over interest rate policy. On top of all that, there is growing talk of a slowdown in the United States which would drag down the rest of the world's leading economies. Despite this, the general view seems to be that, even if technology shares do not again hit the heady heights of early 2000, there is likely to be a recovery in the previously overlooked old economy shares. In that event the FTSE 100 index could well end 2001 at a new peak. So here are 10 companies to watch out for in the next 12 months, ranging from established names like House of Fraser and Cable & Wireless to more speculative stocks such as Systems Union. Berkeley Homes South-eastern housebuilder Berkeley, now at 755p, is likely to continue on its growth path. The company says its niche is providing top quality homes at reasonable prices (this seems to mean an average selling price of around £290,000) and it is still seeing plenty of buyers despite some evidence that the London market may be drifting lower. Recent results showed a 24% rise in half-year profits to £75m, and it says it is on track to complete around 3,500 house sales in the current year which could give full-year profits of some £160m. It recently sold a half-share of its upmarket Gunwarf Quays development in Portsmouth for £80m. The proceeds will cut its borrowings to around £100m, giving it plenty of scope to make further land purchases or even go on the acquisition trail. Cable & Wireless Cable & Wireless, 903p, is being valued by the City as if it were an incumbent telephone operator like BT or France Telecom. This used to be the case when it owned Hong Kong Telecom, but is far from the truth these days, since it has now turned itself into a fast growing internet services business. Analysts say it should be rated closer to Energis and Colt. It is expected to sell off parts of its Optus operations in Australia, including the cable TV and mobile businesses, which should be received positively by the market. After spending two and a half years disposing of unwanted divisions it has around £3.5bn in cash which will give it enough fire power to snap up technology assets at good prices. The company is expected to make a number of smaller acquisitions to take it into highly rated areas like web hosting services. This leaves its shares looking undervalued. House of Fraser House of Fraser has suffered in the general gloom about retailers, and also from trading problems at a couple of its key stores. But it could be time for a bounce back. The company has established brand names like Dickens & Jones, DH Evans and Army & Navy and, at its share price of 61p, it is well below its net asset value of around 100p a share. It also has a good dividend yield of around 9%, which should provide some support to the shares. Its half-year profits were knocked to the tune of £3.5m due to refurbishment of its Oxford Street and Guildford stores, but the benefits of sprucing up these key sites should start to show through shortly. A lot depends on the crucial Christmas trading period, of course, but analysts are expecting profits of around £19m for the current year, up from £17.4m, and rising to £25m next year. Jacobs Holdings After a torrid time over the past 12 months, culminating in the disposal of its loss-making Ontime Logistics subsidiary, this should be the year that Jacobs Holdings (now at 30.5p) finally starts to deliver some performance to its long suffering shareholders. Not, perhaps, from any startling improvement in its core shipping and vehicle handling businesses, but from a realisation that fat property profits are on the horizon. By moving its Dart Line ferry business from Dartford to P&O's newly acquired Shell Haven on the opposite bank of the Thames, Jacobs is freeing up its 60-acre freehold site for a joint redevelopment with P&O. With land values on the adjoining Crossways Business Park reaching £600,000 an acre, scope to speed up Dart Line's growth from its new home at Shell Haven, and even the prospect of profits from its residual interest in a large airfield site in Oxfordshire, Jacobs shares look set for a bounce. Northern Recruitment Northern Recruitment, which specialises in placing permanent and contract staff in the north of England and Scotland, issued a profits warning in November. It said it was suffering from several clients moving their recruitment plans to later in the year, which would hit its half-year figures. But investors could do worse than follow the example of Midlands entrepreneur Bob Morton, who has built up a 9.25% stake in the business. Chief executive Lorna Moran holds more than 50% of the company so there is little chance of a hostile takeover. Investors like Mr Morton, however, are attracted by the dividend yield of 6% and believe the company is likely to get back on track during the course of the year. At 45p the shares are a speculative recovery play. Shire Now a constituent of the FTSE 100 index, pharmaceutical group Shire spooked investors at the tailend of the year with a $4bn (£2.7bn) all share offer for Canada's BioChem. There were suggestions the company had paid too much, and concerns about the amount of paper to be issued. But there were similar doubts when Shire acquired US group Roberts last year. Those worries were soon scotched and the deal seen as a valid one. The same is likely to be true this time round. The track record of chief executive Rolf Stahel is likely to persuade investors of the merits of the BioChem takeover, and the deal continues the move to lessen the company's dependence on the hyper activity drug Adderall. Shire's shares now stand at £10.55, well off their 12-month high of £15.08, and look likely to stage a recovery. Systems Union The bursting of the technology bubble has not helped this internet and software group, formerly known as freecom. But some of its problems were self-induced. When it floated at the end of 1999 it shares soared to more than 550p and it used its paper to make a number of acquisitions. These included accountancy software group Pegasus - subject of a three-way bid battle - and Oneview.net, an online business serving smaller companies. Unfortunately Oneview did not have the number of customers it had originally said, and investors treated the revelation harshly. Chief executive Michael Williams later resigned, to be replaced by Paul Coleman. Mr Coleman has now disposed of the e-tailing side of the business, including Oneview and the freecom operations, to a management team. Now it is focussed on software, and has become one of Europe's biggest accountancy software firms. It is cash rich, should have a turnover of around £90m next year and move into profit. There is also the outside chance of a bid from someone like Sage. At 70p, the shares are a reasonable bet on recovery.

webTitle: Stratus Holdings

fields.headline: Stratus Holdings
fields.standfirst: Goodbye to all that drift for publisher
fields.trailText: Goodbye to all that drift for publisher.
fields.body:
Publisher Stratus Holdings, whose best known author is probably movie star Joan Collins, has seen its shares drift back from a 120p placing price in March to 74.5p, largely in the absence of trading news.

However, that will change in the coming year as the group confirms soon that it has doubled its number of titles to more than 2,000 after signing up a number of new authors, including a reissue of the extensive works of Robert Graves, and new novels from Brian Aldiss, Carol Drinkwater, Barry England and Rosemary Friedman.

Stratus's distinctive approach to publishing, using digital "just-in-time" technology and a marketing-led approach to promoting its authors, is paying off. House broker Williams de Broe forecasts pretax profits of £1m this year, putting the shares on a prospective price-earnings ratio of only 11, far below the rating of its nearest quoted rival, Bloomsbury, which is trading at around 40 times its likely 2001 earnings.

webTitle: Obituary: James Brockway

fields.headline: James Brockway
fields.standfirst: As a poet and translator, he brought Dutch verse to English audiences and English novels to the Dutch
fields.trailText: As a poet and translator, he brought Dutch verse to English audiences and English novels to the Dutch.
fields.body:
The poet James Brockway, who has died aged 84, submerged his talent under translations of English novels into Dutch and Dutch poetry into English. It was with a rueful pride that he recounted how a bibliographer traced more than 700 placings of his translations of Dutch poetry in English-language magazines.

The latest of these, which gave him a boost of pleasure in his final weeks, was in the Hudson Review, of his translation of Wolves, by Patty Scholten. She was a recent interest of Jim's, and he enjoyed conveying into English her alliterative sonnets about pumas, baboons and other creatures, the results of a life-long association with Amsterdam Zoo. Just a few weeks before his death he received the fruits of his labours, Patty Scholten's Elephants In Love And Other Poems, in a fine edition by Alan Ross of the London Magazine.

Jim was the youngest son of a Birmingham industrialist. In 1935, he took a civil service job in London, and, in 1940, joined the Royal Air Force, travelling to Egypt, India and the Far East, and ending up as a flight lieutenant.

The major change in his life came in 1946, when he left homophobic Britain for Holland, where he had friends and could "live life my way at last". A long companionship with a man 20 years his senior gave Jim the stability he needed to write and to begin translating.

Dutch versions of the novels of Alan Sillitoe, Muriel Spark and Iris Murdoch appeared, as well as critical essays on trends in English writing. Meanwhile, he put together his first collection of his own poems, No Summer Song (1949).

But it was translations from his adopted to his native tongue that brought him the recognition he desired. His translations of Rutger Kopland appeared in the early 1980s in Stand magazine, and then as a selection of 10 poems in The Prospect And The River. That was followed by 57 translations of Kopland's poetry in A World Beyond Myself (1991) and Singers Behind Glass (1995), was a selection of eight modern Dutch poets.

In Holland, there were publicatons of Jim's translations from the poet Maria Vasalis and the male Frisian poet, Tsj bbe Hettinga. For his achievements in promoting Dutch literature abroad, in 1966 he received the prestigious Martinus Nijhoff Prize and in 1997 - "to my genuine surprise" - a Netherlands knighthood. In 1990, he took up English poetry again.

It was during the preparation of his collection, A Way Of Getting Through (1995), that I first met "Sir Jim". He was a small, slight, charming man, always wondering how it might have been had he lived on in England after 1946. When he learned that I lived in the Hertfordshire town of Ware, he asked if I thought he could live there. Later, I learned of similar conversations with friends from Devon and Oxfordshire.

Yet he was happy in his apartment in one of the quiet northern suburbs of the Hague, cared for by a small circle of close friends, Dutch, English and Australian. His partner Bram predeceased him, 13 years ago.

It was in the Hague that I saw him last, on a cold, slightly damp day in November, when I took him copies of his latest Rockingham collection, The Brightness In Between. He was pleased that a book of his own poems had been praised by Rutger Kopland. But our conversation, like many of his final poems, like The Brightness In Between, turned mainly on the past: "We are not the single selves we think we are./Nor have we ever been those shadows/moving among shades in other people's minds./We lack all true identity./Yet how we loved each other, you and I,/who lacked all true identity./Come from dust and on our slow way back/to dust, but ah, the brightness in between."

 Tim Heath writes: James Brockway's vocation as a poet grew out of his love for the Netherlands; in the words of a title to one of his poems: "God made the World but the Dutch made Holland". But it was by luck that he received an invitation from friends to their family home in the Hague. In this "magical" house, he set to work on a literary career in a land that had been turned into a German prison camp and whose people longed to break out into the world of culture.

Brockway enjoyed the sport of placing his translations into England's "little" magazines for 50 years; there was little money, and frequent rejections, yet each success was akin to a sexual conquest.

His own early writing had been the target of wartime bombing, but the editor of the Adelphi, John Middleton Murray, asked to see some of his poems. Brockway's work soon appeared in the Poetry Review under Muriel Spark's editorship and in the London Magazine, under John Lehmann and later Alan Ross.

Yet after No Summer Song's publication in 1949, there was to be a gap of 46 years before his second collection. "An entry for the Guiness Book Of Records," he would quip, yet this silence curiously marked out the period of the great love in his life while the translation work continued to flow.

In Hans Lodeizen, Maria Vasalis (a pseudonym for Margaretha Droogleever Fortuyn) and Rutger Kopland, Brockway was responsible for translating three great Dutch poets. With Lodeizen, he learnt an important lesson - to know when a poem is beyond translation. With Vasalis, the process of translation revealed a grammar of love. A full stop inserted in the middle of a sentence can transform a poem and begin a friendship. Translation requires an unusual intelligence, and Brockway met his equal in the spirit of this beautiful and underpublished woman.

Kopland, a professor of psychiatry, reawakened Brockway's voice. Late night telephone calls, struggling together in his garden at the end of a busy week, they advanced line by line as Kopland focused his scientific curiosity on the minute processes of creation. In contrast, Brockway grew less explicit in his own writing, making the reader work harder, and in 1995 his second book of poetry was published: A Way Of Getting Through.

Brockway once wrote: "Discontent leans on the air with giant hands." Yet he himself was a man of disciplined joy - "there was a duty to be happy". He was not a poet of universal themes, but found truth in the particular, moments of psychological insight best caught in poetry. He took pleasure in beautiful things: in paper, type and handmade books. And artists.

 James Brockway, poet, translator and critic, born October 21 1916; died December 15 2000.

webTitle: Ricardo

fields.headline: Ricardo
fields.standfirst: Motoring on
fields.trailText: Motoring on
fields.body:
Ricardo, the automotive engineering consultancy, may not seem to be in the best sector in the world at the moment, given the problems of overcapacity currently besetting the motor industry. But the company has carved itself a valuable niche, and it has been supplying technical expertise for more than 80 years.

Its key clients include Ford and BMW. Recent contracts include a deal to supply engine and transmission services to BMW for the new Mini.

The company has operations in the US and Europe and is looking to expand in Asia.

There had been suggestions that one of the major components companies which it also supplies might be interested in bidding, with Germany's Bosch seen as a prime candidate.

Analysts are looking for profits of up to £15m for the current year, an increase of more than 10%.

The shares stand at 484p and should go higher.

webTitle: Pubs group SFI has been expanding strongly by acquisition.

fields.headline: Slugs, newts and profits
fields.standfirst: Pubs group SFI - Surrey Free Inns as was - has been expanding strongly by acquisition.
fields.trailText: Pubs group SFI - Surrey Free Inns as was - has been expanding strongly by acquisition.
fields.body:
It paid £32m in shares for the Slug and Lettuce chain during the summer, seeing off a couple of rivals in the process, to add to its existing Bar Med and Litten Tree outlets. Shortly after that deal, it paid £4.7m for the Break for the Border chain from Dublin-based Capital Bars.

It has also picked up the odd site here and there from other operators, including two Newt & Cucumber pubs from Greene King.

The company is now seeking disposals to reduce its debt. Its shares have languished recently, perhaps on worries about the acquisition spree. But that seems unfair. Its brands seem to be performing well compared to its peers, and the integration of the acquisitions is said to be going well.

This should give a boost to profits growth, and give some froth this year to the shares, now trading at 176p.

webTitle: Bust on way, says Soros

fields.headline: Bust on way, says Soros
fields.standfirst: Billionaire predicts hard landing for the American economy
fields.trailText: Billionaire predicts hard landing for the American economy.
fields.body:
Billionaire financier George Soros warned yesterday that American authorities were powerless to prevent the long running US economic boom from turning to bust this year, with damaging consequences for the global economy.

"I believe that the [US landing] will be bouncy and hard," he said in a newspaper interview. Mr Soros said he expected the US Federal Reserve to slash interest rates early this year, but that it was too late to avert a sharp slowdown which would have serious consequences for emerging markets, already weakened by the 1997-98 Asian crisis.

"We are in a fairly classic slowdown cycle in the United States. I am much more worried about the consequences on the edge of the system because this edge has been weakened because of the [last] crisis - and I believe will have more serious repercussions in distant regions, such as southeast Asia."

Speaking in Chile, where Mr Soros is on holiday, the financier said: "I think this time the Federal Reserve is more following the market than leading the market. But I believe it will lower rates very aggressively at the beginning of next year."

Asked if the crisis could be stopped, Mr Soros said: "It cannot be avoided, but I believe that positive incentives can be created that could promote investments in emerging countries and those should be put in place by the international financial institutions."

He joins a chorus of senior financiers predicting that hard times in the world's largest economy will damage global growth prospects this year.

Last week, Sir Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, warned that a US slowdown could check Britain's eight-year economic expansion. "If America really sneezes we all catch cold," he said in a BBC interview.

Transatlantic trade and investment links place Britain in a vulnerable position if the US slows down. Economists at HSBC Bank estimate that after America's immediate neighbours, Canada and Mexico, the UK would be the most damaged by a US recession.

"The main issue here is UK company dependence on profits made in the US, together with relatively high capital inflows from the US compared to the rest of Europe," said Stephen King, HSBC's chief global economist.

Mr King believes that the recent spate of US profits warnings point to a hard rather than a soft landing for the American economy. The bank has pencilled in a US contraction in the second half of the year in its latest global forecasts. "We think there are now sufficient signs of distress to suggest that the economy is likely to lurch over the edge during the course of 2001," said Mr King.

Commentators believe that the risks of an American recession damaging UK growth shorten the odds on the government going to the polls in the spring, while the economic fair weather still holds.

New forecasts published today by Cambridge Econometrics, an independent think tank, predict that this year will be the ninth consecutive year UK growth has exceeded 2%, the best economic performance in thirty years.

Forecasters are predicting a bullish performance for the stock market this year, after a poor performance in 2000 when it fell 10%.

The most optimistic prediction is from American investment bank, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter which expects the FTSE 100 index of leading shares to top 7,200 points.

New forecasts published today by Cambridge Econometrics, an independent think tank, predict that this year will be the ninth consecutive year UK growth has exceeded 2%, the best economic performance in thirty years. Forecasters are predicting a bullish performance for the stock market this year, after a poor performance in 2000 when it fell 10%. The most optimistic prediction is from American investment bank, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter which expects the FTSE 100 index of leading shares to top 7,200 points.

webTitle: RJB plans to usher in green coal era

fields.headline: RJB plans to usher in green coal era
fields.standfirst: Hope for jobless in areas crippled by 1980s pit closures
fields.trailText: Hope for jobless in areas crippled by 1980s pit closures.
fields.body:
A new generation of green coal mines may be opened in Britain's devastated pit areas under a plan prepared by the industry's dominant company RJB Mining.

Three sites in Yorkshire and Nottinghamshire have been earmarked for development if the firm can extract funding from the government for experimental coal-fired power stations using "clean" technology which matches the environmental standards of gas and oil.

Hundreds of jobs would be created in South Yorkshire and North Nottinghamshire, which have seen crippling levels of unemployment since the collapse of deep-pit mining after the 1984-1985 strike. The Doncaster-based firm has prepared £100m cost estimates for the first new pit at Thorne, South Yorkshire, where shafts sunk by British Coal 10 years ago have been mothballed.

"The shafts would save a substantial amount of development costs," said Stuart Oliver of RJB. "There are also substantial reserves at Thorne in seams which have been worked by other, nearby pits. So we know the nature of the coal. What we need now is a kickstart to clean coal-fired generating capacity to give us the confidence to invest the money to bring Thorne and other sites into production."

RJB, which employs 8,000 at 13 of Britain's 17 remaining deep mines, is also studying Witham in Nottinghamshire and a third, undisclosed site in the region. The trebling of gas and oil prices in the last year has given the plan a spur, along with a rise of just over a third in the price of imported coal.

"We are looking to expand our existing mines as well, if we can get the clean-coal technology out of the research laboratories and actually up and running," said Mr Oliver. "We've been able to take on 150 former miners in the last six months and start training 50 apprentices, but this would be a step forward on a different scale."

The proposals were welcomed by Michael Clapham MP, chair of the all-party coalfield communities campaign, who is pressing energy minister Helen Liddell for round-table talks with mining companies and the power companies. RJB has already begun talks with National Power about a potential clean-coal power station site at Kellingley, north Yorkshire, home of the 'Big K' pit which is Europe's most productive mine.

"I've no doubt that RJB would go ahead with new collieries if we can ensure that the future is sustainable by investing in clean coal technology," said Mr Clapham. "As well as being exceptionally good news for the coal industry, it would also have a potential knock-on effect in creating other manufacturing jobs."

Britain produced 21m tonnes of coal last year, compared with 110m in 1980, when 211 deep mines employed 230,000 miners. But the global market has expanded over the last decade, along with the potential to export expertise in up to six clean-coal power generating systems which have been developed by government-funded research.

webTitle: Hi-tech flops fail to deter investors

fields.headline: Hi-tech flops fail to deter investors
fields.trailText: The meltdown in hi-tech stocks failed to dissuade UK investors from speculating in new ventures, a survey shows today. Twice as many companies floated on the London Stock Exchange in 2000 as in 1999, according to research by KPMG, and they succeeded in raising double the amount of money.
fields.body:
The meltdown in hi-tech stocks failed to dissuade UK investors from speculating in new ventures, a survey shows today. Twice as many companies floated on the London Stock Exchange in 2000 as in 1999, according to research by KPMG, and they succeeded in raising double the amount of money.

A total of 138 companies floated last year, raising £10.6bn. In 1999, there were 70 initial public offerings which raised £5.4bn. While the technology sector had the most IPOs, with 49, KPMG says traditional companies were also strongly represented, with 39.

"The facts do not support the commonly held view that, with a few exceptions, only technology, media and telecoms companies can float successfully," said Neil Austin, head of new issues at KPMG corporate finance. However he added that some sectors, such as retail, food manufacturing and engineering remained firmly out of favour.

Although much of the market frenzy surrounding tech stocks was concentrated in the first few months of 2000, the busiest time for IPOs was the final quarter of 2000, with 31 companies coming to the market.

"The statistics show that the market has been receptive to good quality companies for most of the year," Mr Austin said. "Valuations for technology stocks have come down from the heights earlier in the year but we have still seen a steady flow of new entrants."

However, he warned: "Although statistics show that the fourth quarter was more buoyant than may have been imagined, the year ended on a low point. Several firms shelved IPO plans and we enter the new year with depressed investor appetite."

webTitle: Business: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Insurers adopt claims code | Funds jump on bandwagon | Byers heads to India for talks
fields.body:
Insurers adopt claims code

Insurance companies will set minimum deadlines today to respond to general claims when the Association of British Insurers claims code comes into force. The code aims to raise minimum standards in the industry.

For the first time it ensures the standard of treatment which can be expected by third-party claimants in addition to private individual policyholders from the moment they make a claim.

In response to frustrated customers who have complained of being left uninformed, all insurers are now required to respond to their claim with five working days and produce replies to letters while the claims are being processed within 10 days.

Customers can also expect to receive a cheque, repair or replacement within 10 days of their claim being agreed, the ABI said.

Funds jump on bandwagon

Fund managers are taking increasing notice of socially responsible investment practices, according to new research.

Almost two thirds of fund managers surveyed by Deloitte & Touche said that they believed demand for funds that take account of environmental, social and ethical issues would increase. Many said they are working with their portfolio companies to help them develop socially responsible practices.

Byers heads to India for talks

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers will go to India later this week for a series of talks aimed at promoting trade and training links with Britain.

Mr Byers will open a new Marconi research and development facility in Delhi and give a speech on the importance of the World Trade Organisation for developing countries.

An increasing number of UK firms are locating research and manufacturing facilities in India to take advantage of a well-educated, English speaking and cheap labour pool.

Super Bowl loses dot.coms

Of the 17 US dot.com firms that bought advertising spots for last year's American football showpiece the Super Bowl, seven are already out of business.

Only three internet companies are buying space for this year's event later this month. Last year's was crammed with dot.com ads. Tighter budgets and disappointing revenues are blamed for the lack of spending this year.

Asset manager rebrands

Scottish Equitable Asset Management has been rebranded as Aegon Asset Management. The move highlights the company's membership of the Aegon group, a global financial services group with £175bn under management. The Scottish firm has £34bn of funds under management.

webTitle: 3,000 new jobs at Wetherspoon

fields.headline: 3,000 new jobs at Wetherspoon
fields.trailText: Pub chain JD Wetherspoon yesterday announced a £140m expansion programme that will create 3,000 new jobs over the next year.
fields.body:
Pub chain JD Wetherspoon yesterday announced a £140m expansion programme that will create 3,000 new jobs over the next year.

It plans to open 110 of its trademark cheap beer but music-free pub units in towns and cities, including Brighton, Glasgow, Leeds, London, Manchester, Newcastle, Tamworth, and Widnes. Some 1,000 pubs, creating 30,000 jobs, will be opened over the next decade.

"We are delighted to be able to start the new year with the creation of so many new jobs," said chairman and founder Tim Martin. "Our pubs continue to prove popular wherever they open, and we are confident that the new outlets will be just as successful."

Wetherspoon operates 465 pubs across the UK and Ireland, most based in unusual buildings like former cinemas and bank branches. The new jobs will be a mixture of full and part-time appointments of bar staff, managers and kitchen workers.

Mr Martin is also looking at expanding another pub brand, the fledgling Lloyds Number One chain, which was bought from Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries in June. The 10 existing outlets are more modern and stylised than Wetherspoon's traditional units and play contemporary music.

In the last financial year the group announced a 37.5% surge in annual pretax profits to £36m - a profit of around £77,000 from each of its pubs. Around £4m was paid out in staff bonuses, while share options were awarded to 2,200 workers.

Pub chains underperformed the stock market for most of last year. Wetherspoon shares have also suffered but strong sales growth has meant that they have not been as troubled as most.
