webTitle: Letters: The gaps in health policy

fields.headline: The gaps in health policy
fields.trailText: Colin Guthrie (Letters, December 30) puts his finger on the key challenge for health policy. Research over the last two decades has shown that the bulk of the higher rates of sickness, accidents and deaths experienced by the poor is caused by obscene wealth gaps and the adverse psycho-social conditions that go with them.
fields.body:
Colin Guthrie (Letters, December 30) puts his finger on the key challenge for health policy. Research over the last two decades has shown that the bulk of the higher rates of sickness, accidents and deaths experienced by the poor is caused by obscene wealth gaps and the adverse psycho-social conditions that go with them. Japan, with relatively low gaps between rich and poor, has strikingly high life expectancy.

It is not a waste of the additional funds and heroic staff efforts to pit the chronically underfunded health service against the toll of extra disease and accidents. But the underlying causes need addressing urgently. Mainly, this calls for action outside the NHS. The good news is that the policies needed to make progress in public health in relation to inequalities and environmental problems are broadly in harmony with the need to shift towards green policies and to address the root causes rather than the symptoms of crime. Many churches and humanist groups are already battling away, as well as the Greens.

Internationally, there is a wealth of policy development to build on, but most of the transnational corporations and their mouthpiece, the US government, will still be fighting vital change. It is not just electoral procedures that the US needs to modernise in 2001. Public health and environmentalism present challenges that reach beyond national boundaries and pre-ecological ideology.
Dr Peter Draper
London peter.draper@btinternet.com

 Your leader (January 1) notes that 2001 may be an election year and rightly asks if things have got better since 1997. Are the poor poorer? Is the divide growing? Is our nation healthier? We shall be asking the political parties what they think and what they will do about it, and hope they will join in making 2001 the start of a popular movement for public health. Health - for all - should be the first paragraph of every manifesto.
John Nicholson
UK Public Health Association

 The government's plans to abolish community health councils (Report, December 28) will remove important civil liberties from individuals and communities. Patients who have suffered lapses of care in the NHS seek the help of CHCs to challenge the hospital staff responsible and seek redress. It is inconceivable that the hospital-employed advocates proposed to replace CHCs would be able to act for patients or bereaved relatives with the fearless determination of the CHCs.

It is not just the erosion of patients' rights to independent representation that causes concern. At the core of the government's plan is its determination to abolish independent monitoring of the NHS and in particular the monthly exposure through Casualty Watch of the government's failure to solve the embarrassing problem of 20-30 hour waits in casualty departments.

The government's plan to suppress public monitoring and criticism of the NHS by closing CHCs will lead to poorer and less sensitive care and treatment, and will hurt the most vulnerable patients.
Malcolm Alexander
Chief officer, Southwark community health council maiexa49@aol.com

fields.trailText: Is the Peter Hain who defends his "direct action" tactics against the South African cricket tour in 1970 (Hain opposition to cricket tour led to talk of prosecution, January 1) the same Peter Hain who condemns my citizen's arrest of President Mugabe on charges of human rights abuses?
fields.body:

Peter Tatchell
London

 It is worth having a Labour government just to hear Peter Hain broadcasting from Nelson Mandela's prison island. Rejoice, rejoice! you liberty lovers.
Michael Foot
London

 When I was growing up in Bristol (Letters, January 1), there was a family with three daughters - Sandral, Veral and Normal.
Martin Long
Frome, Somerset

 No gloating please from citizens of Bath (Letters, December 30), for whom the biggest buzz has always been the double-decker from the buzz station.
Ian MacDonald
Billericay, Essex

 Your front page banner on Saturday (December 30) reads Julie Burchill - "There comes a time when intoxication becomes boring". There became a time, many, many moons ago, when I had exactly the same idea about Ms Burchill. I'm sure I can't be alone. How long does it take her to complete the Quick Crossword, I wonder?
Stephen Potter
St Leonards-on-Sea, E Sussex

 What a relief to have at least one Saturday (December 30) free of letters from men wittering about Julie Burchill.
Mary Wilde
Surbiton, Surrey

 May I be the first to complain about the overuse of the word "odyssey" in the media during 2001.
Martin Henson
Sudbury, Suffolk

webTitle: Letters: Crisis move

fields.headline: Crisis move
fields.trailText: Your report (Charity 'wrong' over winter homeless crisis, January 1) questioned the genuineness of the plight of homeless people.
fields.body:
Your report (Charity 'wrong' over winter homeless crisis, January 1) questioned the genuineness of the plight of homeless people. Last Saturday I stood at the door of the derelict cinema Crisis used this Christmas and watched 300 vulnerable, sad people drift into the snow. Many would return to beds in hostels, but 75 of them pleaded with us for help, arguing and persuading us, a homelessness charity of 30 years standing, that they had nowhere to go but the street. Crisis could either believe that they had homes but were lying; or accept their stories. The temperature was one degree above freezing: we gave them the benefit of the doubt.

Crisis's call on government was simple: implement the severe weather provision. Some additional beds have since been released, sadly too late for many of our clients. The truth remains visible in the doorways of central London.
Shaks Ghosh
Chief Executive, Crisis shaks.ghosh@crisis.org.uk

 No people sleeping rough in the early 70s (Letters, December 29)? I remember going on a late-night soup run in London in the winter of 1972-73 and meeting dozens of people sleeping rough, for most of them it was a way of life.
Gordon Thorburn
Buxton, Derbyshire

webTitle: Letters: New approach to Islam and immigrants

fields.headline: New approach to Islam and immigrants
fields.trailText: Your reactionary headline (British Muslims take path to jihad, December 29), gives the lunatic fringe in the Muslim faith the oxygen of publicity which they depend upon to suggest that their numbers are greater than they actually are.
fields.body:
Your reactionary headline (British Muslims take path to jihad, December 29), gives the lunatic fringe in the Muslim faith the oxygen of publicity which they depend upon to suggest that their numbers are greater than they actually are. It is the type of headline we would expect in the Daily Telegraph and comes only days after the end of Ramadan.

Islam does not advocate people sacrificing themselves as human bombs. Islamophobia is a real social problem in the UK and needs to be part of the equalities agenda. The declaration of jihad and the call for the sacrificing of life for the cause of Islam should come from the highest Islamic religious order, accepted by every muslim in the world. There is no such authority nor is there the unity necessary for such a declaration.

In the UK we have seen the word Paki replaced in the playground by Muslim as a term of abuse. People are increasingly discriminated against on the basis of their names and not only their colour. We daily see images of Muslims like the Palestinians being gunned down. It is not surprising that fundamentalist Islam has an appeal for some, similar to the attraction of the black power movement of the 60s and 70s. Islamophobia needs to be dealt with at the beginning of this new century: the angry young men of the world are Muslim, like Mohammed Omar from Hackney.

The Home Office should set up a working party on the recruitment of young Muslim men from our estates for so-called holy wars. And you should give liberal and secular traditions in Islam exposure, not the lunatic fringe.
Cllr Mustaq Qureshi, Cllr Murad Qureshi Westminster

 The problem of asylum seekers is not confined to Britain (New asylum row erupts, January 1). It is a European problem and it needs a common EU immigration and asylum policy. It is in the interest of Britain to initiate such a policy, which should include sharing the influx of asylum seekers among all EU member states.

The British will certainly have the support of the Belgian government and possibly the German as well. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder recently said that Germany needs to open its gates to immigration and his government should tackle the issue head on. Simultaneously, the British government should educate people that immigrants and asylum seekers are not a problem but an opportunity, not a liability but an asset.
Tara Mukherjee
European Multicultural Foundation

Tara Mukherjee European Multicultural Foundation

webTitle: Obituary: Alan Cranston

fields.headline: Alan Cranston
fields.standfirst: High-minded US senator brought low by scandal
fields.trailText: High-minded US senator brought low by scandal.
fields.body:
As a brilliant young man in the 1930s and 1940s, and a political heavyweight in the US senate who was eventually brought down by scandal, Alan Cranston, who has died aged 86, symbolised the deterioration of American politics in the second half of the 20th century.

He served in the senate for California from 1968 to 1992 as a worker for arms control and world peace, and was a power in liberal Democratic politics. Yet only a bout with prostate cancer saved him from his colleagues' censure for taking thousands of dollars from savings-and-loan banker and convicted fraudster Charles Keating, who went to prison for milking elderly couples out of millions of their life-savings.

As a younger man Cranston had spotted the global menace of Hitler while a foreign correspondent in Europe, written a book praised as one of the best foreign affairs analyses of 1945, and made a reputation in the world government movement before entering state politics in 1959. Yet, in his final years, he was not resting on his reputation, but working for rehabilitation.

He was born into a rich family near San Francisco, his father a property investor and a conservative. He attended university in Mexico City and Stanford, where he graduated in journalism in 1936 and pursued his study of foreign languages. He then headed for Europe as a correspondent for William Randolph Hearst's news agency, International News Service.

Returning to America just before the second world war, Cranston used his knowledge of German and the Nazis to pull off a publishing coup that brought a copyright lawsuit from the führer himself. Mein Kampf, Hitler's personal manifesto, was enjoying commercial success in America in a bowdlerised version. Cranston, who had read the original, dictated a condensed edition in eight days that included its wildest statements and was quickly published at 10 cents a copy. Hitler's lawyers won an injunction, and Cranston's version was withdrawn, but not before it had sold half a million copies.

After wartime service in US intelligence, Cranston wrote another bestseller, The Killing Of The Peace, about the failure of the prewar League of Nations - from which the senate had blocked US entry - and the lessons it offered the new United Nations. Back in California, he used his reputation to become prominent in the one-world movement, and for three years headed the United World Federalists group.

Cranston transferred to the California Democratic Council, which, in five years, he turned into a powerful liberal force that lasted into the 1960s. He first served as an elected official in state government and was California's state controller from 1959 to 1967. He won a senate seat at his second try, in 1968. His bald, gaunt figure, and his passion for jogging long before the health craze, became part of the state's political landscape, and his pre-eminence lasted for a quarter century.

But, behind the scenes, he was increasingly preoccupied with campaign funds and raising money, something which, as a poor speaker, he discovered he excelled at. The public was mostly unaware of suspicions of unethical finances when, in 1983, he launched a presidential bid.

Cranston cut a ludicrous figure, having dyed his fringe of white hair orange, while constantly boasting of his fitness at the age of 69. His campaign flopped, voters being unconvinced by his commercials: "The Cranston presidency will have two clear purposes - ending the arms race and full employment - because that's how you beat Ronald Reagan even if you're bald."

As the New York Times put it: "He was lionised by liberals for calling for a nuclear freeze, while satisfying military contractors as a champion of the B1-bomber, and a hero to good government groups for pushing campaign reform, while boasting of his reputation as the congress's most hardball fundraiser."

In 1986, Cranston set a new low in attack politics in his $20m senate re-election campaign, with ads of such venom that afterwards his manager quit politics. Then the Keating money-for-influence scandal struck, and in 1992 Cranston announced his resignation.

He retired to the family compound in Los Altos and founded the Global Security Institute. Twice divorced, Cranston had two sons, one of whom predeceased him in a car crash.

 Alan MacGregor Cranston, politician, born June 19 1914; died December 31 2000.

webTitle: Leader: Managing German aims in the EU

fields.headline: Managing German aims
fields.standfirst:
That is the new challenge for the EU

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: That is the new challenge for the EU.
fields.body:
Sweden takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union this week to undisguised relief all round. The judgment on Paris is uniformly negative. The French presidency is blamed for its conduct of the Nice summit last month, inconsistency over beef, the way Jacques Chirac played silly buggers on Nato and the rapid reaction force and above all French failure to see just how old-fashioned Gaullism now looks, with its pretence that the interests of the club and those of France are the same.

Paris's loss looks increasingly like Berlin's gain. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder emerged from Nice with enhanced authority. He won a voting scheme that gives the Germans more clout if they need a veto, but also the right to insist - which he undoubtedly will - that the accession of Poland, Slovenia and the other candidates goes ahead and on largely German terms.

Despite Robin Cook's modernising impulse, our Foreign Office still does nothing as human as sigh with relief. It is a moot point, too, whether the Blair government should join the French bashing. In their single-minded pursuit of national interest within the EU and their willingness to take unilateral action when they see fit, the French are doing approximately what the latest Blairite script suggests the UK should do too.

The doctrine as set out in the recent book by French foreign minister Hubert Védrine, especially its "Europe of nation states", shares ground with the prime minister's recent speech in Warsaw. The trouble is that the French also have a certain idea of pan-European action - the charter of rights, common policies on unemployment - which London hates.

But London and Paris will, one way or another, have to come together if the momentum behind the "German version" grows. Of course there is no single German view of Europe's future development. Foreign minister Joschka Fischer is something of a maverick. His colleagues in the Schröder government may share his faith in federation as Europe's future, but they are going to be a lot more cautious in advancing it as the subject for the 2004 intergovernmental conference.

Even so, it is a distinctly different vision from Mr Blair's, let alone the British public's, and managing German aspirations is going to constitute one of the great challenges of EU policy during the next few years, longer if the Schröder government wins power again. There is certainly not much point in looking to Paris for an alternative, at least until the legislative and presidential elections are safely out of the way next year.

webTitle: Matthew Engel: The Tories are finished

fields.headline: The strange, slow death of the Tories
fields.standfirst:
They are on their way out - just as the Liberals were in the twenties

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: They are on their way out - just as the Liberals were in the twenties.
fields.body:
To celebrate the pedant's millennium and the election year of 2001, here's a thought that some Guardian readers might find cheering. First, a bit of historical background: it was 18 years from the general election of 1906, when the Liberals won 400 parliamentary seats, until 1924, when they won 40 and finally descended - so far irrevocably - into the status of a third party. This is the period remembered in George Delderfield's book, the title of which has turned almost into cliche: The Strange Death of Liberal England.

It is now 18 years since 1983, when the Conservatives gave the Labour party, then led by Michael Foot, the mother and father of a hiding. Shortly before that election, opinion poll figures made it seem as though Labour might disappear, to be replaced by the Gang of Four and the SDP.

As we now know, shrewdies (like Tony Blair) were in fact buying Labour shares at the bottom of the market, and 14 years later were in place to reap the dividend of power. These days, the initials SDP evoke either bafflement or a chortle, and Labour's recovery might seem to have been inevitable. It was nothing of the kind. If Tony Benn had scored a handful more votes in the deputy leadership vote in 1981 and beaten Denis Healey to the job, the exodus of moderate MPs from the party could have become an unstoppable stampede.

In 1997 the Conservatives were beaten even more heavily than Labour in 1983 and, four years later, have arguably declined further. Yet Labour is still suffering an Eeyore-ish pessimism. Well, I am all for caution, especially when making predictions in print that can be flung back when they are proved wrong. But just consider another possibility: that the dragon really has been slain, and that we are witnessing, without realising it, The Even Stranger Death of Conservative England.

The most skilled pathologist would find the rigor mortis hard to spot, because the rightwing press is so combative and so powerful. However, although newspapers can nudge people towards what they were already half-thinking - as in the Sun's blisteringly effective attacks on Neil Kinnock's competence in 1992 - the press cannot persuade readers to believe what they know instinctively to be ludicrous. The combined forces of Charles Foster Kane and Phineas T Barnum could not make the present Conservative party popular.

The Tories' problems over personalities and policies are too well-known to be worth repeating here. There remains a terror that the combined might of the Tories and the tabloids might turn "Save the pound" into a rallying cry. But Europe has never been an election issue here, no matter how hot the debate during the rest of the political cycle. The parties have always been too divided; the electorate too uncaring.

Some analysts claim that the Conservatives will gain in the forthcoming election from differential turnout because their opponents will not be as motivated as they were in 1997 when the country voted to turn the rascals out with such unanimity. Actually, turnout is one of the most unpredictable factors in any election, and the effect of a month of shouting is impossible to gauge. Remember that there is a class of voters terrified of change, who cleave naturally to the party in power and actually stayed loyal to the Tories in 1997. There is also one wholly predictable factor which has been overlooked.

The electoral register has a turnover of about 1.6% a year: voters, mostly elderly ones, die, alas; they are replaced by 18-year-olds. In the course of a four-year parliament that means a change of more than 6%. But the Tories have been continuously unpopular (save for the briefest of blips during the fuel crisis) since the autumn of 1992. Indeed, if you exclude that spring and summer, this phase has now gone on since 1988. Since that time, almost a fifth of the electorate has changed. Increasingly, the Conservatives have to woo, not disaffected supporters, but under-30s who have never supported them in their lives.

In governmental terms, it is still a mystery what the Blair Project actually means, if anything. In political terms, the prime minister wanted - probably still wants - a vaguely left-of-centre, touchy-feely alliance that would outnumber the Tories more often than not. He was too unambitious. There is an altogether more alluring scenario in which the present Labour party gets harried in time by a Lib Dem party strengthened by breakaways from the humanoid wing of the Tories, with the existing Conservatives reduced to a rump. Improbable? Perhaps. Impossible? Certainly not.

webTitle: Letters: Work not play for students

fields.headline: Work not play for students
fields.trailText: So, Malcolm Wicks MP tells us it's untrue that "the vast majority of those on degree courses are in serious financial difficulty" (Letters, December 28). Oh, good, I must be in a minority!
fields.body:
So, Malcolm Wicks MP tells us it's untrue that "the vast majority of those on degree courses are in serious financial difficulty" (Letters, December 28). Oh, good, I must be in a minority! Funny, though, so are nearly all the other students I know. Luckily I get a fabulous loan, £3,725 in total; £2,236 of this goes on my rent, which leaves me £28 per week for bills, food, course materials - the last text book I bought cost £26.99, a whole pound left that week! - clothes, oh and the "sharply risen" entertainment spending. Ha.

Never mind, I've got an overdraft, only £500 at the moment but it'll probably be up to £1,000 by the end of term. Luckily, as one of the few remaining mature students, I don't have to rely on my parents for money, because lots of my friends parents won't cough up what they're supposed to. Naughty yes, but that's what happens when theories meet reality.

So what do these "minority" students do? Well, like me they work, they work so hard that lecturers have to reschedule labs to the afternoon so that students won't fall asleep in the middle of experiments. Shame you can't be a part-time MP. Well, not officially anyway.

But the obvious signs of poverty are not the whole story. The introduction of tuition fees has created a culture that only values the academic side of the university experience. Many students are now under such pressure to justify their parents' expenditure and do well academically that they are neglecting the other side of the university experience, the sporting achievements, the membership of clubs and societies. Sadly none of these things fit neatly into a spreadsheet, but it is here students gain the life experiences that help to provide the rounded human beings that this country's future needs.

(I'm emailing this because I can't afford the stamp.)
Tony Wylie
Scrapie, Bradford University students' union magazine editor@scrapie.co.uk

 Comments on students' alleged higher spending on entertainment as a justification for continued student poverty is typical of the neo-liberal claptrap of New Labour. I have a large proportion of students in the ward that I represent and have come across many cases of students whose study is interrupted by having to work long hours to try and make ends meet. They are also routinely denied access to facilities and threatened with debt collection agencies for being unable to pay New Labour's student fees by university authorities.

The Thatcherite government's arguments to justify the poll tax are very similar to this government's arguments to justify student fees, their "poll tax on students". The poll tax was beaten by mass demonstrations and mass non-payment. I will be assisting students in my city to ensure that student fees suffer the same fate.
Cllr Rob Windsor
Socialist party group, Coventry robwindsor@freeuk.com

 Re: R Holland's student debt problems (Letters, December 28), as a recent graduate, I winced while reading of this young man's pain. How well I remember the long evenings in the pubs and clubs, the "strain" of waking up at midday with a hangover, not to mention the soft drugs, the five months of holidays a year or the easy access to money to lavish on all of the above.

Sometimes on top of my seven or eight hours of study a week, I spent as many as 30 or 40 hours watching daytime television. I "survived" too, but thank God I don't have to relive it. The prospect of another 40-odd years of full-time work is much more pleasant.
J Wilson
Neuilly sur Seine, France

webTitle: Rower charged after top designer stabbed to death

fields.headline: Rower charged after top designer stabbed to death
fields.standfirst: Training trip to France by London sculling club ends in tragedy
fields.trailText: Training trip to France by London sculling club ends in tragedy.
fields.body:
A British rower has been charged in connection with the death of his club's president, an international award-winning designer.

It is believed Marcello Minale, 58, who rowed in the Olympics as a teenager, was stabbed after an argument in a car park near Fayence, southern France, on Saturday.

A 23-year-old man was arrested and last night a spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said a man had been charged with the French crime of voluntary homicide.

The men were members of a party from the Tideway Scullers school, based at Chiswick, west London, who were on a 10-day training trip at Lac de St Cassien, near Cannes.

The club chairman, Chris Williams, said: "Details are very sketchy, but it seems there was an argument in the course of which Marcello got killed. We have no idea why it happened, or what caused the trouble. Marcello was a very jovial, quite big Italian guy, very much loved by all members of the club and very respected."

Mr Minale left Italy to study design in Helsinki. In 1964 he set up a practice in London with Brian Tattersfield in a tiny room "with only a window sill to work on", according to the company's website.

Minale Tattersfield and Partners now has 160 staff worldwide in 18 offices and has won more than 300 international awards, including 13 silver medals from the London-based Designers' and Art Directors' Association.

The company's clients include Marconi, Motorola, Nivea and the Royal Armouries, Leeds, with projects ranging from packaging to petrol pumps.

Mr Minale, a father of three from Ealing, west London, had published eight books on design and with Mr Tattersfield received the D&ADA president's award for their outstanding contribution to the industry.

Alex Maranzano, managing director of Minale Tattersfield, which is based in Richmond, south-west London, said Mr Minale had won a silver medal for rowing at the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome and remained a keen rower, often taking to the river in the mornings before coming to to the office.

"As he got older, he got into the coaching side of things more, but he would often come into the office later in the morning, having been out on the water.

"It didn't matter what the weather was like, he was very keen and would always go out."

Mr Maranzano said he had visited his colleague's wife and youngest son yesterday, while the dead man's two eldest sons had flown out to France.

"They are in a hell of a state, as you can imagine," he said.

Mr Maranzano last night paid tribute to the man he worked with for 32 years: "It's the end of an era. He was a great designer and set very high standards of creativity.

"I can't find the right words to express how good he was. He always moved on and never stood still, always stretching the boundaries.

"We only found out on Saturday night and flew straight back here from a holiday in Italy.

"It's all so distressing, I haven't got my head around it. Tomorrow I'll have to tell everybody in the office what has happened."

Mr Tattersfield, who retired five years ago, said he was deeply shocked by Mr Minale's death. "Marcello was so highly respected in the industry - this is a terrible thing to happen," he said.

The Foreign Office spokeswoman said that the man charged, who has not been named, had been transferred to a French prison. He had already been visited by consulate staff and his family had been told of his arrest.
fields.bodyText: A British rower has been charged in connection with the death of his club's president, an international award-winning designer. It is believed Marcello Minale, 58, who rowed in the Olympics as a teenager, was stabbed after an argument in a car park near Fayence, southern France, on Saturday. A 23-year-old man was arrested and last night a spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said a man had been charged with the French crime of voluntary homicide. The men were members of a party from the Tideway Scullers school, based at Chiswick, west London, who were on a 10-day training trip at Lac de St Cassien, near Cannes. The club chairman, Chris Williams, said: "Details are very sketchy, but it seems there was an argument in the course of which Marcello got killed. We have no idea why it happened, or what caused the trouble. Marcello was a very jovial, quite big Italian guy, very much loved by all members of the club and very respected." Mr Minale left Italy to study design in Helsinki. In 1964 he set up a practice in London with Brian Tattersfield in a tiny room "with only a window sill to work on", according to the company's website. Minale Tattersfield and Partners now has 160 staff worldwide in 18 offices and has won more than 300 international awards, including 13 silver medals from the London-based Designers' and Art Directors' Association. The company's clients include Marconi, Motorola, Nivea and the Royal Armouries, Leeds, with projects ranging from packaging to petrol pumps. Mr Minale, a father of three from Ealing, west London, had published eight books on design and with Mr Tattersfield received the D&ADA president's award for their outstanding contribution to the industry. Alex Maranzano, managing director of Minale Tattersfield, which is based in Richmond, south-west London, said Mr Minale had won a silver medal for rowing at the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome and remained a keen rower, often taking to the river in the mornings before coming to to the office. "As he got older, he got into the coaching side of things more, but he would often come into the office later in the morning, having been out on the water. "It didn't matter what the weather was like, he was very keen and would always go out." Mr Maranzano said he had visited his colleague's wife and youngest son yesterday, while the dead man's two eldest sons had flown out to France. "They are in a hell of a state, as you can imagine," he said. Mr Maranzano last night paid tribute to the man he worked with for 32 years: "It's the end of an era. He was a great designer and set very high standards of creativity. "I can't find the right words to express how good he was. He always moved on and never stood still, always stretching the boundaries. "We only found out on Saturday night and flew straight back here from a holiday in Italy. "It's all so distressing, I haven't got my head around it. Tomorrow I'll have to tell everybody in the office what has happened." Mr Tattersfield, who retired five years ago, said he was deeply shocked by Mr Minale's death. "Marcello was so highly respected in the industry - this is a terrible thing to happen," he said. The Foreign Office spokeswoman said that the man charged, who has not been named, had been transferred to a French prison. He had already been visited by consulate staff and his family had been told of his arrest.

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Sometimes, difficult things must be said, and so it is with our splendid police. How easy it is for Guardian readers, safely tucked away in the enchanted kingdom known to my colleague Julie Burchill as NW Twee, to dismiss as dimwits those brave and resourceful men and women who keep this country safe for decent folk. How easy and, as the annual PC Brains Awards will prove, how very, very wrong. My friend Simon Heffer is in Milan at the minute, being fitted out for his catwalk return this spring, but were he here he would be the first to agree with me and whip his helmet out in honour of the unsung heroes of British policing.
fields.body:
 Sometimes, difficult things must be said, and so it is with our splendid police. How easy it is for Guardian readers, safely tucked away in the enchanted kingdom known to my colleague Julie Burchill as NW Twee, to dismiss as dimwits those brave and resourceful men and women who keep this country safe for decent folk. How easy and, as the annual PC Brains Awards will prove, how very, very wrong. My friend Simon Heffer is in Milan at the minute, being fitted out for his catwalk return this spring, but were he here he would be the first to agree with me and whip his helmet out in honour of the unsung heroes of British policing.

 This year's Golden Deerstalker For Inspired Detective Work goes to the still unnamed officer who, a Sunday Times front page revealed in November, nicked Alastair Campbell and questioned him in connection with the Jill Dando murder inquiry. What inspired this arrest was the 1999 Diary item about Ali claiming once to have been the TV presenter's gentleman caller ... a fiasco of the first water arising out of a misunderstanding over Sunday lunch. The irony that the one person in Britain who believes anything here should be a Scotland Yard detective speaks, I think, for itself.

 But policing isn't just about helping yourself to confiscated drugs, stopping black motorists and pulling in the prime minister's official spokesman. There's a lot more to it ... initiatives to involve us all in the fight against crime, for example. The key thing here is finding a name that catches on with the public. Instant promotion, then, to the mastermind who came up with "Finger a thief" for the next Crimestoppers campaign.

 While he considers allowing juries to know about defendants' previous convictions, Jack Straw finds time to give his special prize, the Pinochet International Award for Civil Liberties, to Rhode Island's police department, which installed a computer detection system called Justice Link. Within moments of going online, it was spitting out scores of warrants for people yet to commit the offences in question. Still, as Jack would say, if they hadn't been fated to do the crimes, their names wouldn't have appeared on the warrants.

 These days, officers are under great pressure to show sensitivity when handling people from different backgrounds. This year's William Macpherson Plate goes to the Essex force which in February had to deal with the hijacked Afghan jet at Stansted. At first officers were baffled as to how to feed 80 Muslims, but once they'd put their heads together all became clear: they rang Reubens, the well-known kosher restaurant in Baker Street, to order 80 sandwiches. Ah yes, how they love their salt beef and potato latkas throughout the Islamic world.

 Finally, the Inspector Clouseau Diamond Magnifying Glass goes to the traffic cop who, while using a hand-held radar to catch speeding drivers in the spring, was astounded to clock one vehicle doing more than 300mph. He had locked his machine on to a Tornado in a low-flying training exercise, it transpired, the pilot only deactivating the air-to-ground anti-radar missile that would have blown him to smithereens with seconds to spare. Thank God the officer was saved. This is just the kind of genius who in a year or two could be having a little word in Ali Campbell's shell-like down the cells underneath the Yard.

webTitle: Unionists scorn 'unrealistic' IRA

fields.headline: Unionists scorn 'unrealistic' IRA
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A senior Ulster Unionist last night rejected an IRA statement blaming Tony Blair for the deadlock in the Northern Ireland political process as "totally unrealistic".
fields.body:
A senior Ulster Unionist last night rejected an IRA statement blaming Tony Blair for the deadlock in the Northern Ireland political process as "totally unrealistic".

The New Year message repeated previous claims that the IRA had made "unprecedented initiatives to enhance all genuine efforts to realise a just and lasting peace".

But it accused the government of failing to grasp the opportunities this had created and said that while the IRA remained committed to resolving the arms issue, this would not happen unless the prime minister "takes political responsibility for it".

London and Dublin are due to restart intensive efforts to stop the peace process lurching toward crisis once again, with unionists and republicans deadlocked over paramilitary disarmament, demilitarisation and policing.

The IRA has taken the unprecedented step of allowing international inspectors to examine several of its secret arms dumps twice in the past few months but has not been in contact with General John de Chastelain's disarmament body since a phone call in June.

Republicans want more action on police reform and a substantial security scaledown, particularly in the heavily fortified south Armagh region, before they will consider further moves.

But Ulster Unionist hardliners could force their leader, David Trimble, to pull out of the power-sharing Stormont government within the next few weeks if the IRA does at least re-engage seriously with General de Chastelain.

One of Mr Trimble's closest allies, the Fermanagh/South Tyrone MP Ken Maginnis, said yesterday: "Unionism totally rejects the basis on which the IRA tries to function. This is capable of bringing huge problems. Their wish list is totally unacceptable and their statement based on the false premise that they have done everything right and therefore everything should go according to their dictat. It illustrates Sinn Fein/IRA are incapable of functioning politically in the real world."

The Northern Ireland Office declined to comment on the IRA statement. But sources pointed out that 32 military bases had been shut and 3,500 soldiers withdrawn from the province in recent months, leaving the lowest troop levels since 1970. Senior army and RUC officers are strongly resistant to any further reduction in security, believing the threat from dissident and mainstream terrorists, loyalist and republican, is too great.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, has also insisted that the police bill passed by Westminster at the end of the last session provides a fair rendition of the spirit of Chris Patten's recommendations, but republicans and nationalists hotly dispute this.

webTitle: Middle East peace talks close to failure

fields.headline: Middle East peace talks close to failure
fields.standfirst:
Five Palestinians die as bomb in Israel injures 40

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Five Palestinians die as bomb in Israel injures 40.
fields.body:
Egypt, which has been at the heart of negotiations, yesterday declared the Middle East peace plan initiated by Bill Clinton to be virtually over as five Palestinians, including two children, were killed and a car bomb exploded in Israel, injuring more than 40 people, one critically.

The Israelis and Palestinians marked the start of the new year by clashings all over the region, with elements on both sides vowing revenge attacks. The militant Palestinian group Hamas threatened a resumption of suicide bombings and Palestinians were braced for a punitive strike from Israel in retaliation for the latest bombings.

Amr Moussa, the foreign minister of Egypt, which has been at the centre of negotiations between Israel, Palestine and the US over the last week, gave his most pessimistic assessment yet.

Speaking after a meeting with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, Mr Moussa said there were "no indications" that a deal could be sealed in the 19 days left before Mr Clinton leaves office.

Mr Arafat told the Egyptians he wanted a meeting with Mr Clinton in Washington to clarify the US proposals and look at detailed maps of the territorial arrangements. If such clarification was not forthcoming, he would reject the plan. A meeting was later arranged, possibly in the next 24 hours, but it was not clear whether Mr Clinton would be able to provide what Mr Arafat wanted.

An adviser to Mr Arafat who travelled with him to Cairo gave a stark warning to the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak. He said that if Mr Barak fulfilled his threat to separate Israel and the Palestine Authority forcefully, taking big chunks out of the West Bank in the process, it would be war.

In clashes on the West Bank in the hours before the new year and throughout yesterday, two Palestinian soldiers were killed in a shoot-out with the Israeli army. A three-year-old child was killed and an 11-year-old died of wounds sustained the previous day.

In a separate incident, witnesses said Jewish settlers had driven into Hizma village near Jerusalem in two cars on Sunday and shot dead a Palestinian, Tahrir Rezeq, 22.

The car bomb in Israel, near the coastal city of Netanya, about 12 miles (20 kilometres) from Tel Aviv, marks the second time in a week that Palestinian militants have struck inside Israel, which normally avoids the worst of the violence.

Moshe Seff, Netanya's fire chief, said three blasts occurred in rapid succession, smashing shop windows.

Palestinians marked the anniversary of the New Year's Day founding of the Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organisation with a call for attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

At least 298 Palestinians, 13 Israeli Arabs and 43 other Israelis have been killed in the Palestinian uprising that erupted three months ago.

Jewish settlers blocked roads to West Bank Arab villages in anger at Sunday's killing by Palestinian gunmen of Binyamin Kahane, the son of rabbi Meir Kahane, who was himself killed by an Arab in New York a decade ago.

Still hoping for a peace breakthrough, Mr Barak told conscripts at an army base: "We aren't throwing up our hands. What's needed is level-headedness and strong nerves."

But if no accord emerged, "the Israeli army will be forced to act against all those who act against us in this violent confrontation".

The Palestinian legislative speaker, Ahmed Korei, back from failed talks in Washington, told Reuters: "If the Americans continue to insist on their position, then in the near future there will be no agreement."

The EU foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, met Mr Barak to discuss Mr Clinton's proposals.

"I think we have a narrow window of opportunity and everybody has to do their best to grasp this opportunity that will never be back," he said.

webTitle: Railtrack misses target

fields.headline: Railtrack misses target
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Frustrated rail passengers will today still face chaos and delays on large parts of the network .
fields.body:
Frustrated rail passengers will today still face chaos and delays on large parts of the network after the holiday break amid increasing anger among the 25 train-operating companies that Railtrack is failing to deliver its recovery programme.

Senior sources from the Association of Train Operating Companies (Atoc) last night accused Railtrack of adopting a "high-handed" attitude to restoring the network to normal. They said they had protested to Railtrack on several occasions that it was not consulting properly with the companies.

The train companies are angry that Railtrack appears to be making decisions on the restoration of the network following the Hatfield crash in October, and then telling the companies what it has done.

For the moment, Atoc is not prepared to air its grievances in public. The companies ac cept that the industry has suffered considerably from criticism in the past few months and are anxious to maintain a unified stance with Railtrack. But if the recovery programme keeps slipping, they are threatening to break ranks.

Railtrack said yesterday that at least 80% of the network should be operating normally by the end of the month, and the rest by Easter. But it can give no guarantees because bad weather may thwart progress. So passengers may have to wait until late spring - around the probable time of the general election - before normal services are running.

The frustration of passengers has already been felt over the long Christmas break during which Railtrack committed itself to resignalling improvements at various key points, including Leeds and London.

Because of the weather, it has not been able to complete some of the work on time, although it is making every effort to finish the job on the west coast mainline and hand over the railway to the train operators by 6am today.

Yesterday only local services were running to and from Euston station in London because of delays in completing the resignalling programme.

A Railtrack spokesman said yesterday that the severe weather conditions and technical difficulties had delayed some of the repair work being carried out. As a result, and in order to try to avoid further disruption, Railtrack closed the line to all trains except local services to carry out extra work.

More than 300 staff have been working day and night since December 23 to ensure the work is carried out as quickly and safely as possible, Railtrack said.

One train operator said: "Every day over the Christmas period, there's been a cock-up, which shows that the recovery programme is not being properly managed. Railtrack just cannot deliver its promises."

Virgin Trains, which operates inter-city services on the west coast mainline, said: "We regret the inconvenience experienced by our passengers. The engineering work has taken longer than anticipated."

This means that commuter and inter-city services in and out of Euston could be affected today because Railtrack may not be able to return all train paths to the operating companies. This would seriously dislocate morning services.

Railtrack said it would not be able to announce how many speed restrictions would be lifted on the network as a result of the intensive Christmas operation, described as the largest the railway has ever seen, until later today.

The complaints from the rail operators about Railtrack's failure to deliver the recovery programme are serious. One of them said: "Railtrack is behaving like an organisation which owes its allegiance to the City and its shareholders. But it is first and foremost an engineering company with a duty to the public and it should remember this."

The companies say they are angry that Railtrack has been muddled and not straightforward in its dealings with them. Railtrack replied that its senior operations director, Johnson Cox, has been meeting the companies almost daily to discuss mutual problems.

It said: "We are doing this in cooperation with the government and the strategic rail authority. We are acting in the best interests of the public be cause we want to get the railway back to normal as quickly as possible."

The companies say they will need at least £300m, more than double the amount of money set aside by Railtrack to compensate them for the hundreds of speed restrictions and track repairs deemed necessary after the Hatfield crash. The government may be required to bail out Railtrack with some of the money from the strategic rail authority.

Last week Railtrack announced plans to recruit 1,000 extra staff as part of its efforts to get services back to normal. The company is looking for 700 signallers and 300 engineers and will attempt to lure back some of its former engineers who have taken early retirement.

webTitle: Palestine's Napoleon draws up battle lines

fields.headline: Palestine's Napoleon draws up battle lines
fields.standfirst:
Support is growing in the West Bank for the people's general and Yasser Arafat's potential successor

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Support is growing in the West Bank for the people's general and Yasser Arafat's potential successor.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
Marwan Barghouti is dangerous company. As the leader of the Palestinian uprising, he is a top target of the Israelis. A nervous Palestinian, watching him go down a flight of steps on the way out of a block of flats in Ramallah yesterday, said: "Give him a few minutes in case the Israelis are waiting."

Those around him have been especially nervous in the last 48 hours as the rate of killings has increased. Among the casualties was one of Mr Barghouti's colleagues in Fatah, the dominant faction in the Palestine Liberation Organisation, shot dead by Israeli security forces on Sunday.

Mr Barghouti is leader of Fatah on the West Bank and its army of stone-throwers, the Fatah youth wing that Israelis refer to as the Tanzim.

He has been dubbed by the Arab press "Fatah's Napoleon", partly because of his diminutive stature and partly because of his energy and charisma. He is a general on the ground, who can be found at street corners during stone-throwing, mobile phone in hand.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has personally blamed him for the intifada. But the uprising has left Mr Barghouti both popular and powerful, and a candidate for succession after the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, goes.

Mr Barghouti is part of Mr Arafat's dilemma. The Palestinian leader is caught between the US president, Bill Clinton, who wants him to accept his peace proposals, and Mr Barghouti, who wants them rejected.

Mr Barghouti, one of the younger generation of Palestinian leaders, is a problem for Mr Arafat because he has come to represent the mood among Palestinians on the ground.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Barghouti was unequivocal: "The US plans are very bad. They have to be rejected. They go against all the UN resolutions [that call for a return to the border that existed before the Arab-Israeli war in 1967 and a return of the refugees]."

Any journalist wanting to meet Mr Barghouti will be directed to Ramallah but no address will be provided, in case the Israelis are listening or following. He does everything possible to minimise the chance of assassination. Once in the town, after a series of phone calls, directions will be given to wherever he has set up his office that particular day, usually in a dingy block of residential flats.

The interview was conducted in an office with dirty white walls, sparsely furnished, with men in jeans and T-shirts armed with AK-47s lounging around. Above his head was a huge portrait of Jerusalem's disputed holy site, called Haram al-Sharif by by Muslims and Temple Mount by Jews. Both sides claim it.

Anniversary

Yesterday was an important day for Mr Barghouti, the 36th anniversary of the founding of Fatah (Victory). Soon after it was established, Palestinian commandos began raids into Israel. Rallies were held throughout the West Bank yesterday to mark the day, adding to the volatility.

Crucially, Mr Barghouti has emerged as the most important Palestinian sceptic about Mr Arafat's conduct of the peace negotiations over the last seven years, especially as during that time the number of Jewish settlements on the West Bank has expanded.

He said publicly that Fatah would refuse to obey an order to stop the intifada on the basis of the US plan on the table at present. This proposes sharing control over Haram al-Sharif and a territorial division more favourable to the Palestinians than before.

But Palestinians have difficulty, in particular, with a US proposal that they renounce the right of return of the 3.5m refugees to Israel.

What if Mr Arafat were to do a deal on the basis of the US plan? Would he oppose his own leader? "He [Arafat] will not. I am confident he will not accept this suggestion because it is an offer to reorganise the Israeli occupation rather than an Israeli withdrawal."

He has built up Fatah on the West Bank as a separate powerbase, separate from the Palestinian Authority, the embryonic government. "We are a party which is the party of the leadership, but we are not the Palestinian Authority," he said.

He provoked controversy when he criticised the Palestinian Authority police for failing to join in the intifada. "Fatah has seven years' experience of an intifada without a Palestinian Authority, and seven years' experience of an Authority without an intifada."

In a direct challenge to Mr Arafat, he wants the delegation negotiating with the Israelis to be widened beyond Mr Arafat and his inner circle to include voices such as Hamas, the Palestinian group committed to violence.

The reason for Mr Barghouti's popularity with Palestinians, especially the young, is his high-profile involvement in the intifada. In contrast with Mr Arafat and his inner circle, who have seldom been seen on the streets during the uprising, Mr Barghouti is visible at each stage of the violent cycle: rallies, riots and funerals.

Mr Barghouti, 41, belongs to the coming generation of Palestinian leaders. He was brought up on the West Bank, unlike Mr Arafat's closest colleagues, almost all of whom were with him in exile in Tunis.

Mr Arafat, 71, is showing signs of ill-health. Palestinians generally are reluctant to speculate on who might replace him, though the assumption is that his successor will be one of the Tunis crowd. The names usually mentioned are Abu Mazin, Abu Ala and Faruq Qaddumi.

Even if one of those takes over, Mr Barghouti's generation, with their different views, know their time will not be long in coming.

When Mr Arafat goes, the Palestinians might even go directly for Mr Barghouti or one of his contemporaries. It would not be the first time that a society living with conflict has opted to follow the man with the gun.

Outspoken critic

Mr Barghouti is a farmer's son, raised in the West Bank village of Kafr Kuber. He was head of Fatah's student movement while at university and was in and out of prison over a six-year period before being deported by Israel to Jordan.

While in exile, he was elected to the Fatah Revolutionary Council, becoming its youngest member. He returned to the West Bank in 1994, among the first group of deportees to go home under the Oslo agreement signed by the Israelis and Palestinians, ending the first intifada.

In a society where few Palestinians will publicly criticise Mr Arafat, Mr Barghouti has been outspoken, especially about the widespread corruption involving those round the Palestinian leader.

The extravagant lifestyle of some of them has led to a lot of disillusionment with the Tunis crowd among young Palestinians.

Mr Barghouti has said repeatedly that the only language Israel understands is force. He has consistently advocated a more aggressive approach towards Israel. When Israeli forces pulled out of Lebanon in the summer after sustained attacks from the guerrillas of the Islamic group, Hizbullah, the lesson Mr Barghouti drew was that Israel responds to force.

Against that background, it is no surprise that the Israelis have already made one strike against one of his offices since the uprising began: he was absent when the helicopter fired its missile.

He said at the time: "The Israelis say they bombed the headquarters of the Tanzim and the offices of Marwan Barghouti, but as you can see, that is not true. Marwan Barghouti is right here. They say they wanted to send me a personal message. But you can tell them I did not receive the message."

They missed that time. They may not miss next time. He and those surrounding him have good cause to nervous.

webTitle: Escape blocked in Dutch cafe fire

fields.headline: Escape blocked in cafe fire
fields.standfirst: Blocked exits raised toll in Dutch New Year fire
fields.trailText: Blocked exits raised toll in Dutch New Year fire.
fields.body:
Burning Christmas decorations were being blamed last night for a horrific fire that turned a Dutch New Year's Eve party into a smoke-filled hell in which at least eight young people were choked or burned to death. The toll is expected to rise as high as 20 dead.

The simple green-painted seafront cafe where the mostly teenage victims died in the sleepy Netherlands coastal village of Volendam was called Het Hemeltje, "Little Heaven".

While police in the sleepy Netherlands coastal village of Volendam said that the precise cause of the deadly blaze would not be known until investigations were completed, the mayor, Frank Ijsselmuiden, said the fire originated in Christmas decorations covering the ceiling of Little Heaven.

The crowd had panicked, he said, because all but one of the emergency exits were blocked.

Some witnesses reported having seen partygoers take fireworks inside the cafe, which was bedecked with fairy lights and pine branches, like so many others in Volendam, a former eel-fishing community turned tourist destination on the inland Ijsselmeer sea, just half an hour's drive from Amsterdam.

Of 90 people still in hospital, some flown by army helicopters to special burns units as far afield as Belgium and Germany, 12 were in serious to critical condition.

Witnesses described nightmare scenes on the top floor of the three-storey wooden building as flaming debris rained down on hundreds of terrified young revellers. "All the lights went out and there was panic and people were screaming and treading on top of each other as they tried to get out," said one young woman, still dazed by the night's events.

"It was like warfare, people screaming and trampling over each other to get out," recalled Henk Jong, who ran out of a bar around the corner to help a distraught woman with bloodied hands who was looking for her children - one of many parents who watched in horror as emergency services scrambled to get the dead and injured out of the building.

"Volendam is a small village and everyone knows each other," said Arie Derksen, who coordinated the Dutch Red Cross workers on the scene.

The blaze was shortlived but intense and left largely intact the steeply gabled building with its red roof, looking out over a frozen marina and the slate-coloured winter sea.

Smashed panes in the second floor windows showed where terrified partygoers had jumped screaming to escape the choking fumes and flames.

"The people I saw will be scarred for the rest of their lives," said Mr Jong. "They were maimed and burned - a woman without an ear and her hair burned off, and a boy without skin on his arms."

Red Cross officials said the alarm was raised shortly after 12.30 am, and that it took about 15 minutes for the first ambulances and medical teams to arrive.

Dutch NOS television, which had closed down for the evening after wishing its viewers a happy new year, returned to broadcast live from Volendam throughout the night. One injured man be ing carried out on a stretcher was heard saying: "Panic, panic, everywhere panic."

Later grim-faced villagers gathered silently around televisions in their sitting rooms to watch Mayor Ijsselmuiden give a sombre press conference in the council offices.

It was only last May that 20 people died in a massive explosion at a fireworks factory in the town of Enschede in the eastern Netherlands. That was the country's worst disaster since 43 people were killed by an El Al plane that crashed into flats near Schipol airport in 1992.

Many unanswered questions lingered over last night's tragedy, including the access to exits, and the apparent removal of a fire escape at the rear of the building.

Dutch radio reported that owners of clubs had been ordered to treat tinsel and other decorations with fire-retardant spray. Every disaster is a disaster for those who are involved," said Jos Van Kemenade, the provincial governor. "But this is a very big one."

Mr Ijsselmuiden called it a night of terror: "I saw disoriented youngsters with fear in their eyes. I watched as one of those youngsters died while rescue workers tried to resuscitate him."

Doctors at a trauma centre near Amsterdam said scores of people were still being treated for severe burns and smoke inhalation and predicted that the death toll could rise as high as 20.

"I was partying together with my mates, and all of the sudden, boom! In one second, everything vanished. You couldn't see a thing," one of the partygoers told reporters.

The eight confirmed dead were aged 17-22 and all lived in Volendam, according to the local authorities.

Officials said that many of those who suffered burns were wearing fashionable clothing made of highly flammable synthetic material.

webTitle: Curse of customs and hexcise

fields.headline: Curse of customs and hexcise
fields.trailText: When suspicious customs officials dismantled a wooden monkey statue to discover 666 grammes of cannabis inside, the quantity alone should have been enough of a warning.
fields.body:
When suspicious customs officials dismantled a wooden monkey statue to discover 666 grammes of cannabis inside, the quantity alone should have been enough of a warning.

Their delight turned to terror when the monkey's owner - a witch doctor from Ghana - was arrested and promptly put a curse on the inanimate beast against which their rubber gloves were no protection.

Soon the "devil monkey", as it was swiftly dubbed, had been blamed for scores of injuries at work. Customs officials were wounded by splinters, tripped over it or had the figure fall on them from shelves.

"It is cursed. It is very dangerous," said Nigel Knott, spokesman for customs at Dover docks, where the statuette was seized.

The cautionary tale emerged as customs officers yesterday revealed some of the more bizarre tricks in the smuggler's repertoire.

Filling condoms with drugs and then hiding them on the body is a favourite tactic; in one recent case a man who was stopped in his car in the Channel tunnel was jailed for seven years after an x-ray revealed 117 condoms inside his stomach.

"He also had one stuffed somewhere else for good measure," Mr Knott said.

There have been people who have swallowed more than 200 condoms, and they can be stored for up to 14 days.

One of the most unusual smuggling methods is to dissolve cocaine in alcohol. "The alcohol is placed in a bath and the cocaine is absorbed into the liquid," Mr Knott said. "A suit is then put in the bath and the suit is transported across the borders."

Seven hundred boxes of fake avocados made from papier-mache and filled with cocaine have also been seized, while a man was jailed for 14 years for trying to smuggle thousands of ecstasy tablets in the arms of a JCB digger.

A number of women have been detained after drugs were found flattened on to their heads and covered by Afro-style wigs.

webTitle: Snow and rain spoil the party as 2001 gets off to a soggy start

fields.headline: Snow and rain spoil the party as 2001 gets off to a soggy start
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The curse of the millennium, which has dogged the dome, the wobbly bridge and a string of other grandiose projects, saved up its final bite for the last hours of 2000.
fields.body:
The curse of the millennium, which has dogged the dome, the wobbly bridge and a string of other grandiose projects, saved up its final bite for the last hours of 2000.

Insurance companies are faced with a long list of claims for cancelled concerts, damp laser electrics and unused firework displays, after snow and rain played havoc on New Year's night.

Among victims were the civic celebrations in Liverpool, Bradford and Middlesbrough and large parts of other planned beanfeasts financed by the millennium commission's valedictory "party budget". Stirling, Derry and Brighton and Hove - one of Britain's two new millennial cities - also cancelled, while Bristol scaled celebrations down and Belfast moved them indoors.

The cruel timing of a band of snow, gales and sleet affected almost a third of the 32 major centres financed by the millennium commission in a £6.5m attempt to see the year out in style. It topped the earlier London letdown which saw the mayor, Ken Livingstone, cancel a huge firework display because of fears about public safety and problems with tube and bus services to get revellers home.

Festivities also suffered from fear of the weather rather than actual Arctic conditions in a number of cities, including Newcastle upon Tyne which had been given doom-laden forecasts during the countdown to New Year's Eve. In the event, the 40,000 people who took the risk to watch fire works on Tyneside enjoyed a clear and not particularly chilly night and were consequently in an excellent mood.

Good humour also marked the 10,000 who took to much colder streets in Birmingham and an estimated 70,000 in London who ignored official advice to stay away from Trafalgar Square.

The commission could not be contacted yesterday, but a number of the disrupted cities and towns are expected to reschedule events early in 2001. In Leeds, where rain and snow made a laser show too risky, abandoned highlights of what was to have been "the biggest party ever held in Yorkshire" are being pencilled in for next month.

The city had been given £210,000 by the commission to help the celebrations.

webTitle: Ministers bridle at Tory taunts on patriotism

fields.headline: Ministers bridle at Tory taunts on patriotism
fields.standfirst:
Government 'open to suggestions' on celebrating 1801 union

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Government 'open to suggestions' on celebrating 1801 union.
fields.body:
The government yesterday rejected Conservative complaints that only its contempt for the traditional UK institutions had prevented official celebration of yesterday's 200th anniversary of the union between Britain and Ireland.

Tony Blair's "patriotism minister", Michael Wills, and the cabinet office minister, Lord Falconer, both insisted they were open to suggestions, in the face of Tory taunts that Labour's commitment to Britishness was skin deep.

Lord Falconer, who is also in charge of the Millennium Dome project, told the Guardian that 2001 was also the tercentenary of the 1701 Act of Union which united the crowns of England and Scotland, six years before political union of the two parliaments was finally agreed.

"If people have ideas about how we should celebrate them, let them come forward," he said.

Mr Wills, whose main job is minister for information and communications technology, said: "We haven't made a decision on this yet. The Cabinet Office is still considering what to do about this."

The even more controversial abolition of the Irish parliament by William Pitt took place in the wake of radical rebellion in 1798 and war against revolutionary France - which invaded Ireland. It was steered through the Dublin parliament, long dominated from London, in August 1800.

The union, which gave the union flag its current form, came into force on January 1 1801 but was never accepted, not least because Pitt was unable to fulfil his pledge to restore the vote to Catholics in the package that gave Ireland 100 MPs at Westminster.

When they finally got the vote after 1829, Catholics began the long agitation for home rule which culminated in the partition of Ireland in 1921.

None of which prevented the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, on Radio 4's Today programme, from accusing ministers of lacking respect for or understanding of British institutions.

"It is a bit rich for Michael Wills to say: 'We are still considering whether we are going to celebrate the birthday', when the birthday has taken place. The very fact that this government has appointed a junior minister as the patriotism minister puts in perspective what this government thinks about the union."

As a Scottish Catholic aristocrat and former Northern Ireland minister, Mr Ancram is better placed than most people to understand the controversies lurking below the surface or the historic propensity of his own party to "play the Orange card" in Irish politics.

Yesterday he went no further than to stress that the union flag "stands for one nation, a United Kingdom, for our country as a beacon of democracy ... These are things we know instinctively. We don't have to have junior ministers considering in what way we will mark that."

Labour ministers, who have presided over sweeping constitutional reform, notably in devolving power to Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast, are hyper-sensitive to charges that they lack patriotism. They believe that devolution has saved the union with Scotland.

But they are also exploring new forms of national identity for a post-imperial, multicultural Britain in the "heart" of the EU. Mr Wills is organising debates on such themes throughout Britain this year.

Robin Ashburner, president of the Flag Institute, said the institute had urged an official ceremony to mark the 1801 anniversary. He had written to Mr Wills "suggesting that something be done", but his reply was "non-committal and showed no interest", he told the Today programme.

Tony Blair's "patriotism minister", Michael Wills, and the cabinet office minister, Lord Falconer, both insisted they were open to suggestions, in the face of Tory taunts that Labour's commitment to Britishness was skin deep. Lord Falconer, who is also in charge of the Millennium Dome project, told the Guardian that 2001 was also the tercentenary of the 1701 Act of Union which united the crowns of England and Scotland, six years before political union of the two parliaments was finally agreed. "If people have ideas about how we should celebrate them, let them come forward," he said. Mr Wills, whose main job is minister for information and communications technology, said: "We haven't made a decision on this yet. The Cabinet Office is still considering what to do about this." The even more controversial abolition of the Irish parliament by William Pitt took place in the wake of radical rebellion in 1798 and war against revolutionary France - which invaded Ireland. It was steered through the Dublin parliament, long dominated from London, in August 1800. The union, which gave the union flag its current form, came into force on January 1 1801 but was never accepted, not least because Pitt was unable to fulfil his pledge to restore the vote to Catholics in the package that gave Ireland 100 MPs at Westminster. When they finally got the vote after 1829, Catholics began the long agitation for home rule which culminated in the partition of Ireland in 1921. None of which prevented the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, on Radio 4's Today programme, from accusing ministers of lacking respect for or understanding of British institutions. "It is a bit rich for Michael Wills to say: 'We are still considering whether we are going to celebrate the birthday', when the birthday has taken place. The very fact that this government has appointed a junior minister as the patriotism minister puts in perspective what this government thinks about the union." As a Scottish Catholic aristocrat and former Northern Ireland minister, Mr Ancram is better placed than most people to understand the controversies lurking below the surface or the historic propensity of his own party to "play the Orange card" in Irish politics. Yesterday he went no further than to stress that the union flag "stands for one nation, a United Kingdom, for our country as a beacon of democracy ... These are things we know instinctively. We don't have to have junior ministers considering in what way we will mark that." Labour ministers, who have presided over sweeping constitutional reform, notably in devolving power to Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast, are hyper-sensitive to charges that they lack patriotism. They believe that devolution has saved the union with Scotland. But they are also exploring new forms of national identity for a post-imperial, multicultural Britain in the "heart" of the EU. Mr Wills is organising debates on such themes throughout Britain this year. Robin Ashburner, president of the Flag Institute, said the institute had urged an official ceremony to mark the 1801 anniversary. He had written to Mr Wills "suggesting that something be done", but his reply was "non-committal and showed no interest", he told the Today programme.

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Now is the time to go through all last year's notebooks and diaries to gather together sightings and records for the county recorder and his annual report. The importance of these observations cannot be emphasised enough - not only do they help provide a picture of the year and an indication of nature's wellbeing or otherwise, but they add another chapter to the continuous monitoring of the health of our natural environment.

I recall, back in the 80s, a colleague, who was then bird recorder for a neighbouring county, muttering darkly each year about the pages and pages of records he was receiving from one contributor, all about the house sparrow. At that time this was a very common bird, probably common enough to be almost taken for granted, but how important those records have turned out to be, as widespread concern is now being expressed about the plight of the house sparrow. In the village, the valley and the surrounding local farms its numbers have dropped dramatically in recent times.

It is no longer a regular visitor to my garden, and the flocks that used to gather around the farmyards at this time of year are now few and far between. Current opinion seems to favour the lack of winter food as the cause, which is a similar situation to that affecting the finch flocks that have always relied on winter seed and grain supplies to see them through to the next spring. These and similar trends usually only come to light by constant monitoring and recording, in which both your and my records play a vital role.

webTitle: Suspicion and anger over army watchtowers

fields.headline: Suspicion and anger all along the watchtower
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An Orwellian invasion of privacy and a health hazard - or an integral part of a sophisticated and indispensable security system? The army watchtowers of south Armagh, 80ft high and covered in satellite dishes and observation equipment, are at the centre of a debate which threatens to obscure the Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
An Orwellian invasion of privacy and a health hazard - or an integral part of a sophisticated and indispensable security system? The army watchtowers of south Armagh, 80ft high and covered in satellite dishes and observation equipment, are at the centre of a debate which threatens to obscure the Northern Ireland peace process.

Republicans say they should be pulled down and the whole south Armagh operation, including foot patrols and helicopters, got rid of as part of the demilitarisation promised in the Good Friday agreement.

But unionists, the security forces and to date, the government, insist that the menace from dissident and, in some cases, mainstream paramilitaries, means the towers, built in 1986, are still essential.

There are between 600 and 1,000 troops in the region, depending on operations, though these are spread as far as Newry and Downpatrick, and 14 watchtowers.

An army spokesman would only confirm: "We will continue to provide the level of protection and support the RUC requires to provide a service to the entire community."

It is believed police officers venturing out in south Armagh have around a dozen soldiers covering them, and if the towers were taken away, two or even three times as many troops would be on the ground during RUC manoeuvres.

For the residents' spokeswoman Toni Carragher, the damage caused and dangers posed by the security operation outweigh the supposed benefits.

She claimed there was evidence that the electronic surveillance equipment in the towers caused radiation contributing to the high incidence of cancer in the region. She argued patrols and helicopter activity were spreading cattle disease from farm to farm.

Infringement of civil liberties was also an issue. "The towers are a bloody eyesore but they are much more than that. There is nowhere in south Armagh where you are not being watched and listened to, every minute of the day and night. It is a spider's web and we are caught in it. They watch your home, they search your car when you go shopping ..."

She maintained the towers served no discernible function. "The dissident threat is very small. How do they know the Omagh bomb was made in this area? They have no proof, and anyway, if they say it was, what did the towers do to stop it?

"The Good Friday agreement said there would be demilitarisation but instead, the army has been rebuilding and refurbishing. We are being forced to live in a war zone and the army is dictating to the government."

The issue was affecting republican confidence in the peace process just as lack of the decommissioning of IRA weapons was sapping unionist confidence. "Around 99% of south Armagh voted for the agreement. If there was a referendum tomorrow I doubt you would get half that."
