webTitle: Blinding light that hides cosmos

fields.headline: Blinding light that hides cosmos
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners plead for darker skies because children are growing up ignorant of nightly glories of natural skyscape

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Campaigners plead for darker skies because children are growing up ignorant of nightly glories of natural skyscape.
fields.body:
The clouds had cleared over Guy Hurst's back garden and, as our eyes adjusted to the night, a few pinpricks of light resolved themselves in the sky. "That's Jupiter, in the east," said Hurst, pointing to the brightest object. "To the right, much fainter, is Saturn. That belt of stars is the Pleiades."

With a shuddering and a clattering, a tight constellation of stars, two white and one red, detached itself from the firmament and moved swiftly across the heavens. "That's a helicopter," said Hurst. Military helicopters from the airbase at Odiham nearby are the gentlest kind of interference coming between Hurst, one of the country's best-known amateur astronomers, and the glories of the night sky.

He lives outside Basingstoke, Hampshire, which is trapped, like much of Britain, in a giant bubble of light pollution - billions of watts of wasted light, poured into the sky from signs, security lights, floodlights and around 7m street lights.

Over Christmas, when the skies were briefly clear, people got their best chance to see the International Space Station, its newly-attached 200ft sun-gathering "wings" catching the light for several minutes as it tracked across the horizon. City dwellers could only see it through the thick fog of artificial lights, because it is one of the brightest objects in the sky. In 2000, if we want to see wonders of the cosmos, we have to make them.

Anger over light pollution has coalesced into a campaign for planning controls called the British Astronomical Association's Campaign for Dark Skies. The coordinator, Bob Mizon, said they wanted better lights, not no lights. "We're not campaigning for dark streets," he said. "We're campaigning for dark skies."

All of us are blinded by the light, he points out. Children are growing up ignorant of the nightly glories of the natural skyscape - constellations, meteors, comets and the richness of a black sky dusted with thousands of stars. "One reason why astrology is promoted in popular culture more than astronomy is people can see horoscopes any day, but nobody can see real stars and planets. Because of light pollution, most children in this country have never seen the Milky Way."

A few years ago evening shoppers in the centre of Basingstoke saw a man standing in the middle of a supermarket car park, his shopping forgotten, gazing at the sky. They asked him what he was looking at. They followed his finger: it was comet Hale-Bopp, a comet so bright it could penetrate the heart of the town's electric glow.

That man was Guy Hurst. No wonder the shoppers were intrigued. There's usually precious little reason to scan the heavens over central Basingstoke, a town no more or less light polluted than scores of others. The road from the station is awash in apricot-coloured streetlight bright enough to read a newspaper by. A retail park blazes with car park lights, metre-high logos glow on retail warehouses. The moon is bright, a couple of days off full, but it is outshone into insignificance by the illuminations of corporate and municipal Britain.

Hurst lives in the suburbs four or five miles away. It is darker, but is still well within the area of Basingstoke's primary light bubble. Two street lights gush bright orange light outside his house. Across the road, his neighbours - whom he gets on fine with otherwise - have installed a powerful security light, the latest scourge of stargazers. Hurst has surrounded the garden with tall laurel and leylandii but the light leaks through into his shed-like home-made observatory.

"The security light shines straight through this gap here," he said. "If it comes on just as you're about to start looking at something, you find your whole dark adaptation goes." He nodded at the streetlights. "They're not really designed to reflect light downwards. A good proportion of that light is going horizontally, or even slightly upwards."

Back in the garden, Hurst pointed to where the Milky Way, a river of millions of stars making up one of the spokes of our spiral home galaxy, should be visible, running through the constellations Auriga (the Charioteer), and Perseus. There is nothing to be seen.

We drove across the M3 and headed into the countryside, seeking darkness. On a B-road close to the village of Axford, we got out to see a sky which was almost black. More stars could be seen. In quick succession, three meteors cut white streaks through the night. Even here, the Milky Way was invisible. We were in the overlap between the edge of Basingstoke's night glow and that of other southern towns and villages. There are thousands of stars and at least one galaxy to be seen with the naked eye, but we could only see a few dozen. Hurst indicated the square of Pegasus, formed by four stars. "There are lots of stars in that square, but we can't see any of them."

Serious light pollution began blotting out the stars in the 1950s, when electric street lighting became widespread and powerful. The government is becoming aware of the problem, and is starting to realise that street lights are available which direct light into a broad cone downwards, leaving the sky dark and saving energy.

Campaigners praise Railtrack and the highways agency, which are beginning to install sky-friendly lighting. Some town streets and a handful of supermarket car parks have been purged of lamps such as the dreaded globes which radiate illumination evenly in all directions.

Sometimes there are other reasons for darkening the skies. Railtrack found its old lights were confusing drivers on the lookout for signals, while a scheme to illuminate the Humber Bridge with 72 thousand-watt floodlights - the glow would have been visible 50 miles away - was dumped mainly because of fears that migrating birds would get fatally lost.

The era of the security lights - a high powered external light linked to a movement detector to deter burglars - means a new threat. "Anyone can put a 1000-watt security light on their cottage and there is nothing you can do about it," said Bob Mizon. "Light isn't considered pollution like barking dogs or dirty air.

webTitle: Police recover bodies of skaters drown in lake

fields.headline: Police recover bodies of skaters drown in lake
fields.standfirst: Inseparable cousins will be buried together after divers find them beneath broken ice in New Year's Eve tragedy
fields.trailText: Inseparable cousins will be buried together after divers find them beneath broken ice in New Year's Eve tragedy.
fields.body:
Police yesterday recovered the bodies of two girl cousins who drowned when ice gave way under them on a lake in Co Monaghan in the Irish Republic.

Louise McAloon, 12, and Veronica McAloon, 10, left home on Sunday after telling family they were going skating on Hollywood lake, and were reported missing when they did not return in the afternoon.

Their bodies were found lying close to each other, a few feet from holes in the ice and in about 10ft of water. Divers and a police helicopter had been searching the lake, between Ballanode and Scotstown outside Monaghan town, as had 200 to 300 local people.

The water had been covered in a thick layer of ice for several days, and dozens of people had been skating on the lake on Saturday. However, a thaw began in most parts of Ireland on Sunday.

Louise's father, Owen McAloon, said the family had at first hoped the children had gone into town, rather than skating, when they failed to return home. His daughter was "a strong swimmer" who had attained her lifesaver's certificate last year.

Mr McAloon described Louise as a quiet child who loved school, and said she had been given silver jewellery and sweets for Christmas. "When I saw her in the coffin, there she was wearing the earrings I gave her," he said.

Veronica, a pupil at St Mary's national school, was one of five children. Her parents, Martin and Mary, were too distraught to speak yesterday.

According to Mr McAloon, the two girls were inseparable, and they will be buried together.

Also in Ireland a 16-year-old died from neck injuries when her makeshift toboggan hit a tree in Swords, Co Dublin, on Saturday night.

In Surrey, Charlie Gordon, 15, was killed when she touched an electrified rail track. She had been walking along tracks near Shepperton train station with teenage friends at 11.50pm on Sunday, a spokesman for British Transport police said.

On the M25 in Hertfordshire, two men died when their BMW convertible spun off the road. South of Bodmin in Cornwall, a man was killed when his Ford Sierra struck a wall on an icy country road. The body of a man in his 30s was discovered on Sunday by a walker near Darwen in Lancashire.

In Scotland a climber died after falling 100ft off Ben Nevis, while yesterday mountain rescue teams were searching for a second climber.

In Devon a firefighter had to be winched to safety as he clung to a tree to prevent himself from being swept away by floodwaters. He had been helping rescue three people whose Range Rover became trapped in the flooded river Axe at Weycroft mill in the early hours of yesterday.

After clinging to the tree for more than an hour the firefighter was rescued by an RAF Sea King helicopter from Chivenor in north Devon, which had just returned from two other rescues on the same stretch of the river - a man winched from the roof of his car, and another plucked from a tree where he had climbed to escape the floodwater; both were taken to hospital with hypothermia.

Six more firefighters had to be rescued by lifeboat when their fire engine became stuck in floods near Stranraer in Ayrshire.

Last night 30 flood warnings remained on rivers across the country as an unseasonably warm start to the new year melted snow, while forecasters predicted more heavy rain.

In the Atlantic, 13 fishermen, Spanish and African, were rescued by helicopter. The crew of the UK-registered Pembroke were taken to an airbase in Cork, in the Irish Republic, by a Royal Navy Sea King after their fishing boat lost her rudder and began taking in water 180 miles west of the Isles of Scilly.

A helicopter also saved the life of a 10-year-old boy who fell through ice on a pond in London yesterday afternoon. A spokeswoman for the Royal London hospital, where the boy was treated for cold and shock, said: "The team had no time to land the helicopter, so they hovered a few inches above the ice and a doctor leant out to pull the boy on board."

In Wales a 19-year-old woman was seriously injured outside the Rack and Roll club in Newport at around 5.50am. Detectives said a car had apparently driven deliberately at a group leaving a New Year's Eve party.

In Bristol police were questioning a man following a death at a private party in the Harcliffe area.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Antz | Stand By Me | The Apple | Great Expectations
fields.body:
Antz

(Eric Darnell, Tim Johnson, 1998) 11.15am, 6.15pm, Sky Premier

The DreamWorks animated blockbuster that took on Disney/Pixar's A Bug's Life in the insect war. It starts hilariously, with the Woody Allen-voiced Z-4195 on the psychiatrist's leaf wondering if there's more to life than being a worker ant. There is: romance with Princess Bala (Sharon Stone) and war with the termites is just around the corner. With Sly Stallone as a soldier ant and Gene Hackman as crazy General Mandible, this is inspired fun - even if the screen is at times stodgy with subterranean hues.

Stand By Me (pictured)

(Rob Reiner, 1986)

8pm, FilmFour

Reiner creates from Stephen King's story a moving, Huckleberry Finn-ish childhood in a 50s US backwater. Four pals are trekking through the woods one summer in search of the corpse of a missing teenager; they are captured perfectly on the cusp of adolescence, between innocence and experience. Fine performances, particularly from gangleader Wil Wheaton and soulful River Phoenix; Richard Dreyfuss is the adult narrator, reminiscing on his rite of passage.

The Apple

(Samira Makhmalbaf, 1998)

12midnight, FilmFour

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Children see scientists as geeky, bespectacled white men with beards and bad hair, according to research in Britain and Australia. Dr Tina Jarvis of Leicester University said those opinions must be challenged if pupils were not to lose interest in science.
fields.body:
Scientists seen as geeky

Children see scientists as geeky, bespectacled white men with beards and bad hair, according to research in Britain and Australia. Dr Tina Jarvis of Leicester University said those opinions must be challenged if pupils were not to lose interest in science.

Heads attack colleges plan

Headteachers yesterday claimed the government's move to create 1,000 "specialist college" comprehensives which receive extra funds due to their expertise in a subject was unfair. The Secondary Heads Association said the scheme should be extended to all secondary schools.

Race is on for delayed sailor

British sailor Tony Bullimore, 62, yesterday started The Race, a round-the-world challenge, from Barcelona nearly 24 hours late after a last minute dash to qualify. The skipper of the catamaran Team Legato is 100 miles behind the slowest competitor.

Paramedics suffer stress

One in three ambulance workers suffers mental health problems, with burnout and post-traumatic stress both common problems, according to a survey of 110 staff in Scotland published in the British Journal of Psychology yesterday.

£4m fund to help brain gain

A £4m fund to attract the world's leading scientists by promising salaries of more than £100,000 was announced by the science minister Lord Sainsbury yesterday. Universities will bid for the awards, which will top up salaries.

webTitle: Interview: Daniel Craig, star of Sword of Honour

fields.headline: Declaration of Waugh
fields.standfirst: Any adaptation of Evelyn Waugh inevitably evokes images of aristocratic languor, Brideshead-style. But Sword Of Honour, a Channel 4 two-parter, is a far grittier affair. Mark Morris spoke to its down-to-earth star, Daniel Craig
fields.trailText: Any adaptation of Evelyn Waugh inevitably evokes images of aristocratic languor, Brideshead-style. But Sword Of Honour, a Channel 4 two-parter, is a far grittier affair. Mark Morris spoke to its down-to-earth star, Daniel Craig.
fields.body:
Ah, Brideshead Revisited, that monument of British TV. An icon of ITV's better days, source of style tips for Thatcherite fops everywhere, and great comfort of Anglophile Americans to this day. And, presumably, an inspiration to anyone considering appearing in a TV adaptation of an Evelyn Waugh book. Someone like Daniel Craig, star of Sword Of Honour.

"When I went to meet the director I said 'If this is anything like Brideshead, fuck off. I can't be bothered with it.' He just went, 'No, we're not going to do that.'" The casting alone is enough to tell you that Sword Of Honour isn't Brideshead Revisited revisited. Rather than Jeremy Irons, we have Craig, still best known as Geordie - the one who learns the dark ways of Soho from Malcolm McDowell - in Our Friends In The North. Mike Leigh favourite Katrin Cartlidge plays a scheming expat, and Leslie Phillips is the central character's father. William Boyd has boiled the whole thing down from Waugh's autobiographical trilogy about the Second World War, a disillusioned and bitterly funny series of books that is a world away from the social-climbing nostalgia of Brideshead Revisited. In Sword Of Honour, middle-aged posh failure, Guy Crouchback, joins up in search of redemption through glory, and finds that the British army only values cowards and liars. Boyd likes to think of it as an English Catch-22. The best bits of this TV adaptation, showing the sick comedy of the disastrous British operations in Crete, are exactly that.

"If we got a page in the Daily Mail saying 'This is not Evelyn Waugh!' I'd be very happy," says Craig. He knows that Crouchback isn't an obviously sympathetic character. "That's what makes him interesting. The fact is that he's a bit of a screwup. That either endears you to him, or you wish he'd get on with things. But I related to that, that's quite a modern feeling, that feeling that life ends up passing you by if you don't stop and think about it. And he forces himself to think about it, but he forces himself in the wrong way: he thinks he's going to find it by going to war."

At 32, Craig is a bit younger than Crouchback, but he has one of those faces that is neither transparently young nor old. It helped him in the long timespan of Our Friends In The North, and has allowed him to play a series of wildly different characters, perhaps, most memorably, Francis Bacon's lover, George Dyer, in Love Is The Devil. But he is easily recognisable because of his striking blue eyes.

This is the Daniel Craig story, as he tells it: "Grew up on the Wirral, left home at 16 or 17, came down to London, did the National Youth Theatre, managed to stay in London somehow, went to drama school, became an actor. There is some other stuff, but really that's it."

His performances suggest someone gruff, insular and hard, but he turns out to be affable and talkative, even on the subject of Tomb Raider. He is in the middle of shooting the film version - his first blockbuster - and all sorts of dire warnings have been issued about plot secrecy.

"The deal is: I know about the game, I find out that this guy Simon West is directing it, I get an interview to meet the guy and I really like him. I don't want to be screwed around and I think I'm going to play the poor English cousin in this big old movie. But my profile had been raised because of Love Is The Devil, and they were going 'We WANT YOU to do this movie' and for an actor that's 'Oh, you do? Really?' It was shit-or-get-off-the-pot time. I mean, I want to make smaller-budget movies, much more character-based, with more of a message. But if I can do this movie and it can raise my profile enough..."

As Kate Winslet did with Titanic? (Incidentally, a younger Winslet and Craig once played a couple in A Kid In King Arthur's Court.) "That's my ideal. She's doing it right. Now she can go to do a movie that is short of half a million quid, and that half a million quid will then appear, and that film will get made, and she'll have some artistic control and, on the back of her name, she'll be putting something back into the business. And that seems to be the right move."

He is fully versed in the Tomb Raider worldwide-phenomenon statistics, which he recites with a laugh. Usefully, before he ever got the role, he'd wasted enough hours sending Lara Croft down secret passageways himself. But he has a more pertinent argument about why the film might just work: "This guy Simon West...Con Air [directed by West] is a very funny movie, its tongue is placed firmly in its cheek, but with style. I think he's bright. And Angelina Jolie is a piece of classic casting." Of course, Tomb Raider could be the hit of the summer and international superstardom could still pass Daniel Craig by. After all, The Mummy hasn't turned John Hannah into someone who makes people faint in the streets. But that doesn't seem to be what Daniel Craig is after, anyway. He's not interested in making it too easy for himself, or the audience. Which is why you should give Sword Of Honour a go, even - no, especially - if the decaying aristos of Brideshead made you feel nauseous.

"If you stick with it, there is a sort of pay-off, but what I like about it is that it's not an obvious pay-off. It's not like everything joins up and is happy. Waugh was a bitter and twisted old man by the time he died, and that's what Sword Of Honour is about. It is a bit inconclusive. The audience has to work a bit, and I think that's a good thing."

 Sword of Honour, tonight & tomorrow, 9pm, Channel 4,

webTitle: Answer me: Basil Brush

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Basil Brush
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Basil Brush
fields.body:
Full name: Basil Merryweather DeVere Rothschild Brush III.

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

My Swiss Banker knows me as 1792038976.

Have you ever lied about your age and if so why?

Certainly not. I'm 32 and I make no bones about it. "Someone who would lie about his age cannot be trusted with anything," as Lloyd George once said to me.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Short celebrity, VVVGSOH, wishes to meet petite non-smoking vixen with charming personality and pots of cash. No time-wasters.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Smuggling Jelly Babies into Dubai.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Shared my great gift with the British public unstintingly.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Me.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

BM and JN.

Has a critic ever made you cry? Yes. Kenneth Tynan stood on my paw once, while he was queuing up to get my autograph.

What would you advertise without a fee? Jelly Babies and Dandelion and Burdock.

What would you never advertise?

My own accomplishments. They speak for themselves.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

That dream where I've forgotten my catchphrase.

What takes you to a "happy place"? The No 14 bus to Richmond Park - there's a lively little chicken coop I know nearby.

 A new series, Foxed, is due to be screened later this year.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Consultants | The Colour Of Music
fields.body:
Recent cases before the General Medical Council have badly dented the standing of some of our leading medical specialists. Now, in The Consultants (8pm, Radio 4) Edi Stark tries to see things from their side of the bed. This week and next she follows senior physicians and surgeons around hospitals in London and Glasgow. She investigates their training and daily work - and why so many of them feel besieged by politicians and misunderstood by patients.

Lionel Richie (pictured), co-author of We Are The World, the charity single which raised funds for Africa, acts as narrator for a mammoth radio history of African music. In eight hour-long episodes, The Colour Of Music (9pm, Radio 2) illustrates the enormous influence of the continent's musical heritage. The traditions carried around the world by slave traders range from music improvised on different parts of one's own body to the complex polyphonic choral singing that has now been traced back to prehistory.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Mac the knife
fields.trailText: The Real Macbeth | Gentleman's Relish | 2000 Acres Of Sky | Postcards from Monica
fields.body:
You remember Big Al, over Christmas? This was simply enormous Al.

Alan Torrance has long, red-gold hair and looks like Thorfinn Skullsplitter. Tony Robinson looks as if he is standing in a hole and, curiously enough, often is. He took a quick step backward. Simply Enormous Al was laying about him with a disembowelling tool and giving an informed running commentary the while. "You're stabbing. You're slashing. You're upper-cutting. You're disembowelling. You're aiming for the ligaments. You're catching the back of the guy's leg. You're crunching bones." Battle, he added, would be nasty, brutish and short. "How short...?" said Tony Robinson nervously, morphing into Baldrick. "You're probably looking at 30 minutes," said Al. At which point in the 11th century, if your ligaments were still intact, you legged it.

All this was apropos The Real Macbeth (Channel 4), who turned out to be charming, at least in terms of his time, earning a warm endorsement from, of all people, the Duncan clan. By the way, have you any idea what Macbeth's first name was? The question never seemed to arise. Lady Macbeth was called Gruoch, which sounds like a sheep coughing in the fog. Her husband killed Macbeth's father so Macbeth naturally burned him alive and married Gruoch. Robinson, an old softie, asked if Gruoch loved Macbeth. Dr Louise Yeoman of the National Library of Scotland was convulsed. "What's love got to do with it? I mean, come on."

Gentleman's Relish (BBC 2) is so called, I assume, because it goes particularly well with crumpet.

Billy Connolly has silvered into something rather flowing and leonine, which could go on as Moses without make-up. Here he plays an Edwardian painter, Kingdom Swann, who turns to photography when his crowded canvases of tangled goddesses go out of fashion. Cromwell Marsh, a quick-talking cockney with an eye to the main chance, pops up like a minor devil. The devil always has the best jokes and Douglas Henshall's perfect imitation of Michael Caine tickles you throughout like a feather in your vest. Cromwell's titillating tit-bits from Kingdom's tableaux are soon selling well under the counter at selected tobacconists to gentlemen with pronounced moustaches. Gentleman's Relish is Edwardian slapstick, a broad-bottomed, jumbo joke which seemed to trundle down the runway for a long time without becoming airborne. On paper it must have seemed perfect. A costume drama about photography and pornography (but was there ever an uglier period? Women seem to be lost in a blizzard of crocheted doilies and moulting poultry. Even the luminous Sarah Lancashire is snuffed out).

Exploding jokes along the way remind you that David Nobbs wrote the screenplay. For instance, at the time ladies' bottoms were very much to the fore, so to speak. As Cromwell says, caught in flagrante with an ample model, "Oh bugger!"

You sense with maternal pleasure what fun the researchers must have had.

We all want to go and live on a Scottish island. In theory. As Michelle Collins says, "Scotland's beautiful. I've seen it on TV." The evocatively named 2000 Acres Of Sky (BBC 1) is a sort of Hamish Heartbeat, set on a Hebridean island. (Not, in fact, an island but Port Logan on the west coast, if you fancy rushing up there.) A bunch of scruffs from Hackney are lured in to bring the haemorrhaging island school up to numbers. The Scottish cast is unobtrusively strong. As Abby, a single mother, Michelle Collins looks like a flower and croaks like a frog and Paul Kaye makes an impact as the lankily dislocated but oddly imaginative Kenny, pretending to be her husband. In the first episode the islanders interview prospective families. Dame Sybil Thorndike said of audiences, "Some nights they're porridge and some nights they're electricity." These, no doubt about it, were porridge. As the hotel owner said, "Anyone prepared to give up their lives and come here, they'd have to be the sort of people we'd rather not come here." The view is an eyebath, you feel refreshed just looking.

Postcards from Monica (Channel 5 Sunday), "Monica Lewinsky visits exotic parts of America." You couldn't make it up.

webTitle: Beat it

fields.headline: Beat it
fields.trailText: Scenes By The Sea: The Life And Cinema Of Takeshi
fields.body:
Somewhere among the gizmos, Godzillas and Graham Norton travelogues that make up Channel 4's Secret Life Of Japan, there's a documentary that stands head and shoulders above the clichés that surround it. Scenes By The Sea: The Life And Cinema Of Takeshi "Beat" Kitano (Channel 4, tonight, 11.25pm) sheds some welcome and occasionally hilarious light on the wit and wisdom of Japanese auteur Kitano (pictured), director and star of such inspired cult classics as Sonatine, Violent Cop and Hana-Bi (which screens straight afterwards). And - as viewers will see for themselves - what a strange man he is.

Opening on the set of Brother, his forthcoming Hollywood debut, Scenes By The Sea finds a grizzled Kitano dabbling artistically in a culture-clash storyline (Japanese Yakuza toughing it out with the American Mafia) while terrifying the cast with his minimalist approach to film-making (two takes, he believes, is one take too many). Cackling and chain-smoking while a flunky holds his ashtray, what we're watching is a man truly in his element.

But what really makes the show special is its focus on Kitano's role as the "king of all media" in his home country. webTitle: Another year of 'unmissable' shows

fields.headline: The truth about those mega-exhibitions: the best works are absent, the curator has an axe to grind and you'll learn nothing about the artist.
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones contemplates another year of 'unmissable' shows.
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones contemplates another year of 'unmissable' shows.
fields.body:
Imagine if Botticelli's Birth of Venus were to leave its permanent home at the Uffizi in Florence and be brought to London for an exhibition at the Royal Academy. Imagine it accompanied by a sackful of other Italian Renaissance masterpieces: Giorgione's Tempest, Masaccio's Crucifixion, Piero della Francesca's Flagellation. How long would the queues be? What would the critics say?

In 1930 what they said was, 'Thank you, Mr Mussolini.' This stupendous exhibition actually happened, as the art historian Francis Haskell recounts in his book The Ephemeral Museum: Old Master Paintings and the Rise of the Art Exhibition. It was the brainchild of Lady Chamberlain, wife of the Conservative foreign secretary and an ardent fan of Italian fascism; it was made possible because Mussolini himself backed the plan as a piece of propaganda and ordered museums and local authorities to lend works they would never have normally parted with.

And the reviews were worth it. Haskell reprints the cartoon in Punch that portrayed "Mussolini the Magnificent" presenting Botticelli's Primavera to John Bull. Even the socialist New Statesman admitted that Britain was in the dictator's debt. Italian Art 1200-1900 was one of the greatest hits in the Royal Academy's history. It attracted 540,000 visitors.

It would be nice to think that today we would greet such an exercise with scepticism. But let's face it - we'd fall for it head over heels. Who asked any difficult questions about the potential harm to Russia if the Hermitage Rooms at Somerset House mark the beginning of a general diffusion of its art treasures? The art exhibition has become one of our favourite treats. Orgies of hype and merchandising, blockbuster shows are the cultural equivalent of a royal wedding or the World Cup - spectacles that make us feel part of a community of chat, deciding that yes, we really do all feel that late Monet is as fascinating if not more so than the Monet of the 1870s.

Last year hardly a week went by without the opening of some absolutely unmissable show, and this year the procession rolls on, genuflecting before one modern or ancient master after another. Many of these exhibitions reconstruct whole cities and art worlds, offering the chance to travel magically to great moments in history: Caravaggio's Rome at the Royal Academy later this month; Brassaï's Paris at the Hayward Gallery in February; and Vermeer's Delft at the National Gallery in the summer.

Vermeer will be the ultimate blockbuster of the year, the guaranteed crowd magnet, though in sheer eye-knackering scale the big blowout is Tate Modern's first loan exhibition, Century City, opening next month, which takes us from Picasso's Paris to Gary Hume's London in 10 normal-sized shows dedicated to 10 cities at significant cultural moments.

But at this banquet of art enters the ghost of Francis Haskell, warning us, if we care to listen, that we're losing something precious in the riot and noise. Haskell, an art historian who changed the way his subject was understood, died a year ago and The Ephemeral Museum is a posthumous publication. He worked on it in the knowledge he was dying and it was prepared for publication by his friend and collaborator Nicholas Penny. There's a subtle passion running through what is on the surface a sombre history of the rise of the Old Master exhibition. But it's love rather than anger that shines out of the book - Haskell's love for the art of the past and his conviction it is being abused.

He is fair in showing the positive side of exhibitions. The first shows were contemporary ones, beginning with the Salon in 18th-century Paris. The Old Master exhibition, Haskell's b te noire, came into its own in 19th-century Britain, where the National Gallery (founded in 1824) took a long time to build its collection to the standard of European rivals. The gap was filled by temporary shows from Britain's private collections; from 1870 the main venue of these was the Royal Academy's new home at Burlington House in Piccadilly. Yet the most awesome Victorian exhibition took place in Manchester.

Art Treasures of the United Kingdom opened in a custom-built pavilion at Old Trafford in 1857. This was not just a huge popular hit, with workers at Lancashire mills more or less frogmarched there by employers keen to overturn Manchester's philistine image, but also, Haskell acknowledges, a triumph of scholarship. It presented a cogent history of western art and made several masterpieces well-known for the first time, including the Manchester Madonna, probably by Michelangelo, which is now in the National Gallery. This exhibition transformed British attitudes to art: it was as significant in its own day as the opening of Tate Modern in ours.

Haskell never completely spells out the nature of his rage with exhibitions, all exhibitions, and you might come away from the book believing his only real objection to blockbuster shows is that they endanger works of art by ferrying them around the world. The art treasures sent by Mussolini to the Royal Academy were transported in a single cargo ship, Haskell recounts in horror; if it had sunk, so many beautiful things would have been lost. The trouble is, it didn't sink, and despite the image Haskell evokes of airways crowded with flying art treasures - "jets speed through the skies carrying their freight of Titians and Poussins, Van Dycks and Goyas" - there's no real evidence of art being damaged by transport to exhibitions. Nevertheless, Haskell argues, the rise and rise of the blockbuster has been tainted by dubious motives and dodgy methods. Nationalism has played its sinister part in mega-shows of famous artists, from Germany showing off Holbein and Dürer to Mussolini's RA spectacular.

Most telling of all is the way exhibitions are put together. No exhibition is ever the one its curators intended. Some requests for loans are always refused, some artworks simply cannot be moved, yet when the museum announces its definitive Rembrandt show or whatever, all this backstage politics is hidden. The exhibition is presented as a disinterested, perfect expression of an argument. Critics review it on that basis, and audiences are encouraged to think they've seen all the Rembrandts that are worth seeing. Done that, been there.

The most glaring example was the Royal Academy's massively hyped Monet in the 20th Century show in 1998. The show presented itself as the last word on Monet's late waterlily paintings. This was ridiculous. The most important late paintings by Monet, his final masterpieces, are housed permanently in a custom-built space in the Musée de l'Orangerie in Paris, arranged as Monet intended in memorial to the dead of the first world war. There's nothing like seeing these paintings there. So the exhibition we queued for was not at all the unmissable, definitive survey of late Monet it claimed to be but a second-best alternative to visiting Paris.

The blockbuster exhibition encourages an idiotic attitude to art. We think we're getting the best possible chance to see a certain artist or period in art, we think that by seeing an exhibition on Jackson Pollock or Botticelli (who comes back to the RA this year) we know these artists, fully experience them. There's always something chest-beating and phony about it. What we get is a selective view, determined partly by practical considerations, from the RA's financial situation to the fact the National Gallery owns several Rembrandt self-portraits, and partly by the views of curators. But perhaps the biggest lie is the one that this exhibition is urgent here, now. Does Vermeer need another big exhibition this year? Will it change the fact that he's one of the world's great artists? Whenever there's a big exhibition it's as if this artist had just been discovered, and we all need to get along there or miss out. This is crushing, it's the opposite of the love of art. Love is personal, it is complicated. You can't hurry love.

We're not just talking about old art. I haven't met one artist who thinks the RA's Sensation (1997) offered anything but a cartoon view of contemporary art in London: it took 10 years of history and turned them into fiction, erasing from the record artists who were not in Charles Saatchi's collection. And because Sensation was a huge hit in Britain and then toured the world, it became the official compilation of 1990s British art.

In the end what is wrong with travelling, making an effort, waiting years to see works of art? You can spend a lifetime looking at a favourite artist's work, and over a lifetime is how it should be done - as a romance, a relationship. And is it such a terrible thing to admit you don't want to share your favourite art with so many others? There's something about the big show that erases the moments of discovery, surprise, bafflement that make art live. Art is difficult. Not all art, not all art by the same person, can interest you in the same moment. Yet this is the premise of the blockbuster exhibition - that you can take a mental photograph of 30, 50, 80 works by Rembrandt and it will mean something.

An experience of art that is instant, quick, and directed by another's eye and taste is an experience not worth having. Art is worth giving time to, or it's not worth bothering with at all. More and more, we are bombarded by exhibitions that foster the opposite of a worthwhile experience of art. They turn art into a commodity. We pay for our ticket, and in the act of paying we are encouraged to feel we have bought an experience of the artist, so we can fit Goya's extreme visions (showing at the Hayward Gallery in February) into our busy lives. But that's the last thing art should do - fit into our lives.

It's fantastic that art has become so popular in Britain. But let's not allow our love of art to be destroyed by chaperones and bullies. Let's love it in secret assignations, in out-of-the-way places.

Five shows to queue for (or not)

The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 Royal Academy, January 20-April 16

Explores the birth of the Baroque style and the hothouse atmosphere of Rome in the early 17th century, featuring works by Caravaggio, the Carracci family and Rubens.

Century City: Art and Culture in the Modern Metropolis

Tate Modern, February 1-April 29

Ten cities, 10 curators, the first loan exhibition at Tate Modern and the first chance to decide if its intellectual approach to modern art is as impressive as its architecture.

Brassaï: The Soul of Paris Hayward Gallery from February 22

Lovely, dark and romantic pictures of Paris by the surrealist photographer who defined the modern look of the city.

Botticelli: The Drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy

Royal Academy from March 17

One that deserves the hype: the first time all the surviving fragments of Botticelli's illustrated manuscript of The Divine Comedy have been exhibited. A chance to see a sublime masterpiece. OK, exhibitions aren't all bad.

Vermeer and the Delft School

National Gallery from June 20

We'll queue like idiots for this one, even though it comes so soon after the mega-Vermeer show in the Netherlands and the US, and even though it features not just everyone's favourite Delft painter but lesser contemporaries.

 Francis Haskell's The Ephemeral Museum is published by Yale University Press, price £16.95.

webTitle: Liz Campbell on teenage motherhood

fields.headline: A brilliant mistake
fields.standfirst: Twelve years ago, Liz Campbell was 18 and pregnant, and so enraged by attitudes towards her that she wrote a piece for this paper about teenage motherhood. Here she looks back at what happened after she made a brilliant mistake
fields.trailText: Twelve years ago,  Liz Campbell was 18 and pregnant, and so enraged by attitudes towards her that she wrote a piece for this paper about teenage motherhood. Here she looks back at what happened after she made a brilliant mistake.
fields.body:
Twelve years ago, I was at secondary school. I was also pregnant with my first child. The most shocking consequence of the pregnancy test had not been the impending baby (which I accepted with that trademark teenage mixture of boundless optimism and bravado), but my instant descent to an underclass about which everyone seemed to reserve the right to be rude and scornful.

I borrowed a typewriter and vented my fury in an article published in the Guardian. Here's a taster: "I have found the attitudes of many members of the medical profession presumptuous and patronising . . . I am determined to prove that teenage parents are not social problems, vegetating on bleak council estates, but capable of achieving the same goals as others."

I grew up in a single-parent family in the days when it was unusual (at least in Norfolk) and John Craven still talked gravely on Newsround about "broken homes". Mum struggled to provide for my sister and me, working evenings in pubs while she studied for a degree. She assumed we had learned from her mistakes and was horrified that I might even contemplate not terminating my pregnancy. Eviction from the family home followed swiftly.

I was referred to a social worker who was also pregnant (but in a strange parallel universe where everyone could afford maternity clothes and people said "Congratulations" rather than "God, what are you going to do?"). I assumed she would offer practical help (housing, money for baby equipment, childcare support so I could finish my education). In reality, there was little other than an archaic mother and baby home run by the Catholic church and a care system predicated on the assumption that no one got any qualifications anyway. When she tried to find common ground between us ("Isn't morning sickness the pits?"), I found it hard to contain my anger. Eventually my boyfriend's parents took pity on me.

I considered myself quite ordinary (we lived in a small terrace house and I went to the local comprehensive) but much of my pregnancy was spent waiting in long queues (at the housing office, at the DSS, at social services) with people who suddenly made me feel obscenely well-educated, healthy and privileged. I never realised so many people were living lives so devoid of opportunity. The thought that I would be joining them was terrifying.

Following the birth of my son Joshua, I was allocated a grim council flat on a desolate estate apparently reserved for teenage mothers and ex-psychiatric patients. I saw desperately poor teenage women struggling to provide basic care for their children against substantial odds, in an environment in which carpets and washing machines were luxury items.

I was deemed "fortunate" (and I was compared with the other people queuing at the DSS), but this limited my entitlement to help. Finishing my education seemed a sensible route out of the benefits system, but social services did not provide care for children not categorised as "at risk". To qualify, I needed to prove I was about to neglect my son, put him into care or be admitted to a psychiatric unit - all of which began to look increasingly possible as I contemplated spending my life trying to make ends meet on the estate.

So I lived with Josh's father (a teenage undergraduate) in his poky university rooms, because at least I was surrounded by people whose lives were filled with opportunity and hope. Nevertheless, motherhood came as a tremendous shock and I was miserable and isolated.

I started my degree when Josh was a toddler and, almost inevitably, I separated from his father. Unusually (for teenage fathers), he remains actively and positively involved.

Essex University was a fantastic place to be a teenage mother. There was a campus nursery, I lived in a shared house with lots of babysitters and I had a ball, despite making some embarrassing mistakes. Universities are full of rich kids writing glib essays about "structural inequalities" and as a sociology student, I wrote my dissertation on teenage motherhood, confident that at least I was prepared for the humility of the powerless working-class women I interviewed. I wasn't - and I reluctantly recognised that my impending graduation proved nothing about schoolgirl mothers.

Teenage motherhood is linked to poverty and low educational achievement (middle-class girls have more reasons not to get pregnant and those who do overwhelmingly choose abortion). The vast majority of the women I spoke to were from families who already lived in poverty on "sink" estates. Their lives were characterised by educational failure and some had spent time in care. They hoped for the best ("I'd like us to get a nice house - when my boyfriend gets a job"), but expected the worst ("Well, they usually leave you, don't they?").

I found little evidence that they would have been any better off had they delayed motherhood into their 20s. If their children fared badly at school and drifted into delinquency, they were simply taking their places in a cycle of deprivation that owed a great deal to the failure of our social care system and little to maternal age or moral laxity. Our shared experience of being teenage mothers did not magically dissolve the inequalities between us. My attempts to form a sisterhood ("Yes, I remember when I had mould up the walls") were met with the same derision I had shown the social worker four years earlier.

I argued that patriarchy seeks to control women by dictating the circumstances in which it is desirable to reproduce. Deprived working-class boys can indulge in the sort of laddish resistance to dominant morality that is celebrated by Guy Ritchie et al. Working-class women have fewer role models and for them, reproduction can be (or appear to be) a way of acting in the world and changing your life.

Teenagers experiment and take risks. If teenage fathers emerge from irresponsible sex relatively unscathed, they have male peers disabled by a range of reckless behaviours in which stupid driving features prominently. Their treatment and rehabilitation costs thousands. Generally they are pitied, rather than castigated, by Tory politicians and the tabloid press.

By contrast, student politics was kind to teenage mothers in the early 90s. The NUS had (belatedly) woken up to the discrimination faced by sections of its population and suddenly, if you wanted to get ahead in student politics, you needed an oppression. I never had to say more than: "Speaking as a teenage mother" to prompt a standing ovation. Getting my tokens out for the lads became a way of life. So what if the macho politicos who occupied the lecture theatres in support of a campus nursery were ignorant of the realities of teenage motherhood?

Childcare began to be taken seriously and I became sabbatical vice-president of the Students Union. My election night celebrations included the sort of spontaneity that results in morning sickness, but by then I'd convinced myself I was invincible. I survived on a week's maternity leave following the birth of Hannah, but I was too exhausted to fight any more. It was time to move on.

Subsequently, I followed a typical graduate trajectory. I trained as an English teacher and married a local government officer. We got a mortgage and had a third child. Occasionally, when colleagues were berating female pupils for squandering our taxes on their wanton reproduction, I'd "out" myself as a schoolgirl mother. The sudden staffroom silence would be broken by: "Oh, but you're different; at least your kids have the same father."

"Well, um, actually . . . " And there would be a frantic scramble to find ways to separate me (someone similar to themselves) from the seething amoral hordes on the local estates.

As a student, I was taught that "deviants" become so defined by their label that normal "non-deviant" life is impossible. It is probably the only way to explain my decision to become a Labour councillor. Looking across the rows of balding heads at my first meeting, I saw what an oddity I was (less than a fifth of our councillors are women and I'm 20 years younger than all of them). In a world dominated by old men who live their politics, my lack of a long-suffering wife has turned a morning spent doing the playgroup shift and mopping the kitchen floor into something verging on subversive.

When JK Rowling spoke in support of single mothers, Nigella Lawson applauded her, noting that "feckless teenage mothers" accounted for only 3% of single parents (phew!). Substitute the words "teenage mothers" with "asylum seekers" or "travellers" and you begin to hear the complaints of a disgruntled minority convinced they've been denied their fair share of life's rewards (from council housing to the moral high ground) and are trying to apportion blame.

This scapegoating of society's most disadvantaged has not lessened in the years since I wrote my original article. Back then I yearned for a public arena in which to challenge these attitudes. Now that I've found one, I'm relying on my son (my brilliant mistake) to nudge me if I get complacent.
fields.bodyText: Twelve years ago, I was at secondary school. I was also pregnant with my first child. The most shocking consequence of the pregnancy test had not been the impending baby (which I accepted with that trademark teenage mixture of boundless optimism and bravado), but my instant descent to an underclass about which everyone seemed to reserve the right to be rude and scornful. I borrowed a typewriter and vented my fury in an article published in the Guardian. Here's a taster: "I have found the attitudes of many members of the medical profession presumptuous and patronising . . . I am determined to prove that teenage parents are not social problems, vegetating on bleak council estates, but capable of achieving the same goals as others." I grew up in a single-parent family in the days when it was unusual (at least in Norfolk) and John Craven still talked gravely on Newsround about "broken homes". Mum struggled to provide for my sister and me, working evenings in pubs while she studied for a degree. She assumed we had learned from her mistakes and was horrified that I might even contemplate not terminating my pregnancy. Eviction from the family home followed swiftly. I was referred to a social worker who was also pregnant (but in a strange parallel universe where everyone could afford maternity clothes and people said "Congratulations" rather than "God, what are you going to do?"). I assumed she would offer practical help (housing, money for baby equipment, childcare support so I could finish my education). In reality, there was little other than an archaic mother and baby home run by the Catholic church and a care system predicated on the assumption that no one got any qualifications anyway. When she tried to find common ground between us ("Isn't morning sickness the pits?"), I found it hard to contain my anger. Eventually my boyfriend's parents took pity on me. I considered myself quite ordinary (we lived in a small terrace house and I went to the local comprehensive) but much of my pregnancy was spent waiting in long queues (at the housing office, at the DSS, at social services) with people who suddenly made me feel obscenely well-educated, healthy and privileged. I never realised so many people were living lives so devoid of opportunity. The thought that I would be joining them was terrifying. Following the birth of my son Joshua, I was allocated a grim council flat on a desolate estate apparently reserved for teenage mothers and ex-psychiatric patients. I saw desperately poor teenage women struggling to provide basic care for their children against substantial odds, in an environment in which carpets and washing machines were luxury items. I was deemed "fortunate" (and I was compared with the other people queuing at the DSS), but this limited my entitlement to help. Finishing my education seemed a sensible route out of the benefits system, but social services did not provide care for children not categorised as "at risk". To qualify, I needed to prove I was about to neglect my son, put him into care or be admitted to a psychiatric unit - all of which began to look increasingly possible as I contemplated spending my life trying to make ends meet on the estate. So I lived with Josh's father (a teenage undergraduate) in his poky university rooms, because at least I was surrounded by people whose lives were filled with opportunity and hope. Nevertheless, motherhood came as a tremendous shock and I was miserable and isolated. I started my degree when Josh was a toddler and, almost inevitably, I separated from his father. Unusually (for teenage fathers), he remains actively and positively involved. Essex University was a fantastic place to be a teenage mother. There was a campus nursery, I lived in a shared house with lots of babysitters and I had a ball, despite making some embarrassing mistakes. Universities are full of rich kids writing glib essays about "structural inequalities" and as a sociology student, I wrote my dissertation on teenage motherhood, confident that at least I was prepared for the humility of the powerless working-class women I interviewed. I wasn't - and I reluctantly recognised that my impending graduation proved nothing about schoolgirl mothers. Teenage motherhood is linked to poverty and low educational achievement (middle-class girls have more reasons not to get pregnant and those who do overwhelmingly choose abortion). The vast majority of the women I spoke to were from families who already lived in poverty on "sink" estates. Their lives were characterised by educational failure and some had spent time in care. They hoped for the best ("I'd like us to get a nice house - when my boyfriend gets a job"), but expected the worst ("Well, they usually leave you, don't they?"). I found little evidence that they would have been any better off had they delayed motherhood into their 20s. If their children fared badly at school and drifted into delinquency, they were simply taking their places in a cycle of deprivation that owed a great deal to the failure of our social care system and little to maternal age or moral laxity. Our shared experience of being teenage mothers did not magically dissolve the inequalities between us. My attempts to form a sisterhood ("Yes, I remember when I had mould up the walls") were met with the same derision I had shown the social worker four years earlier. I argued that patriarchy seeks to control women by dictating the circumstances in which it is desirable to reproduce. Deprived working-class boys can indulge in the sort of laddish resistance to dominant morality that is celebrated by Guy Ritchie et al. Working-class women have fewer role models and for them, reproduction can be (or appear to be) a way of acting in the world and changing your life. Teenagers experiment and take risks. If teenage fathers emerge from irresponsible sex relatively unscathed, they have male peers disabled by a range of reckless behaviours in which stupid driving features prominently. Their treatment and rehabilitation costs thousands. Generally they are pitied, rather than castigated, by Tory politicians and the tabloid press. By contrast, student politics was kind to teenage mothers in the early 90s. The NUS had (belatedly) woken up to the discrimination faced by sections of its population and suddenly, if you wanted to get ahead in student politics, you needed an oppression. I never had to say more than: "Speaking as a teenage mother" to prompt a standing ovation. Getting my tokens out for the lads became a way of life. So what if the macho politicos who occupied the lecture theatres in support of a campus nursery were ignorant of the realities of teenage motherhood? Childcare began to be taken seriously and I became sabbatical vice-president of the Students Union. My election night celebrations included the sort of spontaneity that results in morning sickness, but by then I'd convinced myself I was invincible. I survived on a week's maternity leave following the birth of Hannah, but I was too exhausted to fight any more. It was time to move on. Subsequently, I followed a typical graduate trajectory. I trained as an English teacher and married a local government officer. We got a mortgage and had a third child. Occasionally, when colleagues were berating female pupils for squandering our taxes on their wanton reproduction, I'd "out" myself as a schoolgirl mother. The sudden staffroom silence would be broken by: "Oh, but you're different; at least your kids have the same father." "Well, um, actually . . . In a world dominated by old men who live their politics, my lack of a long-suffering wife has turned a morning spent doing the playgroup shift and mopping the kitchen floor into something verging on subversive. webTitle: Side lines

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: My mother calls to tell me that she woke up to a foot of snow on the garden wall. Wellies are required. But, having recently escaped the frozen north for the altogether slushier pastures of east London, I feel no snowbound twinge. A solemn child, I always found it hard to see the fun in snowmen and had issues with sledging on account of my size. Furthermore, solemnity proved hard to carry off while sporting one of the unnecessarily bright snow suits Ma insisted on forcing me into.
fields.body:
My mother calls to tell me that she woke up to a foot of snow on the garden wall. Wellies are required. But, having recently escaped the frozen north for the altogether slushier pastures of east London, I feel no snowbound twinge. A solemn child, I always found it hard to see the fun in snowmen and had issues with sledging on account of my size. Furthermore, solemnity proved hard to carry off while sporting one of the unnecessarily bright snow suits Ma insisted on forcing me into.

Instead, the Child Sidelines could be found huddled in front of the fire, a jumbo Toblerone secreted in the folds of her jumper (an only child, no sharing) and book in paw. The book was usually of the murder-mystery variety: Conan Doyle, Christie, Poe, James. My interest in extreme gore, coupled with my imaginary friend - a detective called Sylvester Sneakley - turned into a love of all things mysterious, both natural and supernatural.

A psychologist would doubtless say that Sidelines' obsession relates to some unresolved anger over an absent parent, or a missed lollipop in 1978. But the truth, as Wilde had it, is rarely pure and never simple: it is the tidiness of these stories, set against the messiness of pain and peril and putrefied guts, that so delights. Their appeal lies in that devilish conjoining of the moral, the amoral and the utterly random.

It is perhaps unsurprising that in adulthood, Sidelines should be attracted to those of similar bent. And hence the reason for my bate. One would have thought it a teeny task to purchase a decent collection of ghost stories for a fellow spook-lover. I know different, having spent a fruitless morning trawling more book emporia than there are varieties of eucalypt. For some reason, the assistants found it impossible to accept that a request for such a collection ought to be met not with a sniffy bit of finger-pointing, but with a gasp, a glance and a perceptible chilling of the atmosphere. Then a wizened old man comes out of the back room and presents one with a dusty tome which turns out to be possessed and has to be burnt.

The inability of any shops to arrange this reinforces my belief that we are headed towards social and moral implosion faster than a ping pong ball out of a Thai bar room. Have a happy new year, if you really must.

webTitle: Pass notes: Sweden

fields.headline: No: 1791 Sweden
fields.trailText: Sweden? Yes, Sweden. Land of saunas, meatballs, Ikea and pickled herrings. Do you have a problem with that?
fields.body:
Sweden? Yes, Sweden. Land of saunas, meatballs, Ikea and pickled herrings. Do you have a problem with that?

I just wasn't aware that Sweden still existed. Of course Sweden still exists, you nitwit.

Sorry, I thought Sweden went out of vogue in the 80s. Along with Abba and crispbread. Well, Sweden is now once again the talk of the town.

So you could say it has been Björn again? You could, but only if you intended to forge a career in substandard BBC1 sitcoms.

Touché. So is this going to be another smartarse column about how England has a Swedish football manager? No, it's a smartarse column about how Sweden has just taken over the EU presidency.

And what changes will the Swedes be making? They'll be taking a long hard look at the chintz, for starters.

And replacing it with what exactly? Contemporary, machine washable fabrics at affordable prices.

Should we expect any other changes? Well, stylish, ergonomically designed prime minister, Goran Persson is intent upon enlarging the EU. It is hoped that in the next few years up to 13 new countries will be accommodated.

And how are we supposed to accommodate these 13 new countries? Er, well we've got the Moppe under-bed storage, the Skubb nylon shoe hangers with Velcro fastening. . . and of course there's always the Kungalv sofabed with easy click-clack mechanism.

And which 13 countries are we talking about? Candidates include Poland, Estonia and Latvia.

I thought Latvia was a galvanised steel spotlight (halogen bulb included)? That's enough Ikea jokes.

Don't say: "Could you help me carry this stuff to my car please?"

Do say: "Goran sounds just the Persson for the job."

webTitle: Leader: Brown's budget needs a European context

fields.headline: Facing the US downturn
fields.standfirst: Brown's budget needs a European context
fields.trailText: Brown's budget needs a European context.
fields.body:
This year the fate of the British economy could - for the first time under Labour's stewardship - be scuppered by events outside its direct control. Gordon Brown will return from his new year festivities to prepare his pre-electoral budget knowing there is a real prospect that the current downturn in the US could turn into a recession. As Sir Edward George, governor of the Bank of England, warned last week, the US economy is slowing down unexpectedly quickly. He reminded us that "it is still true that if America really sneezes we all catch cold".

There are no signs of an economic crash yet, despite the collapse of hi-tech stocks last year, when 60 of the largest internet companies suffered a 90% drop in their share prices since the peak in March. Even Yahoo!, arguably the most solidly based of the web's superstar companies, saw its shares fall by 86% last year on the stock markets.

So far all this has not triggered the disaster scenario in which collapsing share prices force US consumers to stop spending and rebuild their battered savings. That is mainly because the Old Economy stocks have not joined the Gadarene rush to the edge.

The Dow-Jones industrial index only dropped by 6% last year. But it still looks vulnerable after the 46% rise of the previous two years. US consumers, their confidence buoyed up by skyrocketing share prices, have drawn down their savings to next to nothing to finance a ravenous spending habit. If they now stop spending that could trigger a collapse of imports and an end to an era in which the ballooning US trade deficit has financed expansion in the rest of the world including the UK. A sinking US economy would reverse the strong capital flows from the rest of the world, including Europe, to the US and risk a vicious spiral of economic decline.

The rest of the world is a mixed bag. Japan, the second biggest economy in the world, is still locked in a recession that has lasted a decade. Whereas Americans will not save more, the Japanese will not spend more - and since 60% of economic activity is consumption, that spells trouble. Exhortations by the prime minister to spend more have fallen on deaf wallets. It is a timely reminder that behind confident sounding economic equations lie the free choices made by people.

If they decide not to spend, as in Japan, then that is that. And if people in the US decide en masse to rein in their spending too sharply, then there is a not a lot that even the mighty US Federal Reserve can do about it. Elsewhere, Russia's economy is expanding at a very encouraging 7% - but it has to be set against a 50% contraction since the fall of communism; China is growing by 8%, having largely shrugged off the Asian downturn, while Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea are back in the 9% to 10% a year growth league.

But none of these countries are big enough to take up the slack if the US and Japan (which together account for over 50% of OECD output) are both in serious recession. At present the US is merely adjusting from unsustainable growth of over 5% a year to a sustainable pace of around 3%. If it can do that and notch up a 10th year of continuous growth without recession, then maybe the US economy should be awarded the Nobel prize for economics. And if it does not, then there will be no shortage of economists rewriting history and claiming that the warning signs were there for everyone to see.

In these circumstances there is one thing above all the chancellor should do. Think European. Europe is the third biggest economy in the world and the only one with the potential to take up the slack of a flagging US recovery.

Unlike the US, it has a strong trade balance and as a trading zone it is largely self sufficient - well over 90% of its trade is done with other European countries - so the scope for spontaneous combustion is big. It is surprising that Europe has recently had more success in areas of industrial policy (like challenging Boeing with its planned super-jumbo jet) than in coordinating economic policies. There are signs of change. Germany and France are now planning tax cuts. This should be encouraged, as long as Europe's central bank does not spoil the revival by raising interest rates unnecessarily.

Britain does not need tax cuts, though we will almost certainly get some in Gordon Brown's budget, if only to defuse the Conservatives' irresponsible populist clamour for even steeper tax cuts.

Britain's problem is different from Europe's one of struggling to sustain a moody recovery. It is to prevent an unnecessarily steep downturn in the wake of the US slowdown. There is no need to feed our near-record trade deficit with yet more spending on imports. What people desperately want, and are daily reminded of as they struggle into work, is decent infrastructure.

The government, after an unnecessarily severe freeze during its first two years, has stepped up spending considerably. But it is not enough to deal with the backlog. Any money left over from Mr Brown's unspent budget surplus, beyond a ritual cut in taxes, should go to improve our infrastructure in the broadest sense, including railways, roads, hospitals, schools and the arts. Maybe some of the small change should be used to send civil servants to night school to learn how to spend public money efficiently, since years of squeeze have dimmed their memories about how it is done.

The Treasury also needs to be reminded of the vital importance of a proper manufacturing sector, at a time when industries like steel, motors and coal (at least until higher energy prices changed the outlook) are reeling from the effects of an overvalued pound. As dot.com companies bite the dust almost daily, the government should need no reminding that the bulk of our exports still come from a manufacturing base that has been wantonly eroded by a Labour administration that ought to have known better. If ministers are looking for ways to cushion the dangers of a downturn, then the rediscovery of the importance of manufacturing would be a sign that they really mean business.

webTitle: Teen drivers face half pint limit

fields.headline: Teen drivers face half pint limit
fields.trailText: Teenagers would be allowed to drink little more than a half pint of beer or lager before driving a car or motorbike under EU proposals to limit alcohol consumption among children and young people.
fields.body:
Teenagers would be allowed to drink little more than a half pint of beer or lager before driving a car or motorbike under EU proposals to limit alcohol consumption among children and young people.

The change would cut the maximum legal blood alcohol limit by three-quarters for young people. A report being considered by health ministers in all member states also recommends that they should be compelled to carry proof of age cards to curb their illegal buying of alcohol.

The government's own figures suggest that about one in six drivers and motoryclists under 19 killed in road accidents is over the blood alcohol limit of 80mg. In the 16-24 age group, nearly 1,100 drivers or passengers are killed or seriously injured in drink-drive incidents.

The commission proposal, which does not specify the exact age at which a blood alcohol level of 20mg might apply, is part of a wide ranging package to stem the tide of binge drinking by young people across Europe, including some countries where motorcyclists are as young as 14. Young Britons have to wait until 16 to ride a motorbike, but they are among the most likely teenagers in the EU to be heavy drinkers.

Half of Welsh boys of 15 say they regularly drink beer, but levels in Denmark (43%), Greece (42%) and England (40%) all cause concern.

In addition, Britain will come under renewed pressure this year to cut its drink-drive limit to 50mg for all drivers - the so-called "one-pint limit" - a measure the government has so far resisted after lobbying by the drinks industry and rural pubs.

Only three other EU countries - Ireland, Italy and Luxembourg - share the 80mg level, and the energy and transport directorate of the European commission is expected to try again for reductions.

Thousands of teenagers in Britain already carry proof they are entitled to buy drink in pubs or off-licences, but the commission says official cards would be better than the present voluntary arrangements.

webTitle: Omens bad for fortune-hunter

fields.headline: Omens bad for fortune-hunter
fields.standfirst: £41,000 stolen from car as owner prays for good luck
fields.trailText: £41,000 stolen from car as owner prays for good luck.
fields.body:
Most of Japan's 126m people ushered in the new year with visits to shrines and temples yesterday, but for at least one man this traditional quest for good luck resulted in an inauspicious start to 2001.

A thief stole 7m yen (£41,000) in cash from the car of a doctor, Shinobu Ogura, while he prayed for good fortune at the Kita-in Buddhist temple in Kawagoe, Saitama prefecture.

The fact that Dr Ogura left such a large sum of money in his car has raised few eyebrows in Japan, where crime rates are far lower than in Britain and where many people prefer hard currency to credit cards and cheques.

But as an omen at this most superstitious period, the timing of his misfortune could not have been much worse.

Only 53% of Japanese people profess any strong religious convictions, but most people honour the customs of the shogatsu - New Year - festival, which is a time to wipe away the bad luck of the old year and start afresh.

The final weeks of December were spent purging the mind of unpleasant memories with bonenkai - forget-the-year parties. Then as soon as the first bell of the New Year chimed, an all-out effort began to attract good fortune in the year ahead.

Dr Ogura was among the 93m people expected to seek the favour of the gods in a traditional and spiritual fashion with a hatsumode, or first religious visit of the year.

At temples or shinto shrines, this is considered a lucky time of the year to buy road-safety charms, bats for slapping away bad luck, and omikuji - fortune slips that claim to spell out the buyer's prospects for love, business, travel and health in the year ahead.

If Dr Ogura's omikuji was at all accurate, it would have read " dai-kyo " (miserable fortune) - the worst of six possible fates - and he would have followed tradition in tying the slip to a temple tree in the hope that the bad luck would never leave the grounds.

But the misfortune appeared to be continuing yesterday afternoon as police reported that they had found no witnesses to the crime.

His fate, however, was certainly not the worst. New Year customs resulted in more tragic consequences for two elderly Japanese people who choked to death yesterday on the dish of mochi. These highly glutinous rice cakes cause fatalities every year as they can easily stick in the throat.

Nationwide, there was gloom about the year ahead. Television specials debated how Japan can recover from economic stagnation and newspaper editorials expressed anxieties about rising juvenile crime and the possibility of a new financial crisis.

The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, acknowledged that the country faces some tough challenges.

"I feel a sense of urgency about the various problems Japan faces," he said in a New Year address that expressed sentiments with which Dr Ogura probably agrees.

webTitle: Northern Ireland: army watchtowers, the soldier's view

fields.headline: The soldier
fields.standfirst:
'Those people don't want peace. How can we walk away?'

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: 'Those people don't want peace. How can we walk away?'
fields.body:
The army did not want to give an official interview because the south Armagh issue was "too politically sensitive", but a senior military source expressed the following opinions.

"South Armagh is like nowhere else in the British Isles. It remains the heartland of terrorism and a very dangerous place. It poses a higher threat than probably anywhere else in western Europe.

"The border region along with north Louth is where the majority of dissident republicans operate from, and where the most effective wing of the Provisional IRA was and is based.

"They are not just producers but exporters of terrorism. The Omagh bomb, the Canary Wharf bomb both passed through here.

"Weapons from Croatia are bought to be smuggled to this area. It's only just over a year since Eamon Collins [the former IRA man turned one of their fiercest critics] was found murdered in a ditch. Those people don't want peace. How can we walk away?

"It's not just about terrorism but general lawlessness and criminal activity. Troops are required to back up police officers to enforce the law. They have to go around by helicopter because it is not safe by road.

"Smuggling and fuel laundering is big business. Customs and excise lose around £10m a year in this area. Paramilitaries are up to their necks in it.

"Just over the border a few weeks ago, customs officials were trying to investigate a fuel laundering scam on a farm when they found £100,000-worth of dodgy goods in a shed.

"The next day, Gardai were sent to recover the stuff but the gang jumped out of a hedge with automatic weapons and seized goods they'd confiscated.

"It's hard on the people who keep the law, yes, but the towers are a necessary part of the operation here. It's either that or more foot patrols tramping over land.

"It's no picnic for soldiers here. Many of them are working seven days a week and most are away from their families for months.

"Yes, the watchtowers are ugly. But they provide vital cover and information that cannot be disclosed because it would jeopardise future security. What do these people want? They're complaining about the view while we're saving lives."

webTitle: Northern Ireland: army watchtowers, the farmer's view

fields.headline: The farmer
fields.standfirst:
'Me and my animals want to be left in peace'

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: 'Me and my animals want to be left in peace'
fields.body:
Henry McElroy's family has farmed in south Armagh for the best part of a century. But for the past 20 years, he insists, the British Army has done its utmost to ruin his livelihood, writes Rosie Cowan.

He took over the 115-acre farm at Mounthill, which straddles the Irish border with Co Louth, when his father retired in 1977, mainly grazing sheep and cattle.

He claimed that soldiers spied on him constantly from the watchtowers and had threatened to shoot him, accusing him of hiding bombs when he was only loading hay. And he blamed them for spreading disease among his livestock, and terrifying his animals with helicopters.

"They're a complete menace," he said. "They threatened to blow the head off me a few years ago. I was just pitching hay onto a trailer with another man when they ran down shouting and screaming they were going to search the place for bombs.

"One fellow shouted that if I didn't do as they said they'd shoot me and throw a gun beside me, saying I pulled a gun on them. It was a farce.

"But the army don't want to go. They're happy to stay here and settle old scores."

Mr McElroy claimed that hundreds of his animals had died of disease and stress because of the military presence. "They've been tramping from farm to farm, cutting through fences and letting cattle mix which spreads brucellosis.

"Then there's the helicopters landing all over the place every day, 375 flights a month.

"Animals are scared witless when one of those comes down in a field beside them. They run off in all directions into ditches and do themselves harm. It's not the compensation I'm after, I just want them to let me and my animals live free from fear and stress."

Related stories
