webTitle: Prescott loses grip on Whitehall empire

fields.headline: Prescott loses grip on Whitehall empire
fields.trailText: January 2 2001: John Prescott is losing control of transport policy to his deputy, Gus MacDonald, and under the strain of this power struggle their sprawling ministry is said to be effectively breaking up.
fields.body:
John Prescott is losing control of transport policy to his deputy, Gus MacDonald, and under the strain of this power struggle their sprawling ministry is said to be effectively breaking up.

Senior officials in the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions claim that the rivalry between the two politicians has triggered increasingly bitter battles between the environment and transport wings of the merged body.

Mr Prescott and Lord MacDonald of Tradeston have clashed over road, rail and air issues during recent months. A key Westminster figure close to both maintains that the Labour peer is winning against the deputy prime minister. Tony Blair appointed Lord MacDonald late last year to revitalise transport after the Conservatives identified it as one of Labour's weak points. The DETR was also considered too big for Mr Prescott to manage.

"Gus is obviously in a difficult position," said a Labour MP. "He's got to be loyal to his boss and he's got to also do it for Blair and [Chancellor Gordon] Brown for that matter. Gus sees himself as the managing director transport, Prezza as the department's chief executive and Blair as the chairman. It is obvious that Gus has taken more and more of a role."

The conflict came to a head when the environment side of the ministry was misled about the extent of a road building programme unveiled shortly before Christmas by Lord MacDonald. The u-turn on policy by the government entailed more than 70 road bypasses.

The plan was championed in the department by Lord MacDonald, minister of state for transport, despite reservations by Mr Prescott. Michael Meacher, the department's minister of state for the environment, complained he was not properly consulted.

Lord MacDonald also took charge of the government's controversial plan to privatise air traffic control. Mr Prescott was said by an adviser to have been furious at not being consulted before his deputy negotiated a deal with the Conservatives on this issue, involving what was presented as a three-month delay, to get the sale through the House of Lords.

And the peer is resisting pressure from Mr Prescott to "come down heavy" on the rail companies, arguing that the government should work with rather than against the operators to get them to run decent train services as demanded by passengers.

The tussle has prompted concern in and out of government among supporters of the merged DETR - created by the marriage of the old environment and transport minis tries - that the potential benefits of policy coordination are being lost.

As well as transport, Mr Prescott's department is responsible for many other things, from local authorities and regional development to water and the wider environment, including global warming. But it is transport that is Mr Prescott's specialist subject and the former seafarer - who made his mark in opposition during the late 1980s and early 1990s after the Clapham, Lockerbie and Marchioness disasters - jealously guarded it during his early years in government.

Lord MacDonald's links with Downing Street, however, make him more powerful than the three previous transport deputies Mr Prescott had in 30 months - Gavin Strang, John Reid and Helen Liddell.

Mr Prescott persuaded the prime minister to remove the transport post from the cabinet in Labour's first reshuffle but Lord MacDonald is a cabinet member in all but salary, attending and speaking at the Thursday morning meetings.

Mr Prescott is now thought to believe he made a mistake taking the reins of the complex DETR rather than acting as a Cabinet Office enforcer. He is widely expected to give up the department after the election.

Parts of the DETR may be hived off, possibly to a new social inclusion department, with regional development agencies passing to trade and industry. But Mr Blair has shown no signs of wanting to split environment from transport.

webTitle: Reviews: Opera:  The Elixir of Love

fields.headline: Improbable love in Leeds
fields.standfirst:
The Elixir of Love
Grand Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
The Elixir of Love

Grand Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.body:
The trick with Donizetti's most popular work is to keep everything light and apparently effortless. Much of the music is very hard to sing successfully, but the moment you show the strain you are sunk. Opera North's new production benefits enormously from the presence of David Parry: he conducts with a manifest love of the score, drawing a marvellous range of sounds from the responsive orchestra, while staying constantly aware of the need to keep the singers' lines free and easy.

Another great asset is Paul Nilon in the role of Nemorino. He is on absolutely top form singing the tender lines of the lovesick idiot, and has the most magical variety of bodily gestures; at his most lugubrious he can make his face look like a carved pumpkin, and then he can suddenly light up the entire stage. This is a classic, unforgettable performance.

He is well partnered here by Mary Hegarty, who sings Adina's music with witty elegance; she too transforms herself convincingly, from condescending rich kid into insecure sexual vamp, without missing a trick. The other two main characters - Richard Whitehouse as Belcore and Christopher Purves as Dulcamara - make slightly less impact than in many productions, but that may well be a decision of the director, Daniel Slater.

Slater and the production team of Robert Innes Hopkins (designer), Simon Mills (lighting) and Vanessa Gray (choreography) have worked together for Opera North before and hardly put a foot wrong. They transfer the action from a Basque village to a Mediterranean seaside hotel (called Hotel Adina, of course) in the 1950s. Belcore and the soldiers - here naval officers - zoom in on Lambrettas, their body language reminiscent of the carabinieri. All the colours are bright, and there are enough visual gags to cover the music's thin patches.

What the team present is a neatly turned pantomime that resists any search for deeper meanings. It is perhaps not entirely wise that the last scene opens with everybody rolling drunkenly around the stage, but they at least make most of the turns in this improbable plot seem for the moment plausible.

In repertory until February 6. Box office: 0113-222 6222.

webTitle: Reviews: Sleeping Beauty gets a kiss from Einstein

fields.headline: Sleeping Beauty gets a kiss from Einstein
fields.standfirst:
Sleeping Beauty
Cochrane, London
****
fields.trailText:
Sleeping Beauty
Cochrane, London
****
fields.body:
If such a thing is not a contradiction in terms, then this is an intelligent pantomime for intelligent adults and children. There are no soap stars in it - in fact there are no stars at all. There are no cover versions of Robbie Williams pop songs and no double entendres.

Instead London Bubble, one of the best and most enterprising community theatre companies around, dishes up good, committed, generous acting, and a clever script with a strong narrative that brings a new twist to a familiar story, but not too many detours and interruptions.

There is also an entertaining and classic dame in the shape of the little princess's nanny (City and Guilds in projectile vomiting) and some audience participation that doesn't make you cringe but cheer. And it marks the first time in a panto that I've found myself called upon to play about with Einstein's theory of relativity.

Writer and director Jonathan Petherbridge relocates the beginning of the story to wartime Britain, where the heirless king and queen consult a wise old woman about their predicament. The couple are soon the parents of a baby girl but when they refuse to keep their side of the bargain and invite the old woman to their parties, Princess Talia is doomed to prick her finger on her 16th birthday and fall asleep for 100 years.

Then it is fast forward a century to 2056, and if the princess is not awoken with a kiss before the 100 years is up she will die. Only it's hard to find a prince to do the deed when the people have overthrown the monarchy and Britain has become a republic.

The silly moments are really silly, the shivery moments extra shivery. When the wicked old woman settles down beside the sleeping princess to wait for her death 100 years hence she starts knitting: it is like watching Madame Lafarge at the guillotine. The jokes are as old as the hills but still funny: Queen: "You better change that baby, nurse." Nurse: "Did you keep the receipt?"

But it is the way the show plays with the concept of time that is really smart. When Prince Justin arrives at the palace, the princess is already dead. It is up to the audience to cheat time by turning the clock backwards, which turns out to be as easy as tick tock - or rather, kcot kcit.

This is a lovely, inventive treat for all the family that might convert even the most dedicated pantomime hater.

Until January 13. Box office: 020-7242 7040.

webTitle: Reviews:  Art: Saturday Night Is Alright With Me

fields.headline: Saturday Night Is Alright With Me
fields.standfirst:
Bulkhead 24-Hour Window, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Bulkhead 24-Hour Window, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
The best time to see Kathleen Little's work, filmed over eight Saturday nights in Glasgow, is Sunday morning. Shown in the window of Bulkhead's headquarters, on the city's High Street in the east end, the videos play on silently, even though the window has suffered the slings and arrows of outrageous drunkenness and partying the night before.

A dark red liquid is smeared across the pane: it could be blood, or ketchup detached from its chips. A pile of loose change is stacked with inexplicable neatness between pools of vomit stretched out on the pavement. None of these extras are Little's doing, but it's impossible to detach a work shown in a 24-hour window onto the street from the life lived around it.

On screen, anonymous characters perform rituals associated with Saturday night. Asked by Little to engage with the camera for three minutes without speaking, the films record moments in a pub, club, bookshop, Central station, a gym and an accident and emergency ward. In the club setting, a couple swig from beer bottles, grin madly and then snog with a marked sense of urgency. They do it all again as other clubbers pass by; nobody looks at them especially. The screen fades.

The next pair, two women in their early 20s, attract far more attention. Their ritual is to blow huge pink bubbles with the gum they are sulkily chewing. Competitiveness (they blow together, eyeing each other to see who has the biggest bubble) gives way to respect as the winner gets a nod of approval from the other. Clubbers who pass, meanwhile, are treated to a mean, sarcastic glare.

This is what Little captures so well: the private worlds and codes that make up the bigger picture of a Saturday night. Presenting these worlds silently lends the work an edge, makes the horribly familiar strange. Best of all - and this goes for all of Bulkhead's work shown in public spaces across the city - the 24-hour window is a genuinely demystifying tactic. On a street that forms an informal boundary between the refurbished Merchant City and the east end, the window breaks down that barrier between life as it is lived and the precious space of the gallery. The work in the window is free and easy to engage with - a cross between watching television and window-shopping - whatever time on a Saturday night you might be passing by.

Until 13 January. Details: www.bulkhead.org.uk

The screen fades. The next pair, two women in their early 20s, attract far more attention. Their ritual is to blow huge pink bubbles with the gum they are sulkily chewing. Competitiveness (they blow together, eyeing each other to see who has the biggest bubble) gives way to respect as the winner gets a nod of approval from the other. Clubbers who pass, meanwhile, are treated to a mean, sarcastic glare. This is what Little captures so well: the private worlds and codes that make up the bigger picture of a Saturday night. Presenting these worlds silently lends the work an edge, makes the horribly familiar strange. Best of all - and this goes for all of Bulkhead's work shown in public spaces across the city - the 24-hour window is a genuinely demystifying tactic. On a street that forms an informal boundary between the refurbished Merchant City and the east end, the window breaks down that barrier between life as it is lived and the precious space of the gallery. The work in the window is free and easy to engage with - a cross between watching television and window-shopping - whatever time on a Saturday night you might be passing by. Until 13 January. Details: www.bulkhead.org.uk

webTitle: Top Tessa savers in line to collect £7,000 pay-off

fields.headline: Top Tessa savers in line to collect £7,000 pay-off
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Top-performing Tessas, the tax exempt special savings accounts which have begun to mature this year, have delivered savers a 77% return over five years on their investment, according to new research.
fields.body:
Top-performing Tessas, the tax exempt special savings accounts which have begun to mature this year, have delivered savers a 77% return over five years on their investment, according to new research.

A new study from the independent financial adviser, Chase de Vere, analysed returns on investment on all types of Tessas, and found that the top performing account from Bristol & West returned around 12.1% a year over the past five years, compared to returns from benchmark gilts which have fallen from around 8.5% to under 5% over the same period.

Savers with money in Bristol & West's equities-linked Tessa - where returns were pegged to the performance of the UK stock market - over the past five years will see their original deposit of £9,000 boosted to nearly £16,000.

The study which examined the rates of return available from 59 financial institutions assuming that the full £9,000 was invested in a Tessa on January 2, 1996 also found that the difference between the best, Bristol & West's Stock Market Linked account, and the worst performing one from Flemings Premier Bank was nearly £3,900.

Chase de Vere believe that £9,000 in stock market-linked Tessas returned around £15,000 and accounts where the rate of return was fixed over the five-year term would yield a little more than £12,800. Investors with funds in variable rate Tessas - whose return is linked to base rates - have come out the worst with average returns of around £12,455.

Investors whose Tessas are due to mature this year, can transfer some or all of the money they have paid into tax-free individual savings accounts (ISAs) introduced in 1999, without affecting their normal tax allowances.

Banks and building societies are set to return more than £18bn to savers with maturing Tessa accounts within the first four months of the year. This is the largest tranche of the total £26bn of Tessa savings that will reach the end of their five-year terms over the next 12 months. The sum will include the last big Tessa rollover which occurred in 1996, when savers could reinvest up to £9,000 into a second generation Tessa. For further information on the Tessa league table, call 0845 609 2001.

webTitle: Reviews: Dance: The Nutcracker

fields.headline: Christmas lingers on at the Royal Ballet
fields.standfirst:
The Nutcracker
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.trailText:
The Nutcracker
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.body:
Now that the gremlins in the Opera House machinery have been more or less exorcised, the Royal Ballet's Nutcracker can finally work all of its powerful magic. The enchanted Christmas tree grows, unimpeded, with heartstopping grandeur; the snowflakes flutter the promise of a perfect, white Christmas; the dancing dolls emerge like clockwork from their wooden boxes; and even if, on opening night, the Mouse King almost failed to materialise from his hellish trapdoor, his entrance was made all the more threatening by its brief delay.

With the stage in order, Peter Wright's revamped production arguably ranks as the definitive Nutcracker. It's certainly one of the most deliciously old-fashioned parties in town.

Wright's great achievement is not only to cherish the sense of wonder that drives the story but also to focus its humanity. Crabby Herr Drosselmeyer has had a glossy makeover; he flaunts a glittering cloak and extravagant conjuring gestures, but his underlying grief for his cursed nephew and his tenderness for little Clara also imply strange, withheld mysteries in his character. As for Clara herself, a child on the brink of adolescence, there's a clearer sense that the whole ballet is her charmed but significant rite of passage.

Clara has in fact been made a more substantial character than in previous productions; here she has more dancing and dramatic motive. Wright's original reason for this was to create a link between the ballet's plot-heavy first act and the dance-dominated second. Watching Alina Cojocaru make her debut on the first night, however, Wright must have felt he had created the role in anticipation of her - because she brought to the performance enchantment of a totally non-mechanical kind.

Cojocaru hasn't stopped surprising us since she joined the Royal last season; she pulls out new gifts for each role that she tackles, and in The Nutcracker it seemed as though her feet never touched the floor. Tiny as she is, her jump is huge and her phrasing untrammelled, allowing her Clara to whirl through the miraculous adventures of the story like a speck of pure, entranced energy.

Cojocaru's performance alone would have made the show memorable, but the rest of the cast seemed equally primed to dazzle. Anthony Dowell as Drosselmeyer was clearly relishing the fact that he no longer had to cover up the clunking malfunctions of last year's run; he strode through his part with dark, wheeling glamour. Miyako Yoshida was a perfect 18th-century Sugar Plum Fairy, glass-spun and exquisite, Jonathan Cope and Jonathan Howells as the Prince and the Nutcracker were impeccably romantic, and the assorted toys and flowers danced with rare aplomb. For two hours the traffic, the crowds and the credit card bills receded. For two hours we got a shot of pure Christmas.

In repertory until January 20. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Do I have to do more work than I am paid for?

fields.headline: Do I have to do more work than I am paid for?
fields.trailText: What is the legal position is regarding unpaid overtime. I was under the impression that a compulsion to "work" must be rewarded by at least the minimum wage.
fields.body:
The problem

What is the legal position is regarding unpaid overtime.I am a part time lecturer, so I only get paid for the hours I am teaching. However my contract says I am required to work such additional hours as may be necessary for marking work. By this they mean for free.

I was under the impression that a compulsion to "work" must be rewarded by at least the minimum wage - can they sack me if I only work the hours for which I am paid?

The solution

First of all, you should get a paid holiday allowance as set by European legislation on working time rights. Your allowance will be pro-rata in accordance with your part-time status. I suggest that you contact your union, ACAS or Citizen's Advice immediately for their advice as to exactly what you are entitled to.

The overtime issue is less black and white. In theory, overtime counts as your 'working time' so that if you include this and find you are working for less than the minimum wage then you may have a case. On the other hand, there is also an acceptance that unpaid overtime does not count if it is 'voluntary'. The problem is, of course, that employees are often under enormous pressure to carry out 'voluntary' overtime.

You should really take legal advice from the sources mentioned before.

Your specific case is interesting, however, because it might be argued by your employer that marking is a necessary part of the role and is thus part of the work for which you are paid. In other words, you receive a fee for, says, one hour's teaching, which includes not only the time in delivering that lecture, but also in preparing for it and marking work that results from it. But, if the fee you get, when stretched across all these aspects, is woefully inadequate (and below the minimum wage), you should feel entitled to ask for a separate fee for marking. It would be reasonable to agree to a certain amount of marking 'for free', but beyond that, you should ask to be paid. Check your legal rights first, then I would advise you to try negotiating before refusing point blank to do the extra.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Reviews:  Don Weller 60th Birthday

fields.headline: Don Weller 60th Birthday
fields.standfirst:
100 Club, London
****
fields.trailText:
100 Club, London
****
fields.body:
"Welcome to my 100th birthday, here at the 60 club," said saxophonist Don Weller, kicking off four and a half hours of music in honour of his big day.

Whatever age he feels - or jokes about feeling - he certainly doesn't give it away in his blowing. His reputation as one of the "tough" English tenor players to have emerged, post-John Coltrane, stands firm. Although he can dip into airy vibratoed sweetness when required, with a sound that seems to emerge imperceptibly from the sanding of the drummer's brushes, his trademark is still a bold, coruscating, sometimes belligerent voice. He is playful, too, managing the difficult musical manoeuvre of translating wit into sound without resorting to slapstick.

Weller's own quartet started the evening. They were virtuosic, bouncing little improvised phrases off each other, turning jazz standards on their head. "We would like to play our version of a tune called The Way You Look Tonight," said Weller. "It's called The Way You're Going to Look Tomorrow Morning." Their set culminated in a party-piece piano solo from Dave Newton that took a theme and car-chased it through stride and Latin styles, with Weller, joined by Allan Barnes on baritone sax, improvising a swinging, complex, snake-like fugue.

This was followed by three-quarters of the Stan Tracey quartet, and a more angular style. While saxophonist Bobby Wellins chopped tunes up into little solitary packets, Tracey's voicings on the piano varied from rich percussive handfuls to primitive two-note cliff-hangers at either end of the keyboard.

All this great playing was for the initiated jazz fans - and the crowd confirmed it with every nod, beret and wisp of creative facial hair. But the final hour made you want to proselytise madly to those who wouldn't touch jazz with a pair of hair clippers. Weller's big band, formed in the mid-1990s, attracts the best of the mainstream players in this country (Peter King, Art Themen, Alan Barnes, Dick Pearce, Mornington Lockett and Martin Speake). It's a testament to the respect Weller commands among players and to the quality of his writing, which brings to a traditional big band set-up a distinctively earthy and jubilant sound.

There was an energised, collective feeling to the music, partly because Weller often favours keeping the different sections playing as one block, with internal melodic lines tumbling over each other. Also, faced with the forces of a big band, soloing players tend to take risks, to push themselves to the edge of their playing. It's a visceral, visual, and musical experience that, for economic reasons, has become a rarity.

As the band roasted through its last number, it couldn't take the pace, and peeled off in search of the floor. But the man himself was still standing, swinging happy birthday to himself.
